webTitle: The modest idol who entranced Lancashire

fields.headline: The modest idol who entranced Lancashire
fields.standfirst: Brian Statham, who died last Sunday, was a true star, says  Colin Shindler
fields.trailText: Brian Statham, who died last Sunday, was a true star, says Colin Shindler.
fields.body:
With the death of the greatest of all my youthful heroes Brian Statham last weekend, a part of my childhood feels like it has vanished. To me, and I dare say to every other middle-aged Lancastrian who cherishes the cricket of his native county in his soul, his premature death at the age of 69 will have come as a terrible shock.

They are all gone now, that team of our early youth: Washbrook and Grieves, Ikin and Hilton, Edrich and Wharton. Now the greatest of them all has joined them.

Brian Statham was our idol for all the right reasons that great sportsmen should become heroes. He combined outstanding achievement with an uncomplaining willingness to bowl all day uphill into the wind so that Tyson and Trueman could steal the headlines. Whether it was on the flat pitches of the West Indies and Australia or on a green top at Chesterfield Brian Statham bowled his heart out for his country and his county and we loved him for it.

No matter how many times he went past the outside edge or saw the ball bisect the slips he never posed with outrage as many of his contemporaries and all of his successors now do, hands on hips, a volley of abuse aimed indiscriminately at batsmen, fielders, umpires and God. He walked back to his mark knowing perfectly well that the next ball was more than likely to knock the middle stump out of the ground.

On a bitterly cold April day in the Parks, Statham bowled the first ball of the match against Oxford University. It drew Duncan Worsley, the future Lancashire opener, into a groping prod. The ball whipped away, missing bat and off stump by a fraction of an inch and thumped into the wicketkeeper's gloves.

An embarrassed Worsley kept his head down, waiting for the traditional cutting remark of the opening bowler. He looked up to find Statham four yards away smiling gently. "Good morning!" he said kindly.

I spent whole days of my summer holidays imitating his distinctive windmill action. We lived in a semi-detached house with a longish drive and a garage at the end on whose doors were permanently chalked three stumps.

To achieve the full majesty of that run-up, shirt filling with breeze, I really needed to start in the driveway of No15 but the Grosskopfs who lived there were not cricket lovers and didn't appreciate the importance of the fast bowler's rhythm so the nine-year-old Brian Statham was reduced to bowling permanently off his short run.

It pained us that Statham's action was deemed insufficiently classical as compared with that of Fred Trueman. To us it was an aesthetic delight, an awesome thing of beauty. Trueman's looked like the pumping pistons of a steam engine in comparison.

We were conscious too of how often in test matches Statham was brought back to bowl to a batsman when he was on 98 or 99 whereas Trueman was never subjected to this indignity.

I always believed that captaining Lancashire was the easiest job in the world, comprising as it did the one task of throwing the ball to Brian Statham. From 11.30 in the morning until 12.40 Statham bowled eight or so overs from the Stretford end, at which point the opposition would be struggling on 33 for two, Statham having taken both wickets. Somehow we bumbled along for half an hour until Statham came back at 10 past one for three overs before lunch.

When play resumed at 10 past two and our hero had smoked half a dozen fags and downed a pint of bitter he was ready to bowl all afternoon, pausing perhaps only to bowl from the City end for a change of scenery. Frankly, had it been legally permissible for him to have bowled from both ends throughout the day we would have been delighted and it is doubtful if he would have demurred.

In these pages many years ago Neville Cardus reported of Wilfred Rhodes that he considered himself "nivver a star - just a good utility player". That would probably have been Statham's self-assessment as well.

He would have been wrong. He was a bright shining star to all of us who gazed at him in adoration, the greatest Lancastrian bowler who ever drew breath.

 Colin Shindler is the author of Manchester United Ruined My Life, a homage to Manchester City

webTitle: Pitch hit as Warne plots depleted Durham's misery

fields.headline: Pitch hit as Warne plots depleted Durham's misery
fields.trailText:
Hampshire 340

Durham 83 and 93

Hampshire win by an innings and 164 runs
fields.body:
It was a painful three days for Durham here at May's Bounty. Defeat on a controversial pitch allowed Hampshire to leapfrog over them at the bottom of the First Division and they may have lost the services of their fast bowler Steve Harmison until August.

The 21-year-old prospect, who limped off the field on Thursday, will have a bone scan next week on his injured left shin. "It's probably a stress fracture," said Nigel Kent, Durham's physio. "If it is, he will be out for six to eight weeks, maybe longer."

Harmison had already been ruled out of England's squad for the second test at Lord's and a confirmed stress fracture would effectively end his chances of making his test debut this summer. He did not even bat in Durham's second innings yesterday.

Not that it would have made any difference. The game was over before lunch on a pitch which was the subject of an official inquest by the England and Wales Cricket Board's "pitch liaison officers" Tony Brown and Mike Denness, who eventually awarded it a no-stars (but no-deductions) "below average" rating.

Durham's coach Norman Gifford, for one, was convinced the surface was unfit for first-class cricket."After the toss of the coin we haven't had much chance of winning," he said. "What would it have been like on the fourth day?"

Durham did not always help their own cause but Shane Warne has bowled out better sides on truer pitches so there was an inevitability about the day after the visitors resumed on 12 for one, following on 257 behind. The only surprise was that Robin Smith delayed the leg-spinner's entry until 12.15. Warne then took four wickets in eight overs for match figures of eight for 56, his best for the county.

He bowled with menace but most things went his way. Simon Katich and Nicky Phillips were caught at slip via the wicketkeeper's gloves, Martin Speight was bowled round his legs via bat and pad, and Durham's captain Nick Speak did not appear to agree with the umpire Trevor Jesty that the ball had made contact with his outside edge.

The day's other issue was whether Warne had made phone contact with a certain Donna Wright, as the Mirror claimed last weekend. Jesty would have had no problem with this one as Warne gave himself out: he denied menacing Wright but admitted he had uttered the odd salacious word.

"As an international sportsman who gets pestered a fair bit, I would never harass anybody," he said.

Admitting it had been a mistake to leave messages on the woman's phone, Warne said his wife Simone was "disappointed with what I did, talking dirty on the phone. The bottom line is, we are like any married couple and we have our ups and downs."

Who said county cricket was dull?

webTitle: Sidebottom on song on imperfect pitch

fields.headline: Sidebottom on song on imperfect pitch
fields.trailText:
Kent 129 and 82

Yorkshire 149 and 63-4

Yorkshire win by six wickets
fields.body:
Yorkshire, fortunate not to be docked points for an awful pitch, beat Kent by six wickets here to take their lead to 16 points at the top of the First Division of the County Championship.

The match lasted just over two days, and 34 wickets fell in the 214 overs bowled. But poor pitches are now such an established feature of county cricket - something the men at Lord's have never come to terms with - that they got away with it.

Yorkshire even survived a visit yesterday from the PLO, which was not the Palestine Liberation Organisation but something far more frightening: it was a Pitches Liaison Officer, A C Smith, the former chief executive of the old Test and County Cricket Board.

Smith watched a day's play when 11 wickets tumbled in three hours, with some deliveries flying off a length and others scurrying along the ground like frightened rodents, and decided to take no action. It was the wrong decision, but at least he made it quickly, not something he was noted for in the past.

Alan Fordham, the cricket operations manager at the England and Wales Cricket Board, said yesterday: "Alan Smith has not seen enough to put it in the poor category." This sounded bizarre. Smith saw only a little cricket because the pitch was such a horror the batsmen could not survive long enough for him to make a more leisurely judgment.

The umpires had not reported the pitch, but when 16 wickets went down on Thursday the men at Lord's decided to dispatch Smith. Kent are battling to avoid relegation but yesterday their captain Matthew Fleming, with weary honesty, said: "It was not a good pitch but to be honest I've played on worse."

One Yorkshire committee man was not so philosophical. "We should have had points knocked off for that surface," he said. "We have been producing bad wickets for years but nothing gets done."

Kent, resuming on 36 for three, only 16 runs ahead, were bowled out for 82. Ryan Sidebottom, bowling faster these days, took the last five wickets to finish with match figures of 11 for 43, the best by a Yorkshire bowler since Chris Silverwood took 12 in 1997, also at Leeds and also against Kent.

When it was all over two men inspected the pitch with forensic care. They looked like experts from Lord's. Or, perhaps, the bomb disposal unit. But it was just a routine visit from Bingley's Sports Turf Research Institute.

fields.headline: Honest Adams cleanses the soul
fields.trailText: Honesty of purpose has never been more highly prized in international cricket with the match-fixing scandal heaping immense sadness upon the game. Yesterday, in the shape of Jimmy Adams, there was honesty of purpose here in abundance.
fields.body:
Honesty of purpose has never been more highly prized in international cricket with the match-fixing scandal heaping immense sadness upon the game. Yesterday, in the shape of Jimmy Adams, there was honesty of purpose here in abundance.

With the attention span of the average Briton now estimated at 15 seconds, Adams may drive half the nation to distraction by the summer's close. This is not an undependable sound-bite cricketer but a man of unshifting purpose and obligation. There has never been a more appropriate time to acclaim him.

It took nearly four hours for him to reach his half-century, a period in which West Indies methodically squeezed the life out of England's bowlers, and faith was restored in test match verities. The main chancers, the deceitful and the downright corrupt, seemed a million miles away.

Adams never actively sought the West Indies captaincy, and when he dutifully accepted it this year he inherited a shambles. New Zealand had just meted out a thrashing at test and one-day level and Brian Lara had resigned in such mental turmoil that he turned to a psychologist.

Adams immediately offered Lara unstinting support. "He is like a brother," he said. But these are two disparate brothers, as diametrically opposed as Danny DeVito and Arnold Schwarzenegger in Twins: Lara flash, impulsive, capricious; Adams unspectacular, consistent, straightforward.

West Indies are already proving remarkably difficult to beat under Adams's captaincy. "There is a long road to travel and it will be travelled by everybody," he warned. It will not be a pretty route but one that is forever slightly uphill, consistently straight, and with few opportunities to stop and admire the view.

In the first test under his charge, in Port of Spain, Zimbabwe needed only 99 for victory, and lost. In the second test, Adams's first test hundred for four years ensured a series victory. Another home series success against Pakistan then followed, achieved in St John's with a wicket to spare.

It is impossible to shake up Adams. He cannot be bored out, talked out or conned out, merely bowled out. He survives with an inscrutable expression and unyielding defence.

The crowd's patience never wavered, as if they welcomed a cleansing of the game's soul. One spectator in the Wyatt stand filmed him on a camcorder for most of the afternoon session and now is an expert on the art of the forward defensive.

The dash had come in the first hour, as Lara and Sherwin Campbell sped along at five an over. It took Lara's dismissal, edging Darren Gough to the wicketkeeper, to break the momentum, although it was a surprise that it was Andrew Flintoff who applied the brake.

"Freddie" is no bowling stylist. His gormless, galumphing run does not hint at guile. As his heavy frame pounded in, there was every chance that if cracks did not open up on the square then craters would assuredly appear on his run-up.

But Flintoff stuck gamely to his task and bowled tightly - and just as quickly as Gough - at the left-handers from around the wicket. There was the bonus of Shivnarine Chanderpaul's wicket too, and even the honour of the second new ball. It lasted only an over, but he grinned broadly at it all.

More honesty, more joy. It is just a shame that England broke their contractual agreements and were too gloomy to talk about it.

fields.headline: Kluivert makes Oranje bloom
fields.trailText: The Oranje may again have played like lemons for much of this match but in the end they sailed impressively into the next round. Frank Rijkaard should consider publicly slating his players even more harshly in future. The coach's only problem would be finding enough expletives and put-downs to last to the final.
fields.body:
The Oranje may again have played like lemons for much of this match but in the end they sailed impressively into the next round. Frank Rijkaard should consider publicly slating his players even more harshly in future. The coach's only problem would be finding enough expletives and put-downs to last to the final.

Finding enough to fill his half-time talk can hardly have been difficult. For 56 minutes Holland looked far from champions but, after Patrick Kluivert eased the pressure by scoring, the natural juices flowed. The fans displaying the banner "Sex, drugs and Orange goals" might have experienced all three by the time they hit the pillow.

Denmark's quarter-final hopes are dead, and Holland too may have left the field with a feeling of regret. One more goal would have put them on top of Group D. Now they need a win over France on Wednesday to avoid an unwanted trek to Bruges in the next round, with a possible semi-final in Brussels. Their failure to press hard for a fourth was bizarre.

But if this is the last the Dutch fans see of their team on home territory - at least for a while - they will remember the last half-hour with glee. What went before was almost forgotten. And who can blame them? Having accused his team of lacking spirit, Rijkaard must have been disappointed to see his team start as if determined to prove him right.

Perhaps bemused at playing in blue when the stadium was a sea of orange, a nervy Holland struggled to find their rhythm. Passes went astray, free-kicks were poor and an excess of long balls were aimed at Kluivert's head. With Dennis Bergkamp lurking a long way behind his strike partner, the flicks produced nothing.

The resort to route one was a reflection of the hard work Denmark were getting through in closing down. And with the wingers Jesper Gronkjaer and Morten Bisgaard using their pace to exploit the defensive weakness of the full-backs, there were worrying moments for the co-hosts. Shortly before half-time the woodwork came to their rescue for the third time in this tournament.

Holland's failure to make the most of their wide men was behind much of their struggle. Rijkaard's decision to play the right-footed Marc Overmars on the left and the left-footed Boudewijn Zenden on the right seemed perverse. Only when Overmars departed and Zenden switched did he begin to flourish. For too long the team seemed to lack the spark of imagination that could win the match.

It was half an hour before they had a decent chance, Peter Schmeichel parrying a Kluivert effort and Overmars sending the rebound wide. The goalkeeper also saved well from Edgar Davids and saw Bergkamp curl a shot just wide, but this was far from one-way traffic.

Bisgaard narrowly failed to squeeze a cut-back into Jon-Dahl Tomasson's path, and when the ball broke back to the Udinese player his effort was deflected kindly into Edwin van der Sar's arms. The keeper was a spectator when Thomas Gravesen clipped the bar from outside the area. The whistles at half-time said it all.

The breakthrough came at the end of a swift counter- attack started by Davids and ended by Kluivert, who stroked the ball into an empty net after Schmeichel had beaten out Bergkamp's shot. Ronald de Boer then scored from a yard after meeting Zenden's low cross. And only two good saves by Schmeichel kept Holland out before Michael Reiziger ended a 60-yard burst by providing Zenden with the third. Three Barcelona players had done the trick.

Denmark, whose power and spirit melted once the first goal went in, saw their misery compounded when Michael Schjonberg missed a penalty after Van der Sar brought Ebbe Sand down. "We know now that we are not good enough," said the coach Bo Johansson, who steps down after Wednesday's match with the Czechs.

With the Dutch fans chiming "We are the champions" the feeling was clear. Rotterdam bills itself as the City of the Final and, if the finish is anything to go by, Holland may be there when it counts.

With the Dutch fans chiming "We are the champions" the feeling was clear. Rotterdam bills itself as the City of the Final and, if the finish is anything to go by, Holland may be there when it counts.

webTitle: France tear up Czechs and send them home

fields.headline: France tear up Czechs and send them home
fields.trailText: Who can stop France? Euro 2000 has shown itself to be a place for those who twist on 17, and there cannot be another team in the Low Countries with a sense of adventure to match the world champions.
fields.body:
Who can stop France? Euro 2000 has shown itself to be a place for those who twist on 17, and there cannot be another team in the Low Countries with a sense of adventure to match the world champions.

On another evening of Gallic back-slapping Zidane, Anelka et al were left to bask in the knowledge that they had secured a place in the quarter-finals with this close but ultimately deserved victory over the side who eliminated them from Euro 96.

As a result the Czechs will have the rest of summer to conduct an arduous and sombre inquest into how, for all the talent at their disposal, for all the brilliance of Pavel Nedved, they must shoulder the ignominy of being the first country to be knocked out.

There will be worse teams in the final eight, make no mistake, but after 10 successive victories in the qualifiers Jozef Chovanec and his players will no doubt reflect that, when the show starts, nobody remembers the warm-up act.

It is the main event that counts and though France have spluttered along in fits and starts for the past two years, when it matters most they are guaranteed to deliver.

Only seven minutes had gone before Thierry Henry instigated the first lung-bursting strains of Allez Les Bleus. Petr Gabriel was the culprit, his scuffed backpass allowing Henry to streak away.

The Arsenal striker, as the Premiership has seen, is not prone to squandering such gifts and the execution was clinical, a toe-poked shot beneath the goalkeeper Pavel Srnicek and in off the post.

So the tone was set for a half in which the Czechs appeared to view the basic art of defending with little more than disdain. Gabriel in particular had a torrid evening before being relieved of his duties at half-time. But his bout of jitters was contagious.

In tantalising, albeit brief bursts of attacking verve France threatened to dismantle the Czech Republic as clinically as they had done the Danes five days earlier.

Every time they extended themselves they looked capable of capitalising upon the flimsiness of their opponents. Henry failed in another one-on-one, Nicolas Anelka arrowed a header wide and poor old Srnicek must have won dered if he was back at Sheffield Wednesday.

Just as the superlatives were beginning to run dry, however, closer inspection of the machinery revealed that France might be in need of some fine-tuning. Most notably in the spine of their defence where Marcel Desailly and Laurent Blanc are looking increasingly vulnerable on the turn.

Never more so than in the 65th minute when the Czechs weaved through the middle for Nedved to advance on Fabien Barthez. Didier Deschamps, attempting to retrieve the situation, succeeded only in grounding his opponent on the edge of the penalty area and after much deliberation Graham Poll, officiating in his first match of the championship, awarded a dubious penalty which Poborsky fairly smashed beyond Barthez; Manchester United's past triumphing over the future.

Only the reactions of Barthez prevented Nedved from putting the Czechs ahead at the start of the second half and with the Lazio midfielder doing his damnedest to upstage Zinedine Zidane, they had their moments.

But for as long as the Czech defence continued to go awol they always retained a dubious air of vulnerability, and France capitalised on some more negligible marking on the hour. This time Henry had to make do with an assist, laying on the ball for Youri Djorkaeff to fire a powerful drive beyond the exposed Srnicek.

The towering striker Jan Koller steered a header on to the top of Barthez's crossbar shortly afterwards but, that apart, there were few instances when the Czechs appeared capable of salvaging a draw. The first task for Chovanec this morning will be booking an early flight home.

Pre-competition controls and doping tests during the first round of eight games were all negative, Uefa said yesterday. It is the first time it has carried out unannounced out-of-competition controls, the samples taken in the teams' training camps up to June 6.

webTitle: Wanted: water carriers for some Gallic graft

fields.headline: Wanted: water carriers for some Gallic graft
fields.trailText: Eric Cantona once famously described the French captain Didier Deschamps as a mere water-carrier, a man fit only for a bit of fetching and carrying rather than being entrusted with anything seriously creative.
fields.body:
Eric Cantona once famously described the French captain Didier Deschamps as a mere water-carrier, a man fit only for a bit of fetching and carrying rather than being entrusted with anything seriously creative.

This was ignoring the fact that every team needs a player or two to carry out the menial tasks, particularly if they want to indulge someone like Cantona. And last night we were given an example of what can happen when a team cannot find any volunteers to heave a few buckets or even to sweat a few.

The French have so many potential playmakers that even Deschamps believes himself to be more upstairs than downstairs these days. And for a long spell after receiving the gift of an early goal they sat back and admired their pretty passing as the Czechs threatened to empty a bucket over their pretensions.

Even Zinedine Zidane, gifted footballer that he is, was rolling the ball under his feet and flicking it to colleagues in the manner of someone entertaining dinner guests rather than a man attempting a deadly use of his skills.

The French coach Roger Lemerre, however, has shown in his dealings with the press here that he is not a man to take a lot of nonsense. So the red lights of the substitution board were blinking by the start of the second half, when he brought off a strangely subdued Emmanuel Petit and replaced him with Youri Djorkaeff.

Djorkaeff might not consider himself a water- carrier. But he is no lace-and-frills man either, and it was his combative instincts, as much as the goal he scored, which helped the French to remind themselves, as much as theiropponents, of their talents.

After their performance in the opening game, France became, in the eyes of many commentators, the overwhelming favourites for Euro 2000. A side, so many believed, who would coast through the championship to add this trophy to the World Cup that they brought with them to the Low Countries, in the manner of world boxing champions taking their belts into the ring to intimidate opponents.

Those who believed this most were the French themselves, which can be the only explanation for their performance. They are, even below par, an outstanding team and may yet be good enough to become only the second team after Germany in the early 70s to hold the World Cup and the European Championship at the same time.

They have eased into the quarter-finals and, as in France 98, one can expect them to improve as the tournament progresses. One expects the same of Zidane, whose only real telling pass was a delightful through-ball to Thierry Henry, who was ruled offside.

But how the England coach Kevin Keegan would like some of Lemerre's problems. Keegan cannot find a left-back for love nor money, yet when France's No3 Bixente Lizarazu was pulled out of the game minutes before kick-off, they were able to send out an impressive replacement in Vincent Candela.

The poor old Czechs must have wondered what they have done to continually end up in the so-called Group of Death. They escaped it in England in Euro 96 but a second escape was beyond them, despite the skills of Pavel Nedved.

France will convince themselves that this performance was just a stutter on the way to ultimate glory. But they learned a lesson last night, though it would have been lost on the likes of Monsieur Cantona.

webTitle: The ultimate test of Keegan's faith

fields.headline: The ultimate test of Keegan's faith
fields.trailText: Middle England must hold tonight under aggressive pressure from their old adversaries. David Lacey reports.
fields.body:
If ever a former Saint needed the devil's luck it will be Kevin Keegan in the Stade Communal here tonight. Twenty years ago Keegan swapped ports when he moved from Hamburg to Southampton, now he will be hoping against hope that his ship comes home.

For England the situation is graphically simple. If they lose to Germany they will be out of the European Championship, a draw will still give them a sporting chance, and a win will breathe new life into their chances of qualifying after Monday's numbing defeat by Portugal.

England have not beaten the Germans in one of the major tournaments since the 1966 World Cup final but, having lost to them only on penalties in Italia 90 and Euro 96, they are getting close. An English victory tonight, though unlikely, is not out of the question but a draw looks the better bet.

Keegan is virtually certain to field the team that began the friendly against Brazil at Wembley three weeks ago, with Martin Keown and Dennis Wise replacing the injured Tony Adams and Steve McManaman, both of whom may be available against Romania here on Tuesday. Wise missed part of yesterday evening's training session with a stomach upset but is expected to start the game.

The Portuguese meet Romania in Arnhem in the earlier of today's Group A matches. Thus England will know before the kick-off how strong would be their chances of going through with four points; a draw tonight, say, followed by a win over the Romanians.

Such a hypothesis will be meaningless, however, if Keegan's players have not absorbed Monday's lessons of Eindhoven. While Portugal played some wonderfully imaginative football and deserved their 3-2 victory England performed like novices after taking an early 2-0 lead and allowed the advantage to slip away.

"We intended starting cautiously against Portugal," Keegan admitted yesterday, "but after a fantastic start we got carried away by it. Against Germany we've got to be a lot more sensible about how we go forward and try to open them up."

Keegan's fiercest critics offer Monday's result as proof that the England coach has the tactical acumen of Captain Mainwaring. Even those more sympathetic feel that it might be a good idea to switch from 4-4-2 to 3-5-2 to give England a better chance of holding an ingenuous but aggressive and athletic German midfield.

By the logic of his own reactions to the Portugal result, however, Keegan is not about to alter either the shape of his side or the personnel, apart from the two changes forced on him by the injuries to Adams and McManaman. If he did otherwise he would be contradicting his own argument that Monday's defeat was brought about not by the formation but a collective loss of discipline after Paul Scholes and McManaman apparently put the match beyond Portugal's reach by the 18th minute.

Keegan and his coaching staff believe both the system and the team selection were justified by the strength of England's start to the tournament and that against Germany success will depend more on adjustments than a complete overhaul. In other words remember what went right in Eindhoven and put right what went wrong.

Adams was not fit on Monday and that became clear long before he went off towards the end with a calf strain. Keown's presence should leave the defence less vulnerable to the angled pass or late run and Germany do not have a Rui Costa, Luis Figo or Joao Pinto. Nor do they have their talisman, Oliver Bierhoff, now out for the whole tournament with a calf injury.

Nevertheless Mehmet Scholl will be prowling around the approaches to goal, seeking to set up chances for Carsten Jancker and Ulf Kirsten, and unless Sol Campbell has recovered his sharpness over the past five days England will again be suspect through the middle.

So much of the argument comes back to Paul Ince and the role at the back of midfield which he made his own with a solid, sensible performance against Brazil. After that game Keegan told him: "I don't want you going all over the pitch fighting everybody else's battles, I just want you to win your own."

Poor old Incey. On Monday, as the support vanished upfield in search of more goals and glory, everybody else's battles came to him. In the end he was left on the hard shoulder of a Portuguese motorway and tonight he will be renewing acquaintance with Pierluigi Collina, the Italian referee who sent him off in Sweden at the start of the qualifiers.

Ince, at 32, no longer has the legs to cover ground in his old manner. The game in Eindhoven was more a battle of wits than a test of stamina but you still wondered how he would cope against Jens Jeremies, the driving wheel of the German team, and Liverpool's Dietmar Hamann.

This is why one school of opinion believes that Keegan should be reinforcing his midfield with the younger, fresher Steven Gerrard, so impressive when he won his first full cap against Ukraine, while recalling Gareth Southgate to tidy up behind Keown and Campbell in a back three.

Some also feel that Scholes should be playing off Alan Shearer up front but Michael Owen looks set to return to the attack despite being substituted at half-time against Portugal because Keegan felt he was not holding the ball up properly. "I didn't take him off in order to leave him out in the next game," the England coach explained. "Michael is a big-occasion player, he proved that in the last World Cup."

Keegan is no doubt hoping that Owen's speed will trouble the 39-year-old Lothar Matthäus, whose slowness at the back of the German defence has been a source of angst among Erich Ribbeck's players. The German coach, meanwhile, has brought in Sebastian Deisler, a 20-year-old, on the right side of midfield in the hope of exploiting England's weakness on the left.

Christian Ziege, poor in the 1-1 draw with Romania, has been reprieved at left- wing-back because of his Premiership experience at Middlesbrough, and Markus Babbel and Jens Nowotny will be Matthäus's crutches in defence.

If Scholl is Germany's most likely match-winner then England will again look to the Manchester United combination of David Beckham and Scholes to regain the initiative lost against Portugal. At least England will need no warning about German comebacks.

Kick-off 7.45pm BST

Referee Pierluigi Collina

(Italy)

fields.headline: The Odds Fellow
fields.trailText: Bank on England to cash in for once, says Jamie Reid.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan's view that there will never be a better time to play Germany should be confirmed in Charleroi this evening. The Germans, whose chances have been diminished by the injury to Oliver Bierhoff, were unimpressive against Romania on Monday.

Germany's coach Erich Ribbeck has failed to inspire confidence and his players do not appear united. England's prospects would be improved if Keegan made more than the expected team changes, but his side's efforts early on against Portugal - who look the best team in the top half of the draw - suggest that they can at last get the better of their old rivals.

Most bookies are honest enough to admit that many of the prices quoted about England take advantage of patriotic punters' willingness to accept short odds about the national team.

An outright English win is a best-priced 8-5 with Littlewoods Bet Direct and 7-5 with Chandler and Hill's. A German victory is 6-4 with Surrey and a draw is available at 15-8 with Heathorns. Sceptics might opt for a 1-1 scoreline, which has been popular at 11-2 with Chandler, but personal preference is for a 2-1 victory to England at 6-1 with Chandler.

There are dozens of side-bets on offer. The most attractive is Sporting's fixed-odds special called Victoria Cross, which quotes a tempting 3-1 about an England player scoring directly from a David Beckham centre. Sporting's U-Boats market invites punters to speculate on "how many subs the Germans will use", and three is the suggested option at 5-4.

Portugal can follow up their classy display against England by beating Romania in Arnhem at 6-5 with Heathorns. Norway look a good bet to beat Yugoslavia in Liège tomorrow at 11-8 with Heathorns.

Spain's 1-0 defeat by Norway was bitterly disappointing and Jose Antonio Camacho's men now need a win badly against Slovenia tomorrow. Their opponents, fresh from that remarkable contest with Yugoslavia, are 7-1 with Heathorns, which is quoting 3-1 about a draw. A Spanish victory, a top-priced 1-2 with Ladbrokes, ought to be a formality but this looks a game to watch rather than bet on.

fields.headline: Spanish vow to get mean
fields.trailText: Spain have not gone as far as smuggling in Egil Olsen for lessons in tactics and lectures on marxism. But they realise that since they could not beat the Norwegians they might as well join them in spirit: every Spaniard is ready to sacrifice style for success tomorrow.
fields.body:
Spain have not gone as far as smuggling in Egil Olsen for lessons in tactics and lectures on marxism. But they realise that since they could not beat the Norwegians they might as well join them in spirit: every Spaniard is ready to sacrifice style for success tomorrow.

Tuesday's defeat prompted an inquisition even 16th- century Iberians might have balked at, and the mood back home is clear. "Spain not only lost the game, it lost its credibility," one paper declared.

In short, this looks a case of make or unwanted summer break. The team will happily abandon tradition to leave paella on their critics' faces.

"It doesn't matter any more if we play brilliantly or poorly as long as we win," said the defender Paco. "I don't care what the commentators say about our game. It would obviously be better if we could win 4-0 and play superbly but to be honest I don't really care."

High balls will hardly be pumped to Raul but a revolution of sorts is required. "Maybe we needed more aggression and speed," the striker Ismael Urzaiz said. More width would help too, together perhaps with a change of genes. El Pais asked whether something in the Spanish DNA causes the team to lose their way once major tournaments start. Cloning old Germans might be the solution.

After Slovenia's spectacular collapse against the Yugoslavs, someone must be tempted to suggest going 4-0 down and having two sent off. But there is little room for humour in a camp noticeably stern from the start. Victory is everything. Never mind sensitivities in Charleroi, the message here is "Don't mention the draw".

At least Raul had cause for celebration yesterday after signing a new five-year deal with Real Madrid. He should scrape by on £68,000 a week and may prosper against the Slovenians, who play a less sti fling style the Spanish prefer and look suspect at the back.

Yet the opening match raised serious questions about the invention and killer instinct of Jose Antonio Camacho's team. The coach has promised changes, with Gaizka Mendieta expected in for Fran and the white-booted striker Alfonso a possible starter. Much, though, will rest in the mind.

The Spanish sound as likely to underestimate their opponents as to head for a break in the fjords. "We have to get the mental aspect right before we go out on the field," said Michel Salgado. "From the first minute we have to bear in mind we cannot afford another failure."

With the detailed video sessions to come today, Spain's players admitted they knew little of their opponents. Slovenia's coach Srecko Katanec has fallen out with his country's press after being criticised for his substitutions. For his side this is a test of mental strength after the disappointment of blowing a three-goal lead. For Spain the real pressure is on.

webTitle: Portugal nervous of Romania's old dogs

fields.headline: Portugal nervous of Romania's old dogs
fields.trailText: The team they are calling the Brazil of Europe bring their beguiling skills to the banks of the Rhine this evening hoping Romania do not spring an upset.
fields.body:
The team they are calling the Brazil of Europe bring their beguiling skills to the banks of the Rhine this evening hoping Romania do not spring an upset.

Portugal's coach Humberto Coelho said the advantage of cramming a team with old dogs is they do not need to learn new tricks to perform respectably. He meant Romania not England.

He added a warning note: "We are fully aware the eyes of the world will be upon us and those eyes expect to see us win another game."

If Romania concede as much space as England did, Portugal will head for the quarter-finals as Group A winners. Emerich Ienei, the Romania coach, said: "Portugal had a good day but the English played naively. We will not. [Luis Figo] is a player of true quality and someone out on that pitch is going to have to follow him everywhere."

In qualifying for this tournament Romania won 1-0 in Portugal and the sides drew 1-1 in Bucharest.

fields.headline: Norway go with interrupted Flo
fields.trailText: Tore Andre Flo hopes to end his goal drought for his country in tomorrow night's match with Yugoslavia. The Chelsea striker has not scored for 560 international minutes but his record for Norway remains a respectable 21 goals in 49 matches.
fields.body:
Tore Andre Flo hopes to end his goal drought for his country in tomorrow night's match with Yugoslavia. The Chelsea striker has not scored for 560 international minutes but his record for Norway remains a respectable 21 goals in 49 matches.

"It would be nice to end it against Yugoslavia, but it will be a very difficult game," Flo said. "They are a very good team, but their defence is not the Spanish defence. It may help us too that they have to beat Norway to go through and that could give us more space for counter-attacks."

Flo was disappointing in Norway's 1-0 victory over Spain, and was replaced in the second half by John Carew. But Flo, who turned 27 on Thursday, laughed off reports that Ole Gunnar Solskjaer might take his striking role.

The coach Nils Johan Semb hinted he might change things but added: "Flo is an important player in my plans and he gives the squad a lot."

The Yugoslavia coach Vujadin Boskov expects to have a fully fit squad after Vladimir Jugovic and Darko Kovacevic both trained yesterday. But Boskov faces a selection dilemma in attack between Kovacevic and Savo Milosevic.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 Diary
fields.trailText: • Italy's maverick midfielder Stefano Fiore is a hard man to understand. Asked this week what he would take to a desert island, the Udinese star requested a stack of John Grisham's books, lots of video games and not one but two women, "beautiful enough to turn your head". Asked about the things he'd leave behind, he listed ketchup, mess and the mountains of Russia, which are "a proper nightmare".
fields.body:
 Italy's maverick midfielder Stefano Fiore is a hard man to understand. Asked this week what he would take to a desert island, the Udinese star requested a stack of John Grisham's books, lots of video games and not one but two women, "beautiful enough to turn your head". Asked about the things he'd leave behind, he listed ketchup, mess and the mountains of Russia, which are "a proper nightmare".

 Fiore's lightweight tastes are unlikely to endear him to Vitor Manuel Melo Pereira, the Portuguese referee who will take charge of the Azzurri's final group game. His favourite book is The Unbearable Lightness of Being, by Milan Kundera. He would get on better with Pierluigi Collina (maybe it's an Italian thing), who likes "anything by Grisham", England's Graham Poll (The Runaway Jury is his favourite book), Kim Milton-Nielsen ("books by Desmond Bagley and John Grisham"), Holland's Dick Jol (The Firm), or Austria's Günter Benkö, who ranks Grisham's The Client as the best film ever.

 Something to scare musical purists, from the official Euro 2000 album: "Europe's true anthem is not Joyful Joyful by Beethoven," insist the liner notes, "but Go West by the Village People." Oh dear, is this what we've come to?

 Romania's team doctor Pompiliu Popescu lectured the squad on Thursday about why he's decided to ban sex during the tournament, talking about his theory of the ox and the bull. The ox is calm and pensive because he has been castrated, but the bull is nervous and agitated because of all the hormones playing havoc with his mind. Popescu wants his players, like a love- hungry heifer, to be pumping with energy before every game; hence the ban. Asked their opinions later, the players thought it was a load of bull.

 Holland's Jaap Stam must be glad he isn't Romanian, if this entry in his Euro 2000 diary is to be believed: "Yesterday afternoon Frank Rijkaard allowed us to go home. It was wonderful to spend some time at home with my wife Ellis. I have missed her. It helped me to clear my head and think about something other than football."

 English journalists covering Thursday night's Sweden v Turkey match had a particularly bad time. Not only did they see the tournament's worst match so far, they also ended up with flat drinks. Like many others, our man at the game bought a plastic bottle of Coke from the press lounge before heading for his seat. For the first time, though, his bottle-top was removed before he was allowed in. When he asked why, a stadium manager said: "We were aware that English journalists would be sitting together with Turkish journalists and we didn't want you flicking your bottle-tops at each other in an aggressive fashion." Ridiculous.

webTitle: Coach looks back before facing up to former ally

fields.headline: Coach looks back before facing up to former ally
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 front
fields.trailText: If anyone in the England camp knows what makes the Germans tick, it is Kevin Keegan.
fields.body:
If anyone in the England camp knows what makes the Germans tick, it is Kevin Keegan. In the late 70s he became one of those rare English players to enjoy success abroad, winning a Bundesliga title with Hamburg. According to his strike partner from more than 20 years ago, Horst Hrubesch, "The key to his success was that he embraced German culture."

Yesterday the two men met again, for Hrubesch is now No2 to the Germany coach Erich Ribbeck. It was a marvellous reunion for Keegan, his pre-match tension temporarily eased by his former team-mate.

"I haven't seen him for a while," said Keegan, "but it's like we've never been apart. We both said the same thing: 'Whatever happens we're still friends afterwards.' Friendship goes way beyond one football match."

Tempted though he might have been to ask for a preview of the opposition line-up, the German-speaking Keegan was more interested in swapping news of their respective families, eagerly singing the praises of the man who will sit on the opposition bench today.

"He was very important at Hamburg. Whatever Toshack and Keegan were at Liverpool, Hrubesch and Keegan were at Hamburg.

"It was when he joined Hamburg that it really started to happen for me, because I found a partner I could work with.

"He was not only an excellent player but he was very brave, got carried off a lot of times. I used to say to him, 'You should try lasting a few more games, Horst.' He often got concussion by being brave. But, more importantly, he was a great friend to me off the pitch as well.

"So we've been doing a bit of reminiscing today. We talked about our kids and about my daughter who was born while I was there. We're both a little bit older and probably not much wiser, but we're still great friends and will remain so despite what happens in the match."

 At the FA's request, the perspex players' tunnel in Charleroi has been covered over to avoid a repeat of the unsavoury incidents involving abusive fans after England's last game in Eindhoven.

webTitle: A private William speaks publicly for the first time

fields.headline: A private William speaks publicly for the first time
fields.standfirst:
Before his 18th birthday next week, Prince William provides a treat for royal watchers but says he is uncomfortable with the attention

See the pictures
The future of the monarchy: special report
The British Monarchy
fields.trailText: Prince William, possibly Europe's most eligible bachelor, probably Britain's most famous teenager and certainly second in line to its throne, was yesterday pushed reluctantly into the limelight by Buckingham Palace in an attempt to head off what the royal family expect will be worldwide fascination with his 18th birthday next week.
fields.body:
Prince William, possibly Europe's most eligible bachelor, probably Britain's most famous teenager and certainly second in line to its throne, was yesterday pushed reluctantly into the limelight by Buckingham Palace in an attempt to head off what the royal family expect will be worldwide fascination with his 18th birthday next week.

The palace released a selection of photographs of the prince at Eton, five minutes of film shot over several months by ITN and a staggeringly uninformative interview based on written questions submitted by the Press Association. Virtually nothing about the prince, his tastes or views, can be gleaned from his answers.

William's birthday falls next Wednesday, when he will be revising for his history of art A-Level the following day. Asked how he plans to celebrate, the young man replied circumspectly: "I haven't really thought about it, but no doubt I will celebrate privately with some friends."

Royal watchers have claimed that, like many an 18-year-old, the prince had actually hoped to go to a London nightclub and had a row with his father over Prince Charles's plan to organise a ball for him at Highgrove instead.

Now, it is said, he will have a party down the road from his school at Windsor Castle, with the senior members of the family retiring discreetly at midnight.

Yesterday's heavily controlled media operation has already cost Sandy Henney, the Prince of Wales's press secretary, her job last week, for failing to nail down the copyright on official photographs securely.

The pictures and the film show the prince at his computer, on the games field, in the school swimming pool playing water polo, looking pensive, cooking chicken paella and wearing various highly-coloured waistcoats, including one with a union flag under his school uniform to signify membership of the exclusive Eton prefects' society known as Pop.

The ITN film contains his first recorded words - in answer to the question "Can I just ask you, William, what you are preparing?" - "Paella with chicken, rice, garlic and beans" and his first broadcast royal command as the dish starts to go wrong: "Do something - quickly!"

He says that he has enjoyed Eton very much and will miss his friends and housemaster when he leaves, that he likes the uniform, especially the waistcoats and wing collars, and that he is planning to take a gap year before going to university. "At the moment I prefer to keep the details private until all the arrangements have been settled," he says.

He is planning to study the history of art, probably at Edinburgh University, but, asked whether he would like to study abroad, appeared flummoxed at the suggestion. "I can honestly say I haven't thought about it; it hadn't crossed my mind," he said.

The prince admits to enjoying a wide range of books "but I don't have particular favourite authors", to enjoying dancing, as well as team games like soccer and rugby, and to going to the local cinema when there is a good film showing: "I prefer action films."

The prince squashes media rumours about being linked to Britney Spears - "there's been a lot of nonsense put about by PR companies. I don't like being exploited in this way but as I get older it's increasingly hard to prevent" - and confides that his pet labrador Widgeon has recently had eight puppies.

Asked how he copes with the attention of girls, he replied: "In my own way. Trying to explain how might be counterproductive." Asked whether he has a girlfriend, he replied: "I like to keep my private life private."

One decided dislike however is the attention of the public and the media. He said : "I feel uncomfortable with it ... The media have left me alone while I have been at Eton for which I am grateful."

He said : "I feel uncomfortable with it ... The media have left me alone while I have been at Eton for which I am grateful."

fields.headline: A chorus of Mr Spocks
fields.standfirst:
Marriage of Figaro/ Il Mondo della Luna
Garsington Manor
****
fields.trailText:
Marriage of Figaro/ Il Mondo della Luna
Garsington Manor
****
fields.body:
The minor miracle of opera at Garsington is that in the open air, with only a plastic sheet as roofing, the sound would do credit to any opera house. This season begins with new stagings of two operas seen earlier at Garsington, Mozart's Marriage of Figaro and Haydn's Il Mondo della Luna (The World on the Moon). Both operas are given extra freshness and intensity in this setting.

It is disappointing that the new sets cover up the contours of the Garsington Manor stable block where the operas are presented, but the flat screens help to enhance the sound. In the Mozart they also make one relish the directness of the staging by Stephen Barlow, with minimal sets by Neil Warmington. With only two or three props used in each act - a chair, a chest and a couple of classical doorways - the complicated story is made clearer than in the new Glyndebourne production, with fewer trendy distractions. One magical point is that the garden to the right of the audience becomes an integral part of the production.

As so often at Garsington, the cast consists almost entirely of young singers with clear voices. The Icelandic Hulda Bjork Gardarsdottir is a bright, lively Susanna, while Franzita Whelan from Ireland is a maternal Countess and Peter Savidge a formidable Count, whose acting is superb. But the whole production revolves round the brilliant Figaro of the Ferrier prizewinner, Mark Stone, who gives a handsome performance, finely detailed and beautifully sung.

The Garsington Opera Orchestra, incorporating Guildhall Strings, sparkles in the Mozart under Stephen Barlow, as it does in the Haydn under Jane Glover. Though this trivial piece, written for a royal wedding, seems painfully thin musically next to the Mozart masterpiece, the setting at Garsington makes it delightful entertainment, the more so because the endless recitative has been cut to size.

The fantastic Goldoni plot revolves round the bogus astronomer, Ecclitico, (winningly played by Mark Tucker), tricking the doddering old Buonafede (Jonathan Veira) into believing that he has been transported to the moon. Michael McCaffery's production, with designs by Paul Edwards, offers a science-fiction setting, full of references to Star Trek and Star Wars, including a whole chorus of Mr Spocks. It is all great fun.

 In rep until July 8. Box office: 01865 361636.

fields.headline: Supporters clubbed
fields.trailText: There seems to be something of a misunderstanding about the Euro 2000 football championships, with some people mistaking it for a sporting event.
fields.body:
There seems to be something of a misunderstanding about the Euro 2000 football championships, with some people mistaking it for a sporting event.

In fact, it's not even called Euro 2000; look at any document from the organisers and you'll see its proper title is Euro 2000 - a none too subtle reminder that we're talking about a product.

Now, to a few sentimental souls, Euro 2000 might sound a little heartless - like re-branding the heir to the throne as The Prince of Wales or floating Christmas on the Stock Exchange - but we're all citizens of a consumer democracy and everything has a price.

So while there are 16 national teams hoofing the ball around the pitch for a chunk of metal, there is a parallel promotional competition being fought out in the hospitality suites. Euro 2000 has 12 "official" sponsors, teams which have come through the qualifying rounds to claim the exclusive right to be Official Crisp or Official Computer Game or whatever.

These are the usual suspects - health food companies such as McDonalds, Pringles and Coca Cola, finance mega-brand MasterCard and electronics giants Philips and JVC. The Official Beer is Carlsberg - and if UEFA thinks it useful I could forward the names of a few people willing to become the Unofficial Drunks of Euro 2000.

At stake is a television audience of 10bn viewers in 200 countries in a sports tournament only to be surpassed by the World Cup (sorry, that has been packaged for sponsors as "2002 FIFA World Cup Korea/Japan") and the Olympic Games.

And when the English players run on to the pitch this evening in their match against Germany, the cash tills will be ringing for our own Football Association, as the event drums up more business for its merchandising sales.

Those middle-aged men heading off to the pub in their replica England football shirt and shorts have paid about £65 for the privilege of swathing their beer bellies in officially-endorsed polyester. And if Euro 2000 fever has left them wanting more, the FA's England Direct service can supply everything from patriotic curtains to quilt covers (although, perhaps tellingly, these only seem to be available for single beds).

If football is money, then it's only a short step for clubs to cut out the 90 minutes of distraction and begin selling money directly - or, at least, financial services. And in the true Sheriff of Nottingham tradition of football (robbing the poor to pay for the rich), don't expect anyone to be giving anything away.

If you're a supporter of Manchester United plc - able to pay its players more for a week than most of us earn in a year - you might be tempted to sign up for a club credit card. As the advertising flannel has it: "Manchester United's teams have always been fiercely competitive and so is the Manchester United MasterCard." Except that at 19.9 APR it's about as competitive as a goalkeeper in a blindfold. I'd suggest that fans cut out a picture of David Beckham and glue it on a credit card with an interest rate nearer 10 APR - it'll look the same and save you money.

In the same spirit of unbridled altruism, Chelsea has a credit card which promises to help the long-term future of the club. The bad news is you pay an interest rate of 21.7 APR and the payment to the club is a towering 0.2 per cent of spending, which goes into a fund which aims to buy the ground's freehold and lease it back to the club for a pound a year.

If you want to save rather than borrow, Everton has its own savings account scheme for supporters, offering the far from table-topping interest rates of 3.5% gross up to £5,000 and 5% gross for anything over £5,000.

As well as its credit card, Chelsea offers car and contents insurance in a deal with insurance broker Lambert Fenchurch. And Aston Villa lets its fans gamble tax-free on the internet, with its Villabet online bookies. With a large base of supporters and a high television profile, football clubs are using their brand names to lever their way into new markets. It's not that different from how supermarkets entered the banking business - except that cynics might say that supermarkets were used to offering a good deal for customers, while football clubs are too long accustomed to taking their supporters for granted.

Football has always been good at demanding loyalty and not giving back much in return. After a lifetime of supporting Portsmouth I should by now have learned my lesson and accepted that the beautiful game is about giving and not receiving. I wonder if the 2002 FIFA World Cup Korea/Japan needs an Official Pessimist.

webTitle: MTV mall rock makes it big

fields.headline: MTV mall rock makes it big
fields.standfirst:
Matchbox 20
Hammersmith Apollo, London
**
fields.trailText:
Matchbox 20
Hammersmith Apollo, London
**
fields.body:
Considering that the American rock press usually finds something positive to say about even the most world-class dullards, its description of Matchbox 20 as "bland and faceless" suggests that this Florida five-piece must be in a class of their own. When Spin magazine canvassed the audience at one of their gigs, few could even name singer Rob Thomas. This is pretty good going, given that Thomas also wrote and sang the lead vocal on Carlos Santana's 13-weeks-at-number-one hit Smooth.

But Matchbox 20's impressive showing in the dullness olympics has actually proved a boon. Sounding like a facsimile of every middling rock outfit from Semisonic to the E Street Band on Springsteen's day off, they've roped in a huge US constituency hungry for melodic mall rock performed by the dudes next door (whose only concession to the 21st century is goatees and pink shades, to complement their traditional schlepwear). Their debut, Yourself or Someone Like You, sold 14m.

Despite this, their media profile in the UK is nil, so it's an achievement to have sold out the Apollo on only the second London date of their career. During the long interval - caused by an unannounced bomb scare backstage - a fan explained to me that high audience numbers were less surprising than they seemed. Matchbox 20 are apparently on heavy rotation on MTV. So that was why the entire house rose to the first gravelly chords of Angry, from the new album Mad Season, and stayed risen through the dozen or so soundalikes that followed. That MTV magic was also probably responsible for the howls that greeted Thomas's jape: "We were coming in from the airport and saw a poster for our new single, Bent, and we thought, damn, over here that's like calling it Poofter."

There's not much to say about the music, which was warm, affable and as "bland and faceless" as promised. The tunes that possessed a smidgen of character were those that sounded like other people's stuff - If You're Gone, for instance, evoked Springsteen in ballad mode, while Crutch's chewable desolation was indebted to REM. If you hadn't heard either of those artists, you might think Matchbox 20 had uncovered a seam of yearning, old-style guitar rock that can hold its own against more fashionable competitors.

But does anyone, including themselves, really think that these obviously nice guys are doing anything even vaguely original?

Matchbox 20 play the Old Fruit Market, Glasgow (0141-287 5511), tomorrow.

fields.headline: Interactive Investor takes a dive
fields.standfirst:
Plunge in hi-techs provides proof of billionaire financier's view of sector

E-finance: special report
www.iii.co.uk
fields.trailText: Shares in financial services website Interactive Investor International yesterday plummeted to a new low of 56.5p - a seventh of what they were worth three months ago - after the company issued a profits warning.
fields.body:
Shares in financial services website Interactive Investor International yesterday plummeted to a new low of 56.5p - a seventh of what they were worth three months ago - after the company issued a profits warning.

While subscribers to the site flocked to its bulletin boards to vent their anger and speculate on the company's future, chief executive Tomas Carruthers insisted there was no need to panic.

Yesterday's 17.5% fall in the share price followed a trading statement from the company which warned that revenue during the second half of this year would show only modest growth over the first six months.

Interactive Investor, which floated on the stock market in February, is reaping the fall-out from the plunge in tech stock values in March and April.

Many small investors use the site to swap tips and information on hi-tech shares, and the recent volatility will have left many nervous about dabbling in this sector.

"Since March, there has been a significant decline in equity market activity worldwide from record levels earlier in the year. This has depressed transaction volumes and related revenues," said the statement. "Increased emphasis will now be placed on strengthening the company's presence in the UK market."

Yesterday's events were a far cry from February 17, when shares in the company began trading at 150p and finished the day at 335p. The share offer was 26 times oversubscribed, with 82,000 small investors - a record for a British internet flotation - applying for shares. As a result, allocations were scaled back to a flat 145 shares, worth just over £81 at yesterday's closing price.

Mr Carruthers said there was no reason to worry, pointing out that the company had £65m on the balance sheet, recently saw the number of registered account users reach 1.1m and was working on a number of new initiatives.

The slide has left many of its small investors feeling bruised and angry. The company was the talk of its own bulletin boards yesterday, with dozens of users logging on to vent their spleen.

Some contributors speculated that the company might be ripe for a takeover bid, while one claimed he had pinpointed the company's problem - "They don't really sell anything. I think most of their users are like us. If we see a 'You must pay for this message' we back out of there, quick sharp."

fields.headline: Dresdner explores £27bn merger with Commerzbank
fields.trailText: Merger mania gripped the German banking market yesterday as it emerged that Dresdner and Commerzbank were in talks about a £27bn deal.
fields.body:
Merger mania gripped the German banking market yesterday as it emerged that Dresdner and Commerzbank were in talks about a £27bn deal.

Any union is understood to be some way off, but the speculation about a merger resurrected fears of a job cull among their respective investment banking operations in the City of London.

Only three months ago, investment bankers feared carnage in the Square Mile when Dresdner and its larger rival, Deutsche Bank, announced their intention to merge. That deal fell apart with recriminations over the Dresdner Kleinwort Benson (DrKB) investment banking arm.

News of exploratory talks be tween Dresdner and Commerzbank, on which neither would comment, reignited expectations of a wave of consolidation in the German banking sector.

The collapse of the previous merger is expected to make Dresdner's new chief executive, Bernd Fahrholz, determined not to announce any deal until he is confident it can be completed. He told investors only a month ago that he intended to develop the business independently.

Dresdner is understood to have meetings arranged with analysts in London next week to outline its "go-it-alone" strategy.

However, banking sources suggested that Allianz, the German insurance group which owns 22% of Dresdner, was exerting pressure on the new management team to complete a deal.

One source suggested that Hypo Vereins bank, in which the insurer also has a large stake, was being lined up as a potential partner.

Allianz's chief executive Henning Schulte-Noelle was quoted yesterday as saying that "everyone was talking to everyone again and considering all the options" but refused to comment on the latest rumours.

Sources said Commerzbank was also being encouraged towards the takeover table by Rebon, a Dutch investment group which owns more than 15% of its shares.

Senior banking sources played down speculation that substantive talks between Dresdner and Deutsche were to begin this weekend with a top level meeting of management and the banks' boards. One suggested the deal had a 50/50 chance of being cemented.

If it is, investment bankers in the City fear it will again lead to disruption of business amid concerns about job cuts. However, one suggested that the jobs axe might not fall so heavily this time. Commerzbank was only 18 months into building up its investment banking operation in the City while Dresdner had locked in most of its 3,500 DrKB staff with golden handcuffs to deter defections after the Deutsche deal collapsed.

Despite the rumours of long-awaited consolidation in the German banking industry, the combination of Deutsche and Commerzbank - which are roughly the same size in terms of stock market value - met with a cautious response from analysts. Some wondered whether Allianz would accept a deal with Commerzbank with which its rival, Generali of Italy, has a close relationship.

webTitle: Top pension fund is very  well nursed

fields.headline: Top pension fund is very  well nursed
fields.standfirst:
Health workers can get the best retirement provision, says a new survey. Patrick Collinson looks at how the rest of us will fare as administration costs and other charges take their toll
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: No one looks forward to shopping around for a personal pension, yet picking the wrong one can cost the average saver £30,000, according to a survey published today.
fields.body:
No one looks forward to shopping around for a personal pension, yet picking the wrong one can cost the average saver £30,000, according to a survey published today.

The cheapest personal pensions will give a £100 per month saver a retirement pot of around £160,000 after 35 years, with charges lopping off around £20,000. The most expensive will see your final pension worth only £125,000, with more than £50,000 gobbled up in charges.

The survey, by industry newspaper Money Marketing and actuaries KPMG, focused on a 30-year old man wanting to retire at age 65, with £100 per month to invest. It asked each company to project on the same basis - an investment growth of 7% a year - to determine exactly how much is lost because of the company's charges, which pay for commission to advisers and for the administration of the policy.

Top of the table, just ahead of Legal & General and Royal London, is RNPFN, the Royal National Pension Fund for Nurses, which has repeatedly topped tables which focus on "own charge projections".

Unfortunately, RNPFN is open only to healthcare workers and their partners who don't have access to an occupational scheme. Anyone working for a company which offers an occupational scheme, where the employer pays into your pension, is ill-advised to opt out into a personal pension.

Jeremy Drake of RNPFN says: "We are fully supportive of the NHS pension scheme and without question it is the best choice for the overwhelming number of NHS workers. But we operate in a niche which covers agency nurses, pharmacists, opticians, consultants with self-employed earnings and so on, who may not be able to participate in the NHS scheme."

RNPFN beats all comers on charges because it does everything through the post and telephone. "We have no salesmen, no agents, no expensive branches and are a non-commission based office. We also give all advice in writing," says Mr Drake.

As the table shows, RNPFN would expect to pay out £159,701. A pension which had absolutely no charges would pay out £178,643, so the impact of charges on a RNPFN pension is a loss of £18,942. Compare that with bottom-of-the-table Skandia Life, which projects a final pension pot of £124,667, with £53,976 lost through charges.

To most people selecting a personal pension, the projection figures appear outlandishly high and often meaningless. Jobs & Money asked annuity specialists Annuity Direct to convert the payout figure into an income, and found that RNPFN's £159,701 is today equal to an annual income of £11,115, for a man retiring at 65 while Skandia's pension pot would produce just over £9,000. That £2,000 a year is likely to make a significant difference for a struggling pensioner.

But annuity rates fluctuate widely every day, and the figures do not take into account the impact of inflation over the period. Also, the annuity would be even lower if you choose one which gives your spouse an income on your death.

In defence of its projection figures, Skandia says that charges tables compare apples with oranges. Spokesman Nick Bladen says that its pension contract includes a guaranteed element not available on other pensions which make it attractive despite the charges. Skandia also offers a pick-and-mix investment strategy which allows savers to have their money managed by a wide variety of different investment companies.

The Money Marketing survey also reveals that most personal pensions are still charging considerably more than the maximum level that will be permitted under stakeholder pensions when they are introduced in April next year.

Only four of the pensions in the Money Marketing tables of more than 50 companies meet the stakeholder charging criteria. The conclusion for many will be that holding off taking out a personal pension until the cheap ones become available next year may make sound financial sense.

fields.headline: Egg stays on the boil
fields.standfirst:
As the internet bank floats on the stock market, Rupert Jones assesses the prospects for investors
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: As the internet bank floats on the stock market, Rupert Jones assesses the prospects for investors.
fields.body:
Shares in internet bank Egg ended their first few days on the stock market sunny side up, much to the relief of the thousands of customers who bought into the share issue.

The shares started trading at 160p each, hit 177.5p on Monday afternoon and by close of play on Thursday had fallen back slightly to 172.5p - which still adds up to a paper profit of almost 8% for those who held on rather than selling immediately.

However, analysts suggest that even at this price, the shares could be rather overcooked, and now might be the time for those not in for the long haul to bale out.

Despite the recent tech stocks volatility, the partial flotation of the Prudential's e-banking arm was nine times oversubscribed. More than 85,000 Egg customers and employees applied for shares, and as a result of the clamour, those who applied for £1,000 worth of shares got only £752 worth.

However, those who applied for £200 or £500 worth will receive their full allocations, which at 172.5p a share were worth £215 and £538 respectively. Investors will receive their share certificates shortly.

Alex Scott, internet analyst at Barclays Stockbrokers, says that while he is reasonably optimistic in the long-term about Egg, he is somewhat uneasy about the prices being achieved this week. "My feeling is that fair value for the shares is between 140p-150p."

So what can we expect to happen to the share price in the coming weeks and months? Well, we are unlikely to see any massive ups and downs during the next couple of weeks because Goldman Sachs, the investment bank acting as adviser and broker to Egg, will be doing all it can to keep the share price reasonably stable. This is known as stabilisation and involves the investment bank buying and selling the stock to prevent it falling below the offer price.

Mr Scott says that to accept the shares at their current price, you need to be happy that Egg is going to deliver on some very bullish assumptions on customer recruitment - it currently has 1m savers and borrowers - and retention, and its ability to cross-sell other products. "I think caution is called for until they can provide evidence that they are on track on those areas," he adds.

Jeremy Batstone at NatWest Stockbrokers agrees that because of the stabilisation the shares "are not going to go anywhere" during the next month. After that, it could be a very different story. He believes that fair value for the shares is probably around 100p-130p at the very most - and suggests that baling out now might be the wise move. There are plenty of great things in the financial services sector to invest in but Egg is "not one of them", says Mr Batstone.

It will be interesting to see how Egg manages to balance the needs of its customers, who have got used to table-topping rates of interest - up to 6.3% from £1 on savings accounts and a low 10.9 APR on its credit cards - with the demands of its new shareholders, who are presumably not going to put up with Egg haemorrhaging cash forever and are going to be clamouring for their dividends.

It's a cut-throat market out there. This week saw the launch of Abbey National's internet bank Cahoot (see page 6), which is offering some competitive deals, and next month sees the arrival of Intelligent Finance, the Halifax's stand-alone e-bank, which is promising savings account-style rates of interest on current accounts.

Other net ventures such as Smile (the Co-op Bank's internet subsidiary) and First-e (a division of French bank Banque d'Escompte) will also continue to pile on the pressure.
