fields.headline: Scottish Widows boosts the kitty
fields.standfirst:
It was good news and bad news for 1.6m policyholders this week: the about-to-be taken over insurer announced bigger payouts, but delayed for two months. Rupert Jones reports
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It was good news and bad news for 1.6m policyholders this week: the about-to-be taken over insurer announced bigger payouts, but delayed for two months.
fields.body:
While Standard Life is desperately trying to play down how much any windfalls might be worth (see pages 2-3), another north-of-the-border insurance giant has surprised everyone by announcing that its policyholders will actually get bigger payouts than originally thought.

Scottish Widows made a lot of its policyholders very happy when it revealed this week that 900,000 of them can expect windfalls around 8% higher than originally forecast.

The increase boosts the average payout to a typical with-profits policyholder by £450 to just over £6,000. However, the downside is that the Widows windfalls will now not be paid out until the end of August - two months later than planned.

These payouts dwarf those promised by Bradford & Bingley, the building society currently in the process of seeking approval from members to convert to a bank. Voting forms have been dropping on doormats over the past few days, and if they give the go-ahead, B&B members can expect windfalls averaging £731.

The Widows announcement ratchets up the pressure on other mutual insurers facing challenges from carpetbaggers as it graphically illustrates just how much gold there is in "them thar hills".

In all, 1.6m Scottish Widows policyholders are receiv ing payouts as a result of the takeover by Lloyds TSB. As has already been announced, all these people will receive a fixed payout of £500. However, 900,000 of the 1.6m hold with-profits policies and will also receive a variable sum based on the type of policy, its size and how long they have held it for.

Last November, Widows said that payouts to these people would vary dramatically, from just a few hundred pounds to £100,000-plus, and would average £5,600.

However, it now says the payouts are likely to be around 8% higher than origi nally thought, which lifts that average figure to £6,050. The reason for this is that the business is now judged to be worth more than it was when the original valuation was carried out, and as a result Lloyds TSB has upped the amount it is paying for it to £7.3bn from £6.7bn.

Of this extra £600m, £400m will be paid out to policyholders immediately, while the remaining £200m will be added to £1.3bn already set aside and will be paid out over time in the form of enhanced terminal bonuses to with-profits policyholders.

The 8% extra figure is very much an average - some people will get more than this while others will get less. In the case of endowment policy-holders, the younger you started the policy, the larger the slice of extra cash you are likely to receive.

However, policyholders will not know exactly how much they are getting until the cheques actually arrive, which is expected to be during the second half of August.

For example, someone paying £50 a month into a with-profits endowment policy since 1979 is looking at a windfall of £14,700 - up sig nificantly from the original estimate of £12,200 - if they were aged 40 when they took it out. If the person was 30 at the start of the contract they look set to pocket even more - £15,300.

Here are some more examples of revised potential payouts:
 Someone paying £50 a month into a 25-year with-profits pension policy since 1979 is set for a windfall of £17,500 (previous estimate: £16,400)
 Someone paying £100 a month into a 25-year with-profits pension policy since 1989 is looking at a likely payout of £6,550 (previous estimate: £6,010)
 Someone paying £100 a month into a 25-year with-profits endowment since 1989 and who was aged 30 at the start of the policy, is in line for a windfall of £6,340 (previous estimate: £5,010)

Scottish Widows will be writing to policyholders in the next few weeks to ask them how they want to receive their windfall. There are four options:
 Ask for a cheque to be sent to you.
 Have the cash paid into a "VIP Premier Account" with Scottish Widows Bank. This hasn't been launched yet so we don't know what the interest rate will be but it is likely to mimic the bank's existing instant access-style account which pays from 6.25%. To tempt people to go for this option, the company will be awarding an interest bonus of 0.5% for six months.
 Take your windfall in the form of loan notes, a sort of IOU that allows you to take your cash at a later stage. Loan notes are often used where people are worried that a windfall will exceed the annual capital gains tax allowance (currently £7,200).
 For those not sure how much they are getting, but who are concerned about a possible tax liability, there is the option of taking loan notes if the windfall exceeds £7,200, and a cheque if it doesn't.
 If you have any queries call the helpline: 0345 600 100.

webTitle: Carpetbaggers set to pull the rug on mutuals

fields.headline: Carpetbaggers set to pull the rug on mutuals
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Is Standard Life losing the battle against the carpetbaggers? It's six days before the ballot box closes for the 2.3m voters, but early indications are that while mutuality wins the hearts of many, victory may go to the many more who are voting with their pockets for windfalls worth thousands of pounds.
fields.byline: Tony Levene, Jessica McCallin and Philippa Black
fields.body:
Is Standard Life losing the battle against the carpetbaggers? It's six days before the ballot box closes for the 2.3m voters, but early indications are that while mutuality wins the hearts of many, victory may go to the many more who are voting with their pockets for windfalls worth thousands of pounds.

Last week Jobs & Money asked readers if they were backing the Standard Life board or the carpetbaggers. The result (see right) was a near unanimous vote for taking the cash. We also went out on the streets to ask policyholders at random what they thought; more support there for mutuality, but still a large number in favour of conversion.

The results tie in with an earlier newspaper poll which showed four out of five backing the carpetbaggers. They also reveal a hardening of opinion since April, when a private poll conducted by Standard Life found policyholders split almost evenly, but with a large number of "don't knows".

A vote for conversion could be the final nail in the coffin for mutuality, to the fury of more than 60 MPs who have signed an early day motion backing the Standard Life board.

Frank Field, former social security minister and fierce defender of mutuality, told Jobs & Money: "I just very much hope that policyholders vote No on their forms. When mutuals were established, no one conceived of this happening. It's like the Roman Catholic church opening its doors to atheists and then letting them shut it down.

"We had the same problem in the Labour Party with Trotskyists totally opposed to the core values of the party. We had to change the rules and kick them out."

The worst result for Standard Life would be a majority in favour of conversion, but not enough to meet the 75% of those voting necessary for the resolution to be carried. Andrew Love, MP for Edmonton and chair of the all-party building society group who was behind the early day motion says: "Even if the result is 51-60% in favour of conversion, the company can strongly argue that it has won its case against fundamental change. But if it creeps towards 75%, then it becomes very difficult for them to ignore it."

Mr Love urges voters not to be swayed by the windfalls. "It is clear that there are a very large number of policyholders who will receive a relatively small amount, and a small number who will receive huge amounts. Fred Woollard [the leader of the carpetbagging campaign] has produced figures on windfalls but no one knows where they come from.

"Many people voted for the demutualisation of Bradford & Bingley expecting £2,000 windfalls, and must be rather miffed that it is now closer to £750."

Mr Woollard is convinced his campaign will achieve more than 50% support. "I have no doubt we will get a strong majority", he says, although he is less sure of hitting the 75% target. The nightmare for Standard Life is that Mr Woollard - who stands to make £150,000 if the company converts - says he will quit campaigning only if the vote is below 50%.

If the result is between 50% to 75%, he will put forward resolutions next year to stack the board with directors in favour of demutualisation.

"Let's say the vote is 65% for conversion. Standard Life will say to me 'you didn't get your 75% so sod off'. But the problem the company faces is that I will not then go away. I will only go away if Standard Life gets more votes than we do."

The result of the ballot will be announced in Edinburgh on June 27.

The word on the street...

 East Londoner David Turner sells terminals for Bloomberg. And he reckons it should be terminal for the Standard Life board, where he has held a policy for three years. He's voted for demutualisation and hopes to get nearly £5,000. He says: "The company is being incredibly unprofessional. What are they afraid of?"

 Michael Head, an independent financial adviser from Colchester, is voting for mutuality despite a big payout potential. But he expects the carpetbaggers to win. He says: "Competition is important. If Standard Life goes, the public will have less choice. It could have paid bonus payments, but didn't because it was too cautious."

 Brenda Yoxall, an office manager from Beckenham, has binned her ballot paper. She admits she doesn't know which way the vote should go. She says : "I got fed up with the amount of confusing Standard Life infomation and by the time the voting forms came through I couldn't be bothered."

webTitle: Success swamps yet another web bank

fields.headline: Success swamps yet another web bank
fields.standfirst:
Potential customers wanting to get into cahoots with Abbey National's new internet venture were miffed when the site sank under the strain. Rupert Jones looks at the trend and its troubles
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Potential customers wanting to get into cahoots with Abbey National's new internet venture were miffed when the site sank under the strain. Rupert Jones looks at the trend and its troubles
fields.body:
The internet may be changing the way we lead our lives but fears about security and technical glitches have left many wary about handing over their hard-earned cash to an online bank.

Egg and the Halifax are just two of the companies that have experienced problems of one sort or another during the last few months. And net sceptics will have even less confidence in the new technology following this week's Cahoot calamity. Cahoot (www.cahoot.com) is Abbey National's much-promoted new internet bank, which fell foul of gremlins shortly after its launch, resulting in its website being out of action for a large chunk of Monday.

Thousands of people who tried to sign up for Cahoot's mouth-watering introductory offer - interest-free overdrafts and credit cards for a year for the first 25,000 applicants - got the message: "We apologise, but due to unprecedented demand the application process is not currently available."

When Egg hatched in 1998 many customers trying to open accounts faced long delays because it badly underestimated the response to its launch. There were similar problems when Egg launched its credit card late last year. At around the same time the Halifax was forced to temporarily close its online share-dealing service after a technical glitch.

Something like normal service has resumed at Cahoot, though the website was being taken down occasionally to stop it buckling under the strain.

Cahoot is initially offering current accounts and credit cards, with online share-dealing, savings accounts and personal loans due to follow in the next few months.

So how do its deals stack up? Well, if you're prepared to give the technology the benefit of the doubt, the Cahoot current account offers a very competitive, if not table-topping, deal. The main attraction is a savings account-style rate of interest on credit balances. You can choose whether or not to have a chequebook; if you opt for one you will receive a slightly lower rate of interest.

Interest rates are tiered like a savings account, starting at 3% gross for balances of between £1 and £2,000 for those taking a cheque book, rising to 4.5% for those with more than £2,000 in their account and no cheque book. These rates are leagues ahead of the paltry amounts paid by most leading high street banks. The big four - Barclays, Lloyds TSB, NatWest and HSBC - all pay standard current account holders a minuscule 0.1% gross.

There are one or two players that beat Cahoot. Internet bank First-e, a division of the French Banque d'Escompte, is offering current account customers 4.88% gross on balances of £1 upwards. Close behind is Smile, the Co-op's internet venture, paying 4.75% gross from £1. Sun Bank, the UK banking arm of Sun Life Financial of Canada, has a cheque account paying from 4.8% gross, though the minimum balance is £1,000.

Another plus of the Cahoot current account is that it gives you an automatic £250 interest-free, fee-free overdraft. However, where it really hopes to trump rivals is in its ability to "customise" accounts to meet individual needs. For example, if you opt to borrow via an authorised overdraft or a Cahoot credit card, you'll be able to choose between paying interest or a fixed monthly fee. Its credit card and overdraft annual percentage rates are some of the best in the market, ranging from 7 to 11 APR.

The precise rate offered will depend on creditworthiness, agreed overdraft/credit limit and "profitability" to the bank - ie, the more you borrow, the lower the rate you are likely to enjoy.

For example, a typical medium-risk customer with a Cahoot current account who has requested an overdraft facility of £3,000 and has a good credit rating has three options: paying interest of 9 APR; a monthly fee of £17.55; or a combination of interest at 4.5 APR and a monthly fee of £8.78.

This tailored approach makes comparisons with other providers difficult. However, an overdraft rate of 9 APR is very low - less than half the 18.8 APR charged by high street giants such as Lloyds TSB.

On the credit card front, some providers charge less than 9 APR but these are invariably special offers which last for just a few months. For example, Nationwide building society has a card with a rate on purchases of 3.5 APR for the first six months. Then the rate rises to 14.6 APR. Capital One Bank is offering a rate of 3.9 APR for the first six months (then 12.9 APR). The Marbles card and RBS Advanta are both offering 4.5 APR for the first six months and until March 1 2001 respectively.

Cahoot hopes to steal a march on Intelligent Finance, the Halifax's stand-alone internet bank which goes live next month. But the main challenge both e-banks will face is persuading people to ditch their existing bank. Inertia rules, and mostpeople never get round to switching to another provider, even though they know there are better deals out there.

But Intelligent Finance reckons attitudes are changing. It published a survey this week in which two out of five adults said they would be likely to move their account if a savings account-style rate of interest were on offer.

fields.headline: The case for resisting greed
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Carpetbaggers are driven by "pure greed" argues David Simpson, Standard Life's economic adviser
fields.body:
Carpetbaggers are driven by "pure greed" argues David Simpson, Standard Life's economic adviser

Demutualisation means one generation of policyholders seizing benefits passed down to them and denying these benefits to future generations. This is pure greed. Some might even call it theft. Like the landowners of the early 19th century who sought the protection of the Corn Laws, the carpetbaggers want "to reap where they have not sown".

Much of the discussion of demutualisation has focused on the size of "windfalls" policyholders may receive. Less attention has been paid to where this money is coming from. The term "windfall" is really a misnomer - any such payouts would not be costless: in economic affairs there is no such thing as a free lunch.

Members of a mutual benefit from a stock of capital which is handed down from one generation to the next. This capital is typically used to enable a higher proportion of premiums to be invested in shares than would otherwise be the case and is the principal reason why comparisons of investment returns over the long term invariably show that mutuals outperform the average shareholder-owned life company.

What would be the consequences of demutualisation?

The carpetbaggers suggest the company could continue unchanged. In fact, mutuality is a major element of Standard Life's culture, enabling it to take the long view on investment, provide superior returns and offer stability to staff. Destroy mutuality and you destroy the essence of the company. The proposed demutualisation would be an act of corporate destruction like the asset stripping practised by corporate raiders in the US more than a decade ago.

What about the effect on consumers ?

The carpetbaggers say demutualisation would be little more than an accounting transaction. But Clerical Medical, Norwich Union, Scottish Amicable, and Scottish Widows, which have all demutualised since 1996, show this suggestion is false. Standard Life's 25-year with profits payouts are up, yet payouts on comparable policies from these companies have fallen. It cannot be in the public interest for consumers to lose better returns simply to benefit a handful of individuals and institutions that stand to make millions from speculation in second hand policies.

webTitle: The slow and steady way to build a fortune

fields.headline: The slow and steady way to build a fortune
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: You've always been told that you should never judge a book by its cover. So don't be put off by daunting title of investment trust regular savings schemes.
fields.body:
You've always been told that you should never judge a book by its cover. So don't be put off by daunting title of investment trust regular savings schemes.

Saving on a regular basis, whether in an investment trust saving scheme or a monthly Isa plan, has several advantages. First, regular savings give investors the opportunity to spread their investments. Most investment trusts hold on average 100 stocks and even a first regular contribution of £50 buys that entire spread. This avoids the high risk of investing in shares of just one or two companies.

The other benefit of saving on a regular basis is that you don't have to choose the right time to buy. Your monthly payments will smooth over any peaks and troughs in the price of the shares. If an investor wants to invest in a volatile fund or when the market is high, regular saving is best because it can drip feed the money in.

When sifting through investment trust savings schemes it's worth looking for those that have no charges whatsoever - other than the obligatory and statutory half a per cent stamp duty on purchases. Those that are otherwise free include Edinburgh Fund Managers, Fidelity, Finsbury, Friends Ivory & Sime, Pantheon and Personal Asset Trusts.

On the investment trust regular savings Isa front, only Friends Ivory & Sime and Majedie Investments have no charges. Scottish Investment Trust has no initial charge until April 5 2001 and no annual charge.

But charges are low elsewhere so investors should not be put off by having to pay a little - it will almost always be less than a stockbroker charges unless they are dealing in tens of thousands, although one disadvantage of regular savings schemes is the lack of control over when the investment will be made - not every firm gives the day of the month let alone the time of day.

Typical charges include 0.2% for Foreign & Colonial, Glasgow Investment Managers and Rothschild, 0.5% at Dresdner, 0.7% at Framlington and 1% for Fleming, Gartmore, Henderson and Templeton.

So what other features should you look for?

The minimum amount is usually £50 a month or £500 for a lump sum but Glasgow Investment Managers will accept a minimum of £20 for its regular savings scheme and Perpetual will allow £20 a month upwards into its regular savings Isa and savings scheme.

Virtually every fund comes with a dividend reinvestment plan so you don't have to bother with cheques for small amounts - this also has a compounding effect so you build up more shares over time.

Most trusts now come with a low cost selling facility as well. Some charge the same as buying although there is no stamp duty to pay on the way out. But others have a fixed fee - usually £10 - no matter what the size of the deal.

webTitle: Splitting for maximum income as funds come of age

fields.headline: Splitting for maximum income as funds come of age
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: If you want some of the benefits of stock market investment, but want to limit the downside - the kind of share plunges seen in the hi-tech sector - then a zero dividend investment trust may be the answer.
fields.body:
If you want some of the benefits of stock market investment, but want to limit the downside - the kind of share plunges seen in the hi-tech sector - then a zero dividend investment trust may be the answer.

These are shares that provide no income, but do give a low-risk opportunity for a preset amount of capital growth - in other words you know, more or less, from the outset how much you will get.

They may sound complicated, but the principle behind them is relatively simple - they are part of split-level trusts so you can invest in the same company in a number of different ways according to how much return - and the accompanying risk - you are looking for. In other words, investment is like an a la carte menu.

Zero shares have a fixed timespan - usually five to 10 years at the outset - and have a set annual growth rate which accumulates into a fixed repayment value when the trust is wound up.

There is no absolute guarantee (guarantees on investments tend to be very expensive) but as the zero shares are first in line for repayment - apart from money which the trust has borrowed - the risk is low and to date, no zero has ever failed to pay out.

Nigel Sidebottom, of financial advisers BFS Investment, says: "Zeros are something which every private investor who pays income tax and has not used their capital gains tax allowance should hold. They are much less risky than normal equity investments, and they can provide double - and if you are a higher rate tax payer - treble the returns offered by a building society."

webTitle: Put your money on a winner

fields.headline: Put your money on a winner
fields.standfirst:
Eileen Sheridan gives a guide to the form of the best-selling funds
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Picking the winners in the investment trust field can be a tricky business. Going for the big boys is no guarantee of performance, but it does provide the comfort of knowing your selection will not slip far below the average.
fields.body:
Picking the winners in the investment trust field can be a tricky business. Going for the big boys is no guarantee of performance, but it does provide the comfort of knowing your selection will not slip far below the average.

So which are the most popular trusts and what is their form?

Foreign and Colonial Valued at £3.3bn and puts it about a bit, with around 40% invested in the UK and 60% overseas. But it has slipped from its one-time permanent place in the outperformance pantheon after being too generous with Japan and neglecting US and British companies, especially UK telecoms.

The managers claim to have seen the error of their ways. F and C is now in line with the FT all-share index, which rose by 87% over the past five years.

It has gone from trading on a premium to trading on a 16% discount. In demand with private investors.

Scottish Mortgage Quite a lively little number for something with a tartan title, weighing in at £2.2bn. It invests 53% overseas, with a taste for adventure.

If you like some of your money in emerging markets and Argentinian fixed interest bonds this is the one for you. It borrows but brings home the bacon.

Witan Worth £2.1bn. A successful international generalist and popular with small investors. Has invested just under half overseas so qualifies as a Pep, and has invested heavily in telecoms.

Experts say it is underinvested in mid to small British companies. It rose by more than 100% above the FT all-share average.

Alliance Worth just under £2bn. A touch of the John Majors here - shirt tucked firmly in underpants. Conservatively run and doesn't borrow. Invests just over half in the UK - generally in old economy stocks.

Self-managed, so costs are low. Performance last year was poor but overall performance steady. Only 67% rise in the past five years.

Fleming Japanese Worth around £1bn. A cool, sexy and successful trust that bucked last year's setback in Japan.

It mostly invests in large companies which are internationally competitive but puts 15% in smaller companies. Trades at a comfortable 12% discount to net asset value. If Japan comes back into favour - which is always possible - this one will be in great demand.

City of London Bowler and brolly approach to UK investment backs this £600m trust which has suffered for ignoring the new technology companies. Its growth is up only only 51% in the past five years although the 3.3% yield is attractive. Likes to invest in solid things such as banks, retailers and engineering companies but failing to invest in telecoms probably held it back this year.

The trust is a conservative vehicle which needs to modernise and is trying hard. Trading on an 11% discount.

3i With a share price up a stunning 273% in the past five years, this £8.3bn investor in unquoted companies has fans aplenty. It focused on the UK but has now gone continental, investing 20% in Europe. Big in technology stocks.

It has a clear strategy and is tipped for share price outperformance in the medium term. Trades on a premium. A star choice.

Henderson Technology Manager Brian Ashford Russell gets a lot of exposure which won't do his trust any harm - but is it as good as his image? He doesn't dabble in dot.coms but puts money in semi-conductors, wireless communications and business infrastructure for the internet.

It has 70% in the US. Too young to have five-year form and trades on a premium. If technology had a further setback there would be a risk of share underperformance. Looks juicy but not for now.

Templeton Emerging Markets Manager Mark Mobius is another media performer - but is the trust all mouth and trousers? It is selling at a hefty 25% discount which is not encouraging.

The portfolio is well diversified, though it missed out on technology stocks and last year's performance was not great. Up 20% against an average 29%. If you like emerging markets and can wait it should improve.

Fee free if you hurry

Gartmore is offering free investment in its English & Scottish Investors fund until June 30.

Despite the name, the investment trust, set up in 1929, invests across the globe with fewer than half its assets in the UK. The minimum investment for the stamp duty-only deal is £1,000.

Details on 0800 289 336.

webTitle: Help workers stitched up by the big brands

fields.headline: Help workers stitched up by the big brands
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Campaigners for improved wages and conditions for clothing workers in developing countries are capitalising on the Euro 2000 football tournament to build awareness of these oppressed workers' plight.
fields.body:
Campaigners for improved wages and conditions for clothing workers in developing countries are capitalising on the Euro 2000 football tournament to build awareness of these oppressed workers' plight. Postcards addressed to England manager Kevin Keegan, the England team, David Davies of the Football Association and Chris Ronnie, the chief exec of sportswear brand Umbro, are being circulated by a pressure group called Labour behind the Label.

Labour behind the Label is the UK platform of the pan-European Clean Clothes Campaign, which aims to draw attention to oppressive wages and conditions that workers face in sportswear factories in the far east and central America. Workers in these sweatshops earn just £2.80 a day to stitch the shirts that sell for £45 in the UK. It would cost just 16 million euros (£9.7m) to double the salary - for a 40 hour week - of 50,000 workers in the garment industry in Indonesia. That is half of the sponsorship money negotiated with the Dutch national team in 1999 and less than 2% of Nike's entire advertising and promotion budget for 1999. www.cleanclothes.org

Employers are favouring people with internet and web programming skills over those with traditional computer skills. The latest data produced by Salary Survey Publication and Computer Weekly shows that the number of advertised old-style IT jobs fell to 32,000 in the first quarter from 59,000 in the first quarter last year (1999). But the demand for staff with Java, HTML and XML web-related skills rose to 3,600 in the first three months of the year, straining an already stretched labour market.

Stelios Haji-Ioannou, chairman of easyGroup, has won the City Business School's first Entrepreneur of the Year Award. Stelios Haji-Ioannou arrived in Britain in 1984 to study at the London School of Economics and followed his first degree with an MSc in shipping trade and finance at the school. webTitle: Going online? Send for the e-experts

fields.headline: Going online? Send for the e-experts
fields.standfirst:
You don't have to be a genius to get your dot.com idea up and running, as Sun Microsystems marketing director Louise Proddow explains
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: You don't have to be a genius to get your dot.com idea up and running, as Sun Microsystems marketing director Louise Proddow explains
fields.body:
Dotcom businesses are founded on technology but this can be the stumbling block for many entrepreneurs. Terms like html, web server, browsers or networks can be intimidating. Do not worry. Your ability to set up a dot.com business has more to do with business skills than technical expertise as long as you get the right technology team.

A new breed of managers are the leading force behind the net economy, proving that it is business acumen and not infotech know how that counts. They are commercially astute, dynamic and visionary business leaders; definitely not computer nerds. Most are new e-business managers setting up dot.com start-ups, but many in traditional businesses are re-inventing business models, turning them into successful e-commerce enterprises. Take Mike Harris , the man behind Prudential's highly successful internet bank, Egg.

These netrepreneurs are buzzing with new online business propositions. But many business managers fail to develop these initiatives because they do not know how to move forward. The challenge is turning vision into technical reality, where do you start when your contact with technology is limited to an occassional e-mail.

New e-business visionaries have to bring their idea to market faster than the competition. They have to work out how to power, budget and create the IT infrastructure to underpin their enterprise. Getting it wrong is not an option.

In today's dot.com world the whole business model is built on technology. Slow download times, inadequate security and website downtime can destroy even the best-laid business plan.

Customers expect business to be online anytime, anywhere, anyplace. Fast access and high security are the minimum starting points. To create customer loyalty you have to go beyond this with personalised content, order tracking and integration online with offline services.

However, it is not all doom and gloom for tech-challenged entrepreneurs. You do not have to do it alone. Dot.com-ing is all about finding the right partners to create the hardware, software and infotech infrastructure.

There are plenty of affordable options, Business Incubator is one programme that gives advice and access to the four companies' technology which run most of the internet - Cisco Systems, Oracle, Sun Microsystems and Exodus Communications. Successful applicants can lease a range of hardware, software and network infrastructure at £15,000 per month for three months.

You could also go to a service provider to get up and running for a couple of thousand pounds for a basic interactive site. A new breed of service providers, such as Planet Online and Exodus Communications, offer a whole host of dot.com schemes.

Or, for even less money, you can set up as part of an established online shopping mall. See it as having a shop front rather than having to build the whole outlet yourself.

For the more ambitious dot.com, consultancy is a new type of holistic practice offering advice on planning, architecture and covering every area of the internet from setting up a portal, providing e-commerce back-up and servicing the business from the major systems integrators. This is especially attractive when building a heavy, service-driven site with additional features.

PlanetOnline provides the technical support behind Freeserve, highlighting the fact that businesses recognise they get better service, support and time to market by outsourcing management of the technology that powers their e-commerce.

If you are behind one of the new hugely successful dot.com start ups, it is imperative that you have a reliable, easy to upgrade infrastructure that will let you grow with demand. By hosting with leading service providers the founders of leading sites know they can cope with surges in traffic and deliver the best performance to their customers.

Faster time to market , faster time to Initial Public Offering and lower risks. The IT industry has woken up to the need to offer advice, planning and easily implemented solutions to get dot.com ideas online.

Look for consortiums of partners who can give you access to complementary services, depth of experience and faster time to market.

 If you still need advice email me and I'll try to find a partner who can help you. Louise.proddow@uk.sun.com

webTitle: The fitness regime to knock your finances into shape

fields.headline: The fitness regime to knock your finances into shape
fields.standfirst:
TV star and financial pundit Bernice Cohen had to remortgage her house to get her early work published. Now her investment guides are massive bestsellers. Nick Pandya talked to her
Money Unlimited
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: TV star and financial pundit Bernice Cohen had to remortgage her house to get her early work published. Now her investment guides are massive bestsellers. Nick Pandya talked to her
fields.body:
Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale her infinite variety; so the Bard wrote of Cleopatra, but today his words capture the vitality of Bernice Cohen, dentist-turned-writer-turned-stock market guru.

For four years Bernice Cohen wrote a hugely popular fortnightly diary for a Sunday newspaper's financial pages, chronicling the thrills and spills of her stock market investments. Since then she has gone on to become a television personality through her two Channel 4 series, Mrs Cohen's Money.

Now she has embarked on a mission to encourage millions of Britons to boost their personal savings by launching her own website, www.mrscohen.com, and has assembled a team of experienced financial journalists to help in her crusade for fairer finance for all.

She was born 63 years ago in Hackney, east London, and went to the local state school. It took much hard work to go from the East End to King's College, London, where she got a place to study dentistry. There she met her husband, now a general practitioner; they have three sons.

Her books on finance include The Armchair Investor, still a best-selling guide to the stock market. The sequel, The Wealthy Investor, has just appeared and is walking out of the bookshops.

Its theme is that anyone aged, say, 30, on the national average salary of roughly £21,000 who decides to save £2,000 each year will have amassed a capital sum of more than £10,000 after five years which, with some judicious investment, can turn into a tasty lump sum over the next 20 years.

Her message is clear and passionate: "There is no reason why we can't all be financially fit. With a little knowledge and a willingness to take control we can enjoy more comfortable lives. If I can do it anyone can." She began writing in the early 90s, starting with The Edge of Chaos. The book has two main elements: an account of financial disasters - the South Sea Bubble in Britain, the Wall Street crash of 1929 and the global stock market crash of October 1987. The second looks at chaos theory and suggests why it might be useful in explaining the gyrations of financial markets. It attempts to fit past financial catastrophes into a chaos model.

She says: " It is always worth reading about the 18th century financial bubbles be cause they contain all the ingredients of modern money scandals - in particular, greed and gullibility."

Her interest in chaos theory and the related disciplines of systems analysis and behavioural sciences led her to write three books, The Seamless Web, The Origin of Civilisation and Global Perspectives, which set out an ambitious holistic theory of human behaviour. Just as they were about to go to press, her publisher was taken over and the new owners decided not to print. Undaunted, the Cohens remortgaged their house to fund a private publication of all three volumes. Money was tight, then the recession hit. Still unbowed, Mrs Cohen decided to sell their large family house and move to a smaller one. She then invested the proceeds in stocks and shares in an attempt to restore the money lost on the books and to allow her husband to retire two years early, as he had always envisaged.

That meant that all her investment targets were producing short-term returns. She also lacked lump-sum capital but made sweet use of this adversity, which now dictated her strategy. She was in and out of shares, trading regularly, as long-termism was not an option, and kept diversification to a minimum. Her first equity investment, made in April 1990 following a recommendation from her then broker Bar clayshare, was Polly Peck. Within months, she read a report in a Sunday paper which suggested the company was heading for trouble. She left a message on her broker's answering machine and was able to sell first thing the following Monday. She escaped with a loss of "only" 25%; many Polly Peck investors lost everything.

This bitter experience taught her to do her own research, rather than rely on so-called experts.

She uses the FT to revalue her portfolio once a week and update her charts, which are the key to playing the market. "People who say charts are voodoo are denying themselves a very powerful intelligence gathering tool to help them in their investment analysis" she says. Her current portfolio is said to include, Vodafone, Logica, BP Amoco and Autonomy.

Now, as a sprightly sixtysomething, whatever she does next, like Shakespeare's Cleopatra, she is unlikely to let either wealth or conventional wisdom get in her way.

fields.headline: Putting faith in a sector
fields.standfirst:
You can distill big rewards from the right fund at the right time, says Brian Zlotnick. But beware, they can also be extremely volatile
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: You can distill big rewards from the right fund at the right time, says Brian Zlotnick. But beware, they can also be extremely volatile
fields.body:
People looking to add a little more excitement to their lives through investing in the stock market should consider putting some of their money into sector or theme investment trusts, rather than just general funds.

Individual sectors, such as technology or pharmaceuticals, tend to be much more volatile than the stock market as a whole, with the result that the value of a single-sector investment trust can rise or fall much more sharply than a general investment trust.

These sector funds are not suited to anyone who does not want the pressure of choosing the right sector, let alone the right fund. The steep slide in the share prices of many technology stocks, albeit after an incredible boom, underlines the danger of having too much exposure to a particular sector, or buying at the wrong time.

There are nearly 30 investment trust companies, covering the technology, pharmaceutical, biotechnology, utility, financial, tea plantation, brewery, property, media and mining sectors, as well as some lifestyle funds, the majority of which are members of the Association of Investment Trust Companies.

In some sectors, notably the hi-tech field, there are several investment trusts, run by different fund management firms. In others, such as breweries and mining, investors can put their money into only one fund.

Most sector funds have a decided international bias, with less than 80% of their assets invested in any one geographical area. Some, particularly the international technology funds, do have considerably more than half of their money invested in a single country, the US. For example, Henderson Technology has around 70% of its funds invested in US stocks.

The sparkling performance by the technology sector over the past few years led to a spate of tech trust launches in the first few months of this year. Many have continued to trade at a premium, despite the sharp downturn in the sector's fortunes.

Share prices of several trusts, particularly in the technology and media sectors, have swung wildly over the past year, highlighting the hazards inherent in single-sector funds.

Among the more volatile have been Finsbury Technology, which soared from a low of 149p to a high of 732p and is presently 492.5p, Finsbury Life Sciences, which rose more than five-fold from a low of 53.5p to 275p and now trades at 160.5p, andRadiotrust, which has touched a low of 147.5p and a high of 363.5p and now stands at 277.5p.

But other sector funds, such as Taverners, the brewery investment trust, trade in a narrow band. Taverners has stayed between 81.5p and 101.5p over the past year.

Statistics from the Association of Investment Trust Companies show that investors can reap tremendous rewards from picking the right sector and fund. The share price total return on £100 invested in Henderson Technology over one- and three-year periods to the end of May is £264.4 and £445.5 respectively. Similar returns were achieved by Finsbury Technology.

Experts always advise investors to resist temptation and put no more than 5% to 10% of their assets in a more speculative sector fund.

Sector investment trusts are a particularly good vehicle for an investor with limited funds who is prepared to take on board greater risk in pursuit of higher returns. Without a trust, the average investor would have insufficient capital to invest in enough stocks to obtain balanced exposure to a sector.

In some sectors, such as biotechnology, investors who do not have a good spread of equities can easily burn their fingers. The share prices of individual companies can be extremely volatile, collapsing or surging overnight in response to developments.

webTitle: Why you want to take the money and run

fields.headline: Why you want to take the money and run
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Last week Jobs & Money asked readers to email us with their verdict on Standard Life: will you vote for or against demutualisation? The results reveal that even though Guardian readers strongly support mutuality, anger over endowment shortfalls, ballot papers and inadequate windfall calculations is making people vote with their pocket rather than their heart.
fields.body:
Last week Jobs & Money asked readers to email us with their verdict on Standard Life: will you vote for or against demutualisation? The results reveal that even though Guardian readers strongly support mutuality, anger over endowment shortfalls, ballot papers and inadequate windfall calculations is making people vote with their pocket rather than their heart. Here are some of your responses:

Martin Davies: "I will be voting to take the money... I don't feel particularly proud as it smacks of selfish self-interest from one who wholeheartedly supports the idea of mutual status. However, Standard Life may well fail to deliver the promised goods in not only mine but many more cases of mortgage shortfall.

"I have part of my mortgage with Standard Life and have already obtained a reprojection of whether it will meet its expected amount - no surprises it won't!

"In my circle of friends I have two others with Standard Life mortgages and the results are similar. I am married with two children and the thought of shortfalls fills us with dread. I will be voting to take the money and invest it myself to hopefully make up the necessary money to pay the mortgage off."

Mr & Mrs Brealey: "We rang Standard Life recently to ask when we would receive an update on the progress of our endowment policy, to be told August, but they would send one within a few days if we so wished. On receiving the update, we were horrified to read that "there is now a high risk that your plan may not pay out the target amount". Other policyholders may wish to take advantage of the time available before the vote to obtain an update on the progress of their endowment plans."

Richard Cranfield: "I have already voted with the carpetbaggers for the following reasons. I think the board doth protest too much and I felt I was being bullied to side with them. As I understand it, the return on my existing policy will not be affected by the change and I have no intention of taking out a new policy. The windfall will therefore be a bonus to me and I have nothing to lose.

"My experience of Standard Life has been inflexibility to the point of unhelpfulness. I am aware times have changed but they so thoroughly alienated me that even though I can see their side of the argument, I have no faith in the present organisation and will gladly take the money."

Richard Capewell: "I am extremely angry at the behaviour of Standard Life. The glossy booklet sent to all members contained seven pages ar guing against demutualisation while allowing only one page to put the arguments in favour.

"The information about potential windfalls has been partial and misleading. I was informed that my policy might yield a windfall of £6-£10,000 based on a company valuation of £12bn. I was given no information about the basis of such an estimate.

"I phoned to query the basis. I was told this time that I might receive £6-10,000 based on a valuation of £12bn, or £10-15,000 based on a £15bn valuation. I have subsequently discovered that many analysts value the company at £16-18bn, which might yield me over £20,000. Quite a difference from the £6,000 first proferred by Standard Life. Unintended inefficiency or deliberately misleading?"

Berwyn Jones: "I have voted, with great sadness, for demutualisation. I do not want to see it happen, because I firmly believe in mutuality, but I fear that it seems inevitable, if not now then in the near future. Since my policy matures in two years' time, I would lose out if it were delayed.

"How much more sensible if the proceeds from demutualisation had to be shared out among not only current but also past members whose connection with the company had ceased within, say, 10 years. After all, these are the people whose investments had contributed to the fortunes of the company over recent decades."

Dave Clark: "I am being asked whether I want to benefit from the resources of Standard Life until my policy matures or benefit from them in perpetuity. Not too difficult."

Other readers are angry that they have been excluded from the ballot. Don Keller of Haringey, London, found that, though a member since 1988, he has lost a vote because of rule changes made in a 1991 Act of Parliament.

David Rees of Swansea, was also caught out by the 1991 rule change - even though he has been with Standard Life since 1994. His policy matured in November 1999, and shortly before he took out another policy to ensure continuity of membership. But the 1991 rules require that the policy ran through the three-month period before November 15 to ensure a vote and a windfall - conditions which his policy does not meet.

Gerald Marshall, a Glasgow City Council employee, has an in-house and AVC pension with Standard Life, but was not sent a ballot paper. Standard Life told him he is excluded from the ballot because the trustees of his scheme have the vote, and will reinvest any windfall into his policy.

The windfall will therefore be a bonus to me and I have nothing to lose. "My experience of Standard Life has been inflexibility to the point of unhelpfulness. I am aware times have changed but they so thoroughly alienated me that even though I can see their side of the argument, I have no faith in the present organisation and will gladly take the money." Richard Capewell: "I am extremely angry at the behaviour of Standard Life. The glossy booklet sent to all members contained seven pages ar guing against demutualisation while allowing only one page to put the arguments in favour. "The information about potential windfalls has been partial and misleading. I was informed that my policy might yield a windfall of £6-£10,000 based on a company valuation of £12bn. I was given no information about the basis of such an estimate. "I phoned to query the basis. I was told this time that I might receive £6-10,000 based on a valuation of £12bn, or £10-15,000 based on a £15bn valuation. I have subsequently discovered that many analysts value the company at £16-18bn, which might yield me over £20,000. Quite a difference from the £6,000 first proferred by Standard Life. Unintended inefficiency or deliberately misleading?" Berwyn Jones: "I have voted, with great sadness, for demutualisation. I do not want to see it happen, because I firmly believe in mutuality, but I fear that it seems inevitable, if not now then in the near future. Since my policy matures in two years' time, I would lose out if it were delayed. "How much more sensible if the proceeds from demutualisation had to be shared out among not only current but also past members whose connection with the company had ceased within, say, 10 years. After all, these are the people whose investments had contributed to the fortunes of the company over recent decades." Dave Clark: "I am being asked whether I want to benefit from the resources of Standard Life until my policy matures or benefit from them in perpetuity. Not too difficult." Other readers are angry that they have been excluded from the ballot. Don Keller of Haringey, London, found that, though a member since 1988, he has lost a vote because of rule changes made in a 1991 Act of Parliament. David Rees of Swansea, was also caught out by the 1991 rule change - even though he has been with Standard Life since 1994. His policy matured in November 1999, and shortly before he took out another policy to ensure continuity of membership. But the 1991 rules require that the policy ran through the three-month period before November 15 to ensure a vote and a windfall - conditions which his policy does not meet. Gerald Marshall, a Glasgow City Council employee, has an in-house and AVC pension with Standard Life, but was not sent a ballot paper. Standard Life told him he is excluded from the ballot because the trustees of his scheme have the vote, and will reinvest any windfall into his policy.

fields.headline: On track for the 21st century
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: If the trusts get it right, they could enter the 21st century rejuvenated and ready to take on rivals in the packaged investment product market. And that would enrich today's typical trust investor.
fields.body:
Investment trusts are at a crossroads. Turn one direction and the mid-19th century invention of a limited company whose sole purpose is to use its share capital to invest in the assets of other companies will follow other Victorian inventions such as the telegraph and the third-class railway carriage into the museum.

And that will not benefit existing investors.

But if the trusts get it right, they could enter the 21st century rejuvenated and ready to take on rivals in the packaged investment product market. And that would enrich today's typical trust investor. Which way the trusts go pivots on the success or otherwise of the "its" campaign - the major move by the Association of Investment Trust Companies to spread the message beyond the narrow band of existing aficionados.

"Its" has been personified for the general public by moody TV adverts backed by cult Italian crooner Paolo Conte. But the real embodiment of "its" is AITC director general Daniel Godfrey. If the campaign succeeds, he will join the tiny pantheon of investment trust heroes, and no doubt collect big bonus packages.

Failure would mean his head on the block - and the probable end of the low-cost investment schemes. "Its" is spending around £17m this year and is budgeted to lay out a further £17m over the next two years. This is equal to 5p for every £100 of investment trust assets. Research shows that 35% of people now know the "its" logo - a necessary first step to spreading the investment trust message.

Just a few months into the campaign, which began last September, a Sunday newspaper wrote the whole thing off as an expensive flop. But Mr Godfrey reckons that judgment was premature.

"Rome wasn't built in a day nor can you both build a brand and create a new asset class for private investors in weeks," he says. "So far, the proof that we are getting somewhere is that in the first quarter of this year, our Isa sales were 90% higher than in the last Pep season 12 months before. The move to Isas obviously helped because it widened the variety of trusts that could be offered in a tax-free wrapper, but even allowing for that and a buoyant stock market, the figures are well ahead of expectations."

Investment trust managers stress three main points:

Costs These are far lower than rival unit trusts, for which the expenses of running a large diversified fund are up to five times greater. Assuming both vehicles invest in the same portfolio, the investment trust purchaser will get around 10% more after 10 years than the unit trust buyer although the risk will be the same. Trusts do not pay brokers commission although advisers who sell trusts are allowed to bill customers for their services.

Long term Many of the biggest investment trusts hold widely diversified portfolios which the managers adjust over time, whereas most unit trusts are more narrowly defined so investors themselves have to decide where to put their money - with each switch costing up to 6% of their capital.

Gearing Investment trusts can borrow so they can take advantage of the good times with a loan to buy more shares, and they trim their sails in times of trouble.

But Mr Godfrey concedes that, like other investment vehicles, the trusts have drawbacks. "Everyone stresses the bumpy ride from the discount - that's the gap between the share price and the underlying value of the portfolio. It's true that movements up and down in the discount can exaggerate gains and falls in the trusts. And that can matter if you are buying and selling on a regular basis. But over the long term the effect of the discount becomes muted."

Get your guide to private investment

Stockbroker Goy Cartwright Harris is to publish a new Private Investor Guide to help savers who want to know more about specialist sectors. Investment trust expert David Goy admits these can be complex and daunting.

The 100-plus pages list all the trusts in their sectors along with their portfolio preferences, past performance, savings schemes, trust-linked pension plans, and details of major changes over the past year, including takeovers and new trust launches.

The firm, which has a special investment trust management service for those with at least £50,000, reckons most trust buyers forget about risk profiles when investing, and overlook how low management fees are on the long established trusts.

The Private Investor Guide will be available from early next month on 0115 204 5500 at £15.

webTitle: Bust your way through the jargon

fields.headline: Bust your way through the jargon
fields.standfirst:
Follow Joanne Gill through the alphabet
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Follow Joanne Gill through the alphabet
fields.body:
Association of Investment Trust Companies (AITC) The trade body for the investment trust community

Bid price The price you get when you sell shares

Board of directors Appointed to oversee the trust and look after shareholders. Should include independent members

Bonus issue When an investment trust dilutes its share price by giving investors free shares according to the number they already own

B shares No dividend is paid on B shares, instead extra shares are given based on the income paid and price of ordinary shares

Capital shares Shares that receive little or no income during the life of a split capital trust but benefit from the capital appreciation of the portfolio

C shares, or conversion shares Used to raise extra funds for a trust

Diluted net asset value Based on outstanding convertible loan stocks, warrants or options being converted into ordinary shares, thereby increasing the number of shares in issue

Discount When the share price is lower than its net asset value

Exercise price Price a warrant holder pays for converting into shares

Financial services authority Regulates the selling and running of trusts

Gearing Borrowing to make additional investments in the hope these will provide a profit after servicing the borrowing

Hedging Altering currency exposure to reduce the effect of exchange rate fluctuations

Investment restriction Limits on the amount a trust can invest in any one scheme, usually detailed in its rule book

Investment trust A public company that uses the funds provided by its shareholders to invest in other companies

Junk bond A higher risk loan stock

Key features document Sets out charges and investment strategy of investment trust-based Isas

Liquidation When a trust is wound up, creditors are repaid and shareholders receive any surplus according to their class of share

Market capitalisation The value of a trust, calculated by multiplying the number of shares by the share price

Net asset value The underlying worth of a trust per share, usually greater than the share price

Net asset value total return The return on funds per share, assuming net dividends are reinvested in line with the net asset value

Offer The price at which you buy trust shares

Ordinary shares Used in split-level trusts to designate the riskier shares which reflect underlying capital gains

Overweight/underweight holding Higher or lower percentage in a share, sector or market than its ratio in an index

Premium When the individual share price is higher than its net asset value

Quoted investments Have an official listing on a stock markets

Rights issue Raising extra capital by offering existing shareholders extra shares at a preferential rate

Self-managed Trust whose assets are managed by its own team rather than by an outside management company

Split capital trust A limited life vehicle whose capital is divided into various classes of income and capital shares

S shares A variation on C shares which never convert to shares in the main trust, instead remaining effectively part of a different company

Total return Overall return on a trust once the net dividends have been reinvested. These figures allow investors to compare different trusts' performance

Unfranked income Dividends not subject to a prior tax deduction

Venture capital trusts Specialise in high- risk investments in small and young companies, while offering income and capital gains tax advantages

Winding up Closing the trust by selling assets and paying off creditors and shareholders

Xd or ex dividend The day the buyer of a share is no longer entitled to the declared dividend payment

Yield Percentage income in relation to price paid

Zero dividend Preference shares with no right to income. Instead the shareholder is paid a fixed sum on winding up

fields.headline: Virgin profits halved
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson, owner of Virgin Atlantic, yesterday forecast a 50% drop in profits in his airline because of higher aircraft fuel prices.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson, owner of Virgin Atlantic, yesterday forecast a 50% drop in profits in his airline because of higher aircraft fuel prices.

This year's profits will be down from £120m to around £60m, but Sir Richard was confident that profits would bounce back again by next year. "I hope we'll be back up at the previous levels by then," he said.

Apart from escalating fuel charges that have affected all airlines, Virgin acknowledged a decline in north American traffic during last summer. But, he said, it picked up considerably during the autumn and winter.

This is the first time for four years that Virgin has experienced a drop in profits. For the previous three years, they had increased each year from £70m to more than £100m.

Virgin's hole in its profits looks large but compared to the problems of its close rival, British Airways, which effectively lost around £250m last year, Sir Richard's airline is performing well. Indeed, the company insisted that the airline is doing more than enough to hold its own.

Sir Richard also made it clear that he would be meeting BA's chief executive, Rod Eddington, for a friendly chat next week. "In order to have a more gentlemanly relationship than we've had with previous incumbents, we are going to meet and hopefully have a nice drink together," he said.

One of the subjects is likely to be BA's proposed merger with the Dutch carrier, KLM. Sir Richard said that Virgin would have to consider new alliances if the merger went ahead. The issue is fraught with regulatory problems, particularly the Dutch government's attitude towards its national carrier being taken over by a foreign airline.

The main sticking point is that the world's current aviation system allocates flight rights by nationality - so if KLM were to become British, it could not use Dutch rights to fly to third countries.

The United States and the Netherlands have a treaty, for example, that creates a right for US and Dutch airlines to fly between those countries. An "ownership and control" clause in the treaty excludes airlines from other countries.

Under the structure being discussed, KLM would remain intact and become a subsidiary of British Airways, which in order to comply with international aviation regulations would own only 49% of the voting shares in the Dutch company.

"British Airways would have a 100% economic interest in a subsidiary that is KLM, which will have some ingenious bits and pieces in the way it is structured to satisfy Dutch corporate governance rules and the aero-political implications of foreign ownership," said one source close to the deal.

The remaining 51% of KLM would be owned by Dutch investors, with financial institutions brought in as "friendly" shareholders. These investors would hold an "A" share equivalent, with no real economic value, while British Airways would also own a "B" share which would have no nominal value or voting rights but would capture perhaps 99% of the economic interest.

United Airlines said earlier this week that the United States might waive any objection to KLM ceasing to be Dutch but only if Britain agreed to open up the British transatlantic aviation market.

 The airline formerly known as ValuJet is in the early stages of merger talks with US carrier Trans World Airlines. Last month it was announced that United Airlines would buy US Airways Group for $4.3bn (£2.6bn).

fields.headline: The netiquette of cyber-spin
fields.standfirst:
As the revolution in e-commerce gathers pace, employment patterns are in a constant state of upheaval. Liz Stuart weighs the impact on the fragile world of PR
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: As the revolution in e-commerce gathers pace, employment patterns are in a constant state of upheaval. Liz Stuart weighs the impact on the fragile world of PR
fields.body:
The aftershocks of the e-explosion are causing waves throughout the employment market and one of the biggest areas to be rocked is public relations.

Not only has the proliferation of dot.com start-ups created more clients, the virtual nature of the product means that communicating the corporate message is absolutely key.

In other words, websites stand or fall in the first instance not by their contents and service levels, but by how many people actually know they exist.

Narda Shirley set up Gnash, a London PR consultancy specialising in the internet, in February 1997. It became what she terms "an accidental company" and now employs 21 people. "Since the start of this year we have had 124 new business inquiries. Normally in PR there would be a balance between companies contacting you and asking to talk and leads bought in by a new business person. I have never known anything like it," she says.

"PR used to be an afterthought, but with the speed that dot.coms are coming to market, the founders are looking for (PR) agencies even before funding deals have been signed."

The Institute of Public Relations is so conscious of the systemic changes the internet is bringing about in the industry, that it has recently commissioned and published a report on the issue. The Death of Spin says the web is forcing enormous change on both large and small corporations, with the result that they are much more transparent. Spinning - that is, manipulating the message and the audience - will no longer be so possible, because the general public can access source material so much more easily.

The report concludes that the PR professional will no longer be the gatekeeper or guardian of the information, but will instead work much more stategically with the core players in the business, advising on compliance and best practice within the organisation.

This can only be a positive for both the punter and the industry - PR could do with an image overhaul itself, dogged as its reputation is by the extreme cliches of the airhead Ab-fabs on the one hand and the Machiavellian political aide on the other.

Controlling a client's image on-line is the other strand of new work the internet has created. Internet sin-bins can be started by anyone - recent targets include Chase Manhattan Bank, Monsanto and America Online - and chatroom comments, whether or not they have any validity, are often picked up and repeated in the media as gospel.

Kate Nicholas, editor of PR Week - the industry's trade magazine - says the net boom is especially good news for graduates. "E-commerce is presenting a lot of new jobs at entry level. Agencies want to take on people with technical knowledge of the internet and how chatrooms and bulletin boards work.

Hackers are able to put electronic Post-it notes on websites containing damaging messages - again you need someone with technical know-how to deal with that.

Clients are also increasingly assigning a larger portion of their marketing budget to PR. Typically, public and media relations would get just 5% of the amount a company would spend on communicating a message but, according to Narda Shirley, dot.coms are giving PR agencies between 30-40% of the total.

But then, as she says, in the internet arena the lines between PR, advertising and marketing, always blurred, are becoming invisible. "Viral tactics" is the faintly unsavory name given to a method of on-line campaigning - the agency walks into chat rooms and tells people about a new product, giving interlocuters the client's website link for easy access - a technique which a marketing or advertising agency might use.

Gnash is currently running a campaign for one of its clients, the new music website Peoplesound.com, promoting the work of one of its new artists, Helicopter Girl. The campaign involves going into chatrooms and leaving messages exhorting chatters to log on to Peoplesound and listen to her latest recording. The account manager at Gnash denies that this kind of approach could be misleading. "There is a certain amount of 'netiquette' - we would go in to the chatroom as an agency and not as a member of the public."

Methods of payment are being revolutionised by the net. Start-ups often pay part fee, part equity. "While graduates coming into the industry are not likely to see any of that straightaway, they will be accessing it at a later stages," says Ms Nicholas.

But Alistair McLeish, chief executive of MMD, a group of Europe-wide IT and telecoms PR consultancies, says that although the nature of the client is changing, the fundamental work of the PR industry has not. "I think that because we work with companies which are incredibly fast-paced we sometimes get caught up in our own rhetoric. But our work is still about influencing opinion formers and getting the same messages into the media. We are still looking for the same sort of people we have always looked for: good communicators, both verbal and written, good at handling people, flexible, willing to travel and very committed."

Ms Nicholas agrees that the the opportunities for younger people is not mar ginalising more experienced PR executives. "Reputational management is increasingly a board-level issue and this is where more experienced professionals come in. You could not have a graduate sitting down with the chief executive telling them they cannot open a factory in a certain area because it would turn the tide of public opinon against them."

To do this, agencies need people who understand how companies and industry work. So there are more opportunities for people coming from pharmaceuticals, telecom companies and the City. As pressure and consumer groups become more powerful, there may be potentially explosive situations where chief executives will be sitting down with Greenpeace, and these require senior, experienced PR people to interface. That does not mean that the senior public relations staff can afford to ignore the internet, just that their skills are not eclipsed by it. The internet's internationalism also puts PR professionals with language skills at a premium.

The other area which PR's increasingly strategic positioning is taking the profession towards is market research. Many PR agencies are setting up their own in-house consultancies just as 10 years ago advertising agencies were establishing direct marketing arms within their own premises. For this reason people with social science backgrounds are particularly in demand.

Salaries in PR do not match the astronomical sums paid to e-gurus. According to PR Week, the average for an agency account executive (average age 26) is £19,900 and a board director (average age 35) is £47,800. Comparable salaries in-house - based in a company's press office rather than at an agency - are £20,900 for a PR officer and £39,300 for a PR director. In-house PRs tend to be older than their agency equivalents because graduates are attracted to the more structured training schemes offered by the consultancies. But as demand grows salaries should start creeping up too, - especially once those share options start to mature.

 Martin Raymond, who is the current PR Week PR professional of the year, works in an area about as far removed from cyber-hype as possible. He is in-house head of public affairs at the Health Education Board of Scotland.

The vast bulk of his work involves talking to the media to raise awareness of vital health issues such as smoking, healthy eating, exercise, alcohol abuse and sex education.

"Scotland has been at the bot tom of the league in lots of health issues, but things are improving," he spins.

He says that one of the hardest aspects of working in the public sector is the culture clash between PR and the health service. "In the recent past communications has been seriously undervalued. The health service has a history of slow decision making with lots of consultation and this makes it difficult for people working in PR where you have to have very clear vision and it's often better to make a wrong decision than to make no decision at all."

But he also says that the resulting friction can be creative and the organisation can often learn from working with the PR team.

Raymond's background is in the health service itself- this is typical for public sector PRs. "People do come into public sector PR from consultancies, but if you have a deep understanding of what is going on in an organisation you can often react more quickly to a situation.

"In the private sector knowledge is more easily transferrable. Businesses tend to have shared objectives, whatever the business is. But the pubic sector is more diverse and so the more intimately you know it, the better," he says.
