Spinning - that is, manipulating the message and the audience - will no longer be so possible, because the general public can access source material so much more easily. The report concludes that the PR professional will no longer be the gatekeeper or guardian of the information, but will instead work much more stategically with the core players in the business, advising on compliance and best practice within the organisation. This can only be a positive for both the punter and the industry - PR could do with an image overhaul itself, dogged as its reputation is by the extreme cliches of the airhead Ab-fabs on the one hand and the Machiavellian political aide on the other. Controlling a client's image on-line is the other strand of new work the internet has created. Internet sin-bins can be started by anyone - recent targets include Chase Manhattan Bank, Monsanto and America Online - and chatroom comments, whether or not they have any validity, are often picked up and repeated in the media as gospel. Kate Nicholas, editor of PR Week - the industry's trade magazine - says the net boom is especially good news for graduates. "E-commerce is presenting a lot of new jobs at entry level. Agencies want to take on people with technical knowledge of the internet and how chatrooms and bulletin boards work. Hackers are able to put electronic Post-it notes on websites containing damaging messages - again you need someone with technical know-how to deal with that. Clients are also increasingly assigning a larger portion of their marketing budget to PR. Typically, public and media relations would get just 5% of the amount a company would spend on communicating a message but, according to Narda Shirley, dot.coms are giving PR agencies between 30-40% of the total. But then, as she says, in the internet arena the lines between PR, advertising and marketing, always blurred, are becoming invisible. "Viral tactics" is the faintly unsavory name given to a method of on-line campaigning - the agency walks into chat rooms and tells people about a new product, giving interlocuters the client's website link for easy access - a technique which a marketing or advertising agency might use. Gnash is currently running a campaign for one of its clients, the new music website Peoplesound.com, promoting the work of one of its new artists, Helicopter Girl. The campaign involves going into chatrooms and leaving messages exhorting chatters to log on to Peoplesound and listen to her latest recording. The account manager at Gnash denies that this kind of approach could be misleading. "There is a certain amount of 'netiquette' - we would go in to the chatroom as an agency and not as a member of the public." Methods of payment are being revolutionised by the net. Start-ups often pay part fee, part equity. "While graduates coming into the industry are not likely to see any of that straightaway, they will be accessing it at a later stages," says Ms Nicholas. But Alistair McLeish, chief executive of MMD, a group of Europe-wide IT and telecoms PR consultancies, says that although the nature of the client is changing, the fundamental work of the PR industry has not. "I think that because we work with companies which are incredibly fast-paced we sometimes get caught up in our own rhetoric. But our work is still about influencing opinion formers and getting the same messages into the media. We are still looking for the same sort of people we have always looked for: good communicators, both verbal and written, good at handling people, flexible, willing to travel and very committed." Ms Nicholas agrees that the the opportunities for younger people is not mar ginalising more experienced PR executives. "Reputational management is increasingly a board-level issue and this is where more experienced professionals come in. You could not have a graduate sitting down with the chief executive telling them they cannot open a factory in a certain area because it would turn the tide of public opinon against them." To do this, agencies need people who understand how companies and industry work. So there are more opportunities for people coming from pharmaceuticals, telecom companies and the City. As pressure and consumer groups become more powerful, there may be potentially explosive situations where chief executives will be sitting down with Greenpeace, and these require senior, experienced PR people to interface. That does not mean that the senior public relations staff can afford to ignore the internet, just that their skills are not eclipsed by it. The internet's internationalism also puts PR professionals with language skills at a premium. The other area which PR's increasingly strategic positioning is taking the profession towards is market research. Many PR agencies are setting up their own in-house consultancies just as 10 years ago advertising agencies were establishing direct marketing arms within their own premises. For this reason people with social science backgrounds are particularly in demand. Salaries in PR do not match the astronomical sums paid to e-gurus. According to PR Week, the average for an agency account executive (average age 26) is £19,900 and a board director (average age 35) is £47,800. Comparable salaries in-house - based in a company's press office rather than at an agency - are £20,900 for a PR officer and £39,300 for a PR director. In-house PRs tend to be older than their agency equivalents because graduates are attracted to the more structured training schemes offered by the consultancies. But as demand grows salaries should start creeping up too, - especially once those share options start to mature.  Martin Raymond, who is the current PR Week PR professional of the year, works in an area about as far removed from cyber-hype as possible. He is in-house head of public affairs at the Health Education Board of Scotland. The vast bulk of his work involves talking to the media to raise awareness of vital health issues such as smoking, healthy eating, exercise, alcohol abuse and sex education. "Scotland has been at the bot tom of the league in lots of health issues, but things are improving," he spins. He says that one of the hardest aspects of working in the public sector is the culture clash between PR and the health service. "In the recent past communications has been seriously undervalued. The health service has a history of slow decision making with lots of consultation and this makes it difficult for people working in PR where you have to have very clear vision and it's often better to make a wrong decision than to make no decision at all." But he also says that the resulting friction can be creative and the organisation can often learn from working with the PR team. Raymond's background is in the health service itself- this is typical for public sector PRs. "People do come into public sector PR from consultancies, but if you have a deep understanding of what is going on in an organisation you can often react more quickly to a situation. "In the private sector knowledge is more easily transferrable. Businesses tend to have shared objectives, whatever the business is. But the pubic sector is more diverse and so the more intimately you know it, the better," he says.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The sacking of Durk Jager, ceo of Procter & Gamble, after just 17 months at the top shows how far the world has changed. Not long ago, top management was largely immune from the effects of failure; workers and line management paid the price.
fields.body:
The sacking of Durk Jager, ceo of Procter & Gamble, after just 17 months at the top shows how far the world has changed. Not long ago, top management was largely immune from the effects of failure; workers and line management paid the price.

This harsher attitude is not confined to the USA, where the heads of Coca Cola, Xerox and Campbell Soup have recently suffered the same fate. British Airways and Sainsburys have waved goodbye to top managers. No one expects the new teams at Marks and Spencer or Barclays to have more than a few months to perform - or perish.

The new climate reflects the way change affects giant corporations. Their great bureaucracies were valuable while change was gradual. The same structures are liabilities when innovation and risk taking determine success. These problems are vividly described by Ghoshal, Bartlett and Moran in the Sloan Management Review.

They criticise managers who respond to adversity by slashing and burning. Ghoshal and his collaborators call for a more creative response based on purpose, process and people. This means understanding the fundamentals of the organisation and embedding this knowledge in the ways the business operates through its people.

There is widespread cynicism about managers who talk about the importance of people while destroying lives and roles. There is the story of the local authority leader who, just after he took over, asked a packed meeting of his staff: "Who remembers the 60s?" When hands went up he went on: "Well, you are now part of the past." But this attitude does not stop him talking about the value of being people oriented.

True, people-based business are built on two assumptions: that people have brains and will use them to back people they trust and reject those they do not. In the Harvard Business Review Christensen and Overdorf show that the capabilities of people and the way they are shaped within the enterprise define what the company can and cannot do. The task of management is to understand, build on and release these capabilities.

Not long ago the best way to release this potential was through the large-scale mobilisation of labour; the trick now is to achieve the highly focused mobilisation of talent. Authority systems are less important than partnering systems.

The aim is to build a climate of mutual respect. Smart managers know they are constantly being scrutinised for their attitudes, skills and competences and people respond accordingly. Sir Ronnie Flanagan, Chief Constable of the RUC, summarised this recently when he said: "We must never forget that every contact leaves an impression."

The challenge of managing in this environment is beyond the capabilities of many who developed in traditional ways. Often the only solution is find ways to break the business into smaller and smaller enterprises. There is little doubt that if Microsoft is broken up, the Little Bills will be even more dynamic than the parent company. A century ago, John D Rockefeller ended up even richer when Standard Oil was broken up.

The new units open up internal markets for talent and ideas, while making the businesses more dynamic, exciting and fun for employees, suppliers, customers, even investors. The results are more substantial than the energy-sapping, cost-cutting responses that are popular with corporate bureaucrats, who do not realise that they merely hasten their own departure.

 Tom Cannon is chief executive of the Management and Enterprise National Training Organisation.

webTitle: Beware extra costs of new Isa wrappers

fields.headline: Beware extra costs of new Isa wrappers
fields.standfirst:
Fees levied by fund management houses mean that they sometimes offer poor deals, says Ian Wylie
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Fees levied by fund management houses mean that they sometimes offer poor deals.
fields.body:
The investment trusts failed to capture the imagination of personal equity plan investors, never accounting for more than 10% of new Pep business.

But there are signs that investment trusts are capturing a much larger slice of Isa sales.

Under the Isa rules, many more investment trusts are eligible to be included within an Isa wrapper than were allowed within a Pep.

Under the Pep rules only 25% of a Pep portfolio could be invested in markets outside Europe and the UK. Isas, on the other hand, can be invested in any internationally recognised stock exchange. And it is here that the majority of trusts invest.

There are two ways to shelter investment trusts within an Isa. If you only want to invest in the trusts offered by one management group, look at the Isa wrappers offered by the various investment trust houses. Virtually all investment trust groups offer their own Isas.

With the majority of unit trust and Oeic savings schemes there is no extra charge for the Isa wrapper. Investment trusts, however, often make a small extra charge for the Isa package. Foreign & Colonial, for example, has a £50 initial and £60 annual charge, plus 0.2% dealing costs.

Investment trust management charges are lower than those levied on unit trusts and Oeics, so most investment trust Isas remain competitively priced despite fees.

Charges vary, but houses levy an initial charge, usually about 1% of the total investment as well as an annual administration charge. These charges vary and will either be a fixed fee, say £30 or more, or percentage based, perhaps 0.5% a year. If you intend to bundle together several Isas with the same manager, those charging a fixed fee will prove more cost effective over the long term.

Nevertheless, investment trust aficionados need to be sure that any extra charge for an Isa wrapper does not wipe out all the tax benefits.

For example, last year the financial adviser BEST Investment analysed the effect of charges on yields from investment trust Isas compared to their unit trust equivalents based on the average charges of each product.

According to the study, the costs of investment trust Isas knocks, on average, 2.4% off your income. By contrast, the reduction in yield for unit trust or Oeic Isas was just 2.07%. But individual trusts may fare better.

One of the most competi tively priced Isas is available through Alliance Trust, an independently managed international generalist trust based in Dundee. Its Isa charges no annual administration fee, although it does levy minimal charges for investments and the reinvestment of dividends.

Unlike most other Isas, the Alliance Isa also allows investors to buy other investment trusts as well as bonds, gilts and many UK equities.

Another option is to choose a self-select Isa, which permits investment into equities as well as UK-listed investment trusts. Remember that all charges on investment trust Isas are in addition to underlying fund management charges of each trust.

 Unit trusts can invest in a portfolio of investment trusts to give a unique hybrid package.

Funds of investment trusts come into their own because managers can use trading skills to make the most of rising and falling discounts and underlying asset values.

Managers with unit trusts that invest in investment trust shares include Quilter & Co, Aberdeen Asset Management, Equitable Life, Exeter Fund Managers and Jupiter. They can also use their institutional clout to influence investment trust managers so their unitholders benefit.

webTitle: The ideal fund is a click away

fields.headline: The ideal fund is a click away
fields.standfirst:
Online resources can tailor your portfolio, says Jessica McCallin
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Buying an investment trust online is pretty much like buying any financial product on the net. In theory, it's easy. In practice you have to be careful. But don't let this deter you.
fields.body:
Buying an investment trust online is pretty much like buying any financial product on the net. In theory, it's easy. You fill in the application form and then either print, sign and send it or wait for it to be sent back to you for a signature.

In practice you have to be careful - one click on the wrong box and you could send your savings heading in the wrong direction. But don't let this deter you.

Whether you decide to buy through a fund manager savings scheme or through an online stockbroker, the process should be fairly straightforward if you look before you click.

Buying through a fund manager involves deciding which fund you want and contacting the manager via the internet.

This could entail sending an email requesting an application form or filling in and submitting the application form online.

Either way, the fund manager will need your signature, so even if you fill in and submit the form over the internet you will still have to wait for the forms to be sent to you to be signed and returned before your investment can be set up.

To make sure you're dealing with the right fund manager, get help from a financial adviser, read the financial press or study the manager's own literature.

And, when the manager doesn't have a website, a contact telephone number and address are provided. For background information on investment trusts, what they are, how they work and other information, you can visit one of the AITC's websites.

The Association of Investment Trust Companies (www.aitc.co.uk) has links to the websites of more than 90 fund managers who deal in investment trusts.

At www.itsonline.co.uk there is a searchable database of funds from 170 investment trust managers. You enter your criteria and the database will find suitable funds for you.

You can refine your search by how risk averse you are, whether you want to invest through an Isa or a pension, and whether you want the trust to be run for income, capital growth, or both.

You can also specify a preference for geographical areas and industry sectors. Alternatively, if you know the trust or management group you want to invest through, you can use the facility to find out more about them - including what their investment criteria are and how to contact them.

An advanced search facility lets you find funds according to very specific criteria. So, for example, if you wanted to invest a lump sum of £500 in an income-producing trust which invests in commodities and energy, this facility can help you find one.

Buying through a fund manager gives you the option of choosing the vehicle through which you want to invest. You might, for example, want to take advantage of your tax-free allowance and choose an investment trust Isa.

If not then the trusts are available through a wide range of other investment vehicles as well. Just remember that not all fund managers offer investment trusts in all their different guises.

The www.aitc.co.uk site also has links to fund managers. It is good for finding out more background detail than the itsonline site - so it could be a good idea to use both before you buy.

The other way to purchase is through a stockbroker. Many of the traditional stockbrokers have online facilities.

The brokers offer a wide range of different services, so it's up to you to find the one that suits you best. Some will limit your activities to simple buying and selling, asking for your debit card details as you go along.

Others, such as E*Trade or Schwab Europe, will ask you to set up an account with them before you can trade over the internet.

Directors put investors first

Investment trust directors are getting a crash course in corporate governance. They are being told that shareholders are more important than fund managers; to get rid of underperforming managers; to take steps to narrow persistent discounts by share buybacks; and to be honest and open when dealing with shareholders.

webTitle: Reasons to get a union card

fields.headline: Reasons to get a union card
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Cahoot is not the only new credit card in town. This week saw several other issuers launch new cards or revamp their existing offerings.
fields.body:
Cahoot is not the only new credit card in town. This week saw several other issuers launch new cards or revamp their existing offerings.

There was good news for thousands of holders of the Trades Union Congress credit card - they are to pay less interest after the organisation struck a new deal with its card issuer Bank of Scotland.

The two have joined forces to launch a new range of cards next month, and the TUC's 76 member unions, representing almost 7m workers, will all be encouraged to sign up.

There are two versions: one with an annual percentage rate (APR) of 15.9 aimed at those who borrow occasionally, and one with a rate of 12.9 "for those who generally don't pay off the full amount each month". The cards are fee-free and offer a six-month introductory rate for balance transfers of 5.9 APR and 4.9 APR respectively.

The 140,000 existing TUC cardholders will all be transferred to the new lower rates. Those holding the standard version of the card will see the biggest drop. Their current rate is 19.9 APR.

GM Card, the credit card from Vauxhall Motors, has just set up a website allowing people to apply and service their accounts online. The interest rate on purchases is nothing special - 19.9 APR - but it offers one of the most generous loyalty schemes, allowing people to build up points and obtain up to £2,500 off the price of a new Vauxhall. Those applying via www.gmcard.co.uk will get 200 free loyalty points worth £200 off the price of a new car, and every application will be entered into a draw to win a Vauxhall.

Credit card issuer Marbles (www.marbles.com) has a special offer until July 31. Successful applicants can obtain a free CD of their choice worth up to £20, if they take the plunge and buy it online through Streets Online (www.audiostreet.co.uk

New Marbles cardholders will be issued with an on-screen voucher number that they can use to make the purchase.

fields.headline: Verse and worse
fields.standfirst:
Laughter When We're Dead
Live Theatre, Newcastle
***
fields.trailText:
Laughter When We're Dead
Live Theatre, Newcastle
***
fields.body:
It's the kind of timing writers dream of: a play about a Labour government, fast waning in popularity and racked by internal power struggles, opening in the week New Labour's spinners and weavers try to restore the party's credibility after the PM's humiliation by a room full of WI ladies.

In this, poet Sean O'Brien's verse drama about the past, present and future of the Labour party, is blessed. The already dark humour running through this evening of revenge-tragedy-meets-political-satire is intensified; the more extreme Machiavellian machinations make horribly perfect sense. But given that this is a play written largely in rhyming couplets using iambic pentameter, a bigger question than its verisimilitude hangs over the production. Put bluntly, does it work as theatre?

Largely, yes, thanks to O'Brien's dextrous, slick verse, so deftly handled it feels like amplified speech, not forced, stilted words divorced from life. Inevitably there's the odd moment when a rhyme declares itself a tad too forcefully, but these are rare. And there are several outstanding performances, notably from David Whitaker as alcoholic poet William Farr (a stupendously good drunk), Deka Walmsley as Home Secretary Jack Jackson, and Donald McBride as the sadistic doctor of spin.

Ironically, it's not the use of verse that feels unreal but, in the end, the political analysis. This is a gripping drama that John Webster would have been proud of, with its descent into murky revelation and sudden, violent deaths, but politically it feels archetypal. It is universal, rather than specifically about the here and now. Close to television's House of Cards in atmosphere, this could well have been a play about the Tories in power, save for a few clips of miners' strike footage.

Some of the characters veer close to the cliches of the genre, including Daisy, the oversexed, posh, power-crazed PPS and even the spin doctor, although he's well played. The already dark humour running through this evening of revenge-tragedy-meets-political-satire is intensified; the more extreme Machiavellian machinations make horribly perfect sense. fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: The mayor of The Hague has turned down a request from prostitutes who want to stay open later to offset an excess of clean sheets at Euro 2000. "Our customers find they cannot use our services as they are committed to watch the football," explained one Goor - as I hope they are called in Flemish.
fields.body:
The mayor of The Hague has turned down a request from prostitutes who want to stay open later to offset an excess of clean sheets at Euro 2000. "Our customers find they cannot use our services as they are committed to watch the football," explained one Goor - as I hope they are called in Flemish.

Business is almost as bad in Amsterdam. Mariska Majoor of the Prostitutes Information Centre says that football fans are bad for business, and particularly the English. "They are either a pain in the backside or too drunk to perform."

 And your Dutch, they're always fighting among themselves. But here is Marc Overmars to give the lie to that lazy stereotype. On his personal website (access it on icons.com) he is unfailingly generous in his assessment of his team-mates. Edwin van der Sar is "a good friend". Dennis Bergkamp is "a super super person". The De Boers are "lots of fun".

But if you can't say anything good about a person, don't say anything at all, as Dutch grandmothers must say. Because Overmars leaves us guessing about his relationship with Patrick Kluivert, Philip Cocu and Boudewijn Zenden.

 There are still tickets available for the England-Germany game tomorrow but they are all in the hospitality boxes. It seems the corporate bandwagon has steered clear of Charleroi, first because of the potential for trouble, second because the boxes are frighteningly far up in the temporary stand and third because the game is on a Saturday and cannot be claimed as a business expense.

 One business taking an intimate interest in Euro 2000 is the British underwear manufacturer Brass Monkeys. The cheeky monkeys have sent a set of brown underpants to the German players. Said the chairman Jeff Suthons: "We want them to avoid embarrassment when they are taken to the cleaners on Saturday."

 And how did On The Ball react to the news that they would actually be able to use footage of Premiership games starting next season? Give them a couple of months. Yesterday the programme's website was still inviting entries to a competition with a May closing date. And Gabby Yorath was predicting the result of the big match. She reckons Chelsea will beat Villa on penalties or in extra-time.

fields.headline: Portugal enjoys England's agony
fields.standfirst: What the papers said
fields.trailText: England's first 18 minutes at Euro 2000 were exceptional. Supporters were in raptures after two early goals against Portugal, but the delight was short-lived, with England conceding three goals to lose 3-2, leaving them last in their group
fields.body:
England's first 18 minutes at Euro 2000 were exceptional. Supporters were in raptures after two early goals against Portugal, but the delight was short-lived, with England conceding three goals to lose 3-2, leaving them last in their group

Unsurprisingly, the Portugese papers were ebullient. Under an enormous "YES!" headline - in English - Diáro de Notícias congratulated its side: "[Portugal's goal scorers] Luis Figo, João Pinto and Nuno Gomes put a spanner in the works of English arrogance. Portugese fans were delirious. The English were dumbfounded at the skill and the pace of the Portugese team. We sank the English armada."

"We couldn't have done better," proclaimed O Público . "Never before have we managed such a magnificent turnaround in a match with our old allies, England. But the English team just never managed to rise above their straight tactics. They never really used the space above their heads."

British commentators generally concurred with this analysis. "The answer is not technique nor temperament," said Paul Hayward in the Daily Telegraph , "but tactics. That and poor defending ... Portugal, unruffled by England's initial assault, were allowed to thread their intricate pat terns free from the kind of intimidatory pressure which Keegan's defensive players should have applied."

John Sadler, writing in the Sun , suggested that England had been haunted by the knowledge they had never before won their opening match at a European championship. Portugal exploited this "suicidal tendency - knowing if [England] continued to hold out enough rope they could hang us with it." Following the second goal, England needed "to make sure they defended high up the pitch ... Instead, they invited their tormentors to continue running at them, conceding acres of ground and presenting endless opportunities. And Portugal duly obliged."

In the Guardian , Ron Atkinson, too, pointed the finger at the defenders, who "look good in the Premiership but when they step up that extra notch in class they get caught out." With a couple of key changes to the line-up, however, Atkinson was typical of most analysts in refusing to dismiss England yet: "We need more quickness and brightness, but the players should feel they can beat Germany, who looked shaky and rocky against Romania."

There was little sympathy for the English from Portugal's closest neighbour and rival, Spain. Still bitter, perhaps, about the national side's exit from Euro 96 at the hands of England keeper David Seaman, Madrid's AS newspaper calmly reflected on this latest contest: "England would sometimes do far better if they played with a goalkeeper. Keegan insists on starting with that piece of meat with eyes called Seaman."

webTitle: Matthaus offered to return home to solve internal rift

fields.headline: Matthaus offered to return home to solve internal rift
fields.trailText: Lothar Matthäus, under pressure after his poor display against Romania, gave the Germany coach, Erich Ribbeck, the option to send him home from Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Lothar Matthäus, under pressure after his poor display against Romania, gave the Germany coach, Erich Ribbeck, the option to send him home from Euro 2000.

"I asked the coach [if I could] retire and said it was the best solution if I was to be a burden to the team," he told the German daily Bild . "If they don't want me, I will go home without any fuss."

But Ribbeck has stuck by the 39-year-old and is set to start with him against England tomorrow. "I hope Lothar will show what he can do," he said.

webTitle: Deadpan Shearer plays a straight bat

fields.headline: Deadpan Shearer plays a straight bat
fields.trailText: Alan Shearer might have lost a yard of pace, but he still exerts pulling power. Martin Thorpe on the media scum surrounding the England captain.
fields.body:
Alan Shearer might have lost a yard of pace, but he still exerts pulling power. At yesterday's media conference the pack of journalists huddled round his table outnumbered those interviewing Sol Campbell by at least two to one.

This may appear odd given that the talking point after England's last game was the defence more than the attack. But Shearer remains a special story in his own right, not for what he does but for what he does not do.

He has not scored for England in their last seven games and the certainty that he will once against lead the attack on Saturday has left the critics shaking their heads more vigorously than ever.

Shearer's England form has been the subject of collective media sighs for a while now. So when he was asked yesterday to repeat his reasons for retiring from international football after this tournament his reply was predictable: "You don't think it's because I won't have to speak to you lot any more, do you?"

The inference behind the journalist's question was that Shearer has begun to doubt his own ability at the top level, and so is bowing out before it shows too much. But he would never admit that.

If he was a cricketer he would be Chris Tavare, straight batting everything back to the bowler, not a chink in his technique. That way he is never caught out by a question. But as an innings, his interviews tend to send old men to sleep in their deck chairs. Can England beat Germany? "Yes." Can we qualify from the group. "Of course." What about the view that he has lost a yard of pace and is not the striker he was in Euro 96. "I don't respond at all to comments like that. I go out and try to do my best, try and score goals, and try and lead the team to victory which is far more important than anything about myself."

The stark fact is that Shearer is not the ruthless predator that once struck fear into every opponent. His main strength now is his experience, which some may argue is not enough but Keegan obviously believes is crucial.

But if one looks at the argument the other way round, who would the critics throw into the white-hot cauldron of the finals in place of Shearer? Emile Heskey, a rookie with pace but a penchant for fluffing chances and falling over? Robbie Fowler, a great finisher but still unproven at the top level? Kevin Phillips, a clinical convertor of chances like Shearer once was, but again an international rookie?

One can see why Keegan remains so loyal to his captain. "I've never changed my opinion on Alan Shearer and I haven't seen anything in the first game against Portugal to do so," he said yesterday. "Players like Alan Shearer have got a career of proving people wrong and he will get another opportunity against the Germans." Keegan has said that the doubters will only realise what Shearer brings to an England team when it's gone. Maybe. But the manager will miss his captain's ability to accentuate the positive. "If we go out and play as well as we did for the first 20, 25 minutes against Portugal, then we should beat Germany," he said.

And Keegan will miss Shearer's tub-thumping qualities too - not quite Churchill but one gets the gist. "It's about time England won a game against Germany. Why not Saturday? Come on; let's all stick together and show the spirit we know we've got."

And just as Tony Adams steered Steven Gerrard through his first international against Ukraine, so Shearer can provide others with a seasoned shoulder to cry on.

"We played golf yesterday and Michael Owen and I were partners. So we spent a bit of time together. Obviously he was disappointed to be brought off at half-time. It's not nice being taken off because you feel you haven't influenced the game.

"People tend to forget that he's very young. If I can help him in any way then I will." So Shearer still has his uses. Though a goal on Saturday would not go amiss.

fields.headline: Rijkaard blows a Dutch fuse
fields.standfirst: Bitterness infiltrates orange camp as coach slates players for a lack of spirit.  Jon Brodkin reports
fields.trailText: Bitterness infiltrates the orange camp as Holland's coach slates players for a lack of spirit. Jon Brodkin reports.
fields.body:
There was no mistaking Frank Rijkaard's message yesterday as he accused his players of lacking the spirit and focus to win Euro 2000. The flowers here at the Dutch hotel may spell out "Orange Success", but the coach was not fooled into thinking that all in his garden is rosy after his side's lucky victory over the Czech Republic. For almost the first time since his appointment two years ago his friendly public face dissolved into criticism.

"The determination of other teams has struck me," he said. "They have been playing for each other, not just for themselves. Holland didn't show that team spirit. It's a major issue I have to make clear.

"For two years we have been playing friendlies and had the excuse that it was not for real. But when it's for real I expect them to know that because this team has experience. Without everyone giving everything for the team we will have a hard time. We can be confident about our qualities but the qualities need something to come out."

Rijkaard hinted he was as concerned by the attitude away from pitch as on it. He has found several of his squad paying more attention to the ace of hearts than the ace in a potential opponent's midfield when the tournament has been showing. "They have been playing cards and just looking a bit at the game," he said, "and then at the end they say it was a bad match. That's not my mentality. You always need to have the highest respect for your opponents. If you see them fighting you know you have to give something extra. That's my concern.

"One of the first players who didn't watch games in the team-building process [in the 80s] was Ruud Gullit. When we were watching opponents he said he was tired of watching football and put on his headphones. But when he played he always gave 100%. I don't tell them to watch every game but if they don't they must make sure they are ready."

Some locals, shocked by Rijkaard's strong words, suggested the aim was to deflect criticism of his tactics and coaching talent. Almost certainly he hopes to get a response against Denmark tonight and prove to the people he shares their concerns. With the Dutch, though, there is no telling what might happen.

The players sounded bemused rather than angry. In response Dennis Bergkamp blamed poor concentration rather than poor spirit for the lacklustre opening display. Michael Reiziger also begged to differ. "You always have to fight," he said, "but I didn't think that was the problem."

Rijkaard's outburst smacked more of psychology than of evidence that Holland are preparing to implode spectacularly once again, but he is all too aware that the Danes will be more determined than ever to gain a spectacular result following their 3-0 defeat to France. The smallest signs have been seized on by a worried public, with Edgar Davids castigated for conducting a post-match interview in a baseball cap. That, they said, stank of arrogance and superstardom when the performance warranted humility.

Rijkaard insisted his players were not stifled by the expectations, but Peter Schmeichel was not slow to point out after training last night that the pressure on the Dutch was "enormous". Asked what Denmark could do, the goalkeeper was less than impressed. "To ask what we can do is a bit of an insult," he said. "We reached the quarter-finals of the World Cup in 1998 and, of course, eight years ago we won the European Championship."

This time, though, they almost certainly need to win to survive and Holland hope that will leave them gaps to exploit at the back. The Dutch are expected to drop the unpopular Clarence Seedorf and install Ronald de Boer at right midfield and might opt for Arsenal's Marc Overmars ahead of Boudewijn Zenden. Bert Konterman comes in for the injured Jaap Stam.

Denmark's coach, Bo Johansson, who is without Chelsea's Jes Hogh and has the Udinese winger Martin Jorgensen struggling with a groin strain, feels his team are meeting Holland at the wrong time. "Maybe it would have been better for us if they had played wonderfully and won 5-0," he said. "Then they could have underestimated us."

After all the rows it must feel like normality has returned for the Dutch.

Venue De Kuip stadium, Rotterdam

Kick-off 7.45pm BST

Referee Urs Meier

(Switzerland)

Head-to-head

Denmark 9 wins, Holland 10 wins, 7 draws

Television

Live on ITV from 7.30pm and Eurosport from 7pm

Highlights on BBC1 at 11.40pm

Radio

Live on Radio 5 Live from 7.35pm

Holland

Injury J Stam (groin strain)

webTitle: Lemerre makes more waves in ending four-day silence

fields.headline: Lemerre makes more waves in ending four-day silence
fields.standfirst: French esprit de corps is being taken for arrogance, says  Roy Collins
fields.trailText: French esprit de corps is being taken for arrogance, says Roy Collins.
fields.body:
France arrived in the small coastal town of Knokke-Heist yesterday to discover that, for the locals, the most anticipated event this weekend is not the Euro 2000 match with the Czech Republic but the International Cartoon Festival. Organisers should expect to be swamped with late entries from such newspapers as L/Equipe and France Soir, whose cartoonists have worn their pencils to the size of cigarette butts with caricatures of the French coach Roger Lemerre since he stopped talking to the press.

Lemerre provided fresh material for them yesterday when, on the orders of competition officials, he agreed to end his four-day silence, beginning by reading a prepared statement in which he accused the media of inaccuracies, approximations, asking nasty questions and, heaven forbid, downright lying.

If the cartoonists are running out of ideas, perhaps they could portray Lemerre as a cross between Edith Piaf and the Prince of Denmark, since he insisted he had no regrets and that he and the players had the absolute right to decide whether "to speak or not to speak, to do or not to do".

The refusal of 15 French players to share their thoughts with the press has led to accusations that their World Cup win two years ago has fostered, literally, an unspeakable arrogance. Others might remember that Aimé Jacquet created a similar siege mentality in France 98. Yet one certainly has no problem picking out their team coach from the other 15: theirs is the one with the Mondial trophy affixed to the windscreen by a piece of plastic, no doubt on the suggestion of Frank "I won the World Cup" Leboeuf.

The players will argue, however, that it is merely the potency of the squad's esprit de corps that makes them uninterested in outsiders, particularly those carrying notebooks and cameras. And if there is a petit peu - or even a Petit peu - of arrogance, is it not to be expected from a side who so recently conquered the world?

webTitle: TV deal heralds £100,000 per week footballer

fields.headline: TV deal heralds £100,000 per week footballer
fields.trailText: The £1.64bn television deal that has signalled the demise of Premiership action on Match of the Day will be the catalyst for English football to usher in its first £100,000-a-week player.
fields.body:
The £1.64bn television deal that has signalled the demise of Premiership action on Match of the Day will be the catalyst for English football to usher in its first £100,000-a-week player.

The English game saw its first £50,000-a-week player when Roy Keane signed a new contract at Manchester United last season. But Gordon Taylor, the chief executive of the Professional Footballers' Association, believes the vast sums involved - the Premiership's 20 clubs will receive £548m each year under the new terms compared with £148m at present - will push salaries even higher.

"It is a tremendous amount of money that is being pumped into the Premiership, more than anyone could ever have dreamed of a few years ago," he said. "Players' wages have already escalated and there is more money around now than ever. I just hope it is put to good use."

The inflation surrounding broadcasting rights has coincided with an explosion in players' wages since the previous deal was brokered four years ago when BSkyB paid £670m and the BBC £73m. Before that there were very few players earning more than £10,000 a week. One Premiership footballer told the Guardian yesterday that some players stood to make a "financial killing".

"For those of the right age and ability, this is bound to make a big difference," he said. "I don't agree with it because footballers are already paid well enough, but £50,000 per week could be the norm for those at the top of the market in five years, maybe less. I would guess a lot of people within the game are already working out what they can get."

Though membership of football's Millionaires' Row is certain to soar, there are grave implications for the Nationwide League, which stands to be left even further behind in financial terms.

"It is wrong to measure a country's football strengths by having 20 wealthy teams," said the football consultant Alex Fynn. "The authorities seem to have forgotten that there is life outside the Premier League.

"It has become a vicious circle and it will undoubtedly have consequences for the lower divisions. The money that has been set aside for the Nationwide League is nothing more than a token, if well meaning, gesture."

The new deal will take effect from the end of the 2000-01 season and, according to the football agent Rachel Anderson, "the players deserve the lion's share because without them there would be no football.

"The Keane affair was a one-off but, like in any business, these things can spiral," she said. "I just hope the clubs don't go crazy and there is a bit of forward thinking for once. Otherwise half the teams will go under; not in the Premiership but in the lower divisions where it is impossible to keep up.

"If the money is used sensibly it should make the game solvent. But football is a knee-jerk business so maybe that's wishful thinking."

Next season's FA Cup will be played on Saturdays and Sundays with the third round reverting to January. Replays will take place in the week after the original tie.

A new venue for the FA Cup final will be chosen in July while Wembley is rebuilt.

webTitle: Sutton to talk over £6m Boro switch

fields.headline: Sutton to talk over £6m Boro switch
fields.trailText: Chris Sutton's brief and unfulfilling spell at Chelsea is likely to end shortly with a £6m switch to Middlesbrough.
fields.body:
Chris Sutton's brief and unfulfilling spell at Chelsea is likely to end shortly with a £6m switch to Middlesbrough.

Only 12 months after moving to Stamford Bridge from Blackburn in a £10m deal, the former England striker is ready to turn his back on the capital in the belief that he will be able to relaunch a fractured career on Teesside.

The clubs are believed to have agreed a fee yesterday and Sutton is expected to travel to the north-east for talks once the Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson has returned from a family holiday.

Robson is anxious to recruit at least three new players before the start of next season and would finance any deal for Sutton by selling the Colombian international Hamilton Ricard.

Meanwhile, the first member of England's Euro 2000 squad to book a removal van on his return home may well be Everton's Nick Barmby.

Barmby informed the Merseyside club two weeks ago that he would not sign a new long-term contract unless his return to the England squad was rewarded in the traditional manner: with a huge pay rise.

Leeds have already con tacted Everton to express an interest in the much-travelled utility man and if they were to lodge a bid in the region of £7m, Barmby would be theirs.

Although Everton's manager Walter Smith would like Barmby to remain at Goodison Park, money is still an elusive commodity at his club and he would not hesitate to sell a player who will be available on a free transfer in 12 months.

Fulham's manager Jean Tigana has completed his first signing, taking his fellow-Frenchman Louis Saha from Metz for £2.1m.

Tigana said of the 21-year-old striker: "I believe he will be a very good player in the First Division and has the right qualities to be a success in the Premiership."

Ally McCoist has told Kilmarnock he will return for pre-season training before deciding where to finish his career.

The 37-year-old former Scotland striker, who is likely to delay his retirement until next summer, is wanted by Carlisle, whose new manager Ian Atkins is keen to open talks with McCoist once the player returns from working with ITV at Euro 2000.

McCoist is out of contract at Kilmarnock but the Scottish club may offer him a pay-as-you-play deal.

fields.headline: Graham: 'delighted' if Ginola stays
fields.trailText: George Graham yesterday insisted he would be "delighted" if David Ginola stayed at Tottenham, amid angry reaction by fans to the Frenchman's projected £3m move to Aston Villa.
fields.body:
George Graham yesterday insisted he would be "delighted" if David Ginola stayed at Tottenham, amid angry reaction by fans to the Frenchman's projected £3m move to Aston Villa.

The Spurs manager has put the ball firmly in Ginola's court. "I would be sorry to see David go and, if he does, it will be his decision," he said.

But he added that Ginola, furious at being left out of two of Spurs' biggest games last season, "has also made it clear he's not happy with the rotation system, although that now is part and parcel of the set-up at big clubs".

It appears Ginola's tempestuous Tottenham career is over but even £3m, seemingly a good price for a 33-year-old player, will not appease fans. The Tottenham Action Group spokesman Mark Jacob said: "The thought of our only creative player leaving us fills us with dread.

"Just when Tottenham fans were beginning to get excited about the new season following the signing of Sergei Rebrov from Dynamo Kiev, our hopes get dashed."

webTitle: Deschamps: 'I only play at 50 per cent quality for Chelsea'

fields.headline: Deschamps: 'I only play at 50 per cent quality for Chelsea'
fields.trailText: Didier Deschamps has become the latest French star to criticise English football, claiming that a lack of quality in the Premiership meant that he only needed to perform at "50 per cent," in his first season at Chelsea.
fields.body:
Didier Deschamps has become the latest French star to criticise English football, claiming that a lack of quality in the Premiership meant that he only needed to perform at "50 per cent," in his first season at Chelsea.

The French captain told sports daily L' Equipe, "I'm frustrated. You can't compare Chelsea with Juventus because the national championships bear no comparison

"This year, in England, I had the impression of playing at 50 percent of my qualities."

Deschamps, who joined Chelsea from Juventus for £3million last summer, also claimed that the lack English spoken in the Stamford Bridge dressing room has led to him feeling unsettled.

"As three-quarters of Chelsea's players speak Italian , which I speak quite well, I didn't take English courses. That didn't help."

fields.headline: Forward - and forget safety net
fields.standfirst: Drama, comedy, pathos. After a week this contest seems to have everything, writes  Jim White
fields.trailText: From the moment Tony Adams wrapped himself in the English flag and started to quote from Henry V, it was clear what the theme of commentators and newspapermen alike would be when assessing England's first game in Euro 2000.
fields.body:
From the moment Tony Adams wrapped himself in the English flag and started to quote from Henry V, it was clear what the theme of commentators and newspapermen alike would be when assessing England's first game in Euro 2000.

The dictionary of quotations was gutted for Shakespearean metaphors: A Comedy of Errors, All's Well That Ends Well, Much Ado About Nothing all had a run-out. It was, however, Clive Tyldesley on ITV who got it right.

At first hearing, A Midsummer Night's Dream might not have seemed the most apposite of Shakespearean references for him to appropriate. But the way Adams reacted to Portuguese movement in the build-up to their third goal, the England stalwart did appear to be auditioning for a play in which the central character spends most of the action transformed into a donkey.

England's discomfort apart, it has been the best opening week to an international tournament anyone can remember. Brilliant goals, brilliant players, a brilliant comedy cameo by the Yugoslav Sinisa Mihajlovic: already it is a classic.

How different from the dreary fare on offer in the first weeks of World Cup finals, in which participants are able to play for a draw, aware that finishing third in the group stage can be enough to qualify. Thus we are generally treated to seven days of shadow boxing, an opening phase of phoney war, a week of Italy playing out 0-0 draws.

In European Championship finals there is no safety hatch of a third-place finish; only two teams make it through the group stage. A win, at some point, is essential.

Of course, that was the case back in Euro 96 and it did not prevent much of the first week being becalmed. But Italy's experience in that tournament seems to have informed the thinking of most coaches this time round. Playing their traditionally tight first stage, resting leading players in preparation for the real competition of the knockout, Italy found themselves in 96 unexpectedly overtaken by more daring opponents. They were on the first plane home.

In Euro 2000 the mistake has not been repeated: the Italians have ensured the first two games have been won. Following their lead, conventional thinking about cagey openings is being over-turned. As goalless away legs are no longer considered enough in European club competition, so the pursuit of an early bore draw is not the fashion in this tournament. Which is all the better for the armchair audience.

Certainly Kevin Keegan appeared to subscribe to the new orthodoxy. Ultimately fruitless though his team's mad gallop on Monday might have been, it made for a thrilling opening.

And Keegan isn't the only one. The Slovenians seemed determined to distil an entire 50 years of territorial history into their first 45 minutes in international competition. Gary Lineker may have looked appropriately sheepish when he introduced the start of an entire two hours of prime-time television devoted to a local Balkan spat. But by the end, after Yugoslavia's 10 men had restored conventional order, he was crowing about the entertainment on offer.

As if the football itself has not been enough, a bonus in this tournament is that we are so familiar with the cast of characters. Either they play in the English league, or we have seen them in action in the Champions League. Slovenia is the only one of the 16 finalists without a readily recognisable face in their starting line-up: if Norway meet France at any stage, it will be like a Premiership reunion.

Significantly though, a select XI of the best players in the opening week would not feature too many from the Premiership. Despite the growing ability of English clubs to attract top talent (an asset boosted by the huge television deal signed this week), the Italian league still has the individual edge.

In a team which reads Edwin van der Sar (Holland and Juventus); Lilian Thuram (France and Parma), Jaap Stam (Holland and Manchester United), Marcel Desailly (France and Chelsea), Paolo Maldini (Italy and Milan); Pavel Nedved (Czech Republic and Lazio), Luis Figo (Portugal and Barcelona), Rui Costa (Portugal and Fiorentina), Zine dine Zidane (France and Juventus); Thierry Henry (France and Arsenal) and Francesco Totti (Italy and Roma), seven earn their living in Italy. And frankly, one of the English league participants, Stam, is only included out of admiration for the way he retained his touchline dignity while having his eye stitched by a medical man whose hands wobbled more frantically than the Millennium Bridge.

Lothar Matthäus, the only representative of the US league, is picked in a team of his own: that of the over-rated Germans who every Englishman hopes will not be finally rumbled for what they are - past it - until after Saturday.

As for England, only two players could even be considered for a place on the bench in a best XI of the first week: the always reliable Paul Scholes and David Beckham, who did everything that could be expected of him in the marginal role he is afforded in the England set-up, including provoking the standard absurd rant from Roy Hattersley in the Daily Mail.

Indeed, England have so far performed much as everyone thought they might: full of spirit and effort, lacking only tactics and technique. Quite how the Neville brothers, for instance, have accrued such experience in European club competition while remaining apparently incapable of locating a player wearing the same colour shirt as theirs is a modern football mystery.

England are not the only side to live up to their reputation. The Spanish have duly let down everyone who thought they might achieve something at last, the Germans have looked every bit as bad as predicted (though ominously for England, they at least have a point) and the Norwegians will always make everyone's life uncomfortable.

As for the winners, the first week has merely confirmed what most pundits reckoned before kick-off. They snaffled the World Cup with a magnificent defence, a world-class midfield and no forwards. Now that they have added two of the quickest, sharpest, meanest strikers ever to set foot on a football pitch, only a fool anxious to be parted from his money would bet against the French.

Lothar Matthäus, the only representative of the US league, is picked in a team of his own: that of the over-rated Germans who every Englishman hopes will not be finally rumbled for what they are - past it - until after Saturday. As for England, only two players could even be considered for a place on the bench in a best XI of the first week: the always reliable Paul Scholes and David Beckham, who did everything that could be expected of him in the marginal role he is afforded in the England set-up, including provoking the standard absurd rant from Roy Hattersley in the Daily Mail. Indeed, England have so far performed much as everyone thought they might: full of spirit and effort, lacking only tactics and technique. Quite how the Neville brothers, for instance, have accrued such experience in European club competition while remaining apparently incapable of locating a player wearing the same colour shirt as theirs is a modern football mystery. England are not the only side to live up to their reputation. The Spanish have duly let down everyone who thought they might achieve something at last, the Germans have looked every bit as bad as predicted (though ominously for England, they at least have a point) and the Norwegians will always make everyone's life uncomfortable. As for the winners, the first week has merely confirmed what most pundits reckoned before kick-off. They snaffled the World Cup with a magnificent defence, a world-class midfield and no forwards. Now that they have added two of the quickest, sharpest, meanest strikers ever to set foot on a football pitch, only a fool anxious to be parted from his money would bet against the French.

webTitle: Defences go west in goal rush

fields.headline: Defences go west in goal rush
fields.trailText: When you talk to people about centre-halves they say: "Can he bring the ball out?" But for me that's a bonus. First and foremost they have to be able to defend the goal.
fields.body:
What a cracking tournament we've had so far. Once it was Good Night Vienna if you went 2-0 down in a European match but England and Slovenia have proved that the traits of the Champions League are carrying on here.

The first nine matches, ending with Belgium-Italy, produced 26 goals. The stattos tell me that compares with 15 at Euro 96 and 11 at Euro 92. At this rate I'd better hope they can get me into the commentary box for 2044.

It struck me watching the Champions League how open matches have become, with fewer teams squeezing games and pushing up from the back. Perhaps there are more good attacking players but I wonder whether there just aren't as many good defenders, not only at the back but in midfield.

England typify the problems at the back. I think there's a real dearth of old-style defenders. When you talk to people about centre-halves they say: "Can he bring the ball out?" But for me that's a bonus. First and foremost they have to be able to defend the goal.

Look at Jaap Stam. He can play the ball but he knows his basic responsibilities. He'll get his body in. Martin Keown, who's unlucky not to be an automatic choice for England, is similar. He'll hang on to you all day, challenge and dispute everything. Centre-forwards don't like that.

On Wednesday the Italian centre-backs, Fabio Cannavaro and Alessandro Nesta, certainly took no prisoners. They were outstanding, although I must admit there wasn't a great deal of poise. For a top-class side Italy hoofed a lot of balls.

In terms of midfielders it strikes me the quantity of good defensive men has dropped. I'm talking about people like Bryan Robson or Graeme Souness, to use British examples. Marco Tardelli could shut up shop when Italy were attacking. Even in the great France team of 1982-86, Luis Fernandez could play the midfield dog. And whatever people say about the Beautiful Game, let's not forget that Brazil play with two who can dig.

Of course I'm not complaining. Even in the Norway-Spain match there was tension, wondering whether Spain could nick an equaliser. And it was similar in Italy's game on Wednesday, which wasn't one of the best. In fact, with the refereeing generally being good, it's hard to find much to moan about.

The biggest worry for me is the potential for violence in Charleroi tomorrow. It's not exactly like playing a World Cup game in Stratford-upon-Avon but the sidestreets around the ground mean, if it goes off, it could be hard to control. There is no big car-park space to herd people into the right areas.

France were my tip to win the title and I see no reason to change. The only team who have performed as well were Slovenia, for an hour against Yugoslavia. They looked the best-coached and best-prepared team in the tournament, and also brought that element of surprise. I think they would have beaten anyone else comfortably from 3-0 up. But they seemed to get nervous because it was so-called big brother.

They have produced a couple of the stars of the tournament so far in Zlatko Zahovic and the left-wing-back Amir Karic. Alongside them as the outstanding performers I put Zinedine Zidane, Rui Costa, Luis Figo, Pavel Nedved, Paul Scholes, Cannavaro and Nesta.

Holland have been a major disappointment. There was a lot of finger-wagging and they seemed very intense, as if they were feeling the expectation. I think they need Marc Overmars to go down the outside of teams and Patrick Kluivert to put himself about more.

Otherwise the biggest flops have been the England defenders and, in particular, Yugoslavia's Sinisa Mihajlovic. Against Slovenia his free-kicks were useless, he couldn't win anything in the air and his error led to the third goal. He was having such a nightmare he might have strengthened the team by being sent off.

fields.headline: Three Lions' shirty clients
fields.trailText: Darren Tackle finds fame means nothing at the turnstiles.
fields.body:
Disaster. Don't talk to me about unlucky. Don't waste your breath with your bollocks about how it's not over yet. Please, spare me the nonce about wait and see what happens tomorrow. After Monday night, as a nation what has long thought it is equipped to compete at the highest level, we might as well pack in and go home right now.

I refer, of course, to the shower known as the Three Lions corporate hospitality operation and the complete failure of same to get yours truly into Monday's match.

Talk about useless, these pant-sniffers couldn't organise a session round Wattsy's place.

Seems they got wind of the fact I was helping the England lads out with a tip-top secret hush-hush assignment, and belled me to ask if I'd take care of their corporate package since the top player what was supposed to do it had been turned back at Ostend as part of the clampdown on category Cs. (No names, no pack drill: but has anyone spotted John Hartson out here? Exactly.)

"How'd you know where I was?" I says. "Not a bleedin' soul's s'posed to know about yours truly's mission."

"Well," says the face at the other end of the line. "We read that interview you done about it in the Sun."

They'd belled at not the best of moments. Following the instructions of Badger Bonce to the letter in my role as Playstation consultant to the squad, I is having the lads in one by one to the hotel's games room to give them some cheats on avoiding the zombie milk float on level seven of Death Race 2000.

To be honest, I could've predicted what was to come out on the greensward by the lads' behaviour at the console. Tony Adams keeps murmuring "Is this a dagger I see before me?" during Tomb Raider when all that is looming large is Lara Croft's chest area. Big Dave Seaman's fingertip control is so sluggish he's left on the grid in every race in IndyCar Mayhem.

To top it all, I has the Three Lions geezer on the blower waffling on about all I has to do is hire a minibus, pick up the tickets from a contact in the red light district, meet the punters at the station, take them to the ground, entertain them with hilarious anecdotes from the Greens' dressing room, and there'd be three long 'uns in an envelope at reception.

Now, everyone has their standards, but Tackle's start to wobble around the two long 'un mark. Which was how he come to be standing outside the stadium in Eindhoven being vigorously frisked by four Dutch policewomen, while watched intently by a party of 15 software consultants on a package from Slough.

For some reason this quartet of Holland's finest responds to my suggestion that we continue this line of questioning back in the privacy of my place by sending us to the rear end of a very long queue of your ordinary unwashed fans.

And when I sees Old Grandad Mickey Scanlan swishing his way through the turnstiles at the head of a party of chartered surveyors from Bromsgrove, the point has been reached for Tackle to pull out his big weaponry. So I marches to the front of the queue and fires off the ultimate question to the frisking police dollies.

"Do you know who I am?"

"I don't care if you're Darren Tackle," says one. "You're not jumping the queue."

"But I am Darren Tackle," I says, somewhat taken aback by her knowledge of matters world football.

"I know," she says. "So you kept telling us during the frisking. Now get to the back of the queue."

I tell you, software consultants can't half make a nause, particularly when we eventually reaches the turnstile and the tickets from the Three Lions contact turn out to be more snide than Bangkok Armani.

It takes me most of the match to extricate myself from their grip, eventually seeking sanctuary by legging it through the turnstiles when they opens them at the end of the match.

Turns out I is right by the tunnel. And who do I see on the other side of the perspex walkway but said keyboard jockeys yelling all sorts of abuse in yours truly's direction concerning tickets and back passages. When Becks troops past, dressing room-wards, I has to yell at the top of me voice to make meself heard above the gobby geeks.

"Oi, Becks," I screams. "How many spares can you fix us for the Germany game?" And he sticks up a finger in my direction to indicate just the one. Leastwise, that's what I think he was doing.

fields.headline: Holland 3 - 0 Denmark
fields.trailText:
Holland van der Sar, Reiziger, F. de Boer, Zenden, Cocu, Davids, Kluivert, Bergkamp, Overmars, van Bronckhorst, Konterman.
Subs: de Goey, Westerveld, Seedorf, van Vossen, Bosvelt, R. de Boer, van Hooijdonk, Numan, Winter, Makaay.
fields.body:
Holland van der Sar, Reiziger, F. de Boer, Zenden, Cocu, Davids, Kluivert, Bergkamp, Overmars, van Bronckhorst, Konterman.
Subs: de Goey, Westerveld, Seedorf, van Vossen, Bosvelt, R. de Boer, van Hooijdonk, Numan, Winter, Makaay.

Denmark Schmeichel, Schjonberg, Henriksen, Heintze, A. Nielsen, Gronkjaer, Tomasson, Sand, Colding, Bisgaard, Gravesen.
Subs: Sorensen, Kjaer, Hogh, Helveg, Jorgensen, Laursen, B. Nielsen, Tofting, Goldbaek, Beck, Molnar.

Referee U Meier (Switzerland)

1 min The Dutch, who are sporting a blue strip that is nearly as hideous as their orange strip is classic, kick off. They keep the ball for a while and eventually hoof it up to Patrick Kluivert - the Barca striker nearly latches on to Bert Konterman's ball but Peter Schmeichel is out quickly to collect.

2 A foraging run down the left from Marc Overmars. My, he's fast. But his good work is spoiled - he passes straight to Danish feet when there are two Dutchmen clear on the right.

3 Philip Cocu is booked for a needless tackle on Ebbe Sand. The free-kick comes to nowt.

6 Cocu scoops a ball over the Danish back line. Kluivert is in like Flynn, but he's offside like, er...

7 Allan Nielsen sends Jan Dahl Tomasson free down the left. The ex-Newcastle striker sends a cross in which is half-cleared: Thomas Gravesen has a long pop which is well held by Edwin van der Sar.

10 Michael Reiziger, in the centre of the pitch, chips a ball towards Dennis Bergkamp, alone on the left-hand side of the Danish area. But Schmeichel is out to claim comfortably. A worrying defensive lapse for the Danes, that.

11 Reiziger hauls down Gronkjaer. He's in the book.

14 Bergkamp and Boudewijn Zenden combine down the right. The Arsenal striker finds space in the Danish box and fends off a challenge from Jan Heintze... he's free! All he needs to do is square a simple pass to the loitering Kluivert and it's 1-0! Oh look, he's tripped over his own feet.

19 After a small injury break we're back (as is Cocu, the man who was prone). The Dutch pass it around for ages and ages. It's very pretty, but after about 30 passes it ends in a throw-in for Denmark. Shades of Columbia in the 1994 World Cup.

23 Gronkjaer tracks back to upend Bergkamp near the right-hand corner flag. A dangerous position for a free-kick. But Gio van Bronckhorst's delivery is worse than useless and Schmeichel claims easily. He throws it long...

24 ... and Denmark are away. Thomas Gravesen is free on the right. He whips it towards the head of Allan Nielsen, but van der Sar beats the Tottenham man to punch the ball away. Gravesen follows up, but his goal-bound shot hits the prone Nielsen on the head. Unlucky, and strangely comical.

28 Gronkjaer beats Reiziger yet again down the left. His cross is swept away by Frank de Boer.

30 Zenden zips clear down the right. He lashes a cross in towards Kluivert, standing on the penalty spot, but it's behind the striker. Never mind, in from the left comes a rampaging Overmars who bundles it back to Kluivert. He miscontrols, but Overmars gets another chance - he lifts it over the advancing Danish keeper for the opening goa... no, it's agonisingly wide.

32 Tomasson is in the Dutch box, under an inviting cross. He tries an overhead kick, but the end result is like the St James' Park days all over again. In other words, oh dear.

36 Denmark break again, when a move between Bergkamp and Kluivert breaks down. Gravesen could pass to Nielsen, who is free in the middle, but hacking the ball uselessly against Frank de Boer's legs appears to have been more inviting.

37 Davids beats Rene Henriksen to a through ball. He's running at full pelt with the ball at his feet in the Danish area... but no goal, because Schmeichel comes out and parries the Juve midfielder's shot away. Classic stuff.

41 Zenden swings one in for Bergkamp, who nearly gets his head to the inviting cross. Holland beginning to assert themselves in this match now.

44 Gravesen nearly breaks the deadlock. Nielsen and Gronkjaer carve the Dutch defence apart simply by stroking a few passes about. The Hamburg midfielder receives the ball in space on the edge of the area and smoothly curls a ball up and around the stranded van der Sar - but the ball pings the crossbar when it really deserved to go in. For goal of the tournament, that could have been a contender.

45 Injury time in the first half. Davids gets a bit chippy about nothing at all, Overmars nearly latches onto a through ball but Schmeichel collects, the referee blows his whistle.

HALF TIME: Holland 0 - 0 Denmark

46 Denmark kick off. Gronkjaer has been on the pitch for a fair while running off a knock. Will he last the half?

47 Well he looks pretty fit - he tears down the left and smashes a shot into the side netting.

49 Nielsen is booked for a late lunge on Davids.

50 The free kick, which is in a good position for the Dutch, is wasted as the men in those gauche blue shirts faff about. Sometimes you can have just too much intricate passing.

54 Konterman is forced to make a late clearance as Tomasson nips past Frank de Boer, who looked to be comfortably in possession. Complacency is creeping into the Dutch defence.

55 Konterman is booked for scything down Gravesen.

56 GOAL Holland 1 - 0 Denmark The Feyenoord stadium erupts. Bergkamp slides into the Danish box after a through ball. Schmeichel spreads himself to parry but the ball falls outside the box to Kluivert, who cooly sidefoots the ball around the prone keeper and into the net for his 24th international goal.

60 van Bronckhorst wins a corner. Bergkamp takes it from the left: Schmeichel parries and races to collect his own ball. He claims it, but then must drop it as he sails outside the box. Luckily for him, he manages to welt it upfield.

61 Holland make a change: Overmars off, Ronald de Boer on, Zenden moves out to the left wing. So do Denmark: Stig Tofting comes on for Nielsen.

63 Sand makes a useful run into Dutch territory, but he chooses to run into de Boer - ouch - instead of passing to Gronkjaer. Not a classic piece of action, but it shows the match isn't over yet, no matter what the ecstatic crowd may think at present.

64 Frank de Boer goes for goal with an indirect free kick. He wins a corner from a deflection, so it wasn't too daft a move. The same can't be said for the resulting set piece from Bergkamp.

66 GOAL Holland 2 - 0 Denmark Reiziger wins a throw deep in Danish territory down the right. The ball is worked out to the other wing, where Zenden awaits in space. He turns, and slides in a superb ball across the front of the Danish goal, between a hapless Schmeichel and his static defenders. Ronald de Boer, steaming in, simply has to touch the ball into an empty net. Simple, but still lovely to watch.

71 Lovely space-finding skills from Kluivert sets off a speedy Dutch move. The ball is sent out to Zenden, who curls in another delicious cross back to his Barca team-mate. Schmeichel is there in the nick of time - could have been three.

72 Davids steams through but takes a fresh air shot. Could have been three.

72 Zenden finds Kluivert free in the centre with only Schmeichel to beat, but the Barca striker gets a bit too excited and is just offside. Could have been three. Denmark hanging on, shall we say.

75 Kluivert beats Heintze to the ball and races clear - he stumbles.

75 He's in again! Again his control is poor, but the ball breaks to Davids. Sadly for the majority of onlookers, he blasts high and wide. Denmark are suddenly totally useless.

76 Aron Winter replaces Bergkamp.

77 GOAL Holland 3 - 0 Denmark Reiziger gets the ball and bombs down the right. He keeps going and keeps going, even though a pass to Zenden, who is free in the centre, seems the sensible option. But his judgement is vindicated when he tears past the Danish defence and bears down on goal. It looks as though he'll blast the ball into the net himself, but at the very last minute he passes it unselfishly across to Zenden who sidefoots home. These goals are getting better and better.

80 Penalty miss Sand chases after an up-and-under. He's brought down by van der Sar - penalty! Sadly for the abject Danes, Schjonberg passes the ball past the Juve keeper's left-hand post. Within a minute he's replaced by AC Milan's Thomas Helveg.

85 That seems to have taken the life out of the game. We're just running down the clock now...

89 Liverpool's Sander Westerveld comes on for van der Sar, who is being taken off as a precaution after taking a knock.

90 It's injury time. Four minutes of it. There's not much going on. The ref finally has enough. It's over. Holland and France are in the quarter-finals and Denmark and the Czechs are out.

FULL TIME: Holland 3 - 0 Denmark
