He's running at full pelt with the ball at his feet in the Danish area... but no goal, because Schmeichel comes out and parries the Juve midfielder's shot away. Classic stuff. 41 Zenden swings one in for Bergkamp, who nearly gets his head to the inviting cross. Holland beginning to assert themselves in this match now. 44 Gravesen nearly breaks the deadlock. Nielsen and Gronkjaer carve the Dutch defence apart simply by stroking a few passes about. The Hamburg midfielder receives the ball in space on the edge of the area and smoothly curls a ball up and around the stranded van der Sar - but the ball pings the crossbar when it really deserved to go in. For goal of the tournament, that could have been a contender. 45 Injury time in the first half. Davids gets a bit chippy about nothing at all, Overmars nearly latches onto a through ball but Schmeichel collects, the referee blows his whistle. HALF TIME: Holland 0 - 0 Denmark 46 Denmark kick off. Gronkjaer has been on the pitch for a fair while running off a knock. Will he last the half? 47 Well he looks pretty fit - he tears down the left and smashes a shot into the side netting. 49 Nielsen is booked for a late lunge on Davids. 50 The free kick, which is in a good position for the Dutch, is wasted as the men in those gauche blue shirts faff about. Sometimes you can have just too much intricate passing. 54 Konterman is forced to make a late clearance as Tomasson nips past Frank de Boer, who looked to be comfortably in possession. Complacency is creeping into the Dutch defence. 55 Konterman is booked for scything down Gravesen. 56 GOAL Holland 1 - 0 Denmark The Feyenoord stadium erupts. Bergkamp slides into the Danish box after a through ball. Schmeichel spreads himself to parry but the ball falls outside the box to Kluivert, who cooly sidefoots the ball around the prone keeper and into the net for his 24th international goal. 60 van Bronckhorst wins a corner. Bergkamp takes it from the left: Schmeichel parries and races to collect his own ball. He claims it, but then must drop it as he sails outside the box. Luckily for him, he manages to welt it upfield. 61 Holland make a change: Overmars off, Ronald de Boer on, Zenden moves out to the left wing. So do Denmark: Stig Tofting comes on for Nielsen. 63 Sand makes a useful run into Dutch territory, but he chooses to run into de Boer - ouch - instead of passing to Gronkjaer. Not a classic piece of action, but it shows the match isn't over yet, no matter what the ecstatic crowd may think at present. 64 Frank de Boer goes for goal with an indirect free kick. He wins a corner from a deflection, so it wasn't too daft a move. The same can't be said for the resulting set piece from Bergkamp. 66 GOAL Holland 2 - 0 Denmark Reiziger wins a throw deep in Danish territory down the right. The ball is worked out to the other wing, where Zenden awaits in space. He turns, and slides in a superb ball across the front of the Danish goal, between a hapless Schmeichel and his static defenders. Ronald de Boer, steaming in, simply has to touch the ball into an empty net. Simple, but still lovely to watch. 71 Lovely space-finding skills from Kluivert sets off a speedy Dutch move. The ball is sent out to Zenden, who curls in another delicious cross back to his Barca team-mate. Schmeichel is there in the nick of time - could have been three. 72 Davids steams through but takes a fresh air shot. Could have been three. 72 Zenden finds Kluivert free in the centre with only Schmeichel to beat, but the Barca striker gets a bit too excited and is just offside. Could have been three. Denmark hanging on, shall we say. 75 Kluivert beats Heintze to the ball and races clear - he stumbles. 75 He's in again! Again his control is poor, but the ball breaks to Davids. Sadly for the majority of onlookers, he blasts high and wide. Denmark are suddenly totally useless. 76 Aron Winter replaces Bergkamp. 77 GOAL Holland 3 - 0 Denmark Reiziger gets the ball and bombs down the right. He keeps going and keeps going, even though a pass to Zenden, who is free in the centre, seems the sensible option. But his judgement is vindicated when he tears past the Danish defence and bears down on goal. It looks as though he'll blast the ball into the net himself, but at the very last minute he passes it unselfishly across to Zenden who sidefoots home. These goals are getting better and better. 80 Penalty miss Sand chases after an up-and-under. He's brought down by van der Sar - penalty! Sadly for the abject Danes, Schjonberg passes the ball past the Juve keeper's left-hand post. Within a minute he's replaced by AC Milan's Thomas Helveg. 85 That seems to have taken the life out of the game. We're just running down the clock now... 89 Liverpool's Sander Westerveld comes on for van der Sar, who is being taken off as a precaution after taking a knock. 90 It's injury time. Four minutes of it. There's not much going on. The ref finally has enough. It's over. Holland and France are in the quarter-finals and Denmark and the Czechs are out. FULL TIME: Holland 3 - 0 Denmark

fields.headline: When the Sky Falls
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is a respectable feature, but with a TV movie feel to it
fields.body:
When the Sky Falls is a fictionalised account of the life of the late Veronica Guerin, the Dublin journalist murdered in 1996 by the drug barons she was exposing - and in a world of trite PR journalism and empty punditry, she is still correctly revered as a real investigative reporter. John Mackenzie directs, and delivers the elements of taut, efficient drama that he brought to The Long Good Friday, with Joan Allen as the Guerin-figure, Sunday Globe journalist Sinead Hamilton, and Patrick Bergin as Mackey, the glowering copper who is failing to bring the drug lords to book.

This is a respectable feature, but with a TV movie feel to it, and as with so many other films about Dublin crime it uncritically subscribes to the sentimental fiction that the drug lord scum are different in kind from the colourful "ordinary decent criminals" like the Commandant (Pete Postlewaite) and the black-jerseyed Provos who abhor the drug-dealers just as much as Sinead.

fields.headline: 28 Days
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: No sooner has the glutinous Girl, Interrupted squelched off our screens than another, almost exactly similar film replaces it... Sandra (Bullock) looks every inch the kind of wild Hollywood actress who chugs her Evian straight out of the bottle
fields.body:
No sooner has the sick-makingly glutinous Girl, Interrupted squelched off our screens than another, almost exactly similar film replaces it: 28 Days, directed by Betty Thomas, almost constituting another new genre: the rehab chick flick. Like Girl, Interrupted it has an empathetic woman forced into rehab who has to share a room with a wild, defiant girl giving the world the finger with fierce attitude. But soon they will be tearful best buds. Sandra Bullock is sentenced to rehab after a drunk-driving incident which is the culmination of an uproarious day ruining her sister's wedding.

Twenty-eight days is how long she must spend there, and I can only say it is unusual to see a film happening in real time. Sandra looks every inch the kind of wild Hollywood actress who chugs her Evian straight out of the bottle. Frankly, the 13-year-old Ruth Lawrence looked like more of a "party girl", but here Sandra gamely impersonates someone with substance abuse problems - and these are alcoholism combined with what appears to be a situation with painkillers, although this second factor is slipped in for realism's sake; it is not dwelt on and needless to say, there is no question of the female lead actually doing nasty illegal drugs.

That sort of yucky realism is reserved for the ugly crazies in the supporting cast, who include a zany German homosexual. There is not a dry eye in the house when Sandra's sister sobbingly confesses: "Even a pain-in-the-ass needs someone; I should have helped you with your homework...!" Oy.

fields.headline: Small Time Obsession
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: ...May not be perfect, but it's a film with heart, and Szkopiak is a director to watch
fields.body: First-time writer/director Piotr Szkopiak's feature Small Time Obsession, is a story of dodgy dealings very low down the crime food chain among twentysomethings in south London's Polish community. There are some clichés in this film, with its slightly familiar mix of coming-of-age love story with wannabe gangland drama - and there's quite a bit of Grange Hill acting. And yet Szkopiak has devised some interesting and engaging slants on this, deriving from the melancholy wisdom of the older Polish generation, baffled and upset by their children's errant lives. Small Time Obsession may not be perfect, but it's a film with heart, and Szkopiak is a director to watch.

fields.headline: Frequency
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A very workmanlike and entertaining back-to-the-future sci-fi romp
fields.body:
Frequency stars Dennis Quaid, and is directed by Gregory Hoblit - a TV veteran of NYPD Blue and LA Law. This is a very workmanlike and entertaining back-to-the-future sci-fi romp about a thirtysomething cop, John (Jim Caviezel) whose childhood was blighted by the death of his fireman father (Dennis Quaid) in a warehouse blaze in 1969, the date of a historic World Series for the New York Mets.

But when John discovers his dad's old radio ham wireless set, he finds he can communicate with him in a strange 30-year stitch in space and time, and desperately tries to warn him about his fate - but in saving his dad, he changes the course of his history and his own life. Time-travel yarns always involve suspending your scepticism about the insuperable logical problems concerning what characters in the present are now supposed to remember about a past which they changed. It's a bit silly, but this is a film made with great gusto and fun; the pace cracks along, and there's a nice performance from Dennis Quaid.

fields.headline: For Love of the Game
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It is played humourlessly straight with a dull succession of cliched throat-lumpening moments
fields.body:
With Euro 2000 upon us, we are expecting date movies and chick flicks galore, so it is a bit of a surprise to see For Love of the Game, ostensibly a very "guy" movie about baseball. Kevin Costner is Billy Chapel, an ageing pitcher determined to play one last great game as his health, career and girlfriend desert him all at once.

This is a sport which British male cinemagoers can at present be expected to care about even less than American football, and I suspect, our most vivid cultural reference point for the pitcher is Schulz's Charlie Brown, haplessly marooned on a mound much higher and plumper than the real thing. Actually, though, the subtraction of any of the sports-fan charge that the movie would exert in the United States leaves us free to concentrate on the emoting and the non-emoting, the crises and the failure to communicate and open up.

When Billy fixes his future love's automobile on a fluke, he confesses: "I don't know anything about cars; I was trying to be manly!" It could be that this is being marketed as a kind of subliminal male chick flick: a kinder, gentler sort of sports film. Be that as it may, For Love of the Game quite lacks the engaging strangeness of Field of Dreams and has none of the inventiveness of director Sam Raimi's past form in the horror genre. It is played humourlessly straight with a dull succession of cliched throat-lumpening moments.

fields.headline: Supernova
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A hi-tech sci-fi extravaganza... it isn't all bad, maintaining a basic oomph that John Travolta's depressing Battlefield Earth never managed
fields.body:
Supernova is a hi-tech sci-fi extravaganza starring James Spader and Angela Bassett and in space no-one can hear you shout: "Christ, that is a bad performance." Spader plays a pilot of a kind of roving ambulance space-ship who has to take command when the craft leaps with face-wobbling, thigh-rippling overdrive into hyperspace, and the captain (Robert Forster) accidentally gets his face fused to some plastic shield. (Don't ask.)

They pick up a faintly sinister young man, Karl, played by the dishy Peter Facinelli, who you cannot see currently starring in David A Stewart's Honest. Karl has got with him some great big throbbing orgasmatron object, which though it exerts an unwholesome fascination has the power to destroy the whole universe, for goodness' sake!

Who can have created such an awe-inspiring and terrifying thing? Well, says Angela Bassett, heavily, whoever it is, "They're as smart as God, but a lot less nice!" A superb epigram, and surely a good tagline for the poster. The second part of it could conceivably apply to the people responsible for this film.

Actually, it isn't all bad, maintaining a basic oomph that John Travolta's depressing Battlefield Earth never managed. As the pert paramedic Daneka, Robin Tunney is one of the crew members who regularly enjoy zero-gravity sex, with a sexy-Bambi face making her look like the young Demi Moore.

fields.headline: Where to learn to surf
fields.standfirst:
Where's a good place to learn to surf in February/ March?
Jane Spencer
fields.trailText: Where's a good place to learn to surf in February/ March?
fields.body:
 One of the best spots with good weather, warm water and consistent waves, and within four hours' flying time of the UK is Lanzarote, in the Canary Isles. Contact Surf School Lanzarote - 0034 928 528623. Further afield, Australia is a good bet with surf schools all over the place, and it's summer there in Feb/March as well, while if you want to learn in the chill of British waters the British Surfing Association (01736 360250, email colin@britsurf.demon.co.uk) has details of approved surf schools open year-round in this country.

Alternatively check out my book, Surfing - A Beginner's Manual (published by Fernhurst Books, £11.95).
>Alf Alderson
Editor, Surf magazine

 Puerto Escondido, Oaxaca, Mexico is great for surfing at that time of the year and there are various places in the town to learn. Puerto Angel, on the same coast, is also good.
Neil Paterson

 Oleron Island off the west coast of France has an excellent surf school which is open all year round. Contact Diabolo Fun, Surf Wind School, BP l 17650 St Denis d'Oleron (email didier_lafitte@wanadoo.fr). The weather is very good, even in February.
Margaret Duffy

webTitle: Too much stodge, not enough plums

fields.headline: Too much stodge, not enough plums
fields.trailText: Edgbaston may have been hot enough to do justice to the name of summer, but England's play resembled nothing so much as a winter pudding: one or two choice plums, but far too much stodge. The refined cuisine came almost entirely from the West Indies, who transformed insipid English fare into entertaining Caribbean flare with some glorious and determined strokeplay. Jimmy Adams and team have unquestionably manoeuvred themselves into an impregnable position.
fields.body:
Edgbaston may have been hot enough to do justice to the name of summer, but England's play resembled nothing so much as a winter pudding: one or two choice plums, but far too much stodge. The refined cuisine came almost entirely from the West Indies, who transformed insipid English fare into entertaining Caribbean flare with some glorious and determined strokeplay. Jimmy Adams and team have unquestionably manoeuvred themselves into an impregnable position.

First the English plums. Darren Gough, alone of the English attack, found menace and aggression on a pitch with noticeably less in it for the bowlers than under yesterday's clouds. All in the one over, Gough pinned Brian Lara on his crease, had him prostrate on the grass with a spitting short ball and finally dismissed him with one that reverse-swung away from the left-hander. It was classic stuff, class act taking on class act: intelligent, venomous bowling. And by then Gough had already smashed Sherwin Campbell's stumps with one that had the batsman in two minds. It was much needed - Campbell and Lara had scored freely this morning and taken their stand to 99. Lara, especially - on a ground that has seen a memorable innings or two from him before now - had been in majestic form.

There were a few other encouraging English moments - sultanas, perhaps. Andy Caddick summoned a good one that nicked the bat of the out-of-sorts Ridley Jacobs, while Andy Flintoff, almost matching Gough for speed, enjoyed his early spells, and his first eight overs cost just 11 runs.

But for the partisan home supporter, there was little to excite. It's a tad harsh to castigate the inexperienced Flintoff but he did utterly waste the first over with the second new ball. Jacobs, newly arrived at the crease, happily left five balls out of the six well alone. There were signs too that Ed Giddins's days in the team may be numbered. He did wonders at Lord's where conditions were up his street, but now, in his back yard where conditions weren't, he had nothing to offer.

Nor for that matter did Robert Croft, whose selection was always misguided. At Cardiff, where he removed Lara twice, he was helped by a dire pitch and a questionable umpiring decision. A quality off-spinner undoubtedly makes sense against a team with seven left-handers in the top eight. But England does not have a quality off-spinner in Croft. No, make that England does not have a quality off-spinner. Full stop.

fields.headline: Czech Republic 1 - 2 France
fields.trailText:
Czech Republic: Srnicek, Repka,
Nemec, Gabriel, Rosicky, Poborsky,
Nedved, Bejbl, Smicer, Rada, Koller.
Subs: Blazek, Fukal, Horvath,
Jankulovski, Kuka, Latal, Lokvenc, Maier,
Novotny, Vlcek.
fields.body:
Czech Republic: Srnicek, Repka,
Nemec, Gabriel, Rosicky, Poborsky,
Nedved, Bejbl, Smicer, Rada, Koller.
Subs: Blazek, Fukal, Horvath,
Jankulovski, Kuka, Latal, Lokvenc, Maier,
Novotny, Vlcek.

France: Barthez, Thuram, Desailly,
Blanc, Lizarazu, Vieira, Deschamps,
Zidane, Petit, Henry, Anelka.
Subs: Candela, Djorkaeff, Dugarry,
Karembeu, Lama, Leboeuf, Micoud, Pires,
Rame, Wiltord, Trezeguet.

Referee: G Poll (Tring)

1 min Our very own (?) Mr Poll gets things underway.
2 Nedved has the first strike from the edge of the box, forcing Barthez into a typically ungainly-yet-effective save.
3 Zidane has a pop from distance but it floats way over from 20-odd yards.
4 Nedved then Poborsky release Koller who forces a corner, but it comes to nothing.
6 The giant Koller nods wide from a left wing cross.
7 GOAL! Czech Republic 0 - 1 France Gabriel is too conscious of Zidane's presence to realise Henry is waiting enroute to the goalkeeper. The Arsenal man just picks up the poorly hit back pass, strolls into the area and rolls it past Srnicek. So nonchalant he probably deserves a slap.
14 Tomas Rosicky's jinking run ends with a crash as Thuram clatters him, apparently legally, though the Czech's aren't convinced. They're even less happy when, as the ball breaks away, Gabriel ends up getting a yellow card for a foul on the touch line.
15 Thuram wades up-field and releases Henry, though this time there are defenders available to make his job a little less easy. He still gets a good shot in though, but Srnicek tidies up.
18 Again Henry is in, this time thanks to Zidane's gentle nudge through.His rolled shot just beats Srnicek's left post from an angle. The French are at it again.
22 Nemec fires over when he should have done better after Poborsky cuts it deep from the dead ball line.
25 Viera breaks from Henry's ball but has to make do with a corner. The centre is underhit and the Czechs regroup.
31 Viera gets inside Rosicky from a hit-and-hope cross, chests it down and forces Srnicek into a smart save at his near post.
34 Petit loses the ball to Smicer as the French get comfy in midfield. The break ends up at Nedved's feet but he gets pushed over by Deschamps around the edge of the area. Poll consults his assistant who says the foul occured in the area. Penalty.
35 GOAL! Czech Republic 1 - 1 France Poborsky puts the ball straight down the middle from the spot as Barthez goes left.
38 Is this THAT Karel Poborsky? Again Petit is found wanting in the middle, again the Czech's break at speed. The ex-Man Utd lad hits it sweetly along the ground and it fizzes just wide of Barthez's right post.
43 The Czechs have found a way to get at the French and they are using it at every opportunity. Basically, every time they break, there is movement all over the place. Another break ends only becaus Rosicky loses possession down the right.
44 Poborsky again fires wide, this time on the half volley.
46>Henry collects a pass, runs at Gabriel and, with his options narrowed, still manages to test Srnicek.
47 Poll blows for half time - Czech Republic 1 - 1 France.

fields.headline: Farrelly Brothers answer their critics
fields.trailText: Movie directors The Farrelly Brothers are in trouble again over their new film, the Jim Carrey vehicle Me, Myself and Irene
fields.body:
As we reported earlier this week, movie directors The Farrelly Brothers are in trouble again over their new film, the Jim Carrey vehicle Me, Myself and Irene.

Carrey plays a meek and mild Rhode Island state trooper named Charlie who one day - after having been pushed a bit too far - finds his personality has suddenly split, giving birth to a foul-mouthed, sex-crazed character named Hank.

Mental health organisations in the US and Canada have expressed their anger over what they regard as a facile portrayal of a serious mental illness and have threatened to protest against the movie when it opens on June 23 across America.

The Farrelly Brothers seem quite unfazed and a little confused by all the fuss. When asked by US newspaper The Edmonton Sun about their feelings on the controversy, Bobby Farrelly joked: "On Dumb and Dumber, we got a lot of phone calls from dumb people. And they were offended about how they'd been portrayed."

This, of course, is not the first time the Farrellys have been on the receiving end of criticism about bad taste in their films. Although they claim to get "hardly any" letters from people who are upset or offended by their movies, the duo have acknowledged that the mentally handicapped younger brother of Cameron Diaz's character in There's Something About Mary raised some hackles.

"But you know, Ben Stiller sticks up for the guy when he's getting picked on by the bully," said Peter. "And the only one who makes fun of him is Matt Dillon, who's the bad guy. So I think the audience recognises that if your heart's in the right place, you can deal with anything. And in [Me, Myself and Irene's] case, we feel OK about it."

fields.headline: TV footage of Prince William released
fields.standfirst: See the film on ITN
fields.trailText:
6.30pm: The media frenzy around Prince William's 18th birthday has developed today with the publication of TV pictures.
See the film on ITN
fields.body:
The media frenzy around Prince William's 18th birthday has developed today with the publication of TV pictures.

The pictures, which were embargoed until 6.30pm tonight, show the Prince at play and work at Eaton.

The newspapers are already gearing up for the event next week. Last week Prince Charles's press secretary, Sandy Henney, became the first victim of media hysteria over Prince William when she was forced to resign over an unseemly row between St James's Palace and the Daily Telegraph about the copyright of a set of pictures taken to mark the prince's 18th birthday.

Yesterday, a web site invited Internet users on Thursday to send birthday greetings to Prince William, Britain's future king, via a gigantic virtual telegram it will present when he turns 18 next week.

Web site City 2000 http://www.city2000.com/royal/ launched the drive six days before the birthday celebration and hopes to beat the 270,000 greetings it collected for the wedding last year of William's uncle Prince Edward to Sophie Rhys-Jones.

fields.trailText: WE BLEED RED YOU KNOW
fields.body:
WE BLEED RED YOU KNOW

"We like playing in red, the England supporters like us to play in red - and hopefully after the game the Germans will not have liked us playing in red!" It's 24 hours until England play Germany in group A of Euro 2000 and Kelvin Koogan is turning his attention to the things that really matter. No, we're sure he's really sweating about more important matters like getting his midfield to press hard and getting his central defenders to stay awake, but it's just that it doesn't sound like it.

Aside from commenting on the likely colour of England's shirts, Koogan made very few remarks today with lines such as: "The spirit is fantastic and as long as we keep believing in ourselves I think we can still make progress. It is still not impossible for us to win the group if results go in our favour," just as likely to have come from a press conference six months ago.

But then if you were on the eve of the most important challenge of your career then you might be cagey too. Cagey also applies to Koogan's expected team selection. While an official announcement isn't expected to be made on the XI until tomorrow, the usual fast-leaking sources are certain that the introduction of Martin Keown and Dennis Wise for the injured Tony Adams and Steve McManaman will be the only changes and that Koogan will persist with 4-4-2. The Fiver remains quietly unconfident about the result, but wishes Koogan and his men the best of luck. And to all you fans out there: increase the peace.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

OH PLEASE STOP, MY INNARDS WILL TEAR

This morning Germany's coach Erich Ribbeck, 96, took the highly unusual step of announcing his side to face England 24 hours early. Bemused journalists, chewing on their breakfast brockwurst, naturally wondered what the Brecht was going on. Was it a cunning ploy to outwit Kelvin Koogan, asked one wag. "When we play England, there is no need to try to confuse the opponent," a strangely confident Ribbeck replied.

Ribbeck went on to announce that he'd made four changes, with Hamann, Diesler, Kirsten and Jancker taking the places of Hassler, Linke, Rink and the injured Bierhoff. The formalities over, the Germans went back to what they do best (ie being German). It is 34 years since we have lost a competitive match to England, Ribbeck proclaimed. "And we have only one player who can still remember!" - as reporters doubled over with laughter at his oblique reference to lovely Lothar Matthaus (German humour, eh!)

After a week of civil war a strange unity seems to be developing within the German squad. Liverpool midfielder Dieter Hamann, for instance, didn't bother slagging off his own players today (for a change), but instead concentrated his fire on England. "They have talented individuals but they're not a good team," was his damning assessment. And even old sourpuss Matthaus was in a confident mood. "I can reassure everyone I am top fit again and I feel great," he said after borrowing Ribbeck's walking stick: "I am sure I'll play much better against England." Isn't that funny?

German team: Oliver Kahn; Markus Babbel, Lothar Matthaus, Jens Nowotny, Sebastian Deisler, Christian Ziege, Dietmar Hamann, Jens Jeremies, Mehmet Scholl, Carsten Jancker, Ulf Kirsten.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"The press is always speaking negatively about me. It's a problem to make a good performance under such circumstances. It's just like if you were a clown and you needed to perform well in a circus but you are not happy. Your jokes will not be appreciated. I have always been nice to the press, always been prepared to talk to you. Maybe I should become a jerk, maybe I should behave another way." - Clarence Seedorf. You can catch the poor lamb in summer season at Bournemouth from August onwards.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

RADICAL ALTERNATIVES

Aisei, my friends (that's Swahili by the way). It's Rupert Fiver here, the oily teenager with the temporarily active conscience. I'm currently hanging upside down from the top of the Post Office tower in the hope of disrupting signals from ITV sport. The capitalist scum. If everything goes to plan I'll have Match of the Day back on telly before you can say "organic dungarees". Hang on, here's comes another wave...

Of course the majority of you crypto-fascist wussy lightweights aren't prepared to take the necessary steps to achieve your life goals. Take Liam Kirwan for example, who suggested that instead of fighting tooth and nail to reinstate MotD, the Beeb should "Give Gary the anchor on 'Newsround', add Alan to the Top Gear team and get Mark to reprise the role of Mr.Claypole in 'Rentaghost'." Like, very radical. But not as bad as Mark Jay who offered Lawro a couple of hours cleaning a week. Your sort make me sick.

No, if anything is going to be done my brothers and sisters, it'll have to be done properly. So a shout goes out to comrades Martin Wynn, Gus Williams and Steve Sutton who all suggested boycotting any product that dared to advertise during ITV's MotD. Great idea guys, but what happens if it's an ad for the rainforests, eh? Or fertility treatments for polar bears? Think about it, and sort your head.

In fact, of all the electronic trees that were killed to make your frivolous emails only one came close to hitting the spot. "How about someone organising a big march through the streets of London town, the theme of which was: "I'm just fed up of all this nonsense. Match of the Day is Good and must stay." I understand that none of you lying, money-grabbing people care, but I'm angry. then I'd go on it and I'd bring all my mates." Polly Corrigan, will you marry me? Not literally marry, of course - it's an outdated ceremony that only seeks to reinforce the chauvinistic hegemony of...

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

A deal is done to take Sao Paulo defender Edmilson to Highbury for £5m, report Planet Football's 'Brazilian sources'.

Arsene Wenger has put six members of his first team squad up for sale. They are Oleg Luzhny, Stefan Malz, Nelson Vivas, Nigel Winterburn, Christopher Wreh and Alberto Mendez.

Newcastle have accepted Everton's £3m bid for Italian full back Alessandro Pistone.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

ONdigital have confirmed they have secured a £315m three-year deal to show 88 Nationwide League matches each season. ONdigital have teamed up with ITV to secure the deal, which will begin at the start of the 2001-2002 season. In return ITV will broadcast 15 regional matches live each season as well as the Worthington Cup final.

Luis Figo has insisted he will stay remain with Barcelona next season. Both Lazio and AC Milan have been in contact with his agent Jose Veiga, with reported bids of £40m and £32m respectively. But Figo told Spanish paper Marca: "I have said it and I repeat it: my desire is to remain in Barcelona where I feel well, where my family is happy. These are important elements for me."

Real Madrid striker Raul has signed a new-five year contract, worth £4m a year, that will make him one of the wealthiest players in the world. Real Madrid chairman Lorenzo Sanz claimed: "Raul will finish his career with Madrid."

But Real's £6m bid to sign France winger Robert Pires from Marseille has hit a hitch, with Real president Lorenzo Sanz claiming: "Insurmountable problems have arisen at the last minute."

Manchester United have announced they will take part in a pre-season tournament to celebrate Bayern Munich's centenary, despite the inclusion of Galatasaray. Real Madrid complete the quartet of sides in the tournament

Gerard Houllier has signed a new contract, worth £1m a year, which will keep him at Liverpool until 2005.

Motherwell referee Hugh Dallas will take charge of Sunday's Euro 2000 Group C clash between Norway and Yugoslavia in Liege.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC 1: MoTD Live: Czech Republic v France (4.45pm) Gary warms up for live and exclusive coverage of the FA Cup...

ITV: Live Netherlands v Denmark (7.30pm) While Des warms down.

ITV: England v Germany - the First Hundred Years. (10pm) This sort of programming (a 'tongue-in-cheek' history of England and Germany matches or something) reminds why we love ITV sport so.

BBC 1: MOTD at Euro 2000 (11.40pm) Ray Stubbs is a big man...

BBC 1: Euro 2000 (12.45pm) That's why he can stay up this late.

ITV: The Big Match Czech Republic v France (1.50pm) Whereas Sideshow Bob Wilson will be knocked out during the day and only resuscitated half an hour before the show to keep him looking fresh.

Radio 5 Live: Football (4.45 and 7.30) Fresh? Our Alan?

webTitle: Death in the shadow of race fears

fields.headline: Death in the shadow of race fears
fields.standfirst:
Jan Martin Pasalbessi was killed in front of his stepdaughter. Now Newport is asking if its traditional tolerance is breaking down

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The savage racial assault that resulted in the death of an Indonesian-born man in the grounds of a Newport hospital has stunned the south Wales port town where ethnic minority groups have formed a vibrant part of the community for generations.
fields.body:
The savage racial assault that resulted in the death of an Indonesian-born man in the grounds of a Newport hospital has stunned the south Wales port town where ethnic minority groups have formed a vibrant part of the community for generations.

Like other towns and cities in Britain, Newport is by no means free of the stain of racial harassment and abuse. But the town prides itself on its multi-cultural identity and has worked hard in recent years to monitor and tackle the problem.

The death this week of Jan Martin Pasalbessi, 48, in what police are treating as a racist murder has left agencies dealing with race issues in a state of shocked disbelief.

Race relations in Pill, the docklands area where the murdered man lived, are generally good. The area, near the town's world famous transporter bridge, has a down at heel look to it. But once-derelict properties are gradually being replaced by housing developments in mews style settings.

On the walls, flyposters advertising a rally to defend asylum seekers underline local concerns that recent strident publicity on the issue could heighten tensions.

Hostility

Abdi Jama, a youth and community worker who moved to Pill from Tower Hamlets in London three years ago, said he had not found the area violent.

But he had fears for the future in the wake of the political row over asylum seekers which, he claimed, was promoting more hostility towards minority communities.

"The National Front recently came down here handing out leaflets because of the asylum seekers and my fear is that we are going to get incidents in the future. William Hague's attack on asylum seekers has also been stirring up racial hatred."

Judith Williams, who had come from another part of Newport to visit her sick grandfather, said she was shocked to hear what had happened. "I couldn't imagine it happening down here, this is such a multi-cultural area."

But an Asian woman who asked not to be identified claimed outsiders were causing trouble. "They say things like, go back to your own country. It's very rare that we let the children out on their own."

In 1998, 52 racial incidents were recorded in the Newport area. Figures for last year are said to show an increase but agencies believe this may reflect determined efforts to record such incidents rather than an increase in incidents.

Paul Flynn, the MP for Newport West, who knew Mr Pasalbessi as a constituent, said he felt a sense of disbelief that such a thing could have happened.

"No town is free of bigotry but Newport has a proud and successful record of integrating whole waves of people from outside Wales over the past 150 years. I am shocked by what was a senseless act of brutality."

Mr Pasalbessi died after being attacked by a group of white youths outside the Royal Gwent hospital on Monday night.

He had taken his 14-year-old stepdaughter, Christina, who is white, to the hospital for treatment after she received a cut face in what is thought to have been a racist incident outside their home.

A relative of the person involved in the earlier incident was among those who began arguing with Mr Pasalbessi - who suffered horrific head injuries after being punched and kicked by a four-strong gang as he lay on the ground. He died in hospital in Cardiff the following afternoon.

Christina, who watched helplessly, was yesterday being cared for by police family protection unit officers. Relatives were travelling from Holland to be with her.

Mr Pasalbessi and Christina had moved into housing association accommodation in Pill only two weeks earlier after suffering what Mr Pasalbessi claimed was racial harassment from neighbours in another part of the town.

Pill is home to a large part of the diverse ethnic community that took root when Newport docks became established in the 19th century.

Ethnic minorities, including strong Somali, Yemeni and Pakistani communities, make up almost 4% of Newport's 138,000 population.

Suffering

Local fears that Conservative policy on asylum seekers may be heightening racial tension are shared at the offices of the commission for racial equality in Cardiff.

Mashuq Ally, head of the CRE in Wales, said south Wales had witnessed a 150% increase in the number of racist incidents reported to police since last November. He believed the rise was due to the adverse publicity given to asylum seekers moving into Wales.

He said much of the concern that had been generated was due to a lack of knowledge and ignorance about the number of people involved.

"At the moment the fear for many communities within Wales is that their social and economic life may be disturbed," he said. "The people who are really suffering are, in fact, black and ethnic minorities who have enjoyed a long period of peacefulness here and are now being victimised."

Newport has around 200 asylum seekers and refugees living in the area at present, including people from Somalia and former Yugoslavia.

It is currently taking the lead role in negotiating with the Home Office on behalf of Wales over the proposed dispersal of asylum seekers. It is thought south-east Wales as a whole will take in around 600 asylum seekers over a two-year period.

The chief executive of Newport council, Sandy Blair, who chairs the Newport Forum to Counter Racial Harassment, said that while Newport had a somewhat unfair reputation as a tough town, the level of serious racial incidents in the area was low.

 Gwent police were yesterday continuing to question four people in connection with Mr Pasalbessi's death.

fields.headline: Policeman sacked over racist jibe
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A police officer in Bradford has been sacked for calling an Asian colleague a "wog" in a dispute over work rotas.
fields.body:
A police officer in Bradford has been sacked for calling an Asian colleague a "wog" in a dispute over work rotas.

Community constable Rick Pentith, 33, who was based at Eccleshill, has lodged an appeal against the dismissal.

The insult, which was admitted by Mr Pentith, was overheard by a senior officer at another station who was on the telephone at the time to Eccleshill. The Asian officer, who has transferred to another station, did not lodge a complaint.

West Yorkshire police's discipline and complaints department was called in and a panel this week required Mr Pentith to resign.

It is the first such action since the Macpherson report into the botched investigation following the racist murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

West Yorkshire police authority said yesterday that it showed that racism was being taken seriously.

The disciplinary panel which required Mr Pentith to resign was made up of an assistant chief constable and two chief superintendents.

Neil Taggart, chairman of the police authority, said: "This is a landmark case. The authority and the chief constable are united in making clear that racist behaviour or comments are unacceptable."

The West Yorkshire assistant chief constable, Steve Smith, who has overall responsibility for community and race relations, said: "Racist language or behaviour by any member of West Yorkshire police is unacceptable."

Roger Benn, West Yorkshire chairman of the Police Federation, which represented Mr Pentith, said that an appeal had been lodged with the chief constable, Graham Moore. The West Yorkshire force has been campaigning to boost the numbers of ethnic minority officers in a drive called "A Team Strengthened by Differences."

webTitle: Ben, in the World - the sequel to The Fifth Child

fields.headline: Ben, in the World - the sequel to The Fifth Child
fields.standfirst: Chapter One (part one)
fields.trailText: 'How old are you?'
fields.body:
'How old are you?'

'Eighteen.'

This reply did not come at once because Ben was afraid of what he knew was going to happen now, which was that the young man behind the glass protecting him from the public set down his biro on the form he was filling in, and then, with a look on his face that Ben knew only too well, inspected his client. He was allowing himself amusement that was impatient, but it was not quite derision. He was seeing a short, stout, or at least heavily built man - he was wearing a jacket too big for him - who must be at least forty. And that face! It was a broad face, with strongly delineated features, a mouth stretched in a grin - what did he think was so bloody funny? - a broad nose with flaring nostrils, eyes that were greenish, with sandy lashes, under bristly sandy brows. He had a short neat pointed beard that didn't fit with the face. His hair was yellow and seemed - like his grin - to shock and annoy, long, and falling forward in a slope, and in stiff locks on either side, as if trying to caricature a fashionable cut. To cap it all, he was using a posh voice; was he taking the mickey? The clerk was going in for this minute inspection because he was discommoded by Ben to the point of feeling angry. He sounded peevish when he said, 'You can't be eighteen. Come on, what's your real age?'

Ben was silent. He was on the alert, every little bit of him, know- ing there was danger. He wished he had not come to this place, which could close its walls around him. He was listening to the noises from outside, for reassurance from his normality. Some pigeons were conversing in a plane tree on the pavement, and he was with them, thinking how they sat gripping twigs with pink claws that he could feel tightening around his own finger; they were contented, with the sun on their backs. Inside here, were sounds that he could not understand until he had isolated each one. Mean- while the young man in front of him was waiting, his hand holding the biro and fiddling it between his fingers. A telephone rang just beside him. On either side of him were several young men and women with that glass in front of them. Some used instruments that clicked and chattered, some stared at screens where words appeared and went. Each of these noisy machines Ben knew was probably hostile to him. Now he moved slightly to one side, to get rid of the reflections on the glass that were bothering him, and preventing him from properly seeing this person who was angry with him.

'Yes. I am eighteen,' he said.

He knew he was. When he had gone to find his mother, three winters ago - he did not stay because his hated brother Paul had come in - she had written in large words on a piece of card:

Your name is Ben Lovatt.
Your mother's name is Harriet Lovatt.
Your father's name is David Lovatt.
You have four brothers and sisters, Luke, Helen, Jane, and Paul. They are older than you.
You are fifteen years old.

On the other side of the card had been:

You were born ..............
Your home address is ............

This card had afflicted Ben with such a despair of rage that he took it from his mother, and ran out of the house. He scribbled over the name Paul, first. Then, the other siblings. Then, the card falling to the floor and picked up showing the reverse side, he scribbled with his black biro over all the words there, leaving only a wild mess of lines.

That number, fifteen, kept coming up in questions that were always - so he felt - being put to him. 'How old are you?' Knowing it was so important, he remembered it, and when the year turned around at Christmas, which no one could miss, he added a year. Now I am sixteen. Now I am seventeen. Now, because a third winter has gone, I am eighteen. 'OK, then, when were you born?'

With every day since he had scribbled with that angry black pen all over the back of the card he had understood better what a mistake he had made. And he had destroyed the whole card, in a culminating fit of rage, because now it was useless. He knew his name. He knew 'Harriet' and 'David' and did not care about his brothers and sisters who wished he was dead. He did not remember when he was born.

Listening, as he did, to every sound, he heard how the noises in that office were suddenly louder, because in a line of people waiting outside one of the glass panels, a woman had begun shout- ing at the clerk who was interviewing her, and because of this anger released into the air, all the lines began moving and shuffling, and other people were muttering, and then said aloud, like a barking, short angry words like Bastards, Shits - and these were words that Ben knew very well, and he was afraid of them. He felt the cold of fear moving down from the back of his neck to his spine.

The man behind him was impatient, and said, 'I haven't got all day if you have.'

'When were you born? What date?'

'I don't know,' said Ben.

And now the clerk put an end to it, postponing the problem, with, 'Go and find your birth certificate. Go to the Records Office. That'll settle it. You don't know your last employer. You don't have an address. You don't know your date of birth.'

With these words his eyes left Ben's face, and he nodded at the man behind to come forward, displacing Ben, who went straight out of that office, feeling as if all the hairs of his body, the hairs on his head, were standing straight up, he was so trapped and afraid. Outside was a pavement, with people, a little street, full of cars, arm under the plane tree where the pigeons were moving about, cooing and complacent, a bench. He sat on it at the other end from a young woman who gave him a glance, but then another, frowned, and went off, looking back at him with that look on her face which Ben knew and expected. She was not afraid of him, but thought that she might be soon. Her body was all haste and apprehension, like one escaping. She went into a shop, glancing back.

Ben was hungry. He had no money. There were some broken crusts on the ground, left for the pigeons. He gathered them up hastily, looking about him: he had been scolded for this before. Now an old man came to sit on the bench, and he gave Ben a long stare, but decided not to bother with what his instincts were telling him. He closed his eyes. The sun made a tiny bloom of sweat on the old face. Ben sat on, thinking how he must go back to the old woman, but she would be disappointed in him. She had told him to come to this office and claim unemployment benefit. The thought of her made him smile - a very different grin from the one that had annoyed the clerk. He sat smiling, a small smile that showed a gleam of teeth in his beard, and watched how the old man woke up, to wipe away the sweat that was running down his face, saying to the sweat, 'What? What's that?' as if it had reminded him of something. And then, to cover himself, he said sharply to Ben, 'What do you think you're laughing at?'

Ben left the bench and the shade of the tree and the companion- ship of the pigeons, and walked through streets knowing he was going the right way, for about two miles. Now he was nearing a group of big blocks of flats. He went direct to one of them, and inside it, saw the lift come running down towards him, hissing and bumping, tried to make himself enter it, but his fear of lifts took him to the stairs. One, two, three... eleven flights of grey cold stairs, listening to the lift grumble and crash on the other side of a wall. On the landing were four doors. He went straight to one from where a rich meaty smell was coming, making his mouth fill with water. He turned the door knob, rattled it, and stood back to stare expectantly at the door, which opened. And there an old woman stood, smiling. 'Oh, Ben, there you are,' she said, and put her arm around him to pull him into the room. Inside he stood slightly crouched, darting looks everywhere, first of all to a large tabby cat that sat on a chair arm. Its fur was standing on end. The old woman went to it, and said, 'There, there, it's all right, puss,' and under her calming hand its terror abated, and it became a small neat cat. Now the old woman went to Ben, with the same words, 'There, Ben, it's all right, come and sit down.' Ben allowed his eyes to leave puss, but did not lose his wariness, sending glances in her direction.

This room was where the old woman had her life. On a gas stove was a saucepan of meat stew, and it was this that Ben had smelled on the landing. 'It's all right, Ben,' she said again, and ladled stew into two bowls, put hunks of bread beside one, for Ben, set her own opposite him, and then spooned out a portion into a saucer for the cat, which she put on the floor by the chair. But the cat wasn't taking any chances: it sat quiet, its eyes fixed on Ben.

Ben sat down, and his hands were already about to dig into the mound of meat, when he saw the old woman shake her head at him. He picked up a spoon and used it, conscious of every movement, being careful, eating tidily, though it was evident he was very hungry. The old woman ate a little, but mostly watched him, and when he had finished, she scraped out from the saucepan everything that was left of the stew, and put it on his plate.

'I wasn't expecting you,' she said, meaning that she would have made more. 'Fill up on bread,'

Ben finished the stew, and then the bread. There was nothing else to eat except some cake, which she pushed towards him, but he ignored it.

Now his attention was free, and she said, slowly, carefully, as if to a child, 'Ben, did you go to the office?' She had told him how to get there. 'Yes.'

'What happened?'

'They said, "How old are you?"'

Here the old woman sighed, and put her hand to her face, rubbing it around there, as if wiping away difficult thoughts. She knew Ben was eighteen: he kept saying so. She believed him. It was the one fact he kept repeating. But she knew that was no eighteen-year-old, sitting there in front of her, and she had decided not to go on with the thoughts of what that meant. It's not my business - what he really is, sums up what she felt. Deep waters! Trouble! Keep out!

He sat there like a dog expecting a rebuke, his teeth revealed in that other grin, which she knew and understood now, a stretched, teeth-showing grin that meant fear.

'Ben, you must go back to your mother and ask her for your birth certificate. She'll have it, I'm sure. It'd save you all the complications and the questions. You do remember how to get there?'

'Yes, I know that.'

'Well, I think you should go soon. Perhaps tomorrow?'

Ben's eyes did not leave her face, taking in every little move- ment of eyes, mouth, her smile, her insistence. It was not the first time she had told him to go home to find his mother. He did not want to. But if she said he must... For him what was difficult was this: here there was friendship for him, warmth, kindness, and here, too, insistence that he must expose himself to pain and confusion, and danger. Ben's eyes did not leave that face, that smiling face, for him at this moment the bewildering face of the world.

'You see, Ben, I have to live on my pension. I have only so much money to live on. I want to help you. But if you got some money - that office would give you money - and that would help me. Do you understand, Ben?' Yes, he did. He knew money. He had learned that hard lesson. Without money you did not eat.

And now, as if it was no great thing she wanted him to do, just a little thing, she said, 'Good, then that is settled.'

She got up. 'Look, I've got something I think would be just right for you.'

Folded over a chair was a jacket, which she had found in a charity shop, searching until there was one with wide shoulders. The jacket Ben had on was dirty, and torn, too.

He took it off. The jacket she had found fitted his big shoulders and chest but was loose around the waist. 'Look, you can pull it in.' There was a belt, which she adjusted. And there were trousers, too. 'And now I want you to have a bath, Ben.'

He took off the new jacket and his trousers, obedient, watching her all the time.

'I'm going to put away these trousers, Ben.' She did so. 'And I have got new underpants, and vests.'

He was standing naked there, watching, while she went next door to a little bathroom. His nostrils flared, taking in the smell of water. Waiting, he checked all the smells in the room, the fading aromas of the good stew, a warm friendly smell; the bread, which smelled like a person; then a rank wild smell - the cat, still watching him; the smell of a slept-in bed, where the covers had been pulled up covering the pillows, which had a different smell. And he listened, too. The lift was silent, behind two walls. There was a rumbling in the sky, but he knew aeroplanes, was not afraid of them. The traffic down there he did not hear at all - he had shut it out of his awareness.

The old woman came back, and said, 'Now, Ben.' He followed her, clambered into the water, and crouched in it. 'Do sit down,' she said. He hated the submission to the dangerous slipperiness, but now he was sitting in hot water to his waist. He shut his eyes, and with his teeth bared, this time in a grin of resignation, he let her wash him. He knew this washing was something he had to do, from time to time. It was expected of him. In fact he was beginning to enjoy water.

Now the old woman, Ben's eyes no longer fastened on her face, allowed herself to show the curiosity she felt, which could never be assuaged - or indulged in.

Under her hands was a strong broad back, with fringes of brown hair on either side of the backbone, and on the shoulders a mat of wet fur: it felt like that, as if she were washing a dog. On the upper arms there was hair, but not so much, not more than could be on an ordinary man. His chest was hairy, but it wasn't like fur, it was a man's chest. She handed him the soap but he let it slide into the water, and dug around furiously for it. She found it, and lathered him vigorously, and then used a little hand-shower to get it all off. He bounded out of the bath, and she made him go back, and she washed his thighs, his backside, and then, his genitals. He had no self-consciousness about these, and so she didn't either. And then, he could get out, which he did laughing, and shaking himself into the towel she held. She enjoyed hearing him laugh: it was like a bark. Long ago she had a dog who barked like that.

She dried him, all over, and then led him back to the other room, naked, and made him put on his new underpants, his new vest, a charity shop shirt, his trousers. Then she put a towel around his shoulders and as he began to jerk about in protest, she said, 'Yes, Ben, you have to.'

She trimmed his beard first. It was stiff and bristly, but she was able to make a good job of it. And now his hair, and that was a different matter, for it was coarse and thick. The trouble was his double crown which, if cut short, showed like stubbly whorls on the scalp. It was necessity that had left the hair on the top of his head long, and at the sides. She told him that one of these new clever hairdressers would make him look like a film star, but since he did not take this in, she amended it to, 'They could make you look so smart, Ben, you'd not know yourself.'

But he didn't look too bad now, and he smelled clean.

Mean- while the young man in front of him was waiting, his hand holding the biro and fiddling it between his fingers. A telephone rang just beside him. On either side of him were several young men and women with that glass in front of them. Some used instruments that clicked and chattered, some stared at screens where words appeared and went. Each of these noisy machines Ben knew was probably hostile to him. Now he moved slightly to one side, to get rid of the reflections on the glass that were bothering him, and preventing him from properly seeing this person who was angry with him. 'Yes. I am eighteen,' he said. He knew he was. When he had gone to find his mother, three winters ago - he did not stay because his hated brother Paul had come in - she had written in large words on a piece of card: Your name is Ben Lovatt. Your mother's name is Harriet Lovatt. Your father's name is David Lovatt. You have four brothers and sisters, Luke, Helen, Jane, and Paul. They are older than you. You are fifteen years old. On the other side of the card had been: You were born .............. Your home address is ............ This card had afflicted Ben with such a despair of rage that he took it from his mother, and ran out of the house. He scribbled over the name Paul, first. Then, the other siblings. Then, the card falling to the floor and picked up showing the reverse side, he scribbled with his black biro over all the words there, leaving only a wild mess of lines. That number, fifteen, kept coming up in questions that were always - so he felt - being put to him. 'How old are you?' Knowing it was so important, he remembered it, and when the year turned around at Christmas, which no one could miss, he added a year. Now I am sixteen. Now I am seventeen. Now, because a third winter has gone, I am eighteen. 'OK, then, when were you born?' With every day since he had scribbled with that angry black pen all over the back of the card he had understood better what a mistake he had made. And he had destroyed the whole card, in a culminating fit of rage, because now it was useless. He knew his name. He knew 'Harriet' and 'David' and did not care about his brothers and sisters who wished he was dead. He did not remember when he was born. Listening, as he did, to every sound, he heard how the noises in that office were suddenly louder, because in a line of people waiting outside one of the glass panels, a woman had begun shout- ing at the clerk who was interviewing her, and because of this anger released into the air, all the lines began moving and shuffling, and other people were muttering, and then said aloud, like a barking, short angry words like Bastards, Shits - and these were words that Ben knew very well, and he was afraid of them. He felt the cold of fear moving down from the back of his neck to his spine. The man behind him was impatient, and said, 'I haven't got all day if you have.' 'When were you born? What date?' 'I don't know,' said Ben. And now the clerk put an end to it, postponing the problem, with, 'Go and find your birth certificate. Go to the Records Office. That'll settle it. You don't know your last employer. You don't have an address. You don't know your date of birth.' With these words his eyes left Ben's face, and he nodded at the man behind to come forward, displacing Ben, who went straight out of that office, feeling as if all the hairs of his body, the hairs on his head, were standing straight up, he was so trapped and afraid. Outside was a pavement, with people, a little street, full of cars, arm under the plane tree where the pigeons were moving about, cooing and complacent, a bench. He sat on it at the other end from a young woman who gave him a glance, but then another, frowned, and went off, looking back at him with that look on her face which Ben knew and expected. She was not afraid of him, but thought that she might be soon. Her body was all haste and apprehension, like one escaping. She went into a shop, glancing back. Ben was hungry. He had no money. There were some broken crusts on the ground, left for the pigeons. He gathered them up hastily, looking about him: he had been scolded for this before. Now an old man came to sit on the bench, and he gave Ben a long stare, but decided not to bother with what his instincts were telling him. He closed his eyes. The sun made a tiny bloom of sweat on the old face. Ben sat on, thinking how he must go back to the old woman, but she would be disappointed in him. She had told him to come to this office and claim unemployment benefit. The thought of her made him smile - a very different grin from the one that had annoyed the clerk. He sat smiling, a small smile that showed a gleam of teeth in his beard, and watched how the old man woke up, to wipe away the sweat that was running down his face, saying to the sweat, 'What? What's that?' as if it had reminded him of something. And then, to cover himself, he said sharply to Ben, 'What do you think you're laughing at?' Ben left the bench and the shade of the tree and the companion- ship of the pigeons, and walked through streets knowing he was going the right way, for about two miles. Now he was nearing a group of big blocks of flats. He went direct to one of them, and inside it, saw the lift come running down towards him, hissing and bumping, tried to make himself enter it, but his fear of lifts took him to the stairs. One, two, three... eleven flights of grey cold stairs, listening to the lift grumble and crash on the other side of a wall. On the landing were four doors. He went straight to one from where a rich meaty smell was coming, making his mouth fill with water. He turned the door knob, rattled it, and stood back to stare expectantly at the door, which opened. And there an old woman stood, smiling. 'Oh, Ben, there you are,' she said, and put her arm around him to pull him into the room. Inside he stood slightly crouched, darting looks everywhere, first of all to a large tabby cat that sat on a chair arm. Its fur was standing on end. The old woman went to it, and said, 'There, there, it's all right, puss,' and under her calming hand its terror abated, and it became a small neat cat. Now the old woman went to Ben, with the same words, 'There, Ben, it's all right, come and sit down.' Ben allowed his eyes to leave puss, but did not lose his wariness, sending glances in her direction. This room was where the old woman had her life. On a gas stove was a saucepan of meat stew, and it was this that Ben had smelled on the landing. 'It's all right, Ben,' she said again, and ladled stew into two bowls, put hunks of bread beside one, for Ben, set her own opposite him, and then spooned out a portion into a saucer for the cat, which she put on the floor by the chair. But the cat wasn't taking any chances: it sat quiet, its eyes fixed on Ben. Ben sat down, and his hands were already about to dig into the mound of meat, when he saw the old woman shake her head at him. He picked up a spoon and used it, conscious of every movement, being careful, eating tidily, though it was evident he was very hungry. The old woman ate a little, but mostly watched him, and when he had finished, she scraped out from the saucepan everything that was left of the stew, and put it on his plate. 'I wasn't expecting you,' she said, meaning that she would have made more. 'Fill up on bread,' Ben finished the stew, and then the bread. There was nothing else to eat except some cake, which she pushed towards him, but he ignored it. Now his attention was free, and she said, slowly, carefully, as if to a child, 'Ben, did you go to the office?' She had told him how to get there. 'Yes.' 'What happened?' 'They said, "How old are you?"' Here the old woman sighed, and put her hand to her face, rubbing it around there, as if wiping away difficult thoughts. She knew Ben was eighteen: he kept saying so. She believed him. It was the one fact he kept repeating. But she knew that was no eighteen-year-old, sitting there in front of her, and she had decided not to go on with the thoughts of what that meant. It's not my business - what he really is, sums up what she felt. Deep waters! Trouble! Keep out! He sat there like a dog expecting a rebuke, his teeth revealed in that other grin, which she knew and understood now, a stretched, teeth-showing grin that meant fear. 'Ben, you must go back to your mother and ask her for your birth certificate. She'll have it, I'm sure. It'd save you all the complications and the questions. You do remember how to get there?' 'Yes, I know that.' 'Well, I think you should go soon. Perhaps tomorrow?' Ben's eyes did not leave her face, taking in every little move- ment of eyes, mouth, her smile, her insistence. It was not the first time she had told him to go home to find his mother. He did not want to. But if she said he must... For him what was difficult was this: here there was friendship for him, warmth, kindness, and here, too, insistence that he must expose himself to pain and confusion, and danger. Ben's eyes did not leave that face, that smiling face, for him at this moment the bewildering face of the world. 'You see, Ben, I have to live on my pension. I have only so much money to live on. I want to help you. But if you got some money - that office would give you money - and that would help me. Do you understand, Ben?' Yes, he did. He knew money. He had learned that hard lesson. Without money you did not eat. And now, as if it was no great thing she wanted him to do, just a little thing, she said, 'Good, then that is settled.' She got up. 'Look, I've got something I think would be just right for you.' Folded over a chair was a jacket, which she had found in a charity shop, searching until there was one with wide shoulders. The jacket Ben had on was dirty, and torn, too. He took it off. The jacket she had found fitted his big shoulders and chest but was loose around the waist. 'Look, you can pull it in.' There was a belt, which she adjusted. And there were trousers, too. 'And now I want you to have a bath, Ben.' He took off the new jacket and his trousers, obedient, watching her all the time. 'I'm going to put away these trousers, Ben.' She did so. 'And I have got new underpants, and vests.' He was standing naked there, watching, while she went next door to a little bathroom. His nostrils flared, taking in the smell of water. Waiting, he checked all the smells in the room, the fading aromas of the good stew, a warm friendly smell; the bread, which smelled like a person; then a rank wild smell - the cat, still watching him; the smell of a slept-in bed, where the covers had been pulled up covering the pillows, which had a different smell. And he listened, too. The lift was silent, behind two walls. There was a rumbling in the sky, but he knew aeroplanes, was not afraid of them. The traffic down there he did not hear at all - he had shut it out of his awareness. The old woman came back, and said, 'Now, Ben.' He followed her, clambered into the water, and crouched in it. 'Do sit down,' she said. He hated the submission to the dangerous slipperiness, but now he was sitting in hot water to his waist. He shut his eyes, and with his teeth bared, this time in a grin of resignation, he let her wash him. He knew this washing was something he had to do, from time to time. It was expected of him. In fact he was beginning to enjoy water. Now the old woman, Ben's eyes no longer fastened on her face, allowed herself to show the curiosity she felt, which could never be assuaged - or indulged in. Under her hands was a strong broad back, with fringes of brown hair on either side of the backbone, and on the shoulders a mat of wet fur: it felt like that, as if she were washing a dog. On the upper arms there was hair, but not so much, not more than could be on an ordinary man. His chest was hairy, but it wasn't like fur, it was a man's chest. She handed him the soap but he let it slide into the water, and dug around furiously for it. She found it, and lathered him vigorously, and then used a little hand-shower to get it all off. He bounded out of the bath, and she made him go back, and she washed his thighs, his backside, and then, his genitals. He had no self-consciousness about these, and so she didn't either. And then, he could get out, which he did laughing, and shaking himself into the towel she held. She enjoyed hearing him laugh: it was like a bark. Long ago she had a dog who barked like that. She dried him, all over, and then led him back to the other room, naked, and made him put on his new underpants, his new vest, a charity shop shirt, his trousers. Then she put a towel around his shoulders and as he began to jerk about in protest, she said, 'Yes, Ben, you have to.' She trimmed his beard first. It was stiff and bristly, but she was able to make a good job of it. And now his hair, and that was a different matter, for it was coarse and thick. The trouble was his double crown which, if cut short, showed like stubbly whorls on the scalp. It was necessity that had left the hair on the top of his head long, and at the sides. She told him that one of these new clever hairdressers would make him look like a film star, but since he did not take this in, she amended it to, 'They could make you look so smart, Ben, you'd not know yourself.' But he didn't look too bad now, and he smelled clean. Continued here

webTitle: Barmies made welcome in England at last

fields.headline: Barmies made welcome in England at last
fields.standfirst: In the latest instalment of wisden.com's gossip column, Charles de Lisle explains why the Barmy Army are finally finding their voice at home Tests, how victory for England over West Indies would be a real money-spinner, and who this summer's next touring side are (you'll never guess)
fields.trailText: Barmy Army comes in from the cold at last
fields.body:
Barmy Army comes in from the cold at last

The passionate, boisterous support which the Barmy Army has brought to England tours for six winters is finally being replicated at home. This summer, for the first time at home Tests, the army is being officially allocated a small section of each ground. In effect, the Barmies can now finally block-book tickets - as they have been allowed to do abroad for years.

During the current Test at Edgbaston, the army (website: barmy-army.com) is reinforcing the support of the most patriotic crowd in England from a spot in the lively Eric Hollies stand. The ECB's new policy works quite simply: at its request, Test grounds now tell Barmy Army supporters which area they've been assigned, and seats are issued accordingly.

Paul Burnham, the former British Airways cargo agent who now runs the Barmy Army, says: "Our guys don't misbehave abroad, and there's no reason why they should here. It's good the ECB is showing confidence in us." He adds: "The ECB have been helpful. At last, we're being helped, not hindered." The exception is Lord's, where the ECB and the Barmies both felt an approach to MCC would not be well received.

The new policy, which is officially on trial, is a concession for which the Barmy Army has long lobbied. It was unveiled during the last Test, when the Barmy Army massed in the temporary stand under the scoreboard at Trent Bridge. As England batted themselves into what appeared to be an impregnable position against Zimbabwe on the Saturday, 250 Barmies shouted and cheered them on. "I'm sure our support lifted the England boys and improved their performance," says Burnham. "The atmosphere was tremendous. And just look at what happened to England on the Sunday, when there was no Barmy Army and the ground was dead as a dodo."

England eye a £365,000 bonus

There's far more at stake than money, of course, but the special bonuses awaiting the winners of the England-West Indies series are handsome. They make the prize money from sponsors Cornhill - a cheque for £21,000 to the winner of each Test, but nothing extra for the series victors - look like fairly small beer.

England's players are the ones with the sharper financial incentive to win the five-match series. Victory would bring the team an ECB bonus of £215,000, plus £30,000 for each Test they had won. As one ECB optimist put it this week: "A 5-0 win would mean £365,000 for our players."

Should the Windies take the series, their squad will share a bonus of $US 250,000 (£167,000) from their tour sponsors, Sandals resorts and Carib beer. "I'm afraid there's no bonus for a drawn series, or even for each Test the West Indies win," says a Sandals spokesman. "Our aim is to develop exciting, attacking cricket."

And now for this summer's next tourists....the US

West Indies are not this summer's only visitors from across the Atlantic. Next month the United States fly in for their first tour of England in 14 years.

The main purpose of the trip is to prepare America's (amateur) players for next year's ICC Trophy in Canada, at which they hope to qualify, for the first time, for the World Cup, in South Africa in 2003.

The Americans take on MCC, county 2nd XIs and Minor Counties opposition during their two-week trip (details: usaca.org). A multicultural 15-man party has just been named, under the captaincy of the American Alec Stewart - Raymond Denny, an experienced wicketkeeper-batsman. Kamran Khan, the manager, says: "The exciting thing is, it's a very young team. We're bringing some brilliant young players."

Khan, who captained the US in England himself, adds: "When I was a player we had tremendous talent but we never played as a team." With this in mind, the selectors have placed particular emphasis on "sportsmanlike conduct, enthusiasm and discipline".

One of the new faces in the side is actually an Englishman: Stephen Speak, an all-rounder in his mid-20s (but no relation of Durham's Nick) who will shortly become a US citizen. S Speak will surely feel a little torn if picked for the tour opener, against the Royal Household XI at Windsor Castle on July 9 - he will only just have celebrated Independence Day in his adopted country. "We're hoping," says Khan, "that, since it's a US national team, someone from the Royal Family may come and watch us." That sounds a little optimistic, but you never know.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). He can be contacted at cdelisle@ compuserve.com

webTitle: The true cost of Gulf war compensation

fields.headline: The true cost of Gulf war compensation
fields.standfirst: The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait caused financial hardship for businesses and individuals across the globe. But reparations come with their own price tag, writes Middle East editor Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait caused financial hardship for businesses and individuals across the globe. But reparations come with their own price tag, writes Middle East editor Brian Whitaker
fields.body:
Wars never come cheap. Ten years after Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, the bills are still coming in - and they're enormous. Apart from the cost of all the bullets, bombs and missiles used, and the deaths and injuries, there are thousands - perhaps millions - of people who played no part in the war but suffered financially: the poor families in Egypt who depended on remittances from relatives working in Iraq are just one example.

Many companies who were peacefully doing business in the Middle East also lost money - and by no means all of them were rich oil firms. Governments suffered, too. Jordan, for instance, which refused to join the war and was punished by the west for it, provided emergency medical facilities at its taxpayers' expense.

Back in 1991, at the end of the war, the UN decided that Iraq should pay for "losses caused by the invasion and occupation of Kuwait". Iraq agreed to this and since then, 96 countries have presented their bills, which include claims for businesses and individual victims as well as for their governments.

Kuwait is the biggest claimant. Others, more surprisingly, include Bolivia, Iceland, Nepal, Panama, Thailand, Uruguay and Vietnam.We all know how tempting it is to add a few quid to an insurance claim in the hope that no one will notice. Some countries, sniffing a honey pot, have almost certainly done that and their claims are being whittled down by teams of expert assessors.

Even so, Iraq will face a bill running into hundreds of billions of dollars which, with interest, will take several generations to pay. The only sure way to collect this money from Iraq is to extend sanctions, in some form or other, well into the 22nd century. But it would, in the eyes of many, impose a huge burden on Iraq's economy, years after Saddam is gone and dead. Is that fair?

Recall, if you can, a school history lesson about the Treaty of Versailles at the end of the first world war. It forced Germany to pay massive compensation and succeeded in building up resentment which played a large part in starting the second world war.

The alternative to sanctions would be either a gentleman's agreement on the terms for payment (and Saddam Hussein is no gentleman), or an endless series of court cases around the world which would make lawyers very rich but probably achieve little else.

If none of this sounds feasible, the only other option is to forget about compensation. But that would be unfair to Saddam's victims. It would also send a signal to other would-be Saddams that they can wreck a neighbouring country without having to pay for the damage. Compensation, like sanctions, is one of the great moral dilemmas left over from the Gulf war. Unfortunately, Saddam has no need to face such ethical questions himself. But he does understand the problems they create for his foes - and exploits them at every opportunity.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  caipirinhas
fields.body:
Those tacky-but-tasty Bacardi Breezers excepted, rum is the sort of tipple your grandma guzzles to warm her cockles before bed. Yet it's shaping up to be summer's most fashionable spirit. Cachaca, a white rum, is the vital ingredient in the Brazilian cocktail caipirinha (ki-pea-ree-nya), which style-conscious drinkers intent on exotic excess are devouring as if it were Gisele herself. The similarities between the supermodel and the super spirit are uncanny: both are of Amazonian origin, full-bodied and, taken in large doses, can make you feel quite dizzy.

Perfectly complementing this season's predilection for luxurious sophistication, the thirst for caipirinhas is growing apace. "Everybody has been asking for it - it's this summer's drink. People take their time enjoying it," says a barman at Denim in Covent Garden.

Spotted being supped by Nick Moran and the Lock, Stock boys, caipirinhas are a welcome, grown-up alternative to the near-hallucinogenic spirits favoured of late, such as tequila and absinthe. "A very famous model held a party here and caipirinha was the only drink served," says a barman at Soho hangout Circus.

Best drunk with a deep mahogany tan. Also from a bottle, of course.
