fields.headline: Ribbeck names German team
fields.trailText: Germany have made four changes to their line-up after coach Erich Ribbeck took the surprising step of naming his team to face England 24 hours early.
fields.body:
Germany have made four changes to their line-up after coach Erich Ribbeck took the surprising step of naming his team to face England 24 hours early.

Thomas Hassler, Thomas Linke and Paulo Rink have been dropped, while striker Oliver Bierhoff has been ruled out of the rest of Euro 2000 with a calf injury.

Veteran defender Lothar Matthaus, heavily criticised after his performance in Germany's opening 1-1 draw with Romania, retains his place in the team while Ribbeck will bring in 20-year-old Sebastian Deisler and Liverpool's Dietmar Hamann. In the absence of Bierhoff and Rink, Carsten Jancker and Ulf Kirsten will link up in attack.

Initial reports suggested AC Milan striker Bierhoff would be out for the last two Group A games after picking up the injury in training, but Ribbeck conceded today that the injury is more serious than previously thought. "It's a heavy blow for us," said the Germany coach. "Oliver is not only an attacker, but also our captain."

But Ribbeck was in a good mood at this morning's press conference, reminding reporters that Germany have not lost a competitive match to England for 34 years. "We have only one player who can still remember," he joked, as reporters doubled over with laughter at his reference to 39 year-old Lothar Matthaus.

And when he was asked for the reason for his good mood Ribbeck responded: "I haven't read the papers yet this morning," drawing another round of laughter.

"If nothing happens in practice, this will be the 11 that will start," Ribbeck confirmed, adding that he had picked the side early to allow his players to prepare. "When we play England, there is no need to try to confuse the opponent" he said. "But it will give our players a chance to prepare mentally for the match."

Matthaus, who is returning to fitness after a thigh injury, has promised a much better performance this time. "I can reassure everyone. I am top fit again and I feel great," he said. "I am sure I'll play much better against England."

German team: Oliver Kahn; Markus Babbel, Lothar Matthaus, Jens Nowotny, Sebastian Deisler, Christian Ziege, Dietmar Hamann, Jens Jeremies, Mehmet Scholl, Carsten Jancker, Ulf Kirsten.

webTitle: Straw seeks tougher European laws on asylum

fields.headline: Straw seeks tougher European laws on asylum
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw will today call for a Europe-wide asylum system obliging would-be refugees to submit their claims before they enter the European Union.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw will today call for a Europe-wide asylum system obliging would-be refugees to submit their claims before they enter the European Union.

Mr Straw will tell an EU conference in Lisbon that the 1951 Geneva convention needs redrafting to end the current system whereby would-be refugees apply for asylum once they have entered the EU.

The change would mean that the UK and other member states would not have to pay to support asylum seekers while their applications are processed.

"We should stick absolutely to the obligation under the 1951 convention that we do give refugee status to those who are fleeing from a well-founded fear of persecution, but what we should look at is its operation," Mr Straw told BBC radio.

"We need to stick to our fundamental obligations but we must recognise that the world has changed."

Human rights campaigners fear that asylum seekers will remain at risk in their home country or neighbouring states while their applications are processed.

Amnesty International director Kate Allen said some of the world's poorest states could be left to foot the bill for those fleeing persecution across their borders. "Jack Straw wants to turn the refugee convention on its head by making it into a charter for governments to bar asylum seekers, rather than for asylum seekers to seek refuge," she said.

The home secretary argues there is an "inherent contradiction" in the 1951 convention that pushes asylum seekers into the hands of criminal gangs running people trafficking rackets. The convention requires countries to consider any application from refugees who reach their borders, while not doing anything to help them get there. "The result is that many genuine, as well as unfounded applicants, are forced to break our immigration rules and our laws in order to have their applications considered."

Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe said she agreed with Mr Straw's call for the convention to be updated, but said he was wrong to look to the EU rather than domestic law for the answer.

"I think it is very unlikely you will get significant changes because there are a huge number of countries involved and it is unlikely that every single one will be persuaded," she said.

Mr Straw said he would propose three internationally agreed categories of risk - none, moderate and high - to enable countries to set quotas for refugees and assess whether people are real asylum-seekers or merely economic migrants.

He said asylum applications would generally not be considered from so-called "safe" countries. Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes said such a list was "incompatible with the convention".

In 1995-96 the British government spent about £420m on supporting asylum seekers. In 1999-2000 that figure rose to £590m. The waiting list for asylum applications currently stand at almost 100,000.

fields.headline: Euro divisions
fields.standfirst: The government's attitude to the single currency seems increasingly unclear. Julian Glover explains the views of the leading cabinet members
fields.trailText: The government's attitude to the single currency seems increasingly unclear. Julian Glover explains the views of the leading cabinet members.
fields.body:
What's happened recently?
Gordon Brown and Robin Cook have both made well-reported speeches referring to the likelihood of Britain joining the single currency. The chancellor's Mansion House speech, on Thursday night, made it explicitly clear that the Treasury, rather than any other department, will decide whether the time is right for Britain to join the single currency. The foreign secretary's speech, delivered hours earlier in the Commons, did not dispute this. But journalists noticed that four short passages praising the single currency - included in the draft speech handed to journalists - were not used by Robin Cook. They were quick to interpret this as the result of efforts by the prime minister to hide differences between his chancellor and the foreign secretary.

What are these differences?
On specifics, it's hard to tell. Neither the chancellor nor the foreign secretary think Britain should join the single currency immediately, and neither of them wants to rule it out all altogether. Both seem to think it sensible for the government to plan a referendum on membership at some point after the next election. Gordon Brown sets great store by the five 'tests' he has devised to determine whether the time is right to join. He explained them in detail last night. As well as many economists, Robin Cook may think these tests somewhat subjective. Unlike them, he has not said so - in public, at least.

So they really agree?
Not quite. Robin Cook and Gordon Brown might agree about the broad sweep of policy towards the euro, but they certainly disagree when it come to the matter of tone. The chancellor's early enthusiasm for the single currency, in 1997 and 1998, has been replaced by a cautious neutrality. Some people close to him think he has become an enthusiast for the American economic model. In contrast, the foreign secretary - always a pro-European - has become openly keen on joining the single currency. His draft speech, for instance, included a promise that the government 'would not let Britain lose by staying out' - words that the chancellor would be unlikely to use.

Is the government split on the issue then?
To a degree. Apart from the foreign secretary, two other leading ministers; the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, and the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, would like the government to be more openly enthusiastic about the euro. But the real issue is not a fundamental split between pro-Europeans and anti-Europeans, but a concern on the part of pro-Europeans that the single currency is not an issue on which the government should remain neutral. They think that without a clear lead from the prime minister and the chancellor, public opinion will never swing in favour of the single currency.

What about Tony Blair?
The prime minister's main concern is to maintain a united front. The last thing he wants is a public split between his chancellor and his foreign secretary as the election approaches. That's why it looks like Downing Street could have been behind Robin Cook's decision not to use the most pro-euro lines in his speech (although the foreign secretary says it was a spur-of-the-moment decision he made while speaking). Privately, Tony Blair seems keener on the euro than Gordon Brown, but he wants, at all costs, to avoid the single currency becoming an election issue. That might allow William Hague to exploit public disquiet about the subject. After the election, the prime minister hopes to call a referendum on membership - but he will only do so if he thinks it can be won.

webTitle: Des is a seedy old goat

fields.headline: Des is a seedy old goat
fields.standfirst: Jamie Rainbow, our man with right-angular eyes, advises on who to watch the England game with
fields.trailText: Jamie Rainbow, our man with right-angular eyes, advises on who to watch the England game with
fields.body:
Tomorrow, for those of you have been backpacking around the moon - so unspoilt I hear - it's England versus Germany. The main talking point - other than the football, which let's be honest will be awful - is which channel to watch the game on.

Traditionally, only employees of the company, relatives of the panel and those people who enjoy being wilfully perverse, watch ITV when an event of national significance is occurring.

But since recruiting Des Lynam, ITV have been making a big play for our affections. Along with Lynam, they have transferred in other high-profile BBC pundits including: Terry Venables, Ally McCoist (on a Bosman-style freebie, I suspect) and just to prove that they are an equal opportunities employer, Bob Wilson.

Tomorrow, they'll be offering Des alongside three former England managers; plus Ron Atkinson in the commentary box and four hours of build-up including the Romania Portugal match. As the preposterous Peter Drury suggested last night: "Saturday is ITV day."

It should be noted though that ITV could offer free pizza vouchers to all viewers, tickets to the final, a date with Jennifer Lopez and free post-match therapy in case things don't go England's way (in case? Who am I kidding?), while the BBC could screen highlights of the game in black and white with Dougie (what's wrong with plain Doug?) Donnelly presenting and Emlyn Hughes analysing and still more people would watch the match on the BBC. Oddly enough, since the BBC lost Match of the Day, such a scenario is now too plausible to be considered amusing.

Your choice of channel, I suspect, will ultimately be determined by your feelings toward Des Lynam. Des, according to a recent Guardian piece (written by his mum I presume) has sex appeal, but am I alone in thinking that there can't be many women - or men for that matter - who would find the seedy old goat sexually attractive these days?

Even the man himself seemed unconvincing when he signed off last night. "You should give yourself a break this time," he whispered seductively (his mum again), "watch it on ITV".

Unfortunately Des, unlike your good self, we're not bought that easily.

webTitle: PC fires gun on royal train

fields.headline: PC fires gun on royal train
fields.trailText: A royal protection officer accidentally discharged two shots from his gun on the royal train as the Queen and Prince Philip slept in a nearby carriage early yesterday morning.
fields.body:
A royal protection officer accidentally discharged two shots from his gun on the royal train as the Queen and Prince Philip slept in a nearby carriage early yesterday morning.

PC Michael Slade fired his 9mm Glock automatic pistol during an overnight stop in Gwent, south Wales. One bullet damaged a carpet and the other hit a coffee table, initially prompting fears of a terrorist attack.

PC Slade, a veteran firearms officer and a uniformed member of the royalty and diplomatic protection squad, was alone in his carriage at the time. It is believed he was cleaning the gun.

The incident happened as the 10-carriage train was halted overnight before a series of royal engagements in Cardiff yesterday.

An immediate inquiry was launched. A Scotland Yard spokesman said: "A police officer accidentally discharged a firearm on the royal train. There were no injuries and, as is routine, the officer has been taken off firearms duties for the time being. He has not been suspended."

The Austrian-made Glock pistol is the chosen firearm of the royal protection squad but has a notoriously light trigger.

A Buckingham Palace spokesman said the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh were told of the shooting when they awoke in the morning.

The Queen carried out her duties in Cardiff as normal, which included visiting the university where she was told about pioneering medical research on Alzheimer's disease and meningitis.

fields.headline: The royal protection squad
fields.trailText: The gunshots on the royal train yesterday were unusual in that it was a security scare triggered by the elite force which guards the royals.
fields.body:
The gunshots on the royal train yesterday were unusual in that it was a security scare triggered by the elite force which guards the royals.

Who are the royal protection squad?
The royalty and diplomatic protection group is an elite Scotland Yard squad charged with providing 24-hour security for the royal family and London's diplomatic community. Formed in 1983, it is thought that up to 185 SAS-trained officers, including uniformed officers and personal bodyguards, watch over an assortment of royals.

Who do they guard?
The royal protection squad (RPS) watch over the Queen and the immediate heirs to the throne. Before the IRA ceasefire, even the houses of the Queen's obscure cousins were given 24-hour protection. Although this had been scaled back, some fairly minor royals are still considered to merit the protection of the special officers. The Queen ordered an RPS bodyguard to be sent to Switzerland to watch over Princess Beatrice, the Duchess of York's daughter, who is being educated at a boarding school in the Alps. The Countess of Wessex Sophie Rhys-Jones has several RPS bodyguards, and was given special protection before her marriage to Prince Edward after fears of media intrusion.

Who do they not guard?
Most famously, Diana, Princess of Wales, chose to cast off the constant surveillance provided by the RPS after she divorced Prince Charles. Some security experts considered it left her dangerously exposed when she died in a Paris road accident in August 1997, although Trevor Rees-Jones, a former member of the protection squad who had joined Mohamed Al-Fayed's security set-up, was by her side.

When have they been called into action?
Protecting the royals from the threat of assassination was a hectic job in the nineteenth century. Queen Victoria was subjected to five attempts on her life. Security scares are relatively rare these days although the most minor security breaches claim plenty of coverage in the national press.

Last summer, Prince Charles was forced to alert the special officers on what the tabloids delighted in calling "his James Bond-style watch" when he was threatened with a harpoon gun while swimming in the Mediterranean. The waterproof alarm watch, believed to be worn by Prince William as well, sets off security men's pagers.

That incident was regarded as the most serious threat to a royal since 1994, when David Kang, a 23-year-old student, charged at Charles firing a starting pistol in Australia. Not knowing he was firing blanks, security men overpowered him.

The RPS has also been called into action at Buckingham Palace several times in the last twenty years when individuals managed to enter the building - one by paragliding, another by scaling up a wall via a drainpipe. On both occasions neither man posed a real threat, although after one 1982 incident a £1.6m police station was constructed next to the palace, which is now the RPS base.

The most serious incident was in 1974, when an armed man attempted to kidnap Princess Ann in the Mall, central London. Ian Ball shot the Princess's chauffeur, a bodyguard, a policeman and a passer-by before being wrestled to the ground.

The least serious incident occurred moments before the wedding of Princess Anne and Captain Tim Laurence in 1992 when Digger, an RPS sniffer dog, deposited a particularly smelly kind of present at the altar.

What does it all cost?
The price of the 24-hour protection squad is £27m a year. The Home Office cut £3m from the annual bill last year, citing a decline in terrorist activity as the reason to scale down its cost. Guarding Princes William and Harry costs £500,000 a year. Princess Beatrice's protection in Switzerland is said to cost more than £150,000 a year, while the cost of the squad's security at the wedding of Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones was put at £250,000. It is estimated that before the IRA ceasefire the annual cost of protecting some of the Queen's cousin's homes was £350,000.

webTitle: Time for churches to throw in the towel?

fields.headline: Time for churches to throw in the towel?
fields.standfirst: Faithless thieves, passengers with a pasty passion, a buzzing town centre and a trip down libbers' lane
fields.trailText: Faithless thieves, passengers with a pasty passion, a buzzing town centre and a trip down libbers' lane.
fields.body:
Religion's all washed up
It is a distressing sign of the Godless times we live in that while fewer and fewer people are going to church to worship, more and more seem to be going there to steal things. This week alone, valuable ornaments were removed from a church in Bristol, a medieval helmet from one in Bradfield, and a stained-glass window from another in Framlington.

Most gratuitous of all, 200 tea towels were recently stolen from a house of worship on Dartmoor. The towels, decorated with pictures of six local churches, were half-inched from a storeroom at St Pancras Church at Widecombe-in-the-Moor. "It's disgraceful," said one St Pancras worshipper. "Those tea-towels belonged to God. His power was in them, which is why they were so good for washing up. It's unbelievable that someone could sink this low." Although the theft was discovered only this week it could have occurred any time in the last month, and police do not hold out much hope of catching the culprits.

One local worshipper, however, is convinced that the towels will bring no joy to the people who stole them. "It was God who made them so absorbent," she chuckled, "And now he'll make sure they won't dry any more. These people's kitchens will become a hell on earth."

The pies have it
The outlook for rail travellers hasn't been too good of late, what with delayed trains, overcrowded carriages, rising fares and broken signals. This week, however, there was at least one bit of good news for commuters, although it came in an unlikely form: meat pies.

The pies have been introduced to the catering repertoire of First Great Western trains, which run from Paddington to the West Country, and managers are convinced their presence in the buffet car will dramatically improve the journey to and from London for the company's customers. "Pasties are one of Devon's favourite foods," said company catering manager David Crome, "and we felt it was time to develop one to offer on our services." The pasties, comprising a light, flaky pastry crammed with succulent Devon beef, were launched at Newton Abbott, and are part of a wider drive by First Great Western to restore public confidence after the tragedy of the Paddington rail disaster. "They've achieved just the right balance of meat and pastry," enthused one commuter. "These pasties have gone a long way to restoring my faith in rail travel."
This is Exeter

Bee afraid, bee very afraid
Following our report a couple of weeks ago about a swarm of delinquent bees causing havoc at Iford Manor, near Bath, we can now bring you news of more apian antics, this time in Knutsford, Cheshire. The trouble began when 5,000 hooligan bees descended on the city centre, sending shoppers rushing for cover and causing one man to crash his Vauxhall Sierra into a privet hedge after they swarmed in through the sunroof.

"It was like something out of a horror movie," recalled one eyewitness. "They were everywhere. It was terrifying. I just dropped my aubergines and ran." The bees loitered for some while in the town centre before eventually settling on and around a large yellow bollard, where they were rounded up by local beekeeper Theresa Curtis. "There were still a lot of them flying around," she said, "But I couldn't wait for stragglers because there was too much traffic."

It's the twelfth time a swarm of bees has descended on Knutsford this year, although not all local people are overly perturbed by the phenomena. "I actually think they're a good thing," opined one man. "Knutsford is the most boring town in Britain, and the bees give it a bit of a buzz."
Cheshire Online

The road to equality
The sex equality war took to the streets this week - literally - when a town councillor in Chichester demanded that more of the town's roads should be named after women. Liberal Democrat councillor Edith Pingree believes too many of Chichester's streets carry male names and wants to see greater recognition for some of the town's daughters.

"I am not a feminist," she insisted, "I'd just like to see a bit of equality. Traditionally streets have been named after former mayors or bishops who are all men, of course. I'd like to commemorate some deserving Chichester women, like nurses, or outstanding mothers who have brought up their children against all the odds." Eleven new streets are due to be named in the near future and Councillor Pingree has launched an appeal for people to come forward with the names of women who have played an important role in the life of the community.

"I used to know a fabulous girl from up Fishbourne way," recalled one local man. "We used to call her Martha Melons, although I somehow suspect that's not the sort of name they're looking for."
This is Mid-Sussex

Letter of the week
"Sir, police recently prosecuted a man for eating a Kit-Kat whilst driving and they charged a young lady for drinking water whilst at red traffic lights. But here's a better one which they missed.

The time: approximately 9.45am last Friday. The place: well, lets just say somewhere between Heaton and Nab Wood. As I drove along the road I saw a car in the distance, on the opposite side of the road, with hazard warning lights flashing. He must have a problem, I thought. But no! As I got nearer I saw that he was driving with one hand whilst holding a surveyor's measuring wheel on the road with the other. What a pity I didn't have my camcorder with me. It would have been a sure winner for You've Been Framed!".
Peter Rushforth, Bradford Telegraph and Argus

The pasties, comprising a light, flaky pastry crammed with succulent Devon beef, were launched at Newton Abbott, and are part of a wider drive by First Great Western to restore public confidence after the tragedy of the Paddington rail disaster. "They've achieved just the right balance of meat and pastry," enthused one commuter. "These pasties have gone a long way to restoring my faith in rail travel." This is Exeter Bee afraid, bee very afraid Following our report a couple of weeks ago about a swarm of delinquent bees causing havoc at Iford Manor, near Bath, we can now bring you news of more apian antics, this time in Knutsford, Cheshire. The trouble began when 5,000 hooligan bees descended on the city centre, sending shoppers rushing for cover and causing one man to crash his Vauxhall Sierra into a privet hedge after they swarmed in through the sunroof. "It was like something out of a horror movie," recalled one eyewitness. "They were everywhere. It was terrifying. I just dropped my aubergines and ran." The bees loitered for some while in the town centre before eventually settling on and around a large yellow bollard, where they were rounded up by local beekeeper Theresa Curtis. "There were still a lot of them flying around," she said, "But I couldn't wait for stragglers because there was too much traffic." It's the twelfth time a swarm of bees has descended on Knutsford this year, although not all local people are overly perturbed by the phenomena. "I actually think they're a good thing," opined one man. "Knutsford is the most boring town in Britain, and the bees give it a bit of a buzz." Cheshire Online The road to equality The sex equality war took to the streets this week - literally - when a town councillor in Chichester demanded that more of the town's roads should be named after women. Liberal Democrat councillor Edith Pingree believes too many of Chichester's streets carry male names and wants to see greater recognition for some of the town's daughters. "I am not a feminist," she insisted, "I'd just like to see a bit of equality. Traditionally streets have been named after former mayors or bishops who are all men, of course. I'd like to commemorate some deserving Chichester women, like nurses, or outstanding mothers who have brought up their children against all the odds." Eleven new streets are due to be named in the near future and Councillor Pingree has launched an appeal for people to come forward with the names of women who have played an important role in the life of the community. "I used to know a fabulous girl from up Fishbourne way," recalled one local man. "We used to call her Martha Melons, although I somehow suspect that's not the sort of name they're looking for." This is Mid-Sussex Letter of the week "Sir, police recently prosecuted a man for eating a Kit-Kat whilst driving and they charged a young lady for drinking water whilst at red traffic lights. But here's a better one which they missed. The time: approximately 9.45am last Friday. The place: well, lets just say somewhere between Heaton and Nab Wood. As I drove along the road I saw a car in the distance, on the opposite side of the road, with hazard warning lights flashing. He must have a problem, I thought. But no! As I got nearer I saw that he was driving with one hand whilst holding a surveyor's measuring wheel on the road with the other. What a pity I didn't have my camcorder with me. It would have been a sure winner for You've Been Framed!". Peter Rushforth, Bradford Telegraph and Argus

fields.headline: Heatwaves
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the forthcoming weekend scorcher
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the forthcoming weekend scorcher
fields.body:
1. First the good news: it's going to be a baking hot weekend in many parts of Britain, with the Met Office predicting temperatures up to 27 degrees. In old money, that's the high eighties.

2. The not-so-good news is that there is a north-south divide. While London sizzles, Glasgow will be on the dull side, and Inverness could be downright dreary.

3. The bad news is that while most of us gambol in the sun, there will be much wringing of hands in environment-hugging circles about global warming and climate change.

4. The twentieth century was the hottest of the last millennium and it's showing no signs of cooling down in the first year of the new millennium.

5. Although most people in Britain would probably vote for a bit of warm weather, some experts say it could be bad for us. Others say it could be even worse.

6. Campaign groups like Friends of the Earth want us all to do our bit to arrest global warming.

7. The government, too, is doing its bit, with a range of initiatives and agreements like the Kyoto agreement on greenhouse gas emissions.

8. Among the myriad weather watchers around the world, is our very own Hadley Centre for Climate Research at Bracknell, producing detailed and rather scary predictions for the years ahead.

9. In the rather more immediate future, according to a poll taken by Virgin Radio, a great many people are going to bunk off work on Monday if it stays nice.

10. The really, really bad news is that it's not going to. But keep checking here to make sure.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: Day seven

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: Day seven
fields.standfirst: Four men, armed with £50, aim to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. It's You Bet Your Life, brought to you in association with BlueSq.
fields.trailText: Yesterday's tedious 0-0 draw between Sweden and Turkey was bad news for everyone, except Scott Murray of course. The man who obviously has too much time on his hands is sitting pretty at the top of the leaderboard as we head into day seven...
fields.body:
Yesterday's tedious 0-0 draw between Sweden and Turkey was bad news for everyone, except Scott Murray of course. The man who obviously has too much time on his hands is sitting pretty at the top of the leaderboard as we head into day seven...

Scott Murray: £86.67

Mike Hodgkinson: £63.73

Sean Ingle: £54.36

Paul MacInnes: £33

Scott Murray

France v Czech Republic: Half-time/full-time Draw/France 4/1 (£5)

In every tournament, there's always one team which enjoys hellish luck and is sent home early without doing much wrong. After losing to Holland when they deserved no less than a victory, it looks like it could be the turn of the Czechs this time. A repeat travesty against France looks value to me, but because the Czechs deserve better, I'll have mixed feelings if it comes up. Not that mixed, of course.

Mike Hodgkinson

Holland v Denmark Half-time/full-time Denmark/Holland 28-1 (£5)

Denmark start most of their games like a large red and white train going very fast indeed. Most of their goals in competition come in the first five minutes - Ebbe Sand missed a sitter very early on against France - so it may be worth chancing the Danes to take a lead into half time, then blow it all in the second half after Frank Rijkaard has given his side a massive bollocking. And, statistically, the Hollanders do most of their scoring in the second half of competitive matches. Massive odds, very risky, but also very possible.

Sean Ingle

France v Czech Republic draw (9/4) and Holland to beat Denmark (4/9) (£5 double)

Remember ITV's quirky lunch-time show 'Quandary?' Well, that's what I'm experiencing at the moment. You see Paul MacInnes, who - lest we forget - is currently propping up the 'You bet your life' standings, has gone for France to draw and Holland to win, which means it's bound to fail. Miserably.

But I also think he'll be right. Oh, what the hellhere goes. Holland, for all their internal strife, should slice through Denmark. And the Czech Republic should run the French very close and possibly grab a draw. The double pays nearly 5-1 which is why my fiver's on it.

Paul MacInnes

Holland to beat Denmark and France to draw with Czech Republic at roughly 5/1 (£5 double)

Yesterday I wagered a fiver on there being a fair few cards in the Turkey game. Of course I realise now that expecting anything, even bad tackles, in last night's snorefest was a bit optimistic. So for tonight's loss I am returning to the simpler world of predicting results. Simpler in the sense that it's easier to get it wrong, of course.

Anyway, after the all the commotion surrounding Sunday's lethargic display by the Dutch, I expect them to turn it on against the average Danes, and run out winners. The outcome of the France v Czech Republic game is more difficult to call, but while I can see the Czechs piling on the pressure, I can't see the world champs losing - so a draw it is. Put the two predictions together in a nice little double and what have you got? That's right, more money dribbling out of my account.

fields.headline: Adjani snubs state dinner
fields.trailText: The French film star Isabelle Adjani has boycotted a state dinner honoring the Algerian president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, because of what she said were continuing human rights abuses in the country
fields.body:
The French film star Isabelle Adjani has boycotted a state dinner honoring the Algerian president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, because of what she said were continuing human rights abuses in the country.

In an interview published yesterday in Libération, Adjani, whose father was Algerian, said she turned down the invitation because she refused to be an "accomplice" and accused Mr Bouteflika of trying to forget atrocities.

"There's still no justice worthy of that name in Algeria and 10,000 people are still missing," she said. "The government says the guilty parties have been killed or cannot be found, and whole families are attending sham trials. Meanwhile, Mr Bouteflika is in Paris receiving the highest honours."

It is not the first time the star of films such as La Reine Margot and Camille Claudel has spoken out about human rights.

In a 1998 visit to Algeria, she attacked officials who had, she claimed, perpetuated the atrocities they suffered under French colonial rule.

webTitle: Bigelow settles with Besson over Joan of Arc

fields.headline: Bigelow settles with Besson over Joan of Arc
fields.trailText: Kathryn Bigelow has settled out of court with Luc Besson over claims that the French film-maker stole her research and script for his 1999 movie The Messenger: The Story of Joan of Arc
fields.body:
Kathryn Bigelow, director of Strange Days and Point Break, has settled out of court with Luc Besson over claims that the French film-maker stole her research and script for his 1999 movie The Messenger: The Story of Joan of Arc.

Greg Dovel, who represented Kathryn Bigelow in her Los Angeles Superior Court lawsuit against Besson, said the terms of the settlement were confidential. "All I can tell you is that the parties have settled amicably and Mrs Bigelow is satisfied," he said.

Bigelow had worked with Besson on her Joan of Arc script before they fell out over Besson's choice of his then wife, actress Milla Jovovich (pictured), for the lead role. She claimed in her lawsuit that Besson then stole her historical research along with many original elements of her script.

Bigelow has the last laugh in any event: Besson's film and Jovovich's acting attracted critical derision on its release, and it flopped at the box office.

webTitle: Academy turns its back on internet movies

fields.headline: Academy turns its back on internet movies
fields.trailText: The Academy of Motion Pictures Arts & Sciences, which administers the Oscars, announced yesterday that internet-based shorts will not be eligible for Oscar consideration because they were premiered on the internet
fields.body:
Far from embracing what many see as the future of films and indeed perhaps the greatest revolution in film-making since the introduction of 'the talkies', the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts & Sciences, which administers the Oscars, has opted to continue to back good old-fashioned theatrical movies. The Academy announced yesterday that internet-based shorts like Mission: Imp and Frying Private Fryan (which premiered on the ifilm network) will not be eligible for Oscar consideration because they were premiered on the internet.

The Academy's announcement underlines the rule that "films which receive their first public exhibition or distribution in any manner other than as a theatrical motion picture release will not be eligible for Academy Awards in any category." The bylaws will now read, "This includes broadcast and cable television, as well as home video marketing and internet transmission."

Academy executive director Bruce Davis told Variety: "The board just wants to make it crystal clear, so that in the rush to embrace new technologies, a legitimate theatrical motion picture doesn't inadvertently jeopardise its eligibility."

In another change for next year's 73rd annual Oscar awards, foreign-language films that are submitted, but not nominated one year, will now be eligible the following year in other categories.

John Pavlik, the Academy's director of communications, explained that Run Lola Run had prompted that particular change in the rules.

"The film was submitted by Germany for the 71st Academy Awards, yet it had not yet opened in LA. It was released here in 1999 and was not able to resubmit." But many thought the frenetic crime drama could have been a contender in several Oscar categories.

"Under these new rules, the committee is giving excellent films as many chances as they can," said Pavlik.

webTitle: England face grim battle for survival

fields.headline: England face grim battle for survival
fields.standfirst:
England 179
West Indies 336 for 7
fields.trailText: Thrillingly at first, painstakingly later and with a flourish at the end, West Indies have established a position from which they ought to win the first test match.
fields.body:
Thrillingly at first, painstakingly later and with a flourish at the end, West Indies have established a position from which they ought to win the first test match.

Two wickets down overnight, they scored 68 in the first hour before England gained a measure of control. Defending a first innings of only 179, England bowled willingly for the most part - and Darren Gough in particular with enormous heart - and chipped away. No West Indian batsman, once established, was able to go on to make the large score that would have proved definitive in the context of the match, although Jimmy Adams may yet do so.

This was team batting, however. Half-centuries of varying character from Brian Lara, Sherwin Campbell, Shivnarine Chanderpaul and Adams, who has batted with unflagging patience for 4 hours to make 66 not out, hauled West Indies past England and away.

Later in the evening sunshine, as the bowling tired, England were thwarted further by their own incapacity to rattle tailenders. Curtly Ambrose joined his captain and made merry with a seventh-wicket stand of 56 and after Ambrose was dismissed by Robert Croft for 22, Adams and Franklyn Rose added 43 for the eighth without being parted, Rose having already hit five fours and a straight six off Croft in his 33.

Why cannot English bowlers find it in their souls to go for the jugular when tail-enders are at the crease? Only when Andy Caddick finally decided to bounce Ambrose and when Gough's accidental beamer hit the same batsman on the right hand did they look discomfited.

At 336 for seven, West Indies have a lead of 157. England will need to bat their socks off if they are to take this match even into tomorrow. They have never been at their best playing catch-up cricket - although goodness only knows they have had enough practice - but might have fancied their chances more had not successive deliveries from Caddick, armed with the second new ball, not hit Adams on the left elbow and then on the toe of his bat as he dug out a shooter, both deliveries pitching in roughly the same place.

The cracks on the pitch are already opening up in the heat, and it is the variable bounce this generates, particularly when accentuated by tall bowlers of high pace, that is the stuff of nightmares for batsmen. Survival against Courtney Walsh, Ambrose, Rose and Reon King will be desperately hard today.

The England bowlers had a mixed day. Gough puffed out his chest and led magnificently from the front - he is the beating heart of his team - and for a period of time, after Campbell and Lara had threatened to run riot, found an unexpected ally in Andy Flintoff, who ran in aggressively, found impressively muscular pace, but lost nothing in accuracy. It is his bowling rather than his batting that is looking test class.

Caddick and Ed Giddins were a disappointment, though, with the former not learning from the lesson of Ambrose on Thursday and bowling too short, and the latter unable to find the snaking swing of his Lord's triumph. More worrying was the way Caddick's shoulders slumped when under the cosh from Chanderpaul and his inability, or unwillingness, to rattle Ambrose's cage until too late. It was like revisiting times past.

Croft unveiled a bewildering display of new toys - loop balls delivered from barely above waist height, skidders, use of the crease - and gave the batsmen food for thought but found no more joy than the old flat version until he hit Ambrose on the back leg while offering no shot and gained an lbw decision.

Lara played memorably for an hour and a half, but it was Gough's response that was England's most impressive feature, not just of the day but perhaps of the season so far. He had removed Campbell's off stump after the opener and Lara had taken their third-wicket partnership to 99, and then watched as Lara, driving with remarkable power and uncanny sense of placement, reached a half-century from 88 balls with nine boundaries.

In his next over, from nowhere, he produced a bouncer of such pace and skidding accuracy that Lara was dumped unceremoniously on his backside as he swayed out of the way.

Lara countered by taking his massive backlift almost to the stratosphere, and launching into such an extravagant square drive that he spun off balance. For once, his peripheral vision deserted him and he found a fielder.

Gough knew that he was rattled. The fielders clapped their hands in urgent encouragement and the bowler responded with a delivery that bounced, finding the edge and consigning Lara to the pavilion. It was a wicket taken by sheer force of personality, reducing West Indies to 136 for four.

One more wicket and the tail was exposed. It did not materialise, however, as Chanderpaul and Adams dug in with a fifth-wicket stand of 94, ended only when with tea and the second new ball imminent.

Flintoff gained reward for effort and had Chanderpaul caught at the wicket for 73. Twenty-two times Chanderpaul has reached a half-century and only twice has he converted it to three figures. For such a good player, there is something wrong here.

webTitle: Spielberg to mediate in Dieter dispute

fields.headline: Spielberg to mediate in Dieter dispute
fields.trailText: Steven Spielberg has taken on the role of mediator in the ongoing dispute between Mike Myers and Universal Studios
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg has taken on the role of mediator in the ongoing dispute between Mike Myers (pictured) and Universal Studios. As we reported last week, Universal is suing Myers for walking away from the feature Dieter, a comedy based on Myers's Saturday Night Live sketch, 'sprockets'. Myers promptly threatened to counter-sue the studio for fraud.

But Hollywood Reporter relates that Spielberg is hoping that his intervention could mean that the whole nasty business would be resolved amicably. His involvement could also mean that Dreamworks could then take a stake in the film, and the project would survive.

Spielberg apparently intervened at the request of his Dreamworks colleague Jeffrey Katzenberg, who has been working with Myers on the forthcoming computer-animated feature Shrek, to which Myers has lent his voice. A spokesman for Spielberg said it was a case of "one friend helping another", while Myers's lawyer has said that a lawsuit could still be filed against Universal if no agreement is reached.

Universal filed its suit against Myers on June 6, claiming that he had abandoned the project on which $3.8m has already been spent, but Myers, who looked to make $20m from the film, said the script still needed work and that Universal had no case to sue as he had final script approval.

As we reported last week, Universal is suing Myers for walking away from the feature Dieter, a comedy based on Myers's Saturday Night Live sketch, 'sprockets'. Myers promptly threatened to counter-sue the studio for fraud. But Hollywood Reporter relates that Spielberg is hoping that his intervention could mean that the whole nasty business would be resolved amicably. His involvement could also mean that Dreamworks could then take a stake in the film, and the project would survive. Spielberg apparently intervened at the request of his Dreamworks colleague Jeffrey Katzenberg, who has been working with Myers on the forthcoming computer-animated feature Shrek, to which Myers has lent his voice. A spokesman for Spielberg said it was a case of "one friend helping another", while Myers's lawyer has said that a lawsuit could still be filed against Universal if no agreement is reached. fields.headline: One life. One shop
fields.standfirst: First came lifestyle magazines. Now come lifestyle stores. Clothes, candles, CDs, coffee: everything a shopper's heart could desire - in one hit.  Hadley Freeman reports
fields.trailText: First came lifestyle magazines. Now come lifestyle stores. Clothes, candles, CDs, coffee: everything a shopper's heart could desire - in one hit. Hadley Freeman reports
fields.body:
Forget about getting a life; these days, it's all about shopping for a lifestyle. From the clothes you wear to the magazines you read to the CDs you buy, your possessions speak volumes about who you are. Designers such as Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein and Versace have been quick to cash in on the trend for head-to-toe designer living, offering paint, homeware and furniture respectively. Gone are the days of feathering your nest with any old tat.

On Manhattan's Madison Avenue, DKNY's flagship store opened nine months ago, directly opposite the department store Barney's - the old style of shopping confronted by the new. DKNY's enormous window displays promise a life based on the American dream: mannequins in brightly coloured linen outfits lounge decorously on painted beach furniture, piles of art books scattered at their plastic feet.

Inside is a glimpse of a way of life designed entirely by sleek Manhattanite Donna Karan: sunglasses, watches, crockery and candles are laid out in little vignettes, all colour-coordinated to match the nearest rack of clothes. These are interspersed with art installations, an eclectic selection of CDs (Kid Loco, Ben and Jason, Sneaker Pimps) and trendy magazines (i.D., Interview, Out). For decoration, beach chairs, bonsai trees and vases of oversized flowers are placed carefully around the store's three levels. You can even pick up a DKNY surfboard or a DKNY motorcycle. And that's not to mention the overflowing rails of DKNY clothes.

According to Anjali Lewis, vice president of marketing and communications at DKNY: "This is a complete lifestyle environment. Donna Karan is not just about clothing, it's about your whole life. We've learned that the consumer really wants to walk in and not just pick up a pair of jeans, but be able to shop for books, buy flowers, have a juice, meet friends."

Although the store stocks mainly DKNY products, there are also accessories by lesser-known designers and vintage dresses selected by "the lifestyle buying department". "Donna loves all things well-designed, so we look for great products that marry well with our philosophy." Which is? "Basic, beautifully designed products that Donna craves."

It is only within the past five years that lifestyle stores have taken off, following the rise of the so-called lifestyle magazines. As well as DKNY in New York, there is Corso Como in Milan and, most famously, Colette in Paris. "It was a time when lots of people were complaining that Paris was dead and moving to New York or London," recalls Sarah ("We never say our last names"), daughter of the eponymous Colette. "My mother and I knew we wanted something new for our city, to provide products and designs you couldn't get here. Now it has become part of a new generation of fashion that has rescued Paris."

Colette opened in March 1997 "and it just took off right away". Its concept is to stock the best products and designer names from around the world: the coffee served in the cafe is from Harvey Nichols, there is a mini Bumble and Bumble hair salon, the restaurant has multinational dishes. "It is a way of mixing products from various collections, mixing fashion with music with food with design," Sarah explains. "It is a place appealing to all kinds of customers."

The result is like a museum devoted to how the beautiful people live in the 21st century. Chloe sunglasses, Prada kitten heels, Michael Kors cashmere jumpers, Anya Hindmarch wallets, Michel Perry shoes and international magazines such as sleazenation and Nylon are laid out in glass cases, while dummies are decked out in Jeremy Scott. The layout, like that of DKNY, makes even a simple candlestick seem like an object of desire. Ultimately, both have the same aim: to provide the diversity of a department store but with more unusual products and in a more appealing, intimate environment.

While Paris, New York and Milan have long had successful lifestyle boutiques, leading to the logical conclusion of the larger lifestyle store, similar boutiques have only recently arrived in London. Joseph and Brown's have been selling an eclectic range of clothes since the 70s ("Joseph's Sloane Street cafe opened in 1984, a long time before Colette," Sidonie Schoeff, spokesperson for Joseph, points out), but in the past three years there has been a blossoming of these tiny boutiques around the capital. s and m on Primrose Hill sells all things cutting edge, from Hysteric Glamour T-shirts to David Bailey photographs; The Cross in W11 is well-loved for its eclectic labels and accessories; at The Pineal Eye in Soho, you can pick up Japanese gadgetry or deconstructed Belgian clothing, as you can at Kokon To Zai, around the corner.

But size is not the only aspect that differentiates Britain's boutiques from the lifestyle stores overseas. While Colette stocks designers such as Prada and Marc Jacobs, a customer at Mimi on Chelsea's King's Road, for example, will find smaller labels such as Boyd and Paul and Joe. (All still, however, at forbiddingly exclusive prices: the discerning shopper could easily spend £650 in any of these shops and walk out with only three items.)

"Parisians are more chic, more label-focused," says Philine Dumba, PR spokesperson for Brown's. "Londoners like more unusual clothing. At boutiques you can find more one-offs. We often buy only one or two pieces from a new designer. The buyers for boutiques know exactly what the customers want, making it an easier way to shop," she adds. "Department stores are such a headache, going up and down those escalators."

With the growing popularity of these boutiques, and the success of their overseas predecessors, a lifestyle store in London on the scale of those in New York and Paris seems inevitable, even necessary, if London is to maintain its reputation as a fashion capital. Indeed, there is already the similarly conceived Urban Outfitters on Kensington High Street and the large DKNY store on Bond Street, "which will shortly become more lifestyle oriented," Lewis promises. Unquestionably, these stores were created in response to the decline of the department store and, more importantly, the rise of shopping on the internet. Somehow, retailers had to entice people away from their computers and they are doing it by offering variety, a social centre and the suggestion that the customer is not merely shopping but buying into a desirable lifestyle.

"Whether you go in and buy a lot or go in and hang out all day, we've moved you somehow and that's the aim - to touch you emotionally," Lewis says. At last, the old It Girl maxim has become a reality: shopping really is life.

fields.standfirst: Reasons to be patriotic; more poll sabotaging action; and a return to Vladimir Smicer's lair
fields.trailText: Reasons to be patriotic; more poll sabotaging action; and a return to Vladimir Smicer's lair
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"Die beiden haben bewiesen, dass sie sehr gut zusammen spielen können und auch die richtigen Stürmer sind auf den kommenden Gegner bezogen." Carsten Jancker. We don't know what he's saying, but it sends a chill down the spine all the same.

THE EURO-TORIAL

Some wounds take a long time to heal. And Kevin Keegan's England team will be acutely aware of the past when they take to the field against Germany in Charleroi tomorrow evening. We must never forgive the Germans for what they have done and we must punish them on the field for it. Because, let's not forget, 99 Red Balloons by Nena was one of the worst records of the eighties and almost certainly the poorest number one of all time.

Now that we've got the jingoism out of the way, here's a fact: England will beat Germany if they play at a high tempo. It must be said that for all the talk of a Teutonic demise, the Germans are not that threadbare. They still have more players than England who are comfortable with the ball at their feet. Despite their performance in the first half against Romania, their defence is also as tight as England's (they conceded only four goals in qualifying while England conceded five). But what Germany don't have, in abundance, is pace.

As Adrian Ilie showed on Monday, slip the ball behind Markus Babbel or Jens Nowotny and they're in trouble. The midfield has been reshuffled but, with the possible exception of Sebastien Deisler, they won't have Maurice Greene awake at nights. The striking partnership of Ulf Kirsten and Carsten Jancker will offer a powerful physical presence but little else. And, heck, why not say it: Lothar Matthaus is going to play.

If England set about the game at the right tempo the Germans will have no response. But to get this level of performance you need the right personnel. If we assume that Keown is in for Adams, the second sensible change would be to replace Steve McManaman with the equally effervescent Nick Barmby. Keegan should then do us all a favour and bring in the 'little terrier' (copyright Brian Moore) Dennis Wise in place of Paul Ince. And whatever he does, Keegan should not drop Michael Owen. All England then need to do is play like Manchester United. Easy, innit.

You can get all the lyrics to Nena's cold war classic here

LOTHAR'LL FIX IT

It's the latest footballing sensation to sweep across the nation. That's right, rigging polls on foreign websites has got offices everywhere a-thrilling and Euro towers is no different. Today we have mostly been clicking on a poll in German site Sport1, the sporting home of top tabloid Bild. Their poll wants to know where Lothar Matthaus should spend the game against England tomorrow. The options are: a) defence; b) midfield; c) the bank; or d) New York.

New York is currently hot favourite with 46.6% of the vote, but we suggest that a resounding call for Lothar to play in defence would surely remove any lingering doubts from the mind of Erich Ribbeck. Get polling now you crazy funsters!

http://www.sport1.de/verteilseite_dhtml.jhtml/Main.html

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

Football and beer. They go together like... well, top sporting action and a tasty liquid beverage. Win a crate of beer for Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

German coach Erich Ribbeck has named his team to face England tomorrow night. It is: Oliver Kahn; Markus Babbel, Lothar Matthaeus, Jens Nowotny; Sebastian Deisler, Christian Ziege, Dietmar Hamann, Jens Jeremies, Mehmet Scholl, Carsten Jancker, Ulf Kirsten. His team then named him: "Little Lothar's little friend", " Help the Aged" and "Mr No Job".

Frank Rijkaard has accused his Dutch players of not being committed enough after a disappointing start to the tournament. "My players prefer to play cards and have been taking little interest in what is happening elsewhere, and that has disappointed me." When asked for comment the Dutch players said: "What is a royal flush? Is that when you've got six cards of the same suit?"

Didier Deschamps believes the Premiership is a complete doss. "This year in England I had the impression of playing at 50% of my qualities," the French international told L'Equipe. Fortunately for the water carrier, nobody else had noticed.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

"Arhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh, it's too painful, Vladimir! Stop it, I beg you!"

"But Karel, I have not yet flicked the switch to send those thousand volts zinging around your spindly little frame."

"I know, but you telling me that Chris Sutton is going to Middlesbrough for £6m is too much to bare. £6m for him?! You know I like the North East of England. I like its people. And I like its women, especially Vera, who I met at the Captain Cook Memorial museum in Whitby back in 1997. They don't deserve this!"

"But that's not all Karel - Leeds United are lining up a £7.5m bid for Nick Barmby."

"No-oooo!!! £7.5m? For him? But what about me, Vladimir. Surely somebody wants me?

"HA, HA, HA, HA, HA, HA!"

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC 1: MoTD Live: Czech Republic v France (4.45pm) Cheer up Gary - there's always the FA Cup to look forward to.

ITV: Live Netherlands v Denmark (7.30pm) And look, Des is smiling again?

ITV: England v Germany - the First Hundred Years. (10pm) Even though he's got to present this - "tongue-in-cheek" account of Anglo-German relations. But wasn't modern Germany born in 1871?

BBC 1: MOTD at Euro 2000 (11.40pm) A neat, one hour digest of today's play, with Ray Stubbs.

BBC 1: Euro 2000 (12.45pm) A flabby three hour Ray Stubbsathon, also with Ray Stubbs.

ITV: The Big Match Czech Republic v France (1.50pm) For one night only, Sideshow Bob dusts down his dinner jacket goes to Prague and performs your favourite Edith Piaf melodies. In Flemish?

Radio 5 Live: Football (4.45 and 7.30) With Alan Green on backing vocals, and Mike Ingham on percussion.

fields.headline: Steel giant axes 1,500 jobs
fields.trailText: Steel company Corus - formerly British Steel - is to cut almost 1,500 staff in a move to reduce costs in the face of expected heavy losses, it was announced today.
fields.body:
Steel company Corus - formerly British Steel - is to cut almost 1,500 staff in a move to reduce costs in the face of expected heavy losses, it was announced today.

The firm will axe 1,200 jobs from its engineering steels section, mainly affecting plants at Rotherham and Stocksbridge, in South Yorkshire. Another 230 jobs will go under plans to restructure its technology research business, which will affect Port Talbot, in South Wales, and Teesside.

Unions had been fearing much bigger cuts, but still reacted with dismay and urged the government to hold a special steel summit to discuss the future of the industry. Corus said it hoped the restructuring programme would reduce costs through an upgrading of facilities and more flexible working.

The moves should provide a sound basis for the future of the business, said Corus, which was formed last year by the merger of British Steel and Dutch firm Hoogovens. Of the 1,200 engineering job losses, 620 will be at Rotherham and 320 at Stocksbridge. All the jobs will go by the end of next year and analysts believe the restructuring, including redundancy payments, will cost Corus between £30 million and £40 million.

The company produces financial figures later this month, which the City believes will show losses of up to £150 million for the first six months of Corus's existence up to March of this year.

"We are aiming to compete more effectively because over the last five years we have seen UK demand come down 20% as, increasingly, manufacturing moves offshore into mainland Europe," said a company spokesman. Corus said the strong pound had "exacerbated" the position but stressed the main problem had been a fundamental change in the market which the company could not ignore.

Union leaders said the job losses would be a "huge blow" to many communities and pledged to fight compulsory redundancies. Michael Leahy, general secretary of the ISTC steelworkers union, said: "Without consultation and at a time when the company's prospects of achieving a profit this year are improving as rapidly as the pound is falling against the euro, Corus has gone for a quick fix. The company is throwing away opportunities which have been hard won by a workforce whose productivity gains over two decades are unsurpassed in Europe."

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said it would be very difficult to recreate the jobs which were being axed.

fields.body:
Anglo-Dutch steel maker Corus Group Plc will announce "substantial" job cuts today, triggered in part by the strength of the pound, a union official said.

"We don't have the details yet but we fear they will be substantial...possibly more than 1,200," said a spokesman for the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union.

A company spokeswoman declined immediate comment.

Corus, formerly British Steel, is expected to cut 1,200 jobs at its engineering steels operation in northern England, as part of an ongoing efficiency drive - but total losses throughout the company could reach 3,000, according to some media reports. Corus, Europe's largest steelmaker, formed last October through the combination of British Steel and Hoogovens, has been hard hit by the strength of sterling reducing the competitiveness of its UK plants.

The engineering steels division, which supplies the vehicle and components industry, employs a total of 4,000 people in Rotherham and neighbouring Sheffield in northern England.

fields.headline: 'Assassination attempt' on Serb opposition leader
fields.trailText:
An unidentified gunman shot and wounded Serbian opposition leader Vuk Draskovic as he holidayed in
the Yugoslav republic of Montenegro, an official from his party said this morning.
 
"Just before midnight, a new assassination attempt was made on Vuk Draskovic. Several volleys were fired through the window of
his house in Budva," Milena Popovic, head of the press office of Mr Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement, said. "Vuk was hit by two bullets, but fortunately he was only slightly wounded."
fields.body:
An unidentified gunman shot and wounded Serbian opposition leader Vuk Draskovic as he holidayed in the Yugoslav republic of Montenegro, an official from his party said this morning. "Just before midnight, a new assassination attempt was made on Vuk Draskovic. Several volleys were fired through the window of his house in Budva," Milena Popovic, head of the press office of Mr Draskovic's Serbian Renewal Movement, said. "Vuk was hit by two bullets, but fortunately he was only slightly wounded."

Mr Draskovic was taken to hospital but later discharged himself after treatment for minor head wounds, Belgrade's independent Beta news agency quoted a hospital spokesman as saying.

Mr Draskovic, a charismatic maverick who claims more popular support than any other opposition leader in Serbia, alleges that the government tried to kill him last year in a road accident that killed four close aides.

Mr Draskovic regularly accuses the authorities of "state terror" over last year's car crash, in which he was slightly injured. Officials have denied having anything to do with the incident, in which a truckload of sand veered into two cars carrying Mr Draskovic and his friends. Police say they have not been able to find the driver or the owner of the truck.

The latest shooting follows a string of mysterious assassinations of officials and underworld figures in Belgrade. Earlier this month, the security adviser to Montenegro's pro-Western president was gunned down in similar circumstances shortly before a key local election.

Mr Milosevic's government blames the killings on western agents it says are intent on destroying and then occupying Serbia. It has cracked down on dissent this year, accusing Mr Draskovic and other opposition leaders, who have been campaigning to oust Mr Milosevic since last year's Nato air strikes against Yugoslavia over the repression of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, of "terrorism". Earlier this month the government took over the television station in Belgrade which Mr Draskovic controls through his party's leadership of the city council. It later also took over the public transport service in the city, after opposition activists urged Mr Draskovic to use the buses to blockade government buildings.

fields.headline: Robin Cook's speech
fields.standfirst: This edited version of the foreign secretary's speech published on the FCO's website has removed the key phrases Robin Cook omitted
fields.trailText: Madam Speaker,
fields.body:
Madam Speaker,

When this Government took office we gave a commitment that we would make Britain a leading player in Europe. In the three years since then, we have taken Britain off the sidelines of Europe and made it one of the leading players in the team.

Britain is now in the driver's seat on the big issues before the European Councils - we were in the driving seat on enlargement at Helsinki, we were on economic reform at Lisbon and we will again be on European security at Feira.

EUROPEAN SECURITY

European security is a British initiative. The Prime Minister launched it at the Portschach Summit and we then took it forward in alliance with France and Germany. Two years later we can look back with satisfaction at how well that initiative has prospered and at the consensus within Europe we have built around what was a British idea.

The European Union has helped to make possible half a century of unprecedented peace between its members. Integration between our economies has made unthinkable war between our countries. A common commitment to democracy and the rule of law has promoted stability and placed a barrier in the way of extremism.

At Feira, we will agree to detailed arrangements for cooperation between Europe and NATO. In particular, we will approve the basis for participation in European crisis management by the six members of NATO who are European countries but not European Union members. They will have the right to be consulted before the European Union initiates any crisis operation, the right to participate in it, and the same rights in its management as any other participant. I met all of these six countries at Florence at the NATO meeting. They recognise that this is an excellent outcome for them and they also recognise that they would not have achieved that outcome if it had not been for the leading role that Britain played on the security agenda.

Concern that a European Security Defence Policy might result in conflict with NATO is misplaced. Territorial defence will remain a job only for NATO, and the European Union will only launch an intervention when it as a whole is not engaged.

Our higher standing in Europe has not only enabled us to take forward proposals in Britain's interests but they have also enabled us to see off proposals that could be damaging to Britain's interests.

Last year, we were under pressure to agree to a withholding tax across Europe. This year, we have won the argument. There is not going to be a European withholding tax. Britain has secured majority support for our view that the better way forward is through increased transparency and exchange of information. Now it is the four member states who still resist greater transparency who are under pressure to agree to our proposals. My RHF the Chancellor deserves credit for having turned round the argument and ensured the continuing success of Britain's financial industry.

The European Council will also confirm Greece as a member of the Euro zone. This will reduce to three the member states outside the Euro. Denmark will hold a referendum on whether it should join in September and Sweden may take the same decision in 2002.

THE EURO

Plainly Britain can only join the euro if the conditions are right. But we will only be ready for that event if we prepare now and if, when the time comes, we decide, on the basis of economic tests.

As my RHF the Chancellor, said in his statement to the House 'the potential benefits for Britain of a successful single currency are obvious, in terms of trade, transparency of costs and currency stability'. It is obvious because the euro zone is the market for the greater part of our exports and it is our access to Europe that is by far the largest incentive for inward investment.

Our bottom line will be whether membership of Europe will assist in meeting our goal of full employment.

DECLARATION OF FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS

The Feira Council will also hear a report on work in progress to develop a declaration of fundamental rights. The report will be given by Roman Herzog, the Chair of the Convention preparing the Charter. He said:

'The Charter would create no new powers for the EU over its member states. It would apply only to EU institutions without imposing new rights and the Charter was not the kernel of a European constitution.'

There is absolutely no reason why Britain, of all nations, should run scared of discussions on fundamental rights. Britain is after all one of the cradles of European freedom and liberty. Britain took the lead in the drafting of the European Convention on Human Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

Europe already has in the ECHR a legally binding code for members states. We want to make sure that it remains the sole legal guarantee. A separate legal text could undermine, not strengthen, the European system of human rights. That is a view shared by a number of other member states. Britain is not alone on this issue, that is why at the European Council we will together make it clear that there is no consensus for the Charter becoming a legally binding text.

ENLARGEMENT

At Feira, we will also take stock of progress on enlargement. The Portuguese Presidency has maintained steady progress on enlargement. Negotiations have been launched with six more candidates, and the original six candidates are advanced in the negotiation on almost all chapters of the European legislation.

For Central and Eastern Europe enlargement will provide assurance of political security and economic opportunity. For the European Union, it will provide a membership of 500 million people - a market twice the size of the United States and four times the size of Japan. It will give Europe, and Britain, extra leverage in international trade negotiations.

It is a rich prize. But if we are to grasp it, we must reform the European Union to make it ready for enlargement. That is why it is important at the forthcoming European Council that we maintain the momentum of the Intergovernmental Conference on Enlargement and keep it on schedule for completion by the end of the year.

Our key objective is to get a reweighting of votes in the Council of Ministers to give Britain a bigger vote. We want to keep the fixed ceiling on the European Parliament so that it does not balloon with enlargement.

We want to control the size of the Commission so that it does not become a mass meeting rather than a functioning college.

We will agree to majority voting only where it would remove obstacles to reforms that Britain wants.

So there is not going to be anything in the Treaty of Nice that represents a threat to Britain or the British way of life. And there is going to be much in the Treaty of Nice of immense value to the candidate countries. They know that enlargement will only be agreed if these reforms are first agreed. Nothing could do more to lose Britain friends from the Baltic to the Balkans than to block the reforms to prepare Europe for enlargement.

All the applicant countries want to be full members of the European Union. They want to be accepted as equal members. That is why there has been unease among them at the recent speech by Joschka Fischer with its implication of a vanguard of member states providing an inner core of the European Union. What I thought was revealing about the aftermath to the Fischer speech was the degree of resistance to it across Europe. I would not go so far as the Foreign Minister of Finland who described it as Leninist, but I share the fears expressed by the Swedish Foreign Minister about any federal structure that has the effect of 'dividing the EU into a core of nations and other countries with lesser status'.

Even in France the reaction has been, to put it politely, reserved. Hubert Vedrine set out last Friday a series of searching and intelligent questions about the problem of attempting to define an inner and outer core, and the difficulties of a Federation co-existing with strong nation states.

The reality now is that the broader consensus does not seek a federal superstate but a union of free and democratic member states. As Chancellor Schroeder has said 'the nation state will be the centre of people's hopes and needs.' Or as President Chirac has put it 'Europe's, future is not a United States of Europe but a United Europe of States.'

REFORM AGENDA

We have been able to get reform in Europe because our partners believe we want reforms that will make Europe work better.

That is why we have been able to make the running on economic reform at Lisbon. We secured a programme to put Europe at the front of the revolution in communications.

We are setting the targets for reform of the Commission. Indeed we have been so successful in setting the benchmarks for reform of the Commission that in Brussels there are complaints that they are being compelled to accept an Anglo-Saxon model.

We can now go to Portugal knowing that issues such as European Security are top of the agenda because Britain put them there. And confident that we can get a good deal out of the Inter-Governmental Conference because we have allies and partners.

That is good for Britain. Good for the three million households whose income depends on our exports to Europe. Good for Britain's wider standing around the world. And a good demonstration that the British people are best served by Britain being not semi-detached from Europe, but by being a whole-hearted member of a successful European Union.

fields.headline: Cook defends euro speech change
fields.trailText: Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, this morning insisted that the omissions in his keynote speech on the single currency were routine and not the result of censorship from the more eurosceptic Treasury.
fields.body:
Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, this morning insisted that the omissions in his keynote speech on the single currency were routine and not the result of censorship from the more eurosceptic Treasury.

"I didn't drop anything from my speech. When you are having a live debate in the House, you do dip in and out of your text," Mr Cook told the Today programme.

"There is nothing in my text that I resile from. The statement that Britain will then be the last country not in the eurozone was a statement of fact.

"The statement that this government will not let Britain lose out by staying out of the euro is something I have said half a dozen times and I will say it again, because it is true."

But shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude said Mr Cook's deviations from his prepared text showed clearly that he had been subjected to pressure from the chancellor.

"This is Gordon Brown wielding the big blue pencil," he said. "Robin Cook was planning to say that the government would not let Britain stay out of the euro and was very explicit about that. Gordon Brown clearly stamped on that.

"It is more evidence of a really deep rift in the cabinet, but not between those who want to go in and those who want to stay out. They all want to scrap the pound at the earliest opportunity," he told the Today programme.

"The row is about how much they tell the public. Robin Cook wants a proper, honest debate and Gordon Brown wants to hush it up. Tony Blair is weakly vacillating in the middle and can't make his mind up."

In his widely flagged Mansion House speech last night, the chancellor made plain that the government would not shift its "prepare and decide" policy on joining the euro.

In his annual speech to the City, he warned cabinet ministers pressing to step up campaigning on the euro that he would not "fudge" the government's five economic tests for membership.

His comments were outwardly aimed at the Conservatives who have accused Labour of wanting to take Britain into the single currency "by stealth".

But they were being widely seen as a rebuff to senior ministers like Mr Cook and Stephen Byers who have been pressing for the government to be more positive towards the euro in the run-up to general election.

In his 31-minute speech, Mr Brown - who again shunned tradition by attending the black tie event in a lounge suit - insisted that the government's "prepare and decide" policy would be implemented "in full".

His comments, described by Treasury sources as "unusually robust", were viewed as an attempt by Mr Brown to reassert his primacy in shaping policy on the euro.

However, Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman Matthew Taylor said that the chancellor had "simply ducked" the issues surrounding the euro.

"We all know what his five tests are - the real question is how to fulfil them. He is obviously not prepared to make the arguments," said Mr Taylor.

"The Labour party, at the highest levels, is split down the middle on this issue to the great detriment of this country."
