In his 31-minute speech, Mr Brown - who again shunned tradition by attending the black tie event in a lounge suit - insisted that the government's "prepare and decide" policy would be implemented "in full". His comments, described by Treasury sources as "unusually robust", were viewed as an attempt by Mr Brown to reassert his primacy in shaping policy on the euro. However, Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman Matthew Taylor said that the chancellor had "simply ducked" the issues surrounding the euro. "We all know what his five tests are - the real question is how to fulfil them. He is obviously not prepared to make the arguments," said Mr Taylor. "The Labour party, at the highest levels, is split down the middle on this issue to the great detriment of this country."

fields.headline: Brown forces retreat on euro
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
Gordon Brown's full speech
fields.trailText: Rising tensions in the cabinet over the single European currency were cruelly exposed yesterday when the chancellor, Gordon Brown, demanded that the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, remove four favourable references to the euro in his keynote speech to the Commons on Europe.
fields.body:
Rising tensions in the cabinet over the single European currency were cruelly exposed yesterday when the chancellor, Gordon Brown, demanded that the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, remove four favourable references to the euro in his keynote speech to the Commons on Europe.

Although Mr Cook agreed to comply with the demands of the Treasury, imposed with the active support of Downing Street, the Foreign Office inadvertently distributed the original text to journalists.

Mr Brown imposed his will on Mr Cook, with the backing of Tony Blair, hours before the chancellor delivered the annual Mansion House speech in which he insisted that the Treasury was "the guardian" of the government's policy on the single currency.

The prime minister told yesterday's cabinet that the Mansion House speech represented the "settled position" of the government. He instructed all cabinet members to stick to the policy, and ordered an end to covert briefings. The attempt to smooth over divisions in the cabinet collapsed when the original text of Mr Cook's Commons speech was distributed to reporters.

It showed that Mr Cook had planned to say that Britain would only be ready to join the euro "if we now resolve in principle that we want to be a member".

But when he came to speak that had been removed.

The foreign secretary was also required to remove a warning that Britain was in danger of soon becoming the sole member of the European Union outside the euro zone.

He had also intended to say: "It is not difficult to identify why there should be benefits from Britain in joining a successful single currency." Another deleted passage read: "The government will not let Britain lose out by staying out."

Mr Cook is one of a group of cabinet members who believe that the government must do more now to persuade public opinion of the virtues of joining the euro. The group, including Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, and Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, have been sending out signals in recent speeches warning that the government cannot protect the manufacturing industry as long as Britain remains outside the single currency. They believe that the current policy may not survive the rigours of a full election campaign.

But the excision of Mr Cook's four passages reveals the Treasury's absolute determination to show that the economic tests set by the government are genuine and will remain to be met after the election.

Officials claimed that the foreign secretary had omitted the passages simply due to interventions from the opposition benches. However, three of the four dropped passages were not preceded by any interruption.

The officials later expressed irritation that other government sources had been briefing on possible exchanges between the private offices of cabinet ministers, while Treasury officials were privately scathing over the Foreign Office's error in handing out the unrevised text.

Number 10 was playing down the incident last night. If the passages had been included, it insisted, they would have still been in line with government policy.

The row nevertheless overshadowed Mr Brown's attempt to lay down the law on the euro after weeks of infighting. The chancellor told his City audience that the government would not join the euro until there was "clear and unambiguous evidence" of the benefits.

Adding that the policy had "not changed and will not change", he denied that the government intended to fudge its five tests for joining: sustainable convergence between the UK and the euro economies; whether there is sufficient flexibility to cope with economic change; the effect on investment; the impact on the financial services industry; and whether it is good for jobs.

He said he rejected the view that "our intention is to join as quickly as we can get away with, irrespective of whether there is the sustainable convergence we need". He insisted instead that the five tests were genuine and "not a political and tactical device to disguise what is a hidden agenda".

A referendum would only be called if an economic assessment of the case for British membership early in the next parliament showed sustainable convergence had been achieved, he said. To join before "we have secured sustainable convergence would risk repeating past failures, mistaking exchange rate stability across the economy and prejudicing our commitment to move Britain from the instabilities of a stop-go economy to greater long term stability."

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said: "Labour are too scared to debate either the future of the European Union or the euro. Robin Cook has tried to start a debate within the Labour party but has been forced to back down. This is a humiliation for supporters of the euro in the cabinet."

What Cook left out

 "Plainly Britain can only join if the conditions are right. But we will only be ready for that event if we now resolve in principle that we want to be a member."

 "It is not difficult to identify why there would be benefits for Britain in joining a successful single currency".

 "If our economic conditions are met it would be right in principle to join".

 "The government will not let Britain lose out by staying out."

fields.headline: Brown defies euro lobby
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday stood firm against cabinet and outside pressure to adopt a more positive line towards the euro, using his Mansion House speech to insist that a decision to enter the single currency would be based on a post-election assessment of his five economic tests.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday stood firm against cabinet and outside pressure to adopt a more positive line towards the euro, using his Mansion House speech to insist that a decision to enter the single currency would be based on a post-election assessment of his five economic tests.

Reaffirming the policy, described earlier in the day by the Nobel-prize winning economist Robert Mundell as a convenient way of postponing discussion of the real issues, the chancellor said there would be no budging from the government's stance.

"The tests, for which this Government and this Treasury is the guardian are real," he told his audience of bankers.

However, his heavily trailed speech was undermined by Professor Mundell's remarks at the London School of Economics. Speaking at a breakfast lecture organised by the pro-European lobby group Britain in Europe, Prof Mundell, whose thinking gave birth to the euro, said the de cision was too important to be left to the chancellor purely on the basis of passing his five economic tests, which include sustainable convergence with euroland and the impact on jobs and investment.

"I think the five tests shouldn't be the sole criteria because the political issues in the long run are very much more important."

He said the five tests failed to take account of the way in which British membership would change the character of the euro, making it a stronger currency and at the same time enhancing the UK's position on the global stage.

With three currencies - the dollar, yen and euro - holding global sway, countries outside those zones faced an awkward future. While arguments could be made for joining the dollar bloc, Britain would be an appendage rather than a leader.

"In the 18th and 19th centuries, English was the language of the seas; now it is the language of the internet. As a result, Britain has tremendous comparative advantage in Europe."

Describing the decision to join the euro as inevitable, Prof Mundell said a safe entry rate for the pound would be around three German marks.

Although the pound hit 14-year highs six weeks ago, it has since fallen more than 10% and is trading against the euro at the equivalent of 3.09 marks.

Turning to the role of central bankers, Prof Mundell said they opposed the euro for fear of losing control of national interest rates. "They are national people. They are heads of fiefdoms. It's like the president of a cigarette company coming out against cigarettes."

webTitle: Leaders a step closer to creating European army

fields.headline: Leaders a step closer to creating European army
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: EU leaders will next week take a significant step towards a British-led proposal for a European defence force capable of mounting operations ranging from humanitarian help to peacemaking, senior Whitehall officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
EU leaders will next week take a significant step towards a British-led proposal for a European defence force capable of mounting operations ranging from humanitarian help to peacemaking, senior Whitehall officials said yesterday.

Delegates at Monday's European summit in Portugal will agree to guidelines covering the security relationship between the EU and Nato and the need for Europeans to increase their military capability which was found so wanting in the Kosovo conflict.

The EU's aim is to establish a 60,000-strong corps by 2003 ready to reach crisis spots quickly and prepared to stay on for a year. It will start "to become operational" as early as next year, officials said.

"When Nato as a whole is not engaged, the EU will act," Foreign Office sources said. In some areas - they cited the recent crisis in East Timor as an example - the EU could act as an "agent for the UN".

EU forces could also act together in response to such crises as the Mozambique floods. But officials also say the EU corps should be trained for a combat role in anticipation of peacekeeping or peacemaking roles.

The plan also includes setting up a 5,000-strong "European police force" to help establish civil order in overseas conflicts such as Sierra Leone.

British officials insisted yesterday that the plan was not to create a "European army" and said the sovereignty of EU states would not be infringed. Decisions would be taken by consensus and the purpose of the corps was crisis management, not collective defence.

Whitehall also insists there is no contradiction between the EU's defence plans and Nato's transatlantic alliance. Indeed, they maintain, the plans would strengthen Nato.

While it welcomes the Europeans' commitment to improve their defence capabilities - which in some countries means extra defence spending - Washington remains concerned that EU ambitions could divide the Nato alliance.

It is also concerned about the role of non-EU Nato allies, notably Turkey. Though these countries will be invited to take part in Eurocorps operations, decisions on where or when the corps will be deployed will be taken by EU member states.

EU countries have already set up interim military and security committees in Brussels. Three armed forces officers were recently attached to the British mission to the EU.

fields.headline: Record breakers run Northants ragged
fields.standfirst:
Warwickshire 568-9dec
Northamptonshire 147-3
fields.trailText:
Warwickshire 568-9dec
Northamptonshire 147-3
fields.body:
It was a record-breaking kind of day here: sunny, somnolent and slightly distracted by events at Edgbaston. The partnership of 306 between Michael Powell and Dominic Ostler was Warwickshire's highest for any wicket against Northamptonshire, and the final total of 568 for nine declared was Warwickshire's highest total against Northants, beating the 1933 score of 565 for eight.

There were also personal bests for Michael Powell (145), Mohammed Sheikh (58) and Alan Richardson (17), plus a 600th catch for David Ripley. Sheikh rattled and rolled his way to a maiden first-class 50, drove the bowlers to distraction, and walked off the field with a huge grin.

But the most heartening performance came from Ostler, who carried on where he left off yesterday. He is a revitalised man. Bob Woolmer got hold of him pre-season and sternly instructed him to stop playing across the line and start hitting down the ground. He had not made a first-class century for five years but has now accrued two in just over a month and looks full of beans.

Northants did not look as keen in the field as on Wednesday. Powell was dropped three times before lunch, the odd ball crept through lumbering fielders and the extras total crept up. When Michael Davies and Graeme Swann bowled six overs for 45 runs, everyone looked too embarrassed to help.

The most successful bowler was Tony Penberthy. He ran in tirelessly from the pavilion end and took five wickets in 35 balls for five runs with his doddly late inswingers. But Northants could not press home the advantage and the tail wagged away.

Matthew Hayden and Adrian Rollins strutted out after tea and the declaration as if they hadn't a care in the world, and ploughed into Warwickshire's bowling, scoring at 4.5 runs an over.

Rollins fell to a great diving catch by Powell at short leg, and was joined in the pavilion by David Sales, who was most reluctant to go after being caught at silly point.

Mal Loye, who hit one magnificent six, stood unbeaten on 54 but Northants still need 272 to avoid the follow-on.

fields.headline: Warne puts Durham down
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 340
Durham 83 & 12-1
fields.trailText:
Hampshire 340
Durham 83 & 12-1
fields.body:
Victory over the champions Surrey in their opening match convinced Durham they could make a significant impression in the First Division, but their optimism now looks misplaced. Only six weeks later they are heading for the bottom of the table.

Indeed, they will do well to take this game into a fourth day. Following on after recording their lowest first- innings score in the championship, they lost the teenager Nick Peng before the close and are still 245 behind.

And that's not all. Worryingly, their fast bowler Steve Harmison delivered 10 balls in the morning before leaving the field with a shin injury. He later batted with a runner.

"It's too early to say how serious it is," said Norman Gifford, Durham's coach. "His left shin is very sore. He's iced it and will have to see how it settles down."

Without him Durham still prospered with the ball. Simon Brown, innocuous on Thursday, took three wickets in 10 deliveries to end Hampshire's hopes of maximum batting points after they had resumed their first innings on 255 for four.

The left-armer found movement to win leg-before verdicts against Adrian Aymes and Derek Kenway and followed that up by finding Shane Warne's outside edge. England is still waiting for the leg-spinner's cherished maiden first-class hundred. Not for the first time this season he was merely 100 short.

Dmitri Mascarenhas and Shaun Udal then retreated into their shells - 26 runs coming in 18 overs - before the second new ball livened things up. John Wood disappeared for four boundaries and responded by having Mascarenhas caught behind. Udal did his best to secure a fourth batting point but 10 were needed from two overs when he was snared by Brown, whose return for the day was four for 18.

Durham began their reply in mid-afternoon and found the task perplexing on a pitch which, without being spiteful, had switched its allegiance from batsmen to bowlers.

Alan Mullally induced Jonathan Lewis to push a catch to short leg in his third over and Simon Katich was given out leg-before to Mascarenhas. There was sufficient animation in the Australian's body language to suggest he did not think much of the umpire Anthony Clarkson's decision.

Mascarenhas, though, was spot on. Collingwood was caught at first slip and Peng at second to make it 22 for four. The captain Nick Speak briefly threatened a recovery but when he miscued a shortish ball from Warne to short third man the follow-on was inevitable. Mullally sorted out the rest of the middle order and Warne persecuted the tail to take his tally of championship wickets to 25.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: There are those few cynics who once maintained that he never took a wicket honestly, reliant as he allegedly was on the twin evils of ball-tampering and Asian cunning.
fields.body:
There are those few cynics who once maintained that he never took a wicket honestly, reliant as he allegedly was on the twin evils of ball-tampering and Asian cunning.

Which is why, having become the 14th bowler to take 300 Test wickets on a day littered with rather more modest milestones, Waqar Younis had cause to feel just a teensy bit smug. How apt, moreover, that the vital catch in Colombo should come courtesy of the other half of Pakistan's dastardly duo, Wasim Akram.

It would be less appropriate to suggest that Phil DeFreitas is maturing like a fine wine. More like a good whine. Having returned to Leicestershire after dalliances with Lancashire and Derbyshire, however, he has started his 16th season with all the effervescence of Mr Perignon's bubbliest. As his previous employers have been the latest to discover.

In scoring 37 at Grace Road in a seventh-wicket stand of 121, he aided the revival begun by Aftab Habib, whose 164 off 225 balls made him the first chap in First Division history to score a second century. Nor is DeFreitas's own feat - first to the 250 runs-20 wickets "double" - to be sniffed at. The value of the alliance was stressed as Leicestershire slithered from 307 for six to 310 all out, which certainly made Kevin Dean breathe a mite easier. The visitors' highly rated left-armer, who missed virtually the whole of last summer with back problems, had managed only one victim in 50 championship overs this term when he unglued Habib and DeFreitas amid a spell of four in eight balls, hat-trick included, the second of his career.

Jimmy Ormond hit back twice, raising the casualty toll at the Bennett end to six in 16 balls.

At The Oval, Alec Stewart's gloveminder Jon Batty (Repton, Durham, Oxford, BSc Hons in Natural Sciences, Diploma in Social Studies) collected a maiden century as Surrey passed 500, whereupon Ian Salisbury and Saqlain Mushtaq spun out six Somerset batsmen for 25 after an opening stand of 73.

At Lord's, meanwhile, Paul Franks (Minster School, West Notts College, Advanced GNVQ in leisure and tourism) claimed a career-best seven for 56 to give Nottinghamshire a healthy lead over Middlesex. Franks thus became the first fellow in the lower tier to the 200 runs-20 wickets double. Never mind a working-class hero. The New DeFreitas is something to be.

At The Oval, Alec Stewart's gloveminder Jon Batty (Repton, Durham, Oxford, BSc Hons in Natural Sciences, Diploma in Social Studies) collected a maiden century as Surrey passed 500, whereupon Ian Salisbury and Saqlain Mushtaq spun out six Somerset batsmen for 25 after an opening stand of 73. At Lord's, meanwhile, Paul Franks (Minster School, West Notts College, Advanced GNVQ in leisure and tourism) claimed a career-best seven for 56 to give Nottinghamshire a healthy lead over Middlesex. Franks thus became the first fellow in the lower tier to the 200 runs-20 wickets double. Never mind a working-class hero. The New DeFreitas is something to be.

fields.headline: Sidebottom on a high five
fields.standfirst: Kent 129 & 36-3 v Yorkshire 149
fields.trailText: Kent 129 & 36-3 v Yorkshire 149
fields.body:
English batsmen are miniaturists. Cameo performers. Composers of moderate chamber music but rarely of grand symphonies. With poor pitches and poor technique, the latter influenced by the former, it is little wonder that championship cricket is not producing test players.

In five sessions of play, between two of the better sides in the country, 23 wickets have fallen here for only 314 runs, and this already abbreviated match will do well to dribble into the fourth day.

Yorkshire's disappointment at being bowled out by a largely anonymous Kent attack for only 149 was offset by the fact that they had chiselled out a potentially match-winning lead of 20. At the close, Kent were batting for the second time and were only 16 runs ahead.

The pitch looked half decent on the first day, when there was plenty of juice and bounce. The bounce was still there yesterday but now the sun has widened the small cracks that were there at the beginning and too many deliveries are keeping treacherously low.

For most of the day Yorkshire's innings hobbled along in unhappy tandem with England's effort in Birmingham, and Michael Vaughan, after his dashes up and down the M1, might have had the vague and uncomfortable feeling that he was playing in both matches.

Vaughan, not needed at Edgbaston, arrived back here at 12.30, was batting at No. 6 at 2.17 and was back in the pavilion at 2.52. He was caught behind off a shooter from the Kent captain Matthew Fleming, who was his side's most successful bowler with three wickets.

Sixteen wickets went down here yesterday and a quick body count revealed that Yorkshire, the championship leaders, had had the better of it. Kent resumed in the morning at 127 for seven and lost their remaining wickets in the first 15 minutes. Ryan Sidebottom, Yorkshire's left-arm seamer, finished with five for 27; he had never taken more than three wickets in an innings before this.

Yorkshire soon lost David Byas, caught behind off a poor stroke. The makeshift opener James Middlebrook (18) and Richard Blakey then added 33 for the second wicket. It was the most substantial stand of the innings, and it ended when David Masters, with a direct hit, ran out Blakey for 22.

Middlebrook was lbw to Mark Ealham and Matthew Wood was caught at slip first ball. Darren Lehmann then middled the ball with such fluent ease that it was a sur prise when he was caught behind after an exorbitant drive off Masters' bowling.

Kent's bowling is in ruins. Martin McCague has been dropped for the poor form he showed in Bath and yesterday it was revealed that last season's most successful bowler, Julian Thompson, would be out for the season after knee surgery. It has already been conceded that Dean Headley and Ben Phillips will not play this summer. And James Golding (back) and James Hockley (hamstring) are also injured. But it is Kent's batting which is their real problem. The top-order batsmen David Fulton, Robert Key and Ed Smith, now dropped, have not scored a 50 between them.

Kent, meanwhile, have not protested against Vaughan's reinstatement in this match, even though the England and Wales Cricket Board's own rules clearly state that a player called up by England and pulled out of a county match cannot return to that game. Fleming, though, was left as bewildered as everyone else. "I talked to Lord's this morning and agree that the commonsense route was taken. There is no point in Michael not playing but it would seem that in this case the law's an ass."

webTitle: Cartels: the new scourge of the world economy

fields.headline: Cartels: the new scourge of the world economy
fields.standfirst: The future of Microsoft: Special report
fields.trailText: Next week, 16 leading US law firms will file a billion pound suit on behalf of hundreds of millions of people who bought Microsoft Windows and programmes outside the US, alleging that the software giant charged inflated prices.
fields.body:
Next week, 16 leading US law firms will file a billion pound suit on behalf of hundreds of millions of people who bought Microsoft Windows and programmes outside the US, alleging that the software giant charged inflated prices.

The case at the US district court in Maryland, will be the first big test of provisions in American law allowing non-US citizens to claim damages as victims of monopolies after a judge ruled that Microsoft abused its monopoly power and ordered the company to be split into two. The lawyers pursuing the case are members of a new coalition, the Global Anti-Cartel Network, an alliance of 29 law firms from six continents that plant to target other monopolies and price fixing conspiracies in courts throughout the world.

The anti-cartel group reflects the renewed attention on cartels - informal associations of companies that collude to maintain high prices - among private law firms and government officials. The US department of justice has taken the lead in the fight against cartels as they make a comeback. In 1999, its antitrust division secured $1.1bn in criminal fines - almost all of them in international cartel cases - including $500m from a single firm, Hoffman-LaRoche, the Swiss pharmaceuticals firm, in a vitamin price fixing conspiracy.

Cartels have regained the attention of US antitrust officials only recently. There were numerous cases during and just after the second world war, but few after the early 1950s. Prosecutions increased exponentially in 1995 and included a $100m fine on Archer Daniels Midland (ADM), the US agribusiness giant, in 1997. Fines have increased steadily, culminating in last year's record total.

The reason cartels are making a comeback is because of globalisation. Economic globalisation and the lowering of government trade barriers as part of worldwide trade liberalisation have created strong incentives among some firms to collude rather than compete - something that Marx anticipated many years ago. As an ADM executive told his international co-conspirators: "Our competitors are our friends. Our customers are the enemy."

Joel Klein, the head of the justice department's antitrust division (the man who brought the case against Microsoft) recently described cartels as the equivalent of "theft by well-dressed thieves", which deserve "unequivocal public condemnation". In the case concerning ADM and lysine, an amino acid, the US found that prices went up by 70% in the first three months of the conspiracy alone. In a conspiracy relating to citric acid, prices were raised more than 30% to US customers.

Mr Klein says the recent cartel cases point to the need for law enforcement agencies to work together. "Antitrust agencies truly have a shared interest in working together to obliterate this blight on our economies. After all, they don't just hurt consumers in the US or any other single country. Almost by definition, they hurt consumers worldwide." It is difficult to argue with Mr Klein's assertion that international cartels are "a true scourge of the world economy".

fields.headline: I am listening
fields.standfirst: Peter Mandelson responds to Brendan O'Leary's accusation yesterday that he has diluted the Patten report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson responds to Brendan O'Leary's accusation yesterday that he has diluted the Patten report
fields.body:
In the war of words over the police bill the first casualty has been the truth about just how radical the changes to policing will be. The second has been detailed attention to what the government is actually proposing to implement: the Patten commission's report.

I remain absolutely determined to implement the Patten recommendations and to achieve the effective and representative policing service - accepted in every part of Northern Ireland - that his report aimed to secure.

The changes proposed are the most radical seen anywhere. The legislation - even before the changes which it will certainly undergo - promises a police service with stronger accountability, greater community involvement, and a stricter human-rights culture than any policing service in Great Britain or the Republic of Ireland. So what is the reality behind the "dilutions" myth?

Name, symbols and flags: Patten suggested that the name of the RUC should be changed to signal the new beginning in policing that we all desire. He also recommended that the RUC should not be disbanded and said that "the link between the RUC and the new police service should be recognised".

I am being faithful to Patten on both points by suggesting that the name will indeed change - I have suggested the Police Service of Northern Ireland - while the RUC will be retained in the "title deeds" to show that disbandment has not taken place. I believe that most reasonable people will see this as a sensible way of reaching Patten's twin objectives.

Human rights: No one could deny that the bill cements hu man rights as the cornerstone of the new police service, as Patten recommended. The code of ethics - to which all officers will have to sign up - and the policing board's powers to monitor the performance of the service against human-rights standards are tough and innovative. The key point is to ensure that all officers are bound by the same standards of behaviour and the legislation will secure this.

Catholic representation: I am implementing Patten's 50/50 recruitment scheme, although it will mean changing the law and persuading our European partners that this is a special case of reverse discrimination. I have listened to concerns about the time limits placed on this scheme and I agree that it should be allowed to continue for as long as it takes to achieve the appropriate Catholic/Protestant balance. I also agree that it should be possible for a shortfall in one year to be made up in another.

Accountability and the new policing board: The accountability arrangements embodied in the new policing board already go far beyond anything in Great Britain or the Republic of Ireland. However, I acknowledge that I may have been too cautious in placing safeguards on the powers of the board, particularly in relation to the launching of inquiries. I wanted to avoid parties using the police as a political battleground. I maintain this concern but perhaps I was over-pessimistic. Let's hope this is borne out in reality.

District policing partnerships (DPPs): I have faithfully implemented Patten's system of DPPs, although I have stressed that their consultative and advisory role must get off the ground before expenditure and service delivery duties are added. During the consultation period I heard concerns from all sections of the community that DPPs' fund-raising powers might be open to manipulation by paramilitary groups.

Disqualifications: The same concerns were voiced about people convicted of terrorist offences sitting on the policing board or the DPPs. Patten himself said the community would find this hard to accept. However, the bill makes it clear that elected members of these bodies are not subject to any such restrictions. Their democratic mandate overrides other considerations.

A s far as the independent members are concerned, while there may be debate about the exact safeguards for exclusion, the real issue is one of time. We all long for the day when this sensitivity recedes and terrorist convictions can be relegated in the selection procedures for these bodies. But this moment has not yet been reached.

The ombudsman: The ombudsman has powers which are unique in Great Britain and the Republic of Ireland. She can initiate completely independent investigations, using her own investigators to pursue complaints against the police. I believe she will have the power to deal with any "bad apples" in the service. The ombudsman says she is content with her powers.

I welcome the strong interest generated by this debate. The future of policing should arouse passion. But let us get past the political hysteria and concentrate instead on detail and practicality.

No one who has read the bill and the government's recently published implementation plan, and listened to my assurances that I am ready to make refinements and changes, could seriously say that I have "binned" or "gutted" Patten.

Our goal remains a police service which is not only a model for others but is a career choice for the very best of our young people of both traditions. That was Patten's goal and it is mine.

Peter Mandelson is secretary of state for Northern Ireland

comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Hero to tragic idiot: Cronje tells of bribes and threats

fields.headline: Hero to tragic idiot: Cronje tells of bribes and threats
fields.standfirst: Cricket Unlimited
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel on the fall of the South African cricket captain
fields.byline: Matthew Engel  on the fall of the South African cricket captain
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje was as inscrutably po-faced yesterday as in the days when he was just a famous cricketer: he might have been reading out a laundry list. His flat tone of voice was wholly at odds with the devastating nature of what he was saying. He might have done formidably well had he taken up professional poker instead of cricket.

For the best part of an hour, Cronje - until two months ago the much-admired captain of the South African cricket team - sat in a dark suit in front of Judge Edwin King at the match-fixing inquiry in Cape Town and read out his statement. It had a ring of truth to it. Maybe it was not the whole truth, but the sense of messiness and mixed motives seemed real enough.

He did not, as in his earlier confession, prattle on about his born-again Christianity and the influence of Satan. He did talk of having received death threats and said he feared for his safety. But mostly he told in plain words how he had been sucked into the game's corruption.

Meanwhile, 6,000 miles away, cricketing normality resumed: England's batting col lapsed at Edgbaston on the first day of the series against the West Indies. That sounded genuine enough.

The Cronje who abased himself before the world yesterday was greedy, stupid, corruptible and calculating. He was also naive, indecisive, vulnerable and regretful. We can all recognise bits of ourselves in there. It is just that in Cronje the mixture of naivete and greed proved particularly combustible.

He named two other former national captains: Salim Malik of Pakistan, who has already been banned for life by the authorities there, and Mohammed Azharuddin, one of the two great Indian batsmen of the last two decades.

He also said that the contrived finish at Centurion in January - when an apparently rain-ruined match ended in a stunning England victory - was organised at the behest of a gambler, though the result itself was not fixed.

Cronje alleged that Azharuddin called him to a hotel room before an India-South Africa test in 1996 and introduced him to a man known as "MK", who offered Cronje $30,000 to ensure the match was thrown. He said he never spoke to the other players, but South Africa lost fair and square. So he accepted the money anyway. "I had effectively received money for doing nothing and I rationalised to myself that this was somehow acceptable," he said.

Azharuddin denied involvement. "It's all rubbish. Cronje has no credibility left," he said.

But there was something compelling about the banality of Cronje's slow downfall. MK offered $200,000 if a one-day international was thrown later on that tour. This time Cronje did put it to the players, who rejected the idea. Then Cronje - after discussions with some of the team - went back to see if the offer might go up to $300,000. There was no deal.

You might imagine that a corrupt captain of South Africa would be dealing with a Mr Big, probably stroking a Persian cat in a fortified palace. Instead, there was "John", the same shadowy Indian bookie who instigated the much less effective seduction of the Australians Mark Waugh and Shane Warne; a hanger-on called "Banjo" who ran a sweet shop; and "Marlon", who was Cronje's partner in the Centurion enterprise. Cronje tried to get a bet on the Centurion test. He wanted to have 50 rand (£5) on South Africa, but he was too late. From Marlon he received 50,000 rand (£5,000) and a leather jacket. How pathetic can you get?

Indeed, when it emerged in 1998 that Waugh and Warne had been paid for giving innocuous information to John, it was obvious that they had escaped from an attempted sting. They had the nous to get out before the water went over their heads.

Yet even until two months ago, Cronje was still wading further and further out of his depth. As he detailed the increasingly aggressive phone calls from his contacts to his hotel room, at two and three in the morning, it was impossible not to feel the almost Shakespearean depths of his tragedy. But like most of Shakespeare's tragic protagonists, he was, above all else, an idiot.

Cronje alleged that Azharuddin called him to a hotel room before an India-South Africa test in 1996 and introduced him to a man known as "MK", who offered Cronje $30,000 to ensure the match was thrown. He said he never spoke to the other players, but South Africa lost fair and square. So he accepted the money anyway. "I had effectively received money for doing nothing and I rationalised to myself that this was somehow acceptable," he said. Azharuddin denied involvement. "It's all rubbish. Cronje has no credibility left," he said. But there was something compelling about the banality of Cronje's slow downfall. MK offered $200,000 if a one-day international was thrown later on that tour. This time Cronje did put it to the players, who rejected the idea. Then Cronje - after discussions with some of the team - went back to see if the offer might go up to $300,000. There was no deal. You might imagine that a corrupt captain of South Africa would be dealing with a Mr Big, probably stroking a Persian cat in a fortified palace. Instead, there was "John", the same shadowy Indian bookie who instigated the much less effective seduction of the Australians Mark Waugh and Shane Warne; a hanger-on called "Banjo" who ran a sweet shop; and "Marlon", who was Cronje's partner in the Centurion enterprise. Cronje tried to get a bet on the Centurion test. He wanted to have 50 rand (£5) on South Africa, but he was too late. From Marlon he received 50,000 rand (£5,000) and a leather jacket. How pathetic can you get? Indeed, when it emerged in 1998 that Waugh and Warne had been paid for giving innocuous information to John, it was obvious that they had escaped from an attempted sting. They had the nous to get out before the water went over their heads. Yet even until two months ago, Cronje was still wading further and further out of his depth. As he detailed the increasingly aggressive phone calls from his contacts to his hotel room, at two and three in the morning, it was impossible not to feel the almost Shakespearean depths of his tragedy. But like most of Shakespeare's tragic protagonists, he was, above all else, an idiot.

fields.headline: Azharuddin protests innocence
fields.trailText: Mohammad Azharuddin last night attempted to salvage his severely dented reputation by dismissing as "rubbish" the claim that he introduced Hansie Cronje to a mysterious Indian bookmaker.
fields.body:
Mohammad Azharuddin last night attempted to salvage his severely dented reputation by dismissing as "rubbish" the claim that he introduced Hansie Cronje to a mysterious Indian bookmaker during the 1996 Kanpur test between India and South Africa.

The former Indian captain said he had no knowledge of Mukesh Gupta, whom Cronje said gave him $30,000 (£18,900) to lose a match against India. "I totally deny these allegations and treat them with contempt. I am innocent and ready to face any investigation that the cricket board may initiate in the matter," Azharuddin said from Hyderabad. "How can anyone rely on the statement of someone who contradicts himself every day?"

The Board of Cricket Control in India (BCCI) last night signalled that it would not act yet against Azharuddin following Cronje's devastating testimony to the King Commission.

Azharuddin is due to appear before India's Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), which is investigating match-fixing, later today. The meeting was fixed before yesterday's extraordinary revelations.

A C Muthiah, the BCCI's president, last night said he had "no doubt" that the CBI would "get to the bottom of the matter", adding: "The BCCI will not hesitate in taking severe action against players and officials found guilty." But Jagmohan Dalmiya, the International Cricket Council president, conceded that it would be a "difficult proposition" to punish any player unless an allegation was "ultimately proved". The board would act if there was a "prima facie" case, he added.

Azharuddin had only just shrugged off allegations two weeks ago by an undercover documentary team that he was involved in match-rigging. An income tax official named him as a player who took advantage of a tax amnesty to declare millions of rupees of unexplained income. His personal fortune, including at least four properties, was estimated at £22m.

The Indian magazine Outlook, which has been investigating match-fixing since 1997, had already named him as one of four allegedly corrupt Indian players, together with Kapil Dev, Ajay Jadeja and Nayan Mongia. They have all denied the allegations and said there was no proof to back the charges.

It claimed the crime branch of Bombay police obtained telephone calls between players and bookmakers during the Titan Cup match between India and South Africa three years ago. Azharuddin was allegedly recorded as telling one bookie to "put my money on the other side", meaning South Africa.

The name of Gupta, the Indian bookmaker who gave Cronje $30,000 to "give wickets away", has not previously figured in police investigations. Dr K K Paul, the detective who broke the Cronjegate story, last night said he had not heard of him.

The CBI is interviewing current and former players and officials who have been implicated in the match-rigging saga. The bureau has the power to frame criminal charges and could arrest any player who refused to respond to its formal summons to give evidence. So far all of the players summoned have turned up.

fields.headline: King of Cronjegate
fields.trailText: Neil Manthorp on Edwin King, the man heading up the match-fixing inquiry in Cape Town.
fields.body:
The man who will effectively decide whether Hansie Cronje faces criminal charges over match-fixing, Edwin King, is a veteran liberal famous among his legal colleagues for his passion for South African sport, who has faced gentle teasing over his habit of watching cricket on television in quiet moments in his chambers.

The South African government's director of public prosecutions, Bulelani Ncguka, has offered Cronje immunity from criminal prosecution in South Africa if King, who heads the commisson of inquiry, rules that the former South Africa captain has told the whole truth. Similar offers were made to Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams before they testified.

King, widely known by his nickname of "Sharkie", was an active sportsman into his 50s but admits that his athletic exploits these days are confined to "regular visits to the gym to neutralise the effects of my many social activities".

As well as serving as legal adviser and chancellor to the Anglican Diocese of Cape Town, King nailed his liberal colours to the mast by defending clients in political trials during the apartheid years. In the 1960s, 70s and 80s he worked for several organisations that worked against oppression and racial discrimination, including the Institute of Citizenship.

The 71-year-old has a reputation as being tough but fair after 14 years on the bench in which he rose to be judge president - head of the legal system - of the Cape Province until his term ended in late April.

King was born in London but his family emigrated when he was a boy. He matriculated from St Andrew's College in Grahamstown in 1945 and read for his BA and LLB at the University of Cape Town, graduating in 1954. He was admitted to the bar in 1955 and, apart from one year, served until his appointment to the bench in 1986.

webTitle: Cronje comes clean on life of shame

fields.headline: Cronje comes clean on life of shame
fields.standfirst:
Neil Manthorp hears the former South African captain reveal four years of lies and corruption
Cronje's confession in full
fields.trailText: Neil Manthorp hears the former South African captain reveal four years of lies and corruption.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje made his long-awaited appearance before the King Commission yesterday and electrified the packed courtroom when he said that the Indian captain Mohammad Azharuddin had introduced him to the bookmaker who set him on his downward path by paying him $30,000 (£20,000) on December 10 1996, and that the forfeiture of innings that led to England's victory in the fifth test at Centurion Park at the beginning of this year came at the behest of a bookmaker.

The South African captain received R50,000 (£5,000) and a leather jacket for helping to bring about a result after the rain-affected test.

The judge, Edwin King, opened the proceedings with a reminder that his offer of indemnity from criminal prosecution was conditional on full disclosure by Cronje. "May I remind you of the contents of chapter eight of St John's gospel," the judge said. "The truth shall set you free."

Cronje said he was first approached before a one-day game against Pakistan in Cape Town on January 10 1995. The man went by the name of "John". He offered Cronje $10,000 (£6,600) to lose the game. Cronje said he believed it was the same "John" who had approached Australia's Shane Warne and Mark Waugh three months earlier. Cronje rejected the offer.

When Cronje and Salim Malik went out to toss, the Pakistan captain asked whether he had spoken to John, who also contacted Cronje before the next game at the Wanderers in Johannesburg. Cronje said he rebuffed him.

Another approach to Cronje at the beginning of South Africa's tour to India at the end of 1996, this time from "Sunil", was again rejected but then Cronje succumbed.

"On the evening of the third day of the third test at Kanpur [December 10 1996] I received a call from Mohammad Azharuddin. He called me to a room in the hotel and introduced me to Mukesh Gupta, 'MK'. Azharuddin then departed and left us in the room. MK asked if we would give wickets away on the last day of that test to ensure that we lost. He asked me to speak to the other players and gave me approximately $30,000 in cash to do so."

Cronje kept the money but did not speak to any of his team-mates: "I rationalised to myself that this was somehow acceptable because I had not actually done anything," he said. South Africa lost the test.

Then came an offer from MK for throwing the final match of that tour, a benefit game for Mohinder Amarnath. Cronje relayed the offer of $200,000, later upped to $250,000, to the team but it was rejected.

The South African team then returned home and were accompanied by the Indians for a three-test series. MK appeared for the first and second tests and was supplied with team selections, predictions and forecasts by Cronje.

During the second test, which South Africa won, Cronje was asked to disclose specifically at what point he would declare. "I did this. After the second test MK transferred a sum of about $50,000 into my NBS savings account."

MK offered $300,000 to the South African team to lose the third test of that series but Cronje refused and lost contact with him after that. The match was drawn.

The events surrounding the Centurion test thickened the intrigue. After 46 overs on day one and three days of rain, Cronje met England's captain Nasser Hussain, Ali Bacher, the managing director of the United Cricket Board of South Africa, the umpires and the match referee. "Bacher was anxious to save the game as a spectacle."

That evening Cronje had a call on his cellphone from a man he called Marlon Aronstam who offered to donate R500,000 to a charity if he could reach agreement with Hussain on a target. He also promised to give Cronje a "gift".

After Hussain's initial refusal, a message reached Cronje after 45 minutes' play that he was now willing to accept the offer. Cronje left the field and sent a cellphone message to Aronstam reading "the game is on". Cronje stressed that Hussain knew nothing of Aronstam's offer.

Aronstam, however, was unable to place bets as the news had come too late. He is due to testify next week. He paid Cronje R50,000 "in consideration of me giving him information in the future," Cronje said.

On the tour to India this year Cronje approached Pieter Strydom before the first test to underperform, and Jacques Kallis, Mark Boucher and Lance Klusener before the second. All rejected the offer.

Only, according to Cronje's testimony, before the fifth and final one-day match, which he admitted attempting to fix, was an offer accepted, by Henry Williams and Herschelle Gibbs.

"My only consolation is the knowledge that, despite my inexcusable behaviour, South Africa has in fact never thrown or fixed a match," he added.

fields.headline: Old hands with fresh vigour
fields.trailText: There were no steel bands, conch-shell blowers nor the relentless blasting music that pervades the West Indian grounds, but Windies didn't need that atmosphere, reports Donna Symmonds.
fields.body:
The first day of the first test started in blazing sunshine and then the cloud and sleeveless pullovers came. This change was also the signal to invigorate West Indies' bowling attack, it seems. Courtney Walsh (a little rusty in his first five overs) and Curtly Ambrose merely picked up where they left off in their last test in the Caribbean. The improved catching was again evident in the tourists. Just as they would share a bag of mangoes, Walsh with four for 23 and Ambrose, King and Rose with one wicket each had spreadeagled England by tea, when the score was 129 for seven.

There were no steel bands, conch-shell blowers nor the relentless blasting music that pervades the West Indian grounds, but Windies didn't need that atmosphere. Winning the toss and sending England in, these bowlers found the discipline to ensure that their supporters would enjoy the initial exchanges of the tour.

Walsh started the slide, taking the first wicket of the day and his 450th when Mark Ramprakash was easily caught at forward short leg by Wavell Hinds. His tally is now 454 as he continues to break his own world record for the highest number of test victims. Ambrose, one of his fast bowling partners since 1988, is the second highest West Indian wicket-taker and provided admirable support with his impeccable line and length.

Walsh ended the day with five for 36 from 21 overs, the 20th time he has taken five wickets in an innings, and is irrepressible. Thirty-seven he may be but he continues to be such a high-quality performer that he defies the usual view that increased age produces or induces waning performance. Not so with this superbly conditioned fast bowler.

He got the ball to cut both ways and used all of his experience in the conditions to "kerfuffle" the English batsmen. He was superb. He and Ambrose may have lost some pace but none of the guile needed to "work out" batters.

Reon King and, particularly yesterday, Franklyn Rose are good students. However, they do not consistently follow in the footprints of the masters. That means that the annoying habit of dismissing half a side for under a hundred and letting the rest score more than expected still plagues West Indies as it has in the recent past. England managed to rally to 179 all out with some lusty lower-order hitting.

So much hype has surrounded Brian Lara's return to test cricket that a few other stars may have been forgotten. Even at this stage, to ignore the powers of Ambrose and Walsh will lead to trouble. After this start England won't need any reminding.

England did strike back in the 19 overs left in the day. West Indies were 59 for two at the close and their fragile batting may be tested on day two.

webTitle: Rash England charge into Valley of Walsh

fields.headline: Rash England charge into Valley of Walsh
fields.trailText: Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose are almost old enough to relate to Lothar Matthäus, even if on yesterday's evidence they are not quite as exhausted, reports David Hopps.
fields.body:
As Channel 4 strives to reinvent cricket for the masses, no test match is complete without the brandishing of the latest technological contraption. So it was that Simon Hughes crouched on the Edgbaston pitch before start of play and pronounced that the dampometer was "reading around 600". He never exactly explained 600 what, but if it is runs then England are still in with a chance.

However, this is a figure not entirely identified with English success since Lord Cardigan led the Light Brigade into the Valley of Death in 1854, and any English batsman who has faced the West Indies fast bowlers in the past 30 years has an inkling of what it must be like to charge cannons with a few horses and a couple of penknives.

Nevertheless, this is the start of a five-test series and optimism should abound. There is no better time to be facing West Indies, just as there is no better time for the England football team to be playing the Germans.

Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose, embarking upon their farewell tour of England, are almost old enough to relate to Lothar Matthäus, even if on yesterday's evidence they are not quite as exhausted; Brian Lara might have returned to the ranks but can hardly yet be regarded as reintegrated; and West Indies have lost their last 10 overseas tests.

What England needed yesterday was to win the toss and bat on a pitch so flat that, for Walsh and Ambrose, the benefits of three weeks' rest would have vanished by stumps. Instead, a good deal of moisture remained in a pitch which jagged and bounced unevenly all day. The dampometer, which grades the moisture in a pitch between nought and 1,000, had indicated it might; readings at Lord's and Trent Bridge for the two tests against Zimbabwe had measured around 400.

Walsh had reflected overnight that he had never taken five wickets in an innings in England; a quirk considering his proven ability on English surfaces with Gloucestershire. "I haven't done as well as I should in England so I was looking to put it right," he said.

"This is a bit of a farewell. Curtly has already announced his retirement after this series and I won't be dragging on for too long."

Duncan Fletcher, the England coach, emphasised that Walsh, these days the slowest of the West Indies pace quartet, had been presented with an ideal surface. "You can expect movement for the first hour but it did a lot for a very long time. We struggled to know where to score a run."

Some struggled better than others. A duck for Graeme Hick, pushing away from his body, will convince his detractors that he could make 600 test comebacks and he would still fail to make runs when he could not drop contentedly on to the front foot.

There was better from Andrew Flintoff, who at least modified a cumbersome approach against Zimbabwe and responded to Nick Knight's alertness to the quick single. He also managed to pull one of the quickest balls of the day, from Reon King, through mid-on for four, and that was about as good as it got.

The perception that England's bowlers were up against it was illustrated by the ribald cheers that greeted the spectator who sprinted across the outfield dressed as Superman, who cared only for American football. Cricket needs someone quintessentially English. Perhaps Miss Marple might care to limp on with a solution some time today?

The perception that England's bowlers were up against it was illustrated by the ribald cheers that greeted the spectator who sprinted across the outfield dressed as Superman, who cared only for American football. Cricket needs someone quintessentially English. Perhaps Miss Marple might care to limp on with a solution some time today?

fields.headline: Brain surgeons fear writs
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Hundreds of high risk patients are being denied brain operations because surgeons fear being sued, it was claimed last night.
fields.body:
Hundreds of high risk patients are being denied brain operations because surgeons fear being sued, it was claimed last night.

A survey of 133 members of the Society of British Neurosurgeons showed that more than 70% of the surgeons said the growth of litigation had caused them to change the way they practised medicine compared with five years ago.

The analysis carried out for BBC2's Newsnight found that they were less likely to treat elderly patients, those whose condition was not seen as so serious, and patients judged more likely to sue if not left "100% normal".

Around 75% confirmed they had experienced litigation or the threat of serious litigation over the past 12 months. The survey said there were 272 cases or threats of legal action last year compared with 97 a decade ago.

Ciaran Bolger, consultant neurosurgeon at Frenchay hospital, Bristol, told Newsnight: "The atmosphere of blame and looking for someone to blame if things don't work out quite right does make people stop and think."

webTitle: Fashion wars kill high street chain

fields.headline: Fashion wars kill high street chain
fields.standfirst:
4,800 jobs go as beleaguered 'middle market' family name announces the closure of all stores in UK and Ireland
C&A UK
C&A press release: it needs "to refocus the company's activities"
fields.trailText: C&A, one of Britain's high street giants best known for its acrylic knitwear and no-nonsense slacks, yesterday announced that it was closing down its 109 stores in the UK and Ireland, with the loss of 4,800 jobs.
fields.body:
C&A, one of Britain's high street giants best known for its acrylic knitwear and no-nonsense slacks, yesterday announced that it was closing down its 109 stores in the UK and Ireland, with the loss of 4,800 jobs.

The family-owned Dutch chain delayed opening the stores until 11am yesterday to deliver the shock news to staff. Its management blamed increased competition from fashionable new rivals such as Gap and Zara, plus discount chains like Matalan and Primark that sell branded goods at lower prices.

C&A had pitched its product offering squarely at people shopping on an average budget and enjoyed boom times between the 1950s and 1970s by offering functional, good-value knitwear and general clothing to a mass market. Innovations that pulled in the punters included drip-dry synthetics.

But, like its middle-market rivals Marks & Spencer, Debenhams, Littlewoods and Bhs, C&A has in recent years struggled to maintain profits while smaller trendier clothes shops such as Next have sprung up on the high street. The once-prized "Man at C&A" also became tarnished - lending the store an increasingly dowdy public image.

"To be a successful retailer these days you have to perform far better than you were 10 years ago," said Charles Coates of the AT Kearney consultancy which has been advising M&S. "Prices are falling and customers are more fickle. The shopping experience has to be more exciting, the clothes more stylish, the supply chains much slicker."

Despite the general public's apparent dissatisfaction with the store, yesterday shoppers at C&A's flagship store on London's Oxford Street said they were dismayed by the decision to close.

Leslay Hay, a 45-year-old management consultant, said: "It's tragic. I was genuinely shocked to hear about it. I've shopped at C&A all my life. I prefer it to M&S. I'm a high earner but I shop here because it's a good shop and it means I don't need to go to lots of shops to find what I want. It's just incredibly good value."

Patricia Mulligan, a 33-year-old hotel housekeeper, added: "C&A is just really good value for money. There's no real equivalent on the high street. I think it will be missed."

Most C&A stores will close at the end of the year, including its Dublin branch, and the shutters will come down on three distribution centres.

C&A is owned by the Brenninkmeijer family, a notoriously secretive Dutch clan which until two years ago would not even tell its senior managers of the company's financial results.

The store chain's managing director, Neil McCausland, said he and the family had taken the decision after failing to stem losses of £250m during the last five years. "This is an incredibly sad day and has been a very painful decision for the company to make," he said.

"C&A has been part of the British high street for over 75 years and was determined to remain so. Unfortunately business conditions do not allow this to happen. Our prime concern now is for our 4,800 employees. They will be offered generous packages well in excess of the statutory minimum.

"When new tenants take over our stores we will encourage them to employ as many of our existing staff as possible. Training and outplacement agencies have been put in place."

Shrinking market

Mr McCausland agreed that C&A had become "polarised" between its younger rivals such as Gap, which have built success by offering stylish but simple T-shirts, shirts and trousers, and higher volume cheaper discount chains such as Matalan.

"The middle market is being attacked from both sides," he said. "Since early spring we have been looking at ways of radically downsizing our operation, but came to the conclusion that there was not enough we could do to return to profitability in a shrinking market."

Mr McCausland said the chain, which has 577 stores in 12 European countries, had not suffered the same scale of problems in other continental markets.

Several retailers have already expressed an interest in buying C&A's outlets, which are located in most of the major cities across the UK and in major shopping cen tres such as Bluewater in Kent and Lakeside in Thurrock.

Officers Club managing director David Charlton and the Peacocks chief executive Richard Kirk both confirmed that they had registered an interest in in buying a number of stores. Primark, TJ Hughes, H&M and Next are also thought to be interested.

In total C&A employs more than 40,000 people across Europe. In 1999 it recorded a turnover of €5bn.

John Edmonds, the general secretary of the GMB general union, said: "This is a major blow for the employees and for the high street as a whole. Everyone is starting to suffer from the strong pound."

webTitle: Big snapper takes bite of Big Apple

fields.headline: Big snapper takes bite of Big Apple
fields.trailText: The nearest thing to confirming the urban myth that dangerous reptiles live below as well as above the pavements of New York emerged yesterday when a 1.35 metre alligator was discovered living in the wild.
fields.body:
The nearest thing to confirming the urban myth that dangerous reptiles live below as well as above the pavements of New York emerged yesterday when a 1.35 metre alligator was discovered living in the wild.

Tom Lloyd, a contractor out for a stroll with his four-year-old daughter, saw a long dark object that he took to be a toy among the ducks and geese in a stream on Staten Island. But when prodded with a stick, the object came alive and snapped at him.

The closest natural habitat of the creature - alligator mississipiensis - is North Carolina, five states away. "Somebody probably dumped him in there," said Bill Holstrom, supervisor of Bronx zoo's reptile department.

Two police officers, directed by the city's resident reptile rescue expert, Robert Shapiro, lassoed the 16kg gator's jaws, pulled it from the stream and taped its mouth shut.

Then they put the alligator, whose age was put at between two and five years, on the back seat of a squad car and drove it to the Manhattan T-shirt shop run by Mr Shapiro.

"He was hissing but he wasn't darting at us or anything," said Mr Shapiro who has hundreds of unwanted reptiles in the back of the shop and deals with about five illegally-owned crocodilians - alligators, crocodiles and caymans - each year. These have been handed over by owners who have decided that they can no longer look after them.

It has long been an urban myth that beneath the streets of Manhattan live crocodiles and alligators which have been flushed down into the sewers by owners who no longer want them.

"Animals need to be basking in the sun," said Mr Shapiro before the new find was sent on its way to a registered alligator keeper in Pennsylvania.

fields.headline: US 'expanding nuclear targets'
fields.standfirst: Even as it talks to Moscow about arms treaties new and old, Washington is accused of aiming warheads at 20% more foreign sites
fields.trailText: Senior American military officers insist that current nuclear policy prevents them shrinking the US nuclear arsenal to fewer than 2,000 to 2,500 strategic weapons - and that going lower would threaten national security. Their calculations are buried in the nation's strategic war plan and ultimately linked to presidential guidance.
fields.body:
Senior American military officers insist that current nuclear policy prevents them shrinking the US nuclear arsenal to fewer than 2,000 to 2,500 strategic weapons - and that going lower would threaten national security. Their calculations are buried in the nation's strategic war plan and ultimately linked to presidential guidance.

Defence officials do not talk openly about the nuclear targets in the strategic plan. But my estimates lead inexorably to a conclusion that US leaders are clinging to outdated planning that helps keep an unnecessarily large number of American and Russian missiles pointed at one another on hair-trigger alert.

These estimates are based on 25 years of studying strategic policy and operations - beginning with a background in the Strategic Air Command - and extensive contacts with officials knowledgeable in these areas.

The US strategic war plan consists of a very long list of targets in Russia and a shorter list of targets in China. The Pentagon says the United States must be able to destroy these targets to meet current presidential guidance on nuclear war planning, a directive issued in late 1997 to get the number of warheads down from even higher levels required in earlier plans.

Oddly, the target list has been growing instead of contracting since the last strategic arms reduction treaty, Start II, was signed in 1993. The sites the Pentagon says the US must be ready to destroy has grown by 20% in the last five years alone - to 3,000 now from 2,500 in 1995 - according to top military and former administration officials.

The vast bulk of the targets are in Russia. My research and interviews indicate that there are about 2,260 so-called vital Russian targets on the list today, only 1,100 of them actual nuclear arms sites.

By this calculation, the US has nuclear weapons aimed at 500 "conventional" targets - the buildings and bases of a hollow Russian army on the verge of disintegration; 160 leadership targets, such as government offices and military command centres, in a country practically devoid of leadership; and 500 mostly crumbling factories that produced almost no arms last year.

American strategic planners have historically set the level of damage they wish to inflict on vital targets at 80%. To destroy 80% of the 2,260 Russian sites requires the ability to deliver nearly 1,800 warheads to their targets. It is no accident that the US has about 2,200 strategic warheads on alert, according to numbers from Strategic Command officers.

Almost all US missiles on land are ready for launch in two minutes, and those on four submarines (two in the Atlantic and two in the Pacific) are ready to launch on 15 minutes' notice, officers say.

If 1,800 warheads have to be delivered quickly, the Pentagon says, the US needs a larger arsenal to allow for maintenance. Typically six or seven of the 18 nuclear-armed submarines are port-bound at any time and cannot be counted on to survive if the US were attacked. So America needs one-third more sea-based strategic weapons.

And Russia is not the only target of US missiles. Responding to the 1997 presidential guidance, the Pentagon put China back into the strategic plan after 20 years.

For China, the US now has two so-called limited attack options - involving a handful of nuclear weapons on submarines and bombers - for striking nuclear targets, leadership sites and key industries.

There are also many hundreds of secondary targets in China, Iran, Iraq and North Korea that have weapons assigned to them, though not on immediate alert.

Add it all up, and at least 2,500 American warheads are deemed necessary to carry out nuclear war against Russia and China, countries which Vice-President Al Gore recently said represent vital US partners, not enemies.

Getting to fewer than 2,000 warheads [as part of any future treaty with Russia] will be difficult unless the target requirements are eased by new presidential guidance.

Of course they could be - almost without exception, US leaders regard the attack options that would unleash thousands of nuclear warheads as absurd and grotesque. They do not believe that a cold-blooded, nuclear strike by either Russia or the US is remotely plausible.

The only nuclear conflict they do consider plausible involves the use of one or a handful of non-strategic weapons - nuclear-tipped cruise missiles, for instance - against a country other than Russia.

Deterrence would remain robust with far smaller arsenals on far lower levels of alert.

The US and Russia should aim to cut their nuclear weapons to the low hundreds and to take all of them off hair-trigger alert, with a view to eventually eliminating them under existing treaty obligations.

Bruce Blair, a former Minuteman missile launch officer, is president of the Centre for Defence Information and a co-author of The Nuclear Turning Point

webTitle: Putin backtracks on jailing of media mogul

fields.headline: Putin backtracks on jailing of media mogul
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, yesterday made a near complete u-turn concerning the arrest in Moscow of his main media critic, Vladimir Gusinsky.
fields.body:
The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, yesterday made a near complete u-turn concerning the arrest in Moscow of his main media critic, Vladimir Gusinsky.

The detention of Mr Gusinsky, the man whose television station and other media outlets have been critical of the Kremlin and ridiculed Mr Putin, had deepened doubts about the Russian leader's commitment to democracy and cast a sinister shadow over his first official foreign tour.

It appeared yesterday that the Russian president had sensed belatedly the damage done. "One certainly had other possibilities [such as] to question him without an arrest," he said in Berlin. "I think it was excessive."

Mr Putin had previously supported the decision to arrest Mr Gusinsky, but claimed that the decision had been taken independently by the Moscow prosecutor's office.

His latest words found an echo back in Moscow where Valery Nikolayev, the chief investigator at the prosecutor's office, said he would consider letting Mr Gusinsky out of jail. "After carrying out certain investigation procedures, I will consider whether we need to keep suspect Gusinsky in detention any longer," he told state television.

He said the media mogul would be charged today. Mr Gusinsky was jailed on Tuesday on suspicion of embezzlement but, in a statement brought out of jail by his lawyer yesterday, he said he had not yet been told what charges he faced. "This is a political intrigue organised by senior representatives of the state for whom the freedom of speech is a danger," the statement added.

The issue continued to dog Mr Putin's steps in Germany. It was raised by the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, in talks in Berlin with his Russian counterpart, Igor Ivanov. And after a speech to business leaders, Mr Putin stressed that Mr Gusinsky had been arrested on suspicion of taking $10m (£6.7m) in state funds from a privatisation deal.

"It isn't about him as a representative of the mass media or a journalist or editor. He is a businessman," said Mr Putin said. "I assume in Germany you pay taxes, am I right?"

The Russian president's visit marked his return to a country he knows well; he was a Soviet KGB officer in Dresden for five years in the 80s and speaks fluent German. He spoke in Russian during talks with the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, but German officials said he had occasionally corrected his interpreter.

The two leaders' initial encounter appeared to have gone well. "We agree that we want a really substantive new start in our relations," Mr Schröder said.

Meanwhile, US Jewish leaders appealed to Mr Putin yesterday to free Mr Gusinsky, saying his continued detention would damage Russia's image among potential investors in the west.

webTitle: Government's annual report faces independent test

fields.headline: Government's annual report faces independent test
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The government is considering handing over the annual report on its record to independent scrutiny in an attempt to give the exercise greater credibility amid growing public distrust of ministers' claims.
fields.body:
The government is considering handing over the annual report on its record to independent scrutiny in an attempt to give the exercise greater credibility amid growing public distrust of ministers' claims.

The Conservatives have denounced the government's an nual report as an expensive piece of party political propaganda. Tony Blair introduced the concept two years ago, to set out how well the government had delivered key manifesto commitments.

The two annual reports so far have been glowing endorsements of the government's achievements, with few or no references to omissions or failures.

Labour officials now want to give next month's report greater credibility by injecting a stronger statistical element, and ensuring all the statistics have been squared with official bodies. The report will show how many public service targets have been met.

Government backbenchers have been echoing the criticism voiced in focus groups that the party is seen as too much spin and no substance.

Gordon Prentice, a Labour backbench MP, has been urging Downing Street for months to hand its record to independent scrutiny, either by the national audit office or the newly strengthened office of national statistics, overseen by an independent national statistical commission.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has described the ap pointment of the NSC as a seminal step to overcome cynicism in British politics.

Mr Straw also admitted yesterday that carrying out the government's promises was proving difficult.

"It can be years between an idea and its delivery, with policy development, white papers, legislation and cultural change in between," he wrote in Tribune.
