webTitle: Clinton casts around for foreign success

fields.headline: Clinton casts around for foreign success
fields.standfirst: World denies Clinton his place in history
fields.trailText: With just seven months to go before he leaves the White House, Bill Clinton has embarked on what appears to be an increasingly desperate attempt to snatch some last-minute foreign policy glory from his presidency.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington and  John Hooper in Berlin
fields.body:
With just seven months to go before he leaves the White House, Bill Clinton has embarked on what appears to be an increasingly desperate attempt to snatch some last-minute foreign policy glory from his presidency.

But, welcoming Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat to the White House, even the normally optimistic Mr Clinton seemed downbeat over the prospects of pushing the slow-moving Middle East peace process closer to an elusive settlement.

"If we are going to make peace, we are going to have to deal with the difficult issues," Mr Clinton said. He would dearly love to crown his troubled second term with a major Middle East agreement. But high White House hopes at the start of this year have slumped in recent days. The death of the Syrian leader Hafaz al-Assad and the break-up of Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak's coalition have combined to make progress on either leg of the Middle East talks far more uncertain than ever.

Mr Clinton seems to have accepted that the vision of a second Camp David-style three- way agreement involving the US, Israel and the Palestinians is currently unattainable.

In spite of the official caution over this week's talks, the administration aims to do almost anything in its power to contrive a big foreign policy triumph in the closing months of Mr Clinton's presidency.

Last month, he managed a rare international trade success on Capitol Hill, when Congress approved the administration's China trade normalisation legislation.

But that victory owed as much to Mr Clinton's Republican opponents, who provided most of the votes in favour of the measure, as it did to the president himself.

And hopes of a rapprochement with Russia were dealt a blow last night when President Vladimir Putin delivered his most ominous warning yet about the consequences of expanding Nato eastwards.

Amid growing signs of a new tension in east-west relations, he said that the alliance's encroachment on former Soviet states could destabilise the entire world.

Mr Putin was delivering a keynote speech in Berlin during his official visit to Germany. He noted that the former Soviet Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania wanted to join Nato and that, if their hopes were realised, it would bring the limits of the Atlantic alliance to the Russian border.

"If a country like Russia feels threatened, that would destabilise the situation in Europe and the whole world", he continued, calling instead for the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe to be upgraded to a full-scale regional security forum.

The speech is the second time in recent weeks that Mr Putin has ruined Mr Clinton's hopes of a foreign-policy feelgood factor. Any expectations that this month's Moscow meeting between the two men might lead to a triumph for Mr Clinton's diplomacy were dashed by Mr Putin's refusal to support Washington's proposal to amend the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty.

Even some in the White House admit Mr Putin had the better of the Moscow meeting, and he has since pressed home his advantage with a series of west European visits, including the current one to Germany, which seem to be driving a wedge between Europe and the US on the missile defence issue. "Putin is running rings round us right now," said a senior White House source.

Last night Mr Putin sought to build on doubts already expressed by officials in Germany over US plans for an anti-missile defence system ostensibly aimed at "rogue states".

The Russian president said that the plans were "very dangerous" and could have serious consequences if they destroyed the balance of power.

"We cannot allow the balance of power to be disturbed," he said in his speech. "Some elements [of the proposed anti-missile defence system] would be stationed in Europe. What should Russia then think?"

The administration is now looking to the Tony Blair connection and the Northern Ireland agreement to provide the president with his elusive final foreign flourish.

If Mr Blair gives the word that conditions in Northern Ireland allow it, then Mr Clinton will again head for Britain and Ireland to bask one last time in local approval for a deal in which no one disputes he played a central role.

Hillary Clinton would love such a perfect chance to play to the Irish gallery in New York just before the official start of her Senate campaign there in September.

webTitle: Czechs try to ban Hitler's book

fields.headline: Czechs try to ban Hitler's book
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Bookshops throughout the Czech Republic have been raided by police confiscating copies of a new edition of Mein Kampf that has become one of the best-selling books in the country in a decade.
fields.body:
Bookshops throughout the Czech Republic have been raided by police confiscating copies of a new edition of Mein Kampf that has become one of the best-selling books in the country in a decade.

Michal Zitko, whose Prague-based publishing firm Ottaker II re-released Hitler's manifesto for the first time in the Czech Republic in over half a century has been charged with disseminating Nazi propaganda and faces eight years in prison if he is found guilty at a court hearing next week.

Police have indicated that they might even pull the book from library shelves.

Mr Zitko, 28, argues that he is the victim of confusion and lack of legislation to distinguish between freedom of speech and censorship. "Just like under communism an index of forbidden books is being created," he said.

He has also published in translation the US constitution and declaration of independence and has plans to reintroduce Karl Marx's Das Kapital to Czech bookshops. He declared himself stunned at the Mein Kampf crackdown.

"It was published as part of our Books that Changed the World project and some people have misunderstood my in tentions," he said. Mein Kampf is freely available in most western countries.

The raids were ordered by the government after protests by Jewish and German groups. "Freedom of speech has its limits," said Tomas Kraus or the Czech Federation of Jewish communities. "A jail sentence would allow society to show its defensive reflexes."

But defenders of free speech see the moves as a sign that strict censorship - as experienced during the four decades of communism that ended in 1990 - is on its way back.

When 800 copies of the £4.50 book appeared in March they sold out within days after the cultural minister Pavel Dostal mentioned it on commercial television. Ottaker II increased the print run to 6,000 and until the raids was planning a further 4,000 copies - a huge number for a book in the Czech Republic.

According to the Czech criminal code, anyone found guilty of spreading "national, racial, social or religious hatred or who publicly expresses sympathy for fascism or any other similar movement" can face up to eight years in prison.

"But interpretation of the law is hazy due to years of communist oppression," said a Czech legal expert. "We get stuck in this grey area."

webTitle: Poldark story nearly lost in blaze

fields.headline: Poldark story nearly lost in blaze
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The author of the Poldark novels yesterday said a fire at a stately home nearly destroyed his latest work.
fields.body:
The author of the Poldark novels yesterday said a fire at a stately home nearly destroyed his latest work.

Winston Graham, 89, was staying at Prideaux Place, near Padstow, Cornwall, when a fire broke out in the rooms he was using. Around 50 visitors were evacuated.

Forty firefighters rescued paintings and antiques and extinguished the fire before it took hold. The home is temporarily closed to the public.

Mr Graham said that if the "unrepeatable manuscript" in his suitcase had gone up in smoke "it would have, I think, killed the Poldarks".

The owner of Prideaux Place, Peter Prideaux-Brune, said that in another 10 minutes "it would have been the end of the house. [Fire] would have got into the main rafters."

webTitle: Freetown polite to the visitor from Hull

fields.headline: Freetown polite to the visitor from Hull
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: No one - not the British soldiers awaiting their ride out, not the Whitehall diplomats, and least of all Sierra Leone's president - had any idea why John Prescott descended on Freetown yesterday.
fields.body:
No one - not the British soldiers awaiting their ride out, not the Whitehall diplomats, and least of all Sierra Leone's president - had any idea why John Prescott descended on Freetown yesterday.

We were told it was to reassure the government that Britain was committed to preserving democratic rule - or as Mr Prescott accidentally put it "restoring democracy". But Robin Cook did that rather more convincingly during his own visit to Freetown a week earlier.

President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah was not complaining at being blessed with the only visit by two such high ranking British politicians to a small African country in living memory, but he did appear a little confused by it all.

There was no such doubt in Freetown, which is twinned with Hull, Mr Prescott's birthplace and constituency. Freetown's mayor, Henry Fergusson, met the deputy prime minister once before, during a visit to Hull 20 years ago when Mr Prescott was a city councillor. He presented his visitor with two pictures - one an old picture of Freetown's colonial-era council offices, the other of the same buildings after RUF rebels burned them down last year.

The mayor wondered if Hull council might not care to help rebuild the offices. And as a bonus, could Hull spare a few dustbin lorries?

Mr Prescott was non-committal, but made much of the links between the two cities, noting that the anti-slavery campaigner, William Wilberforce, had been MP for Hull and that Sierra Leone was founded by freed slaves.

Then the deputy prime minister was whisked to HMS Ocean where he could not resist yet another reference to his 10 years in the merchant navy. One Royal Navy officer muttered that being a waiter and a seaman are two different things.

fields.headline: Dome's dame-in-waiting avoids blame zone
fields.standfirst: The Millennium Dome: special report
fields.trailText: Hell hath no fury like a Millennium Dome chief executive scorned. But there is nothing like the possibility of a damehood to quell the bitterness of an unceremonious sacking. Jennie Page's appearance before a Commons select committee   was to be her first public grilling since her ousting from the New Millennium Experience Company in February.
fields.body:
Hell hath no fury like a Millennium Dome chief executive scorned. But there is nothing like the possibility of a damehood to quell the bitterness of an unceremonious sacking. Jennie Page's appearance before a Commons select committee was to be her first public grilling since her ousting from the New Millennium Experience Company in February. She was billed to answer questions for 50 minutes - so many people to blame, so little time.

Would she cast the first stone at Peter Mandelson, the erstwhile dome supremo, or his successor, Lord Falconer? And surely Bob Ayling, widely blamed for orchestrating the boardroom coup against her before he himself was sacked as chairman last month, would be dreading the havoc she could wreak with just a few hasty remarks about the behind-the-scenes machinations at the dome.

But with a damehood possibly in the pipeline, could Ms Page possibly intend to rock the boat? Could she be bounced Millennium Bridge-style into saying anything to damage her future prospects? It seemed not.

Instead, she did not get a grilling - not even a light toasting. She was given the Jubilee Line of easy rides; a cosy Hello! magazine chat in which the lovely Jennie invited us all into her beautiful dome.

The culture, media and sport select committee had metamorphosed into the hindsight committee, repeatedly asking the would-be dame whether " with hind sight " all that could have been done, had indeed been done to make the dome a success. Certainly, Ms Page had done all she could, they were assured.

She maintained her cool composure as David Faber, the lone Tory and self-confessed "dome sceptic", made a valiant effort to turn up the heat.

Should the other directors have tendered their own resignations in the wake of the disastrous opening weeks of the dome? Ms Page said only: "I think it would be invidious for me to comment on individual members of the board."

Although Ms Page has not visited the Greenwich peninsula since early February (something she has in common with the rest of the country), Labour's Llin Golding soon dragged her kicking and screaming into the syrup zone.

"It's a great pity that you don't feel you can visit the dome," she mused.

"You can't see the joy, the great smiles of enjoyment and absolute freedom the children have when they go there. It is something to treasure. I do encourage you somehow to go back."

Before she had time to get on to the gambolling lambs in springtime, the no-nonsense Ms Page quickly interrupted: "I've not gone to the dome because I don't think it's fair to other people, not because I don't have courage."

But the doughty Ms Golding would not be put off. "Go in disguise," she advised, with a wise smile. Perhaps she has made this suggestion before - to lots of people, all of whom have indeed chosen to visit the dome in disguise, dressed as the Invisible Man. This would explain a lot.

At this point, though, the chairman, Gerald Kaufman, decided the time was up, apologising profusely to the would-be dame for such a relentless grilling.

At this, Ms Page graciously retired to await her invitation to Buckingham Palace .

fields.headline: MPs criticise government home sales
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Whitehall civil servants have managed to do something no one in Britain has ever achieved - lose £110m buying and selling houses in a rising property market.
fields.body:
Whitehall civil servants have managed to do something no one in Britain has ever achieved - lose £110m buying and selling houses in a rising property market.

The sales scandal is revealed in a Commons public accounts committee report which castigates the government's highways agency for its handling of 1,600 homes compulsorily purchased for roads that were never built. In one case, ministers authorised the demoliton of 200 homes (including those above) at a cost of £18m for a widening of the A40 in west London - a year before the scheme was killed.

In another, Whitehall flooded the housing market by putting up for sale 350 homes when the M62 Manchester relief road at Bury was cancelled. As a result only one was sold privately.

fields.headline: Politics 'harmed dome's image'
fields.standfirst:
Sacked chief executive praised by MPs inquiring into poor figures
The Millennium Dome: special report
fields.trailText: The sacked chief of the Millennium Dome, Jennie Page, yesterday told MPs that she had repeatedly urged government ministers to end their close association with the dome to counter the image of it being an entirely political project.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The sacked chief of the Millennium Dome, Jennie Page, yesterday told MPs that she had repeatedly urged government ministers to end their close association with the dome to counter the image of it being an entirely political project.

Ms Page, giving evidence to the Commons culture, media and sport committee, was speaking for the first time in detail about the project since she was sacked as chief executive after the first month's disastrous attendance figures and the fiasco of the millennium eve party, when thousands of VIP guests were left queuing for hours.

The committee members, renowned for their ferocity with witnesses, treated her with notable gentleness. Norman Page, Liberal Democrat spokesman on the dome, said: "Jennie Page is just the fall guy, former dome ministers should be in the dock."

Committee chairman Gerald Kaufman warmly thanked her for her evidence and wished her well. "Wherever you next go, I believe you will be an asset."

In an hour of answering questions Ms Page never raised her voice or betrayed the slightest emotion, and neither accepted nor allocated blame. However she said she had not been back to the dome since February 4, her last working day, "because it would not be fair on our people".

Market research had shown the public very much wanted something major to mark the millennium, but did not want this to be a political project by the government.

The dome had the problem from the start that the public very much associated it with successive governments, and with significant figures in those governments.

She named no names, but asked if the appointment of Peter Mandelson as dome minister had increased the politicisation of the project, she replied: "I made several attempts to persuade ministers that standing back from the dome would be good for them as well as good for the dome."

She was closely questioned about the rosy visitor projections, the main reason why the dome is now perceived as a failure: the official prediction, before opening, was 12m, and this was later reduced to 7m.

Ms Page outlined the projections of visitor figures, and insisted they were justified by market research. As recently as last October, research showed 17m people were strongly minded to visit the dome.

However by then the dome management knew it would have a cash flow problem because advance ticket sales were so slow, and this was made worse on opening by the thousands of school children let in free - fulfilling a promise made by the prime minister last year.

The cash flow problems grew worse in the opening month, as sponsors held back payment in protest over the inital chaotic queueing, particularly for the Body Zone, and other problems.

"There is no doubt that by the time the dome opened, the management team was exhausted. They had had far too many pressures on them. We were critically short of fresh management expertise to keep us going at that time."

Ms Page said she could not think of anything that could have been done to improve the public image of the dome.

"There is a propensity to visit a place which seems full of joy and interest, and which is strongly recommended by friends, which the Tate seems to have achieved. But the Tate is a very different matter from going down to Greenwich, paying £57 and giving a day to it," she said. "The public needed to be very, very sure of what they were getting."

At the time of Ms Page's sacking it was widely reported that sponsors had demanded her head as the price of their continuing support.

However the committee was assured by representatives of three of the biggest sponsors - Manpower, Boots and BT - that they never called for her sacking.

David Clayton-Smith, former director of customer marketing at Boots, admitted Boots had not paid £2m of its £12m sponsorship. But concerns had been resolved and the money would be paid "this week".

fields.body:
The BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, was last night struggling to defuse an escalating row with the Premier League as the corporation regained some lost ground by winning the rights to live FA Cup and England home international matches.

Hints by Mr Dyke early yesterday that the Premiership auction had been rigged backfired badly as they overshadowed his attempt to put the BBC back on the sporting map.

In a sharp u-turn, he said last night that there had been no "dirty tricks" in the Premiership auction and withdrew accusations that ITV had been given an unfair advantage which allowed it to snatch the highlights package. Mr Dyke put his more cynical line of thought down to being in a bad mood.

"We were quite surprised that ITV bid for highlights when that hasn't been their strategy," he said. "Everyone was surprised by the size of ITV's bid but no I don't think they played dirty. They just had to have it. We should just move on now."

Mike Lee, Premier League spokesman, described Mr Dyke's earlier comments as "sour grapes" and said: "We were disappointed and shocked at some of the things the BBC have said which were unnecessary and also inaccurate. The BBC would have been better advised to be more graceful in defeat. Mr Lee also reacted angrily to suggestions that the league was indebted to the BBC. "Some senior executives at the BBC are suggesting that they built the Premier League brand and we regard that as an insult.

"The brand has been built by the clubs, the fans, the league itself and all our broadcasting partners - particularly Sky and Radio 5 Live."

Mr Dyke said reports of the death of Match of the Day had been greatly exaggerated, with the programme format being revived for the FA Cup coverage, albeit for only a handful of weekends a year, from the start of the 2001-2002 season.

The joint deal with BSkyB is worth £400m over three years with live matches featured on both the BBC and Sky; the final will be broadcast simultaneously. The two refused to divulge how much each was paying.

The agreement will see "FA Cup weekends" featuring two live matches, highlights, previews and the live draw for the next round on Sunday nights. "The FA Cup is coming home to the BBC," Mr Dyke said. "Four million viewers have been lost from the FA Cup final over the past three years and we have plans to restore the magic."

He reiterated that the BBC would never have matched the £61m a year paid for the Premiership highlights by ITV. The offer beat the BBC by £20m.

"I'm delighted we have won the FA Cup and England games," Mr Dyke said. "I'd be much happier if we had also won the recorded highlights but so be it."

ITV earlier angrily denied accusations made by Mr Dyke that it had not made a bid in the first round of the auction and to BBC suggestions that its rival had been made aware that it was not going to retain the FA Cup.

Mr Lee added: "ITV certainly didn't get any tip from us and if they are suggesting there was any kind of collusion then that is absolute nonsense. We had no idea what was in the sealed bids."

Mr Dyke had told Radio 4's Today programme yesterday morning. "We were told ITV weren't in the first round of bidding. Actually the officials of the Premier League rushed round to ITV and said: 'Come on, why don't you join in this auction because we want to push the price up for the BBC'."

He added that "something happened in the last two days that made them decide to throw vast sums of money at something."

webTitle: Hague aide fails to admit firm's help

fields.headline: Hague aide fails to admit firm's help
fields.standfirst:
Parliament: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague suffered a blow last night when a member of the shadow cabinet was forced to admit that he broke Commons rules over his links with a leading accountancy firm.
fields.body:
William Hague suffered a blow last night when a member of the shadow cabinet was forced to admit that he broke Commons rules over his links with a leading accountancy firm.

David Heathcoat-Amory, the shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, faced demands for an apology after it emerged that he failed to tell MPs that he has received support from PriceWaterhouseCoopers.

Mr Heathcoat-Amory, a rightwinger who resigned from John Major's government over Europe, slipped up during the budget debate in March when he spoke about the firm without declaring that he benefited from assistance provided by PWC. Under Commons rules, MPs have to make a declaration during debates if their speeches relate to their interests.

His mistake will prove embarrassing for Mr Hague because the Tory leader lavished praise on PWC on the day after the budget. Mr Hague described the firm - the Tory party's accountants - as the "most reputable" in the world, without mentioning the help provided to his shadow cabinet colleague.

Mr Heathcoat-Amory quoted at length from the PWC press releases attacking Gordon Brown. He told the Commons that he had been trained by the firm, but failed to mention that PWC had seconded an accountant to help the shadow treasury team respond to the 1999 Finance Bill.

His error is embarrassing although Mr Heathcoat-Amory did declare the assistance in the register of members' interests.

Mr Heathcoat-Amory said last night that he would be writing to the parliamentary standards commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin. The MP for Wells told the Guardian: "I always try to keep to the rules meticulously. I do not consider this to have been a major breach of the rules."

However, Labour MPs last night rounded on the shadow chief secretary. Fraser Kemp, the MP for Houghton and Washington East, said: "I hope that Mr Heathcoat-Amory will take immediate steps to offer a full and frank apology to the House of Commons to rectify a blatant breach of the rules."

Ms Filkin said last night: "If any MP has a benefit or a registered pecuniary interest and they refer to that or anything that is relevant to that it would be advisable and wise to declare it."

The row over Mr Heathcoat-Amory highlighted the way in which Tory frontbenchers are accepting outside sponsorship to help them with their work in opposition. Every member of the shadow treasury team received support from PWC last year. Oliver Letwin also received help from other companies - Sainsbury, British Land plc, WJB Chiltern plc and Cameron McKenna.

Mr Kemp has written to Lord Neil of Bladen, the chairman of the committee on standards in public life, to complain about the sponsorship of frontbench spokespeople. In his letter, he said: "This could lead to a situation in which, for example, an airline sponsored a Tory transport spokesperson or an energy company paid the party's energy spokesperson. For which interest would that spokesperson then be speaking - their party, or their sponsor?"

PWC last night attempted to cool the row, saying that it had provided similar help to the Labour treasury frontbench before the last election. Colin Mayes, a company spokesman, said: "We like to provide technical support to the opposition to ensure that parliament passes better legislation." Tories assisted by PriceWaterhouseCoopers: Francis Maude, as shadow chancellor until February; David Heathcoat-Amory, shadow chief secretary to the Treasury

Howard Flight, spokesman, also received legal assistance from three solicitors; Oliver Letwin, spokesman, also helped by three other companies

Tory links with business

 Richard Ottaway, assisted by Deloitte & Touche and Kingston

 Alan Duncan, shadow trade and industry minister, is a non-executive director of NW Brown Capital Partners Ltd which invests in science and innovation companies

 Richard Page, shadow DTI minister, is a director of Page Holdings, which is involved in petrol retailing

fields.headline: Transplant lifeline to death row
fields.standfirst: Organs of executed convicts in China sold to Malaysians
fields.trailText: The night before their execution, 18 convicts were shown on a Chinese television programme, their crimes announced to the public. Wilson Yeo saw the broadcast from his hospital bed in China and knew that one of the men would provide him with the kidney he so badly needed.
fields.body:
The night before their execution, 18 convicts were shown on a Chinese television programme, their crimes announced to the public. Wilson Yeo saw the broadcast from his hospital bed in China and knew that one of the men would provide him with the kidney he so badly needed.

Mr Yeo, 40, a Malaysian who manages the local branch of a lottery company in Malacca, never learned the name of the prisoner whose kidney is now implanted on his right side. He knows only what the surgeon told him: the executed man was 19 years old and sentenced to die for drug trafficking.

"I knew that I would be getting a young kidney," Mr. Yeo says now, one year after his successful transplant. "That was very important for me."

Over the past few years at least a dozen residents of this small Malaysian city have travelled to a provincial hospital in Chongqing, China, where they paid for what they could not get in Malaysia: functioning kidneys to prolong their lives.

They went to China, a place most of them barely knew, with at least $10,000 (£6,650) in cash. They encountered a medical culture where kidneys were given to those with money and a doctor could stop treatment if a patient didn't pay up. Surgeons advised them to wait until a major holiday, when authorities traditionally execute the most prisoners.

China's preferred method of capital punishment, a bullet to the back of the head, is conducive to transplants because it does not contaminate the prisoners' organs with poisonous chemicals, as lethal injections do, or directly affect the circulatory system, as would a bullet through the heart.

More than 1,000 Malaysians have had kidney transplants in China, according to an estimate by Dr SY Tan, one of Malaysia's leading kidney specialists. Many patients go after giving up hope of finding an organ donor in Malaysia, where the average waiting time for a transplant is 16 years.

It goes without saying that the kidney transplants the doctors in China perform are highly controversial. The Transplantation Society, a leading international medical forum based in Montreal, has banned the use of organs from convicted criminals. Human rights groups call the practice barbaric.

But patients here who have undergone the operation in China say they were too desperate at the time to consider the ethical consequences.

"Ethics are only a game for those people who are not sick," says Tan Dau Chin, a paramedic who has spent his career working with dialysis patients in Malacca. "Let me put it this way: What if this happened to you?"

Simon Leong, 35, a Malaccan who underwent a successful operation two years ago in Chongqing, says the principle of buying an organ is "wrong."

"But I was thinking, I have two sons. Who's going to provide for them?"

Corrine Yong, 54, who returned from Chongqing two months ago after a successful operation, was told that if she did not receive a transplant, she would probably not live much longer. "I didn't have a choice," she says.

Kidneys were transplanted from just eight donors in Malaysia last year. Thousands of people are on the official waiting list. Dr Tan, the Malaysian kidney specialist, says the small number of donors is partly due to religious and cultural taboos.

It is impossible to know exactly how many Asians travel to China for organ transplants. But data informally collected from doctors in at least three countries suggest the numbers are in the hundreds every year.

Chinese officials have admitted that organs are occasionally taken from convicts, but deny that the practice is widespread.

That view does not tally with the stories that patients from Malacca tell, where kidneys are essentially handed out to the highest bidders, often foreigners.

Patients say they are advised by friends who have already undergone a transplant to bring the surgeons gifts. Mrs Yong brought a pewter teapot and picture frame. Mrs Soh and her husband brought a bottle of Martell cognac, a carton of cigarettes and a bottle of perfume for the chief surgeon's wife.

To pay for the transplant the Leongs pooled savings from family members and appealed for funds through Chinese language newspapers. The cost of an operation amounts to several years' salary for many Malaysians.

Yet despite financial problems and culture shock, all four patients interviewed for this article said they had no regrets.

Mr Yeo enjoys a life of relative normalcy, maintaining a regular work schedule and jogging almost every day.

Does it disturb him that an executed man's kidney is in his abdomen? "I pray for the guy and say, 'Hopefully your afterlife is better'," Mr Yeo said.

And has he ever wondered whether the prisoner might have been innocent?

Mr Yeo pauses and stares straight ahead. "I haven't gone through that part - the moral part," he said. "I don't know. I can't question it too much. I have to live."

fields.headline: Whitehall audit 'opens up'
fields.trailText: The government is considering handing over the annual report on its record to independent scrutiny in an attempt to give the exercise greater credibility amid growing public distrust of ministers' claims.
fields.body:
The government is considering handing over the annual report on its record to independent scrutiny in an attempt to give the exercise greater credibility amid growing public distrust of ministers' claims.

The Conservatives have denounced the government's annual report as an expensive piece of party political propaganda. Tony Blair introduced the concept two years ago, to set out how well the government had delivered key manifesto commitments. The two annual reports so far have been glowing endorsements of the government's achievements, with few or no references to omissions or failures.

Labour officials now want to give next month's report greater credibility by injecting a stronger statistical element, and ensuring all the statistics have been squared with official bodies. The report will show how many public service targets have been met.

Government backbenchers have been echoing the criticism voiced in focus groups that the party is seen as all spin and no substance.

Gordon Prentice, a Labour backbench MP, has been urging Downing Street for months to hand its record to independent scrutiny, either by the National Audit Office or the newly strengthened Office of National Statistics, overseen by an independent National Statistical Commission (NSC).

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has described the appointment of the NSC as a seminal step to overcome cynicism in British politics.

webTitle: Left behind in the race for style and value

fields.headline: Left behind in the race for style and value
fields.standfirst: 4,800 jobs go as beleagured "middle market"  family name announces the closure of all stores in UK and Ireland
fields.trailText: To any keen fashion eye casting a cursory glance along Britain's high streets on a Saturday afternoon, the news that C&A is to close its 113 stores comes as no surprise.
fields.body:
To any keen fashion eye casting a cursory glance along Britain's high streets on a Saturday afternoon, the news that C&A is to close its 113 stores comes as no surprise. While other high street chains such as Next and Marks & Spencer are buzzing despite a recent drop in profits, the portals of C&A are devoid both of teenage kids looking for a quick fashion fix and of older shoppers looking for a bargain.

So who does C&A appeal to? Despite an expensive advertising campaign, which has been running almost nightly on prime time television since March, nobody knows - least of all C&A. The TV ads urged viewers to "discover the difference at C&A today." But what is the difference?

Rivals Next, Bhs and M&S have turned to well-designed, spacious stores which have a contemporary feel. They stock fashion-conscious clothes which follow the lead of the catwalk. M&S in particular has upped its quota of trend-led clothing in recent seasons, with positive feedback from the fashion press and younger customers. Yet C&A has refused to follow.

As far as design is concerned, it remains stub bornly entrenched in the early eighties, with no concession to the increasing twin demands for cheap, trend-led fashion sold in a pleasing retail environment. Chrome doors, static carpets, cluttered layouts and harsh lighting all look like throwbacks from the era that taste forgot.

The clothes themselves, once at the cheapest end of the market, represent no better value than TopShop or New Look, and worse value than the competitive prices offered by out-of-town retail centres such as Matalan and Peacocks. Matalan is this year's biggest retail success story, and has had a direct effect on C&A's fortunes.

And there's the rub. If C&A can't capitalise on value, it certainly can't capitalise on style. Today, TopShop has cornered the teen market with its quick response to catwalk trends and its interactive, hi-octane environment - computer games, nail bars and a huge array of cheap accessories all vie for teenage pocket money. Miss Selfridge and New Look have also revamped their images.

With the bottom dropping out of the middle market, all C&A can do is concentrate its efforts in Europe, where competition is not as tough.

fields.headline: House seeks own media adviser
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The House of Commons, beset by accusations of failure to modernise, is to haul itself into the cut-throat media-dominated world of the 21st century by appointing its first "communications adviser".
fields.body:
Wanted: spin doctor for 700-year-old institution. Must relish inexplicable customs, impenetrable rules and rows over breastfeeding and wallpaper.

The House of Commons, beset by accusations of failure to modernise, is to haul itself into the cut-throat media-dominated world of the 21st century by appointing its first "communications adviser".

Just as the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, is handing over his daily media briefings to civil servants, the authorities of the lower house are advertising for their own "expert in media relations".

In return for a salary of up to £56,800 plus benefits, the new recruit will explain the mysteries of the Commons to the media and the public as well as advising committees and other departments in the house on media strategy.

The election of new Labour, with its sizeable majority and pledges to modernise parliament, has sharpened the focus on the often obscure ways of the Palace of Westminster. As MPs launched a fresh offensive in the battle for childcare facilities in the 19th century building, accusations resurfaced that the palace boasts a rifle range and a string of bars but no creche.

More recently, a row erupted over breastfeeding, after the speaker, Betty Boothroyd, banned the practice in Commons public areas following pleas from Labour MP Julia Drown to feed her baby son in committee hearings.

The decoration of the palace came under the spotlight when the Lord Chancellor, Lord Irvine, declared his intention to refurbish his Lords apartment with £300 a roll wallpaper in the style of Pugin.

Commons sources insisted that the new post, which includes childcare vouchers but will require flexible working with "long hours on occasion", was not a spin doctor, since the aim was merely to open up the workings of the house rather than promote aspects of it and obscure others.

"There should be a better focus and more professionalism," said one. "Not to have anyone there at all in the year 2000 is pretty remarkable."

The House of Commons, beset by accusations of failure to modernise, is to haul itself into the cut-throat media-dominated world of the 21st century by appointing its first "communications adviser". Just as the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, is handing over his daily media briefings to civil servants, the authorities of the lower house are advertising for their own "expert in media relations". In return for a salary of up to £56,800 plus benefits, the new recruit will explain the mysteries of the Commons to the media and the public as well as advising committees and other departments in the house on media strategy. The election of new Labour, with its sizeable majority and pledges to modernise parliament, has sharpened the focus on the often obscure ways of the Palace of Westminster. As MPs launched a fresh offensive in the battle for childcare facilities in the 19th century building, accusations resurfaced that the palace boasts a rifle range and a string of bars but no creche. More recently, a row erupted over breastfeeding, after the speaker, Betty Boothroyd, banned the practice in Commons public areas following pleas from Labour MP Julia Drown to feed her baby son in committee hearings. The decoration of the palace came under the spotlight when the Lord Chancellor, Lord Irvine, declared his intention to refurbish his Lords apartment with £300 a roll wallpaper in the style of Pugin. Commons sources insisted that the new post, which includes childcare vouchers but will require flexible working with "long hours on occasion", was not a spin doctor, since the aim was merely to open up the workings of the house rather than promote aspects of it and obscure others. "There should be a better focus and more professionalism," said one. "Not to have anyone there at all in the year 2000 is pretty remarkable."

webTitle: Patten urges EU to pull together

fields.headline: Patten urges EU to pull together
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: EU governments must do more to create common foreign policies or face up to "weakness and mediocrity", Chris Patten, the British external relations commissioner warned last night.
fields.body:
EU governments must do more to create common foreign policies or face up to "weakness and mediocrity", Chris Patten, the British external relations commissioner warned last night.

Mr Patten used a speech in Paris to complain about the reluctance of the EU's 15 members to pool their efforts, while simultaneously calling on the union to become a "serious counterpart" to the United States.

France, with a strong tradition of running an independent foreign policy, takes over the EU's rotating presidency for six months from July 1.

The former Conservative party chairman and governor of Hong Kong insisted the supranational commission - whose work represents the pooling of jealously-guarded national sovereignty - must be more closely involved in the EU's global activities. "Our role cannot be reduced to one of painting by numbers, simply filling in the blanks on a canvas drawn by others," he told the French Institute for International Relations in a speech billed as his most important since taking office last September.

Mr Patten said it would be "absurd" to divorce European foreign policy from the institutions dealing with trade, sanctions and humanitarian aid. "What is needed is a sensible and sensitive partnership between the institutions of the union and the member states," he said.

"We should be engaged not in trench warfare but in a common enterprise to ensure that the world's largest trading group also makes its presence felt politically."

Mr Patten said that "luckily" he worked well with Javier Solana of Spain, the former Nato chief who heads foreign policy and defence efforts for the EU's council of ministers.

Aides insisted he was not involved in a "turf-grabbing" exercise. But his carefully-crafted remarks were interpreted in Brussels as powerful criticism of the awkward relationship between two institutions whose areas of responsibility overlap and which often look more like rivals than partners.

Last week the Solana camp was furious over the leak of an earlier version of Mr Patten's remarks, in which he said that "foreign policy was not only about photo-opportunities".

Yesterday he said:"Foreign policy remains primarily a matter for democratically elected member state governments. But it is equally necessary that all should acknowledge that mere inter-governmentalism is a recipe for weakness and mediocrity, for a European foreign policy of the lowest common denominator."

Mr Patten complained that some Europeans had foolishly measured their devotion to the cause of Europe by their anti- Americanism. "It is a fallacy to imagine that there is a choice to be made between Europeanism and Atlanticism," he said.

But he attacked Washington's policy towards the UN, the environment and for "a pursuit of extraterritorial powers combined with a neuralgic hostility to any external authority over their own affairs".

Mr Patten decried "lousy procedures" and bad management of the EU's £7bn annual aid budget.

"Aid volumes have increased two or three times as fast as the staff at our disposal," he said. The average delay in disbursing aid has gone from three to four-and-a-half years and, in some cases, to more than eight-and-a-half years.

webTitle: British exit opens way for rebels

fields.headline: British exit opens way for rebels
fields.standfirst:
Fearful Sierra Leone is left in the hands of a shaky UN
Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The last royal marines withdrew from Sierra Leone yesterday as Britain's deputy prime minister, John Prescott, visited Freetown to assure its government of continued backing from London for the war against the Revolutionary United Front.
fields.body:
The last royal marines withdrew from Sierra Leone yesterday as Britain's deputy prime minister, John Prescott, visited Freetown to assure its government of continued backing from London for the war against the Revolutionary United Front.

But many people in Sierra Leone are not persuaded that the strengthened United Nations force which the British are leaving behind will guarantee security or maintain military pressure on the rebels. The RUF already appeared to be testing the UN's resolve with an attack yesterday on Nigerian peacekeepers near Port Loko, northeast of the capital. The UN said the rebels were beaten off.

Some senior British and Sierra Leonean officials privately say they believe Britain is pulling the bulk of its forces out too early, given that the military expertise and the psychological impact of British forces have been crucial to keeping the RUF at bay.

Mr Prescott insisted that Britain was not withdrawing from Sierra Leone but merely scaling down its forces from a high of more than 1,000 combat troops now that the immediate rebel threat to the capital has been staved off.

A 90-strong British team will remain to train Sierra Leone's new army along with about 200 troops to provide security, including members of the SAS, and a couple of ships offshore.

"We aren't leaving," said Mr Prescott. "We've brought an element of stability and now we're moving to the second stage of restoring and helping in the democracy."

Last month, President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah called on Tony Blair to keep the British combat force in Sierra Leone. Yesterday the president said, "We would have preferred for them to remain here forever," but added: "The British government has promised to help us in carrying forward the stability they have brought."

The commander of the British force, Brigadier David Richards, left Sierra Leone saying he believed the intervention six weeks ago probably prevented the rebels from taking Freetown and had galvanised the UN and pro-government forces.

"I think if we hadn't stiffened the UN's resolve at a critical time", he said, "and materially assisted in the defensive arrangement on the outskirts of Freetown it would have been very different.

"There was the effect on morale, and the direction we gave to people either directly or subtly, particularly in relation to government forces which didn't exist."

He is almost certainly right. It is now clear that the RUF took about 500 United Nations peacekeepers hostage at the beginning of last month in a bid to prevent the UN from resisting a rebel takeover.

Most of the peacekeepers capitulated without resistance, reinforcing the perception of the UN as weak and unwilling to fight. About 200 Zambians surrendered to just 20 rebels, handing over 13 armoured vehicles subsequently used in RUF assaults. A few days later, Jordanian peacekeepers fled long before the RUF reached their position.

The rebels' seizure of the hostages paralysed the UN. The force commander, Major-General Vijay Jetley, appeared more concerned with winning their release than with the RUF threat to Freetown. He insisted that his men had no mandate to do more than defend themselves. They seemed unwilling to do even that.

The arrival of the British military gave some backbone to the UN and a breathing space to the government. The troops oversaw the rapid shaping of the Sierra Leone army and helped ensure that rival forces - notably soldiers loyal to former military ruler Johnny Paul Koroma, and the Kamajor militia - threw their weight behind the government.

The British also laid out a military strategy to drive the RUF from around Freetown, and to seize the rebel headquarters inland at Makeni and the diamond mines which have funded their war.

But while the capital is secure for now, the army advance towards Makeni has stalled and it will be weeks or months before an assault on the diamond areas is possible, especially with the rains coming.

There is considerable scepticism among British and Sierra Leonean officials that the UN will move into and defend those areas newly captured by government forces.

British officials say that Gen Jetley has now been per suaded by them and by UN headquarters in New York that self-defence can still permit peacekeepers to take the initiative against any rebel threat to UN forces or civilians.

But the RUF has once again taken peacekeepers hostage, this time 21 Indians who are members of Gen Jetley's own army, and the UN in Sierra Leone is again talking about the need to avoid any actions that might endanger the captives' safety. Some government officials fear that is once again a code word for inaction.

The UN is keen to shift the emphasis towards negotiation. An Organisation of African Unity delegation is in Freetown to press for a ceasefire but Mr Kabbah says his government will not agree to a cessation of hostilities until the rebels leave areas they have seized since last year's peace accords.

These include many diamond mines that were under the control not of the RUF but of the army loyal to the former military regime and which now backs the government.

webTitle: GM trial farm 'had serious crop disease'

fields.headline: GM trial farm 'had serious crop disease'
fields.standfirst:
Government drive to test biotech agriculture suffers further setback
GM debate: special report
fields.trailText: The credibility of the government backed programme of GM trials was at risk last night when it emerged that a farm involved in the programme had suffered a serious crop disease which required special quarantine measures.
fields.body:
The credibility of the government backed programme of GM trials was at risk last night when it emerged that a farm involved in the programme had suffered a serious crop disease which required special quarantine measures.

Officials defended the decision to use the site by saying different crops were involved.

It piles on problems for ministers who have had a bumpy month ever since it was revealed hundreds of farmers had unwittingly sown conventional oil seed rape contaminated by GM material when the seeds were grown in Canada.

Only this week Michael Meacher, the environment minister, admitted there would be no way of stopping similar occurrences here just weeks after the start of three years of trials designed to reassure consumers and environmentalists that crops grown from the new technology would not damage the countryside.

It also emerged yesterday that the European commission is proposing that member states temporarily allow contamination of conventional seeds by up to 0.5% of GM material, half the tolerance wanted by European seed manufacturers, but five times greater than the limit the Ice land supermarket chain allows on its supplies for non-GM food. This figure would apply until more permanent EU decisions were reached. The Ministry of Agriculture refused to discuss the document last night saying ministers were still considering tolerance levels.

Officials insisted it was safe to use Sunnymead Farm, at Wivenhoe, Essex, as a GM trial site, one of 12 testing GM maize being developed for animal feed. It said the disease problems were restricted to sugar beet. Any decision to remove the site would reduce the number of trials of the maize below the minimum figure said by scientific advisers to be necessary to make the trials robust. They had already reduced the minimum from 25 because of the problem the biotech industry was having in persuading original volunteers to proceed with them.

But the Department of the Environment said it would press on with trials this year, even if numbers dropped further, since they were part of a longer programme. In all, four types of GM crop are being tested - with the number of farm sites announced stand ing at 48, only four more than minimum total. There were originally at least 66 promised this year, with hopes of up to 80.

Sunnymead Farm was chosen by scientific advisers despite the fact that farmer Jim Dutton had to destroy conventional sugar beet and restrict movements on and off the farm to avoid contamination. Local opponents of the trial called for its immediate end.

Mr Dutton said he had not planted any beet this year and that the trial site was on the other side of the farm.

The Ministry of Agriculture said: "There is no risk of the disease spreading. The usual plant controls are adequate to deal with the situation. We can't see this has anything to do with the farm scale evaluation issue."

The disease concerned is rhizomania, a virus that has become widespread throughout Europe since it appeared in Italy in 1955. More than 133 farms are under restriction in England. It is spread via spores found in water held in the soil. The ministry said it can be carried to other fields and farms by "machinery, vehicles, transplanted crops, wind or any other means".

Among hygiene measures demanded are "washing and disinfecting farm machinery, vehicles and footwear before leaving the infested field and when leaving the premises". Farmers are also recommended to "minimise access to your farm by visiting machinery and vehicles".

The Department of the Environment overseeing the trial programme said it had sought guidance from the Ministry of Agriculture and was content with it.

Aventis, the company trialling the maize, said that rhizomania outbreak was no reason to abandon the site since it was a disease that affected sugar beet. It also condemned the pressure anti-GM groups had put on farmers.

Activists working independently of any groups claim to have have destroyed or interfered with three GM oilseed rape fields in the past week and there unconfirmed reports that another six have been tampered with in five counties.

These were all sites licensed for GM testing although not part of the farm-scale trials. "The majority of winter oil seed rape sites have now been destroyed," one of the crop-trashers said.

"We believe that there are only five left. Most of the fields were protected and one, at the National Institute for Agricultural Botany, had round the clock security guards and a chain link fence."

webTitle: Setback for Blair's pledge to ban tobacco advertising in Europe

fields.headline: Setback for Blair's pledge to ban tobacco advertising in Europe
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: The government's manifesto pledge to ban tobacco advertising received a setback yesterday after the European court of justice was told that the directive enshrining a Europe-wide ban was illegal and was advised it should be annulled.
fields.body:
The government's manifesto pledge to ban tobacco advertising received a setback yesterday after the European court of justice was told that the directive enshrining a Europe-wide ban was illegal and was advised it should be annulled.

The government has been fighting the tobacco industry in the UK courts over its determination to implement the directive here ahead of other member states. That plan was in tatters yesterday following the legal opinion from the advocate general, which the European court is expected to accept.

Public health minister Yvette Cooper immediately pledged that the UK would go it alone, bringing in its own primary legislation as soon as possible to ban cigarette advertisements and tobacco sponsorship. "A ban on tobacco advertising is supported by the majority of the general public, the medical profession and in parliament, but the tobacco industry continues to oppose it," she said.

The government is expected now to try to pull out all the stops to get the UK ban in place before the next election - at least a year later than it had hoped.

The ministers' decision to take the European route has badly backfired. They pledged to implement the directive last autumn, but were immediately challenged in the British courts. The high court backed the tobacco manufacturers' argument that the ban was a restraint on trade and should anyway not be brought in before the industry's legal challenge to the European court was settled. The government won in the court of appeal but the case is now before the House of Lords who adjourned their hearings until the advocate general had delivered his opinion.

The advocate general yesterday told the European court that the directive should be annulled because it constitutes a block on trade and does not advance the interests of the internal market, which is contrary to community law. If the court now annuls the directive as expected, the case before the House of Lords is no longer relevant and the government must start again.

Clive Bates of the campaigning group Action on Smoking and Health said: "It's a setback and we are disappointed. The law governing the single market is not supposed to promote trade at any cost, but with a high level of health and consumer protection."

But there was "a bright silver lining", he said. "If a tobacco bill is introduced in Westminster it will enable the government to close all the loopholes in the advertising ban, introduce some of the health select committee recommendations and implement the tobacco product directive that went through the European parliament yesterday.

"Paradoxically, this setback in Europe could give us much tighter legislation in Britain. This will be better in the long term though we will have yet more frustrating delay and further unnecessary harm to health while sound tobacco policies are blocked with legal manoeuvring."

The tobacco industry was delighted by the advocate general's verdict. "Basically we would hope now that the government takes full note of this opinion and withdraws any attempt to impose an advertising ban before the judges have made their final decision," said John Carlisle, the industry spokesman. "What this ruling indicates is that even this government is not beyond the rule of law."

He believes that the legal opinion also throws into doubt the latest directive on tobacco products, which is supposed to bring in larger health warnings on cigarette packets and ban the use of terms such as "mild" and "light" which give the misleading impression that the cigarettes are less harmful.

"All that directive is on a very similar legal basis to the advertising directive," he said.

webTitle: Lack of power cuts rail service

fields.headline: Lack of power cuts rail service
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Railtrack put up its hands last night and admitted that it was not leaves on the line but no power in the overhead cables which was preventing Eurostar trains from running between London and York at peak times.
fields.body:
Railtrack put up its hands last night and admitted that it was not leaves on the line but no power in the overhead cables which was preventing Eurostar trains from running between London and York at peak times.

A new venture by Great North Eastern Railways to run Eurostar trains between the two cities has been set back by Railtrack's ruling that the trains cannot operate between 7-10am and 4-7pm.

The official reason is that there is so much overload on the power lines during this crucial period that the 125mph Eurostar trains might break down.

A GNER spokesman said last night: "We were told that there was a danger that we might blow out all electric kettles and television sets between King's Cross and Peterborough if we tried to run the trains."

The 14-coach Eurostar sets have been hired by GNER to combat overcrowding on the line.

They will provide an extra 2m seats a year and complement the company's new tilting trains when they are introduced in the next few years.

The Eurostar units, which cost around £20m each, are part of the ill-fated fleet of regional Eurostar trains destined for routes from locations north of London to Paris. They have been mothballed for five years.

GNER has also been prevented by Eurostar from using its name and has been forced to provide what is essentially an off-peak service only to passengers.

The service is running under the title the GNER white rose service.

webTitle: BBC players come a cropper in turf wars

fields.headline: BBC players come a cropper in turf wars
fields.standfirst:
Carping over Premiership loss clouds recapture of FA Cup matches
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: To wrest the FA Cup back from ITV and retain the rights to screen Premiership football highlights would have been a famous victory for Greg Dyke. Paraded at shoulder height around the fountain at television centre, his position as the saviour of BBC Sport would have been assured.
fields.byline: Matt Wells, David Teather  and John Cassy
fields.body:
To wrest the FA Cup back from ITV and retain the rights to screen Premiership football highlights would have been a famous victory for Greg Dyke. Paraded at shoulder height around the fountain at television centre, his position as the saviour of BBC Sport would have been assured.

As it is, the director general's strategy lies in tatters. Having apparently misjudged the seriousness of ITV's desire to add a highlights package to its live football portfolio, Mr Dyke was hinting darkly at dirty tricks yesterday. Yet even that plan backfired when the Premiership hit back hard, all but declaring it was glad to see the back of the BBC anyway.

Even the announcement of the FA Cup deal - brought forward in a damage limitation favour - handed him only a few crumbs of comfort.

As the commercial broadcasters scoffed at their newly replenished banqueting table, Mr Dyke could only plead poverty.

When he launched his vision of a new BBC in April, he declared: "We can't justify taking vast amounts of money from licence fee payers and giving it all to footballers. We have to be more responsible than that." Yet he was clearly prepared to spend £120m for the three-year Premiership highlights deal and, it is understood, the best part of £200m for the FA Cup and England's home internationals.

It has long been clear that the retention of the Match of the Day highlights deal was Mr Dyke's priority. When preliminary bids were submitted to the Premier League by May 10, he believed success was within his grasp. His ITV contacts (Mr Dyke's background is in commercial television) told him that the BBC's "indicative" bid, worth about £30m a year, was slightly ahead of his rival's. This fitted in with his assumption that ITV would prefer to hold on to the live FA Cup rights: live football secured higher advertising revenue, he calculated, and ITV would be unlikely to sacrifice its commercial advantage.

But at some point between May 10 and last Wednesday, ITV decided that it was going to go all out for the Premiership highlights. It already had live football with the Champions' League deal, it figured, and given a choice between the ailing FA Cup and the golden jewel of the English Premiership, there was only one way to jump. So ITV chiefs upped their bid significantly for the final round.

The BBC clearly believes that the commercial network was tipped off that it had lost out in the separate bidding process for the FA Cup, and had decided to use the extra cash to boost its Premiership bid in an all-or-nothing pounce: Mr Dyke claimed yesterday that the ITV deal with the Premiership made no economic sense. "We were told that they weren't in the first round of bidding and the officers of the Premier League rushed round to ITV and said: 'Why don't you join in this auction, because we want to push the price up for the BBC.' Something happened in the last few days that made them decide to throw vast sums of money at it, which we couldn't justify beating with licence-payers' money."

A BBC insider added: "There is a real sense within the industry that something must have happened for them to lob in such a huge offer. That's a question which needs answering. ITV has always said that their strategy was live football and not highlights. Greg has heard the rumour that they were tipped off about the FA Cup as has everyone else. Most people who do the number crunching believe what they paid can't be viable. And a lot of people in the upper echelons of ITV are concerned."

The BBC's problem is that it has no evidence to back up its "dirty tricks" allegation. Whatever the veracity of the claim, it appears nothing more than a ploy to deflect attention from its misjudgment. ITV, knowing that it had the upper hand, dismissed the claim as "absolute rubbish".

An ITV insider said: "Dyke believed we wouldn't go for the Premier League and he took a gamble, put in a relatively low bid for the Premier League and bid higher for the FA Cup. Well, that has backfired. The Premier League is a much more valuable asset and yet they are paying more for the FA Cup - you have to ask why.

Names behind the battle for TV soccer

Brian Barwick controller of sport, ITV

Bluff, straight talking. Headed the network's bids for the Premiership and FA Cup. A former BBC Sport executive, he has led the revival of sport on ITV and lured his former colleague Des Lynam to the commercial network

Simon Johnson controller of business and legal affairs, ITV

The details man behind the ITV bids. Young, mid-30s, one of a new breed of commercial lawyers. Described as being highly knowledgeable about sports rights

Richard Sambrook BBC's acting director of sport

Sambrook's background is in BBC News; he is described by Greg Dyke as not knowing who plays left back for Manchester United. A stopgap as Mr Dyke finds his own man to head up BBC Sport, but highly regarded and played a leading part in the BBC bids

Richard Scudamore chief executive, Premier League

Initially considered a lightweight by the broadcasters when he was appointed, but quickly won the backing of the clubs and proved his mettle negotiating the latest deal

Adam Crozier chairman, Football Association

Background in advertising and media sales, a senior figure in Saatchi & Saatchi. In the row over the BBC the lucrative deal negotiated for the FA Cup, worth £400m over three years, has been overshadowed

webTitle: Pottermania makes Harry IV bestseller weeks before issue

fields.headline: Pottermania makes Harry IV bestseller weeks before issue
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The muggles have fallen for it again. The least surprising publishing news of the summer is that the fourth Harry Potter story is a bestseller. The surprising news is that copies are being bought by the thousand, sight unseen, title unknown, three weeks before publication.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The muggles have fallen for it again. The least surprising publishing news of the summer is that the fourth Harry Potter story is a bestseller. The surprising news is that copies are being bought by the thousand, sight unseen, title unknown, three weeks before publication.

The book is the number one bestseller on Amazon.com, the online bookshop, with hundreds of advance orders arriving daily from readers desperate to beat the queues for copies. It has been in the top five since December, when orders starting coming in from all over the world.

The three earlier books are still on Amazon's top 20 list, at 9, 12 and 19, and all sales worldwide, in 30 languages, are estimated at 31m copies.

Paranoid security surrounds the launch of the next episode in the life of JK Rowling's boy wizard, the book that forces Harry to confront the twin demons of sorcery and puberty.

At Bloomsbury, the publishers, a spokesman said only a handful of top executives had read it. Everyone involved, from cover designer to printers, had signed a secrecy agreement.

Amazon has organised security at its Milton Keynes distribution centre worthy of a gold vault: a Harry area has been cordoned off, and staff are forbidden to discuss the book with outsiders.

In the US, where the books have sold 18m copies, interest is being fanned to fever pitch by the planned Hollywood film version, with applications from 40,000 young hopefuls to audition for the part of Harry.

Bloomsbury is planning an elaborate launch for the new book on July 8, with part of Paddington station transformed into the mysterious platform nine-and-three-quarters, where pupils, owls and brooms in hand, join their train for Hogwart's School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.

At the tiny Kew Bookshop in west London the initial order for Harry IV is 100 copies, 10 times its normal maximum order. It is also planning a Harry Potter day on July 8, opening the shop hours early.

Its only fear is that the advance orders will eat up all its copies, leaving it with no hope of reordering until the second edition. "We've had to give in to pleas from regular customers," said the owner, Caroline Blomfield. "I've read all [the earlier books] myself, I adore them, I can hardly wait. It is a genuine phenomenon."

webTitle: Is this what you want to send us back to, Mr Straw?

fields.headline: Is this what you want to send us back to, Mr Straw?
fields.standfirst:
Five-year-old Alberta Bakiu fled Kosovo with her family after their house was torched. Its ruins lie in what is now a Serb stronghold. Britain gave them refuge in a Leeds estate - but now they've got until June 25 to get out. Maggie O'Kane reports

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Five-year-old Alberta Bakiu fled Kosovo with her family after their house was torched. Its ruins lie in what is now a Serb stronghold. Britain gave them refuge in a Leeds estate - but now they've got until June 25 to get out.   Maggie O'Kane  reports
fields.body:
Alberta is a child with strange demands. Her mother doesn't question them any more - she just tries to do what she asks. Alberta's latest obsession is wanting her mother to be a poet, to write poems which Alberta can learn by heart. And she wants the poems to contain these words: blood, liberty, freedom, Kosovo and warrior.

Alberta is on her feet, a five-year-old in a velvet dress, hands by her side, on parade, a child refugee in a Leeds council house. She starts reciting: "Kosovo, you are the old lady and I am your niece. Don't hurt me, don't kill me, don't maim me because I will always be your child." Then she beams and launches into another poem in honour of her father - the warrior.

In her five-year-old mind, it was her warrior father who personally fixed the plane to bring them from the filth and overcrowding of the Koso van border last spring to Leeds, the first of 4,000 refugees offered sanctuary in Britain. Around their council estate in Potternewton in Leeds, most of the windows are now boarded up. The Home Office is insisting Kosovan refugees be out of the country by June 25; those who apply and fail to get asylum will be forcibly removed. Alberta, her mother Selvete Bakiu, her sister Njomza, three, and her brother Pamvarsimi, one, are asking for more time.

The offer of free flights ends on June 25. The Home Office put it bluntly in its latest circular to refugee groups: "The UK has extended generous hospitality to a vulnerable group of people in their hour of need and we have always made it quite clear that protection was given on a temporary basis only." Around half of the 4,000 Kosovans are still in Britain and say they need more time.

Alberta and her family's problem is that she has no home to go to and her father, a vegetable trader in a country that is bankrupt, hasn't the means to buy a new one. Worst of all, their ruined home is in the village of Upper Bitije in eastern Kosovo, now exclusively Serb. It is virtually impossible for any Kosovan to return there, as the Serbs who stayed behind in Kosovo are isolated, angry and bitter. A Guardian photographer was only able to enter the village to photograph the ruins of Alberta's home under armed UN guard, and was warned not to bring his translator, a Kosovan Albanian, into the village.

"People should be allowed to return with dignity and not be forced against their will," says Rod Harbinson of the Refugee Council. "At the moment, the political climate in the UK is very hostile. Some people have real concerns about returning. There's no medical treatment in Kosovo for people who have cancer or heart disease, there are concerns about landmines, some people have no houses. For others, it's just a question of wanting their kids to be able to finish summer term at school."

When their home was torched, Selvete was forced to gag Njomza with her headscarf to stop the child screaming as their house burned. "When they took Daddy away that was the worst," says Alberta. "But I was really scared when we were hiding. Njomza was stupid; she was trying to scream and we nearly got killed."

At dawn they fled their village and for six months stayed with relatives. Then they spent a month hiding in the mountains living on hoards of potatoes that locals had buried, knowing what was coming. "Then Daddy came and took us to Leeds," continues Alberta. "He fixed everything. Now he is in Kosovo, building a lovely new super house for us, but he might not be able to do it if the house is too expensive."

"What possible reason do I have to stay in Leeds?" says her mother. "Kosovo is my home, my place - everyone has their place. But we need more time to find a home. My husband is there now, looking for one for us, but he sleeps on different floors every night. I don't want to bring my children back to that. I can't explain to you how it felt when we finally arrived at the airport in Leeds. To see all those people standing there waiting to take care of us. I was so ashamed in our dirty clothes. We weren't looking our best, but they kept telling us it didn't matter."

Selvete says Alberta has taken to behaving like a mother herself: "When I cry, she says to me, 'Mummy, what is it? Why are you crying?' And then she recites like a list, 'Is it because the house was burnt? Is it because Uncle Mome got killed? Is it because Daddy is not here?'"

The Home Office remains rigid: "Those who stay beyond the 25th are technically overstayers and are liable for enforcement action," says a spokesman. But the Refugee Council says Kosovans need to be treated as individuals and their safety taken into account. "The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has advised the Home Office not to force people out of the UK who come from Serb-dominated areas. The Home Office should be listening to that advice," says Harbinson.

Another woman who faces danger is Julianna, who asks that her full name not be printed. She is 56, and lives in London after fleeing Kosovo. But her elderly mother married a Serb, and now Julianna is frightened to go back. "I went back for three weeks but it was clear I couldn't stay," she says. "My town, Pristina, is still full of people from the villages; they want revenge because it was they who suffered the most."

A former press officer with a large cement company, she speaks perfect English. "They made my mother burn every book in the house that was written in Serb. She is 80 and she had to go up and down the stairs bringing down all the books to be burned. I need to be patient. Sometimes, in London, I still think that it didn't happen . . . the men in masks who took our money and our gold as we queued for two days at the border. They were something from a movie. But I remember the worst thing was being in the middle of thousands and thousands of people having nowhere private to be able to go to the toilet."

Back in Leeds, the children are watching afternoon television and playing with Pokémon. Selvete doesn't know how her family will adjust to the return but for now she is busy coping with her oldest daughter's obsession with poems.

The translator asks Alberta what she remembers most about Kosovo, and the five-year-old jumps up: "I am little. I don't know very much of my beautiful Kosovo . . ."

webTitle: Policewoman in sex bias claim awarded £500,000

fields.headline: Policewoman in sex bias claim awarded £500,000
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard suffered humiliation over a claim of sex discrimination for the second time in two weeks yesterday when a former policewoman, allegedly described as "very confident for a woman", won £500,000 in compensation.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard suffered humiliation over a claim of sex discrimination for the second time in two weeks yesterday when a former policewoman, allegedly described as "very confident for a woman", won £500,000 in compensation.

Belinda Sinclair, 40, a sergeant and training officer with 17 years' service with the Metropolitan police, was granted an immediate £10,000 in an out of court settlement agreed just before an employment tribunal hearing.

But Ms Sinclair - who on joining the force had her bare breasts and buttocks stamped with the name of her police station, and who was called a Plonk (person of little or no knowledge) - will also receive a pension worth £12,665 a year, which should amount to at least £500,000.

And should she receive an injury award and pension in another action, she could get a further £680,000, pushing her payout to well over £1m.

Last week the force paid a record £1m compensation for racial and sex discrimination to Sarah Locker, a former detective constable of Turkish origin. After a settlement on the eve of her legal hearing she was awarded £215,000 in cash and a pension of £1,500 a month, which could add up to £800,000.

Yesterday, after the five-minute meeting at Croydon employment tribunal, Ms Sinclair, flanked by her husband, Graham, a serving officer with the force, said she now intended to fight for the further injury award, worth up to £16,917 a year on top of a £15,500 lump sum.

"I feel I am entitled to it," she said.

"After 17 years of loyal service to the Met I deserve it because of all the stress and anxiety I have suffered."
