fields.headline: Takeover trail
fields.standfirst:
Yang takes Yahoo! into Europe
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Yahoo!, the internet portal and world's most visited website, is looking to expand in Europe after a series of high profile deals by its rivals.
fields.body:
Yahoo!, the internet portal and world's most visited website, is looking to expand in Europe after a series of high profile deals by its rivals.

The Californian group is feeling the pressure to expand outside its home market after Lycos, a rival internet search engine, was bought by Terra Networks of Spain.

Fresh from entering takeover talks with Myplay, the internet music service, Yahoo! indicated yesterday that it was planning an aggressive series of takeovers in the burgeoning European marketplace.

In an interview with the Reuters news agency, Jerry Yang, founder of Yahoo!, made it clear that his attention had turned to Europe from the US.

"We will see similar consolidation opportunities in Europe as we did in the United States and you will see us being very opportunistic and aggressive," Mr Yang said.

Yahoo! is striving to become known for more than just its search engine and has aspirations to expand into the wider media industry around the world.

One of the best-known search engines on the net, it wants to provide a medium by which consumers can buy products in cyberspace as well as communicating with other users.

Mr Yang aims to make the group's services accessible to customers not just through personal computers but also through mobile phones.

"In Europe PCs will continue to do well and the deregulation of the telecoms industry will drive down internet access fees. But personally I think everyone is going to be talking about the wireless arena, where especially western Europe has a significant lead over the US and other countries around the world," Mr Yang said.

fields.headline: Royal Mail 'losing 1m letters a week'
fields.trailText: Nearly a million letters a week are going astray, according to a consumers' group which has revealed the results of a Royal Mail survey.
fields.body:
Nearly a million letters a week are going astray, according to a consumers' group which has revealed the results of a Royal Mail survey.

Fines could be imposed if the Royal Mail is to blame for letters being lost, the new government regulator warned yesterday. A spokesman for the postal services commission said: "Even though there is not yet competition in the market, we need to create a situation where the Post Office behaves as though people could go to a rival."

In the first survey of its kind, the Royal Mail sent out 15,000 first class, perfectly typed and addressed letters - and 17 disappeared. When that figure is multiplied to reflect the 77m items sent daily, and again to account for six delivery days a week, the missing rate is 523,600.

But the Post Office national users' council calculates the real figure is far higher because of the greater uncertainty faced by handwritten letters or ones with incomplete postcodes.

Using a statistician who introduced a margin of error, the consumers' group calculated a figure of 957,600 letters going missing each week from the total of 462m handled.

The council's chief executive, James Dodds, said: "If you look at the volume of complaints the Royal Mail gets, 40% are lost mail. The Royal Mail needs to make a focused effort to tackle this problem. We've been discussing this problem for well over a year but we get the feeling that not a lot of progress has been made."

However, a Royal Mail suggested the lost letters were accounted for by the million items handled each week by the Post Office's national return letter centre in Belfast.

"We definitely don't lose a million items a week. This claim appears to be a regrettable example of putting a PR spin on the truth to create a misleading story."

A spokesman for the Department of Trade said: "Missing mail is always a concern. We have raised the issue with the Post Office. We are pleased that [the users' council] is pursuing this important issue with vigour."

fields.headline: Midnight charity hikers invade Lakes
fields.trailText: The midnight peace of one of the quietest places in Britain has been shattered by sponsored charity attempts on Britain's highest mountains, according to exasperated officials of the Lake District national park.
fields.body:
"Is there no nook of English

ground secure

From rash assault?

Plead for thy peace, thou

beautiful romance

Of Nature ... "

William Wordsworth, 1844

The midnight peace of one of the quietest places in Britain has been shattered by sponsored charity attempts on Britain's highest mountains, according to exasperated officials of the Lake District national park.

Volleys of abuse have followed crocodiles of children up the slopes of Scafell Pike after as many as six buses a night have reversed into Seathwaite hamlet, their occupants slamming doors and using local lavatories at 1am.

The remote collection of farmhouses, previously know for being the wettest place in England, has the misfortune to lie halfway along the Three Peaks challenge, which sees sponsored groups tackle Ben Nevis, Scafell Pike and Snowdon within 24 hours.

A similar problem besets the head of Wastwater, on the other flank of Scafell Pike, according to Bob Cartwright, head of management in the Lakes authority. "Residents are really sick and tired of it now," he said yesterday, after tackling the head of a Birmingham school whose minibus's reversing bleepers had Seathwaite in fresh turmoil at the weekend.

"No one wants charities to stop raising money, but they must be able to find other ways - or other routes. Even a shift to a new set of peaks, like a challenge from a mountain on the isle of Lewis, via Helvellyn to Cader Idris, would help.

"It is such a shame that charities should end up linked to events which show no consideration for the environment and other people."

The protests have prompted the park to reissue a code of practice agreed last year with large charities, after a sponsored walk involving 3,000 people caused furore. Mr Cartwright said several charities had dropped the Three Peaks challenge, but the code appeared little known among smaller fundraising groups.

The voluntary code limits starting times of walks to between 5am and 10pm, requires organisers to bring their own water and lavatory facilities, and lays down rules for effective marshalling of groups. All of Britain's large charities have signed up to respect the compromise between enjoyable fundraising and leaving upland communities relatively undisturbed.

Liaison has been overseen by the Institute of Charity Managers, which has also worked to ensure the advance warning of events. John Scourse, chairman of the institute and fundraiser for Guide Dogs for the Blind, said: "It's worked well, but the Three Peaks walk is a very popular and effective fundraiser for small groups who are beyond our orbit.

"The only way to deal with that is for the charity sector to get together and spread the word ... It's a matter of doing things sensibly and, I'm afraid, not doing the Three Peaks at all."

webTitle: Gulf war reparations may take Iraq more than a century to pay

fields.headline: Gulf war reparations may take Iraq more than a century to pay
fields.standfirst: Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: Iraq faces a series of gigantic claims for Gulf war damage - so large that there is almost no way to recover the money, short of extending sanctions for well over 100 years.
fields.body:
Iraq faces a series of gigantic claims for Gulf war damage - so large that there is almost no way to recover the money, short of extending sanctions for well over 100 years.

Although Iraq has so far paid about $7bn, further claims amounting to $276bn are in the pipeline at the United Nations Compensation Commission in Geneva.

Until now, the commission has processed the smallest and most straightforward claims. But this week it turned to the first of the big ones: a $21.5bn demand from Kuwait.

The scale of the claims has put experts and officials in a quandary. Some argue that future generations of Iraqis cannot reasonably be expected to continue paying for Saddam Hussein's folly. Others insist that war victims are entitled to compensation and that to let Saddam off the hook would set a dangerous precedent.

Altogether, about 100 governments have lodged 2.6m separate claims, on their own behalf and on behalf of individuals and companies.

Of the claims processed so far, many have been reduced substantially by the UNCC. One, from the Egyptian government, sought $491m for 915,000 workers but was eventually settled at just $84m.

Although Iraq agreed 10 years ago to pay compensation for losses caused by the invasion and occupation of Kuwait, there was no practical way to recover the money until December 1996 when the UN's oil-for-food programme started.

Since then, 30% of the revenue from Iraq's oil sales under the programme has been deducted to pay for war damage and the cost of running the UN commission.

The amount that can be collected in this way varies with oil prices but is currently $400m a month. At that rate, if all the outstanding claims were approved, it would take Iraq 58 years from now to pay off the debt.

But as soon as the main debt is paid Iraq will be required to pay interest, at a rate still to be decided, for the delays in compensation since 1990. Even at a very modest rate of 3% a year, interest charges could amount to a further $320bn - in which case Iraq would still be paying for the invasion of Kuwait in the year 2125.

Iraq's compensation payments are, however, dependent on continuation of the oil-for-food programme. A Foreign Office spokesman confirmed yesterday that the UN has no way of enforcing payments if sanctions are lifted.

Unless an alternative mechanism is found, the UN may eventually have to choose between abandoning hope of compensation and continuing sanctions into the next century.

Arthur Rovine, president of the American Society of International Law and an expert on Gulf war compensation, said that when the oil-for-food programme ends "the chances of the claimants collecting all the monies due them would be reduced severely and perhaps to nil".

He continued: "Unless Iraq agreed to a mechanism and process similar to the UNCC, the only alternative would be lawsuits by claimants around the world in places where they can attach Iraqi assets, including oil assets.

"Whether or not such lawsuits represent a viable alternative is open to serious question. In my judgment, it would be a completely disorganised alternative."

The UNCC has already awarded $2.9bn to Kuwaiti oil companies for the destruction of property and the cost of putting out fires in hundreds of oil wells set alight by Iraq during the war.

The $21.5bn claim now under consideration - which Kuwait has backed up with a million documents - is for lost revenue and for oil spilled or destroyed during the war. "This is the big one we've all been waiting for," a diplomat said.

Khaled al-Mudaf, chairman of Kuwait's Public Authority for Assessment of Compensation, called on the UNCC to "confirm Iraq's responsibility before the international community for its criminal acts and its liability to compensate for all consequential damage and loss". He said Iraqi occupying forces had mined Kuwait's oilfields so as to destroy the emirate. "Just before its forces withdrew from Kuwait, Iraq ordered the complete blowing up of Kuwait's oilfield infrastructure: production, refining and export."

But independent experts who evaluated the claim are understood to have recommended reducing it to $15.9bn.

Although the UNCC has always accepted expert recommendations so far, this claim is seen as an issue of principle and could go to a vote. Yesterday, the commission members failed to agree and postponed their decision for two weeks.

Dr Kamil Mahdi, an economist of Iraqi origin at Exeter University, said: "There's no indication yet how the commission is going to deal with this.

"We haven't got to the position yet where these very large claims have been awarded, and it's important that they should not be awarded. Jordan, for example, is claiming $8bn and its economy is minute. It's astounding."

He added: "We're talking of many, many generations of Iraqis to pay this burden. The whole question has to be solved politically."

webTitle: Strong beer on sale to England fans at key match

fields.headline: Strong beer on sale to England fans at key match
fields.trailText: Strong Belgian beer will continue to be sold to fans who will be in Charleroi for this Saturday's crucial Euro 2000 match between England and Germany.
fields.body:
Strong Belgian beer will continue to be sold to fans who will be in Charleroi for this Saturday's crucial Euro 2000 match between England and Germany.

Police in the city said yesterday that they had decided not to adopt the same policy as their counterparts in Eindhoven, the site of England's opening match, where only weak beer was sold.

While the weak beer policy was effective in Eindhoven, police in Charleroi insisted that they would be able to cope with any potential problems that may arise from prolonged drinking of strong Belgian beer, some of which are 12% in strength.

Michel Rompen, spokesman for the local gendarmerie said: "It's impossible to stop people drinking. Alcohol is not the problem, the problem is the consequences of drinking alcohol."

"In Eindhoven they were drinking 10 glasses but here drinking three will have the same effect."

"A man will drink and if he drinks he will drink 10, 20 or 43. We cannot stop them from doing that."

Bars have also been given permission to open at 8am and close whenever they choose. Despite advice from Dutch authorities, police in Charleroi have allowed bar owners a virtual freehand but insist they have the power to close them down if there are any problems.

Around 30,000 fans are expected for the match and the city is mounting its biggest security operation.

Major Rompen said that at least 3,000 officers would be on duty, plus another 120 on horseback.

More than 50 water cannons will be on standby and two helicopters will also aid the operation.

He added: "Ninety-eight per cent of the fans are good fans who don't give trouble to the police. It's only a small part of the fans who are hooligans."

Special bylaws have been drawn up to deal with any potential troublemakers and Belgian judges will also be on standby throughout the weekend.

Police in Charleroi also said that they would be operating a zero tolerance policy towards any troublemakers and that all those arrested by police would have to face prosecution, as has already happened in Holland.

webTitle: Private care plan for NHS patients

fields.headline: Private care plan for NHS patients
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday "crossed the Rubicon" on its march towards NHS reform when ministers announced the preparation of a long term national deal with private hospitals.
fields.body:
The government yesterday "crossed the Rubicon" on its march towards NHS reform when ministers announced the preparation of a long term national deal with private hospitals.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said he was negotiating a "concordat" with the Independent Healthcare Association for the NHS in England to rent operating theatres and beds to cut waiting lists, particularly in winter.

Although NHS trusts have paid the private sector to treat about 100,000 patients over the last three years, this will be the first time the arrangement has been actively fostered by government. The deal is expected to be signed next month.

A government source said ministers were faced with the choice of "leaving elderly people in pain or crossing the Rubicon and renting operating theatres so they can be treated by an NHS doctor on NHS principle".

The intention was to expand the throughput of the NHS by using existing private capacity. This would not be a signal for the construction of more private wards.

The proposals came as the government announced results of a public consultation showed patients' top priorities for the NHS were more doctors and nurses, better pay for staff and shorter waiting lists. Focus groups also stressed the importance of bedside manner and "bringing back matron" to provide someone in charge of hospital wards.

More than 200,000 forms were returned out of 12m sent out for the survey of the public's top three priorities for the health service. Ministers said this exceeded analysts' expectations of a 1% return. But Nick Sparrow, managing director of the pollsters ICM, said the response was "abysmal" and could not be regarded as a reliable guide to the views of the NHS's potential 43m adult patients. The opposition said the £500,000 cost of the exercise could have been better spent on patient care.

According to government sources, the NHS concordat with the private sector will be based on three principles - value for money for the NHS; high standards of care; and no reduction in the number of NHS staff and beds.

Mr Milburn said: "This seems to me a sensible thing to do, to allow NHS patients to get the timely care that they need.

fields.headline: Storm greets Mugabe's mines threat
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's business community reacted with alarm yesterday to President Robert Mugabe's threat to seize the country's mines, warning that nationalisations would severely damage the already ailing industry.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  in Harare and  Sue Cullinan
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's business community reacted with alarm yesterday to President Robert Mugabe's threat to seize the country's mines, warning that nationalisations would severely damage the already ailing industry.

Anglo American, the giant conglomerate which is by far the largest gold and nickel mining producer in Zimbabwe, described the president's comments as "unhelpful" for investor confidence.

"It's disastrous," said a local mining executive with Anglo American. "Just by making such a statement Mugabe is weakening Zimbabwe's mining sector. It will have a terrible effect on mining and the entire economy."

Many businesses are still coming to terms with the decision to confiscate more than 800 farms in Zimbabwe.

The president told the Johannesburg Star newspaper: "After land, now we must look at the mining sector ... At the end of the day black people must be able to say 'Ah, the resources are ours. Our people own the mines. Our people own the industry'."

Mining is a key element in Zimbabwe's economy, accounting for about 30% of export earnings. The country has about 1,000 mines, of which 800 are owned by Zimbabweans, but the big mines owned by multinationals account for 60% of production.

Nick von Schirnding, Anglo American's senior vice-president of investor corporate affairs, said that Mr Mugabe's statement might have been pre-election "politicking" rather than a direct threat.

"Anglo has certainly not been approached on this issue", he said. "We are confident in the long-term future of Zimbabwe. Of prime concern is economic and political stability, the rule of law and policy certainty. Free and fair elections are particularly important for investor confidence."

The United Kingdom is the largest private sector investor in Zimbabwe, with holdings estimated to be worth £350m.

The Confederation of British Industry said: "This is potentially the start of a downward spiral which will not only critically damage Zimbabwe's economic capacity, but threatens to undermine fatally investor confidence in the country."

The Foreign Office dismissed Mr Mugabe's remarks as "posturing" before the elections, due on June 24-25.

"This cannot help Zimbabwean jobs, wealth and opportunities. Zimbabwe is currently suffering from a crippling shortage of foreign exchange and a weak Zimbabwean dollar," said the Foreign Office minister Peter Hain. "These threats only make matters worse and, if carried out, would risk bankrupting the country."

President Mugabe is not learning from history, warned John Robertson, a Zimbabwean economist with extensive experience in mining.

"Look what happened to other African countries that nationalised their mines. Zambia's copper mines went into serious decline. Eventually the Zambian state had to sell the copper mines back to the original owner, Anglo American. That is a telling example for Zimbabwe."

Mr Mugabe's warning would bring "an immediate stop to new exploration and investment in mining in this country", said Mr Robertson.

He added that Zimbabwe's mining sector was already under siege as a result of Mr Mugabe's economic mismanagement. "By fixing the exchange rate at an unrealistic level, the government is making the mines earn less money than they should for their exports, yet their domestic costs are going up by more than 60%."

Zimbabwe's business and industrial leaders were similarly dismayed. "Next he'll go after the factories," said Danny Meyer, director of a company that produces medical supplies and equipment and the former chairman of the Zimbabwe national chambers of commerce.

"I feel cheated," he added. "For years we have stressed the need to work with government and to encourage and accelerate participation of black Zimbabweans at all levels of the economy. When Mugabe talks of ownership by black Zimbabweans, he means black members of Zanu-PF [Mr Mugabe's party]. There is no transparency in this. It is frightening."

Morgan Tsvangirai, the president of Zimbabwe's leading opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), said that Mr Mugabe "has no constitutional right to seize any property".

"By making such irresponsible statements he is doing irreparable harm to the economy," he said.

John Holloway, a Harare mining consultant, said: "There are possible repercussions in neighbouring African countries such as Zambia and Tanzania, where there is already unease about the control of assets.

webTitle: Prism hands back three rail franchises early

fields.headline: Prism hands back three rail franchises early
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The rail company Prism is to hand back a large part of its operation to the state in a move that could eventually lead to the business being renationalised.
fields.body:
The rail company Prism is to hand back a large part of its operation to the state in a move that could eventually lead to the business being renationalised.

The shadow strategic rail authority (SSRA) announced yesterday it had reached an agreement with the company to restructure Prism's four rail franchises.

The first, LTS, once dubbed the misery line, runs between London, Southend and Tilbury, and will be retained by Prism until 2011. The other three, West Anglia Great Northern (WAGN), Wales and West, and Cardiff Railway, are to be surrendered to the SSRA next year.

It will be the first time a franchise has been handed back. Earlier this year, the rail authority was on the point of taking over a franchise but it was acquired by another company at the last minute.

An SSRA spokesman denied last night that the franchises would be renationalised. The handover would give the SSRA the opportunity to reorganise the franchise map.

He said Prism was interested in bidding for a new franchise to run a railway in Wales, incorporating Wales and the West, and Cardiff Railways.

But these are heavily subsidised services and would be largely unprofitable. Industry sources said the SSRA would have to run them if it was unable to find a suitable bidder.

Mike Grant, the SSRA's chief executive, said that shortening the three Prism franchises, which were originally for seven years, would "greatly accelerate the national franchise replacement programme".

Prism has promised to invest £20m in the LTS line. In addition, security cameras will be fitted on 46 new trains to compensate for their late introduction. WAGN is being split into two business units. The SSRA's plans for this service are still being discussed.

Prism yesterday declared a profit before tax of £11.4 m, up 16% on last year. Passenger revenue was up 8.6%. In January it announced that it had received an approach from another company. Talks were terminated because of problems surrounding the future of Prism's portfolio. The SSRA then offered to rework three of Prism's companies.

Giles Fearnley, Prism's chief executive, said: "We are particularly pleased that it has been possible to conclude discussions with the SSRA in such a constructive way. We have achieved a step recovery in our train services at both Wales and the West, and Cardiff Railways, recovering strongly from the problems experienced in previous years."

Firm that got off on the wrong track

Prism started off as a bus company and made the mistake of saddling itself with mostly unprofitable rail franchises at the time of privatisation. During its chequered history it has paid out substantial fines because of a shortage of drivers and widespread cancellations. Prism passengers have sometimes been left waiting for two hours for trains that have not appeared, often with no buses to compensate.

Giles Fearnley, the £190,000-a-year chief executive, once gave a pay rise to a £10,000 pa platform supervisor after he spent a week doing her job for a television programme for which he had to run the gauntlet of angry passengers.

Prism is under threat from BAA, the airports operator, which wants to take over the rail service from Stansted to London, and double the number of trains.

webTitle: Free market fright for music moguls

fields.headline: Free market fright for music moguls
fields.standfirst:
New threat is from downloading that doesn't leave a trace

E-finance: special report

Free speech on the net: special report
fields.trailText: There are few people who scare big business. One who did was the 19-year-old Shawn Fanning, creator of the Napster website. Invented by a gaggle of college students led by Fanning it was embraced by hordes of dedicated users before ever registering on a financial analyst's chart. Only months ago it seemed well on the way to being transformed into a more conventional Silicon Valley start-up.
fields.body:
There are few people who scare big business. One who did was the 19-year-old Shawn Fanning, creator of the Napster website. Invented by a gaggle of college students led by Fanning it was embraced by hordes of dedicated users before ever registering on a financial analyst's chart. Only months ago it seemed well on the way to being transformed into a more conventional Silicon Valley start-up.

The key was sharing music. Napster, which makes it simple to find and trade MP3 music files with other fans, soon had a global user base - all bent on uploading their favourite tracks on to the site so others could download them.

The result was an explosion in free music being swapped over the net. That frightened record companies and musicians. Metallica, the heavy metal band, was first to strike back - asking for lists of users passing on its music. In response a group of programmers set up a site, Metallicster, to swap the group's tracks.

Not all thought Metallica was right. Chuck D of Public Enemy and Courtney Love have both been vocal fans of Napster. But other champions of MP3 found themselves in the firing line. In landmark cases, the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) filed a court injunction on Monday against online music company Napster, and last week forced MP3.com to pay out $40m in a settlement with Time Warner Music and Bertelsmann's BMG Entertainment.

Film executives were quick to support the record industry's claim that services like Napster were a "breeding ground for widespread copyright infringement". MP3.com, with nearly half a million subscribers, still faces a challenge from three other labels - Sony Music Entertainment, Seagram's Universal and EMI. The payout to Warner Music and BMG allows MP3.com to licence the labels' songs for use on its database. The online company will also pay a royalty each time music is logged on its system.

The music industry appears to have the upper hand - but others are waiting in the wings to take Fanning's place. One who might is computer programmer Ian Clarke, a 23-year-old developer of anti-censorship software. He says big business is going to have to rethink its strategy.

Clarke, who designs online-auction software for a company called Instil, has designed a program called Freenet which provides a system of information exchange of the kind that is under attack by the big players in the entertainment business.

The key to Freenet is that it will pluck information from the net without telling you were it came from. Napster's undoing was that record companies could identify people because its server kept records of who sent or downloaded music.

Had Freenet been used to scour the net for MP3 files, the thinking runs, no one could have traced who made copies or where they came from. Many in the industry are aware of the implications. A precursor of Freenet called Gnutella, created by two AOL workers, has been described as a "benevolent virus".

Clarke is unfazed. The issue of copyright infringement, which could cost the music industry more than $10bn a year, has raised questions that "even a year ago would have been dismissed as lunatic," he says. "The question is, is copyright necessary or could we live without it? I believe that information should be free and that people's creative output is for the benefit of everyone. There are other business models that can be used to generate revenue and reward people for their creative output."

Natural heir

Without giving too much away, Clarke hints that while he is considering several opportunities, the combination of his technical ability and the runaway success of online music may be too much to resist. In response to critics who say the artist loses out, Clarke says he is investigating the "digital distribution of music in a way that would help artists".

There are many who see Freenet as a natural heir to the Napster crown and many say the music industry is in for a bigger shock. Janelle Brown, one of web-based Salon magazine's technology writers, pointed out: "If a judge grants the proposed injunction, the fans booted off Napster will probably just flock straight to Freenet or Gnutella, which are competing open source file-swapping technologies. With no corporate backers and scores of unknown users hosting the software on their private machines, services like Gnutella will never cut deals with record labels or musicians. They will never take in subscription fees."

Whatever the business model, it appears Clarke and designers like him will be up against entertainment chiefs like Disney chief Michael Eisner and Seagram's Edgar Bronfman who make no secret of their determination to stamp out unauthorised distribution of their copyrighted material. A software platform which circumvents censorship cannot make him popular with government either. But Clarke says they are way behind the curve. "Even if they put a gun to my head, there's no technical or legal way [Freenet's] system could be shut down, or that you could trace what was put into it," he claims. "It was designed to withstand attack."

The son of a County Meath shopkeeper, Clarke wrote his first computer program on an Atari 800 XL (which he used mainly for computer games) at age 8. He says "it would probably have violated software patents in the US". Self-taught until university, he set about investigating his idea as part of his thesis in artificial intelligence and computer science. "I was only reasonably computer literate - no more than others - but the computer is only a tool; it's the idea that counts."

The idea that there would be no person, computer or organisation in control of Freenet led to the development of the peer-to-peer or "Chinese whispers" platform, coupled with strong encryption and "intelligent routing" which renders its users anonymous.

Although motivated more by technology than politics, Clarke has since become something of a crusader against censorship; he considers moves to block free access to music on the net to be an infringement of free speech. Lately it is the regulation of internet powers bill which has got him fired up. "I never trusted politicians with the internet and this bill proves that government cannot be trusted to legislate on these matters", he said. "The British government is moving in the wrong direction and will drive e-commerce away to countries where it is illegal to monitor internet communications."

'Stupid legislation'

Surely the internet is as border-free as the encrypted information platforms he designed? "If you encrypt data, police in the UK will be able to ask for the key," he explains. You may otherwise be asked to prove that you do not have it. And if you tell anyone that you have been asked, you are liable for prosecution. "It's a stupid piece of legislation - it will hurt commerce as well as civil liberties."

Although Clarke says his system is "only a tool on a simple level", it has unnerved the music industry. Programmers like this could either find themselves very rich, or in jail.

"It's a stupid piece of legislation - it will hurt commerce as well as civil liberties." Although Clarke says his system is "only a tool on a simple level", it has unnerved the music industry. Programmers like this could either find themselves very rich, or in jail.

fields.headline: Dimension Data
fields.trailText: South African technology company Dimension Data is aiming to raise £1.25bn for North American and European expansion from a July flotation on the London stock exchange.
fields.body:
South African technology company Dimension Data is aiming to raise £1.25bn for North American and European expansion from a July flotation on the London stock exchange.

The move, which follows last year's listings of Old Mutual - South Africa's largest assurer - and South African Breweries, would propel the network services group straight into the FTSE 100.

The executive chairman, Jeremy Ord, said the company chose London over Nasdaq "because we would be one of the biggest technology companies in the FTSE but on Nasdaq we would be considered small".

Merrill Lynch International, which is handling the offering, advised that London was the best option because the company's profile was higher in Britain than in North America. Dimension Data entered the British market in 1999 purchasing an 85.7% stake in data systems company GK Communications. Its presence in the US market should double when this month's aquisition of Integrated Systems Group goes through.

The company was established in 1983 and is now valued at almost £5bn. The financial year ending September 30 1999 saw a turnover of over $1bn and an operating profit before goodwill of $129m. The group operates in 36 countries and employs more than 10,000 people. Competitors include AT&T Solutions and IBM.

Mr Ord said yesterday that the company wasn't concerned about recent hi-tech stock volatility but conceded: "These things are always difficult to predict."

The company will maintain a secondary listing in Johannesburg. Its headquarters and tax home will remain in South Africa.

Dimension Data would use the cash raised to take out minorities in underlying subsidiaries and fund the group's acquisitions and expansion in the US and Europe as well as in network services and IT commerce.

webTitle: BSkyB scores high with football rights

fields.headline: BSkyB scores high with football rights
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Throughout the game, the spin from football club chairmen, people inside the premier league and rival broadcasters was that BSkyB stood a good chance of losing its cornerstone contract to broadcast live Premiership matches. Even if BSkyB was to retain it, so the whispers ran, it could be forced to pay a price unpalatable to the City.
fields.body:
Throughout the game, the spin from football club chairmen, people inside the premier league and rival broadcasters was that BSkyB stood a good chance of losing its cornerstone contract to broadcast live Premiership matches. Even if BSkyB was to retain it, so the whispers ran, it could be forced to pay a price unpalatable to the City.

But judging by the market's reaction yesterday the number crunchers down at BSkyB have managed to snatch a last minute victory from the jaws of defeat. BSkyB shares climbed more than 6% to £13.04 yesterday as analysts digested the company's new three-year £1.11bn contract.

In Sydney, shares in Rupert Murdoch's News Corp - which owns 37.5% in BSkyB - closed at a two-month high. After a relatively nervous performance by the shares over the past few weeks this was an impressive day.

Not only had BSkyB retained the contract, it had got it at a lower than expected price. Lehman Brothers analyst Julien Roch had calculated that the top viable price for the rights was £1.36bn. "Winning these football rights is clearly a positive for the company and we expect the stock to be strong over the next few days," he said. Shortly after the market closed it was announced BSkyB had also won rights to live FA Cup and England international games.

But Anthony de Larrinaga, an analyst at SG Securities, urged caution. "BSkyB was widely expected to retain the rights but beyond that there is still the issue of competition which will continue to lift the price of content and lower the return on distribution. When the dust settles, the big issues have not gone away."

A key issue is the creation of Platco, the holding company into which Mr Murdoch wants to inject all his media assets. Vivendi, which has already said it is selling 3% of its 24.5% stake in BSkyB to finance the cost of new UMTS licenses, may or may not take shares in Platco. If it decides not to further downward pressure can be expected on the price. Germany's Kirch group has also sold some of its shares recently.

Analysts also say BSkyB has to deal with the cost of moving from digital to broadband services and increased competition from the likes of cable operator NTL.

webTitle: Farm holds no fear for Mowlam

fields.headline: Farm holds no fear for Mowlam
fields.standfirst: Apathy is the enemy for byelection candidates
fields.trailText: Cautious politicians hesitate before entering an estate with such a past reputation as Broadwater Farm in Tottenham, north London. And William Hague warily stopped on its outskirts when he paid a flying visit to the area yesterday.
fields.body:
Cautious politicians hesitate before entering an estate with such a past reputation as Broadwater Farm in Tottenham, north London. And William Hague warily stopped on its outskirts when he paid a flying visit to the area yesterday.

The Tory leader chose to make his "zero tolerance" speech on drugs from the safety of the local Conservative club.

But Mo Mowlam's chief mission in life is to throw caution to the passing wind.

In mid-afternoon she swept into Broadwater Farm with David Lammy, the Labour candidate chosen to succeed the late Bernie Grant, whose much-misquoted remarks after the 1985 Broadwater Farm riots - when PC Keith Blakelock was murdered - did not prevent him becoming a respected MP.

In 1997 Mr Grant's majority in Tottenham was 20,200 on a 57% turnout - five times his 1987 majority.

Ms Mowlam was not at her most expansive yesterday. She patted the kids, shook hands with their mothers, inspected the community health centre and the small shops. She told the TV crews how well the partnership between government and community had turned the estate round.

When Pastor Kwaku Frimpong-Manson tried to curtail her chat with IT trainer Martha Quinlan at the EU-funded Broadwater Enterprise Training Centre she embraced him with one arm and chucked him under the chin with a clinched fist.

"I'm still talking, pastor," she said, as kids fought over Labour balloons

One of Ms Quinlan's students, Vanessa Lee, has got a research job in Ms Mowlam's department and the upwardly mobile Mr Lammy went to a nearby primary school. But the terraced streets of Tottenham have not enjoyed the economic revival of some Victorian industrial suburbs.

Unemployment is three times the national average, secondary schooling is poor, Labour has run the council for 30 years and there is a feeling that the posher, Highgate end of the borough gets better rubbish collection services. Yet Band C council tax is more than £1,000.

"We're saying to people 'it's time for a change around here',", says the Tory challenger, Jane Ellison.

She is a lively and experienced 35-year old, eight years older than barrister Mr Lammy. She has fought two elections already in Labour Barnsley.

She and Mr Lammy, agree on what bothers voters: schools, crime, rubbish, pensions for a few, a sense of lost civic pride.

Ms Ellison says: "People are ready to listen to us again. The anger with the Conservatives we found in 1997 has dissipated.

"They're glad we're talking about issues that are important to them."

But Mr Lammy is smart enough and personable enough to do the business. "I'm loving it," he says. "I'm young, I'm local and I've not been on the council, so I'm fresh." He constantly bumps into people who know him or he went to school with

"Will you vote for me?" he asked. "Only if you eat your greens," said a woman who used to be his dinner lady.

All the candidates know that the enemy in this election is, as usual, apathy. But the Spurs chairman, Sir Alan Sugar, has declared his support for Mr Lammy - "He's Tottenham, through and through," he explains.

And back on Broadwater Farm, a black mother with two kids and balloons agrees. "He's local, he's strong, he's someone we can talk to."

webTitle: Lame duck president has eye on posterity

fields.headline: Lame duck president has eye on posterity
fields.trailText: With just seven months to go before he leaves the White House, Bill Clinton yesterday embarked on what appears to be an increasingly desperate attempt to snatch some last-minute foreign policy glory from his presidency.
fields.body:
With just seven months to go before he leaves the White House, Bill Clinton yesterday embarked on what appears to be an increasingly desperate attempt to snatch some last-minute foreign policy glory from his presidency.

But, welcoming Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat to the White House, even the normally optimistic Mr Clinton seemed downbeat over the prospects of pushing the slow-moving Middle East peace process closer to an elusive settlement.

"If we are going to make peace, we are going to have to deal with the difficult issues," Mr Clinton said. He would dearly love to crown his troubled second term with a major Middle East agreement. But high White House hopes at the start of this year have slumped in recent days. The death of the Syrian leader Hafaz al-Assad and the break-up of Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak's coalition have combined to make progress on either leg of the Middle East talks far more uncertain than ever.

Mr Clinton seems to have accepted that the vision of a second Camp David-style three-way agreement involving the US, Israel and the Palestinians is currently unattainable.

In spite of the official caution over this week's talks, the administration aims to do almost anything in its power to contrive a big foreign policy triumph in the closing months of Mr Clinton's presidency.

Last month, he managed a rare international trade success on Capitol Hill, when Congress approved the administration's China trade normalisation legislation.

But that victory owed as much to Mr Clinton's Republican opponents, who provided most of the votes in favour of the measure, as it did to the president himself.

Hopes that this month's Moscow meeting with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, might lead to a triumph for Mr Clinton's diplomacy on the missile defence issue were dashed by Mr Putin's refusal to support Washington's proposal to amend the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty.

Indeed, even some in the White House admit Mr Putin had much the better of the Moscow meeting, and the Russian leader has since pressed home his advantage with a series of west European visits which seem to be driving a wedge between Europe and the US on the missile defence issue. "Putin is running rings round us right now," a senior White House source confessed.

The administration is now looking to the Tony Blair connection and the Northern Ireland agreement to provide the president with his elusive final foreign flourish. If Mr Blair gives the word that conditions in Northern Ireland allow it, then Mr Clinton will again be on Air Force One heading for Britain and Ireland to bask one last time in local approval for an agreement in which no one disputes he played a central and sustained role.

The attractions of an Irish visit are at least as strong for Hillary Clinton, who would love such a perfect opportunity to play to the Irish gallery in New York just before the official start of her Senate campaign there in September.

 Israel has apologised to the UN after its troops fired over the heads of UN peacekeepers yesterday when cartographers in south Lebanon tried to open a border gate.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, informed the Lebanese president, Emile Lahoud, of the apology and said Israel had promised such incidents would not be repeated.

webTitle: Iran dares to take coffee in public

fields.headline: Iran dares to take coffee in public
fields.standfirst:
Iran awakens to coffee culture: after years of restrictions on public courtship, new cafes usher in a social revolution

More about Iran
fields.trailText: It may be absurd to name a public place "Cosy Corner" in a country where married couples can be arrested for holding hands on the street, but Alaleh Emami decided it was time to confront convention by opening a trendy coffee shop in one of Tehran's smartest districts.
fields.body:
It may be absurd to name a public place "Cosy Corner" in a country where married couples can be arrested for holding hands on the street, but Alaleh Emami decided it was time to confront convention by opening a trendy coffee shop in one of Tehran's smartest districts.

Hidden behind a tree-lined, outdoor shopping arcade in Elahiyeh, the idle rich spend their afternoons sipping Brazilian coffee and cappuccinos; that's the "corner" part. The "cosy" comes in when statuesque women strut into the coffee shop looking for rich, eligible young men. If they find someone they fancy, they might join their table or suggest going for a stroll.

"The coffee shop is one of the few places people can meet and relax in public," says the 29-year-old Ms Emami, an entrepreneur who spent a 10 years studying in Sweden. "After I opened my shop, others followed."

Similar coffee shops have mushroomed during the past two years; their decor may pale in comparison to successful western coffee chains but, by Iranian standards, these coffee shops are ushering in a cultural revolution.

Forbidden to socialise comfortably in public, Iranians have for 20 years been hosting family gatherings and parties with friends strictly inside their homes. Going to a public place to pass the time has become an alien idea.

"There is nothing to do in Iran. Now, at least we can go somewhere and have a cup of coffee," said Afsane, one patron. "But people like those over there are too showy," she complained, pointing her hands, painted with green nail polish, at the coffee shop window.

Another coffee shop across the street from the Cosy Corner had been in business for about one year until it closed recently. The owner's wife accused him of flirting with the fashionable young women who were his patrons.

He had lived in fear that the police or the Islamic militia would close him down once they discovered young men and women were socialising in the coffee shop.

Last November, a CNN television crew wanted to film the scene for a programme on the decadent lifestyles of Iran's wealthy youth. But the owner prohibited them from taking shots of his coffee shop because he thought the programme would provoke the authorities. But Ms Emami says the police do not bother her customers as long as there are no public displays of affection.

At another trendy coffee shop, the Strawberry Cafe in the Vanak district of Tehran, customers say the police have stopped bothering them, too.

The new coffee shops in Tehran offer an alternative to the most established venue, the Cafe Naderi, in the city centre and known before the 1979 revolution as a gathering place for secular intellectuals.

Furnished with ageing original wooden chairs and linoleum tables, Cafe Naderi's management say they have no plans to surrender to modernity.

Once home to writers such as Sadeq Hedayat, Iran's Kafka who committed suicide in Paris in 1951, Cafe Naderi still attracts primarily an older crowd, and a few of young students who appreciate an artistic atmosphere.

"I like the Naderi better than Strawberry because it is authentic," said Saba, a 20-year-old university student drinking an Iranian-made cola.

Davoud Roshan, Naderi's manager, says his intention is to keep the cafe the same. He could not say how old the Naderi was, but he said it existed when the British were the leading power in Iran. He hinted, however, that he might set up tables and chairs in a sprawling garden extending from the cafe.

"We used to have tables out there but we brought them in during the Iran-Iraq war [of 1980-88] when the shelling was hitting Tehran. Maybe we should try to do this again. I guess humans need progress."

webTitle: One.Tel tries to join the network

fields.headline: One.Tel tries to join the network
fields.trailText: One.Tel, which lost out in the government auction of new generation mobile phone licences, is in talks with the five successful bidders to use one of their networks.
fields.body:
One.Tel, which lost out in the government auction of new generation mobile phone licences, is in talks with the five successful bidders to use one of their networks.

The telecommunications company, backed by Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer, wants to be a mobile virtual network operator, which means buying airtime on the new networks and reselling it under its own brand.

Chris Weston, chief operating officer for Britain and Europe, said: "We are at the very early stages of discussions with the network operators. We haven't got to discussions on price yet."

He was talking to all five operators to establish which might offer the best deal.

The company is forging ahead with its listing on the London market by the year end. Mr Weston said One.Tel was well capitalised. He was non-committal on whether it would seek additional capital with its dual listing.

However, its aggressive British and European strategy has led some analysts to suggest it would be in a position to take advantage of investors' appetite for telecom stocks and raise cash.

Britain is One.Tel's second largest market after Australia, where it is concentrating on offering long distance and internet services to the retail market.

Mr Weston said the British operation was profitable but declined to reveal figures as the company reports its full year results shortly. He believes it can make a success in Britain despite its being one of the world's most competitive telecoms markets. "The market is massive and presents a huge opportunity for a nimble player like ourselves," he said.

One.Tel has built up a long distance customer base of 900,000 since entering Britain two years ago.

He believes it can make a success in Britain despite its being one of the world's most competitive telecoms markets. "The market is massive and presents a huge opportunity for a nimble player like ourselves," he said. One.Tel has built up a long distance customer base of 900,000 since entering Britain two years ago.

webTitle: 5,000 industrial jobs go in double blow

fields.headline: 5,000 industrial jobs go in double blow
fields.trailText: Britain's manufacturing base suffered a double blow yesterday with the news that two top companies are to shed some 5,000 jobs.
fields.body:
Britain's manufacturing base suffered a double blow yesterday with the news that two top companies are to shed some 5,000 jobs.

BAE Systems, formerly British Aerospace, said it was axing 3,800 jobs as part of its cost cutting campaign in the wake of last year's merger with Marconi.

That was followed by reports that the steel maker Corus, the group formed by the merger of British Steel and Holland's Koninkliijke Hoogovens, will announce today it is to cut 1,200 jobs at two south Yorkshire plants.

The BAE job cuts will affect plants as far afield as Clydeside and Essex and span activities as diverse as avionics and shipbuilding. Plants in York and Ilford will close.

The Rovis operation at Blackburn and the South Gyle avionics operations will be consolidated and transferred to neighbouring sites, and the future of the Royal Ordnance plant in Nottingham is under review. The biggest job losses are expected to be at the Brough plant, east Yorkshire.

The jobs cuts form part of a plan to save at least £275m a year within three years of the BAE/Marconi merger.

"We are well on track not only to make these savings but to exceed them," BAE said. It could not quantify the proportion of the savings which would come from the job losses but would make every effort to mitigate their impact through voluntary redundancy and early retirement.

BAE chief executive John Weston said: "Decisions that affect jobs and sites in this way are regrettable and only arrived at after very careful consideration.

"We are committed to min imising the effects of this programme by offering a comprehensive range of measures."

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, expressed concern about the level of cuts at BAE but said the union would work with the company to ensure redundancies were on a voluntary basis. "We are very disappointed with the scale of the job losses although it is not unexpected."

Local MPs are bracing themselves for Corus's job cuts, which it is expected to blame on the strength of sterling. The MPs are anticipating up to 1,000 jobs will go in Rotherham with the rest to be shed at another engineering steel plant in Stocksbridge near Sheffield. John Healey, MP for Wentworth, said: "With the euro strengthening considerably against the pound and with steel demand in Europe and the UK at its height, this may be a serious misjudgment by Corus."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Hamleys profits fall to £27,000
fields.body:
Hamleys profits fall to £27,000

Shares in Hamleys, Britain's most famous toy retailer, dipped 2.5p to 120p yesterday, after announcing that pre-tax profits for the fourteen months to March 25th plummeted to just £27,000 from £6.4m for the previous 12 months.

Hamleys, which has posted two profit warnings in the past year, blamed the decline in profits on higher than usual exceptionals including a large investment in refurbishing the company's flagship store in London, which is due for completion next month.

Asahi leaves merger talks

Japan's banking sector was jolted by the collapse of a planned mega-merger that was supposed to fortify the industry against financial contagion. Three months after agreeing to a tie-up that would have created the world's third biggest bank in terms of assets, Asahi Bank walked out of talks with its prospective partners - Sanwa Bank and Tokai Bank - citing differences of opinion over strategy.

Jaguar S-type boosts figures

The success of Jaguar's S-type has helped the car company to a record sales year so far, it was announced yesterday.

Global sales for the first five months of this year have reached 40,000 - an 80% increase on the January-May total last year.

The S-type, launched in 1999, has accounted for more than half (25,356) this year's sales for the firm.

The number of Jaguars sold in the US doubled from the same period last year to 18,622. Sales in Europe increased 87% to 10,513 in the first five months of this year.

KLM sale to BA wins favour

The Netherlands traffic minister, Tineke Netelenbos, said she was in favour of an acquisition of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines by British Airways.

In a letter to parliament, Ms Netelenbos said that the long-term benefit to the Netherlands "is better guaranteed by the acquisition of KLM by British Airways than by a merger with Alitalia" as previously planned. The government owns 14% of KLM.

£14m film rights for UK company

British film company Winchester Entertainment has clinched a deal to distribute Sigourney Weaver and Gene Hackman's new film Heartbreakers outside the US. The group has paid $21.5m (£14.3m) for the rights to distribute the film to cinemas, TV, video and DVD global market.

Racal clears Brussels hurdle

Thomson-CSF, the French defence electronics group, yesterday declared its £1.82bn bid for Racal Electronics unconditional. The move follows the European commission's decision to clear the bid. More than 72% of Racal's shareholders have already accepted the French offer.

webTitle: Foreign farce Immigration play causes uproar in Vienna

fields.headline: Foreign farce Immigration play causes uproar in Vienna
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: A German theatre director has caused an uproar in Vienna with a staged event parodying the anti-immigrant policies of Austria's Freedom party. The party has warned of legal action and the site of the event was the target of an arson attack early yesterday.
fields.body:
A German theatre director has caused an uproar in Vienna with a staged event parodying the anti-immigrant policies of Austria's Freedom party. The party has warned of legal action and the site of the event was the target of an arson attack early yesterday.

Last Sunday, Christoph Schlingensief, the resident director of the Volksbühne in Berlin, locked 10 "foreigners" into a portable office in a square in central Vienna and invited Austrians to decide which of them should be "deported".

One foreigner was to be removed from the site each day and arrangements were made for votes to be cast by telephone or through the internet. A sign with the words "Foreigners Out" was put on one of the four offices.

The event - entitled "Please Love Austria" - mimicked Dutch and German docu-soaps in which viewers were asked to decide which of several young people should continue to share a sealed-off house.

Mr Schlingensief, who hired actors to play the parts of asylum seekers, said it was a way of "bringing into the open the dirty images that Austria does not want seen in Europe". What it has unquestionably done is provoke a response.

After an inflammable liquid was sprayed on one of the units and set alight, Wole Osifo, who plays the part of a car mechanic from Nigeria, said it had prompted fears among the actors.

"It began as a project which aimed to show that everyone has the same right of abode," he said. "Now it has become dangerous."

There have been furious reactions from Austrians outside the portable offices in which the foreigners are housed. "Where is the swine who authorised this?", one man asked. "They showed these containers on television in Paris. In France, people are pointing to us and thinking this is a country of Nazis."

The Freedom party has threatened to sue over Mr Schlingensief's use of its symbols and announced that it will seek a vote of no confidence in the Vienna city councillor who approved the event.

The Freedom party has been immersed in controversy since joining a coalition government earlier this year.

fields.headline: Bomber's Nazi dreams
fields.trailText: From the age of 16, nail bomber David Copeland dreamed of being an SS commander with female sex slaves, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
From the age of 16, nail bomber David Copeland dreamed of being an SS commander with female sex slaves, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Copeland became fascinated with nazism when he was 13 and with violence before he was 19, he told a psychiatrist.

"He said he would have liked to be tall, white, good looking, an SS commander, powerful with female slaves to have sex with but not rape," Nigel Sweeney QC, prosecuting, read from one psychiatric report.

"He would torture and kill men but not women or children. He used to dream about this from the age of 16."

Copeland was interested in sadomasochistic sexual activities, according to the report.

Mr Sweeney was cross-examining defence psychiatrist Paul Gilluley about his view that Copeland was suffering from an abnormality of mind - paranoid schizophrenia - when he carried out his bombing campaign.

Copeland, 24, an engineer from Cove, Farnborough, Hampshire, has admitted causing explosions at Brixton in south London, Brick Lane in east London, and Soho in April last year. He denies murder on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

webTitle: Germany's Greens split by nuclear closure pact

fields.headline: Germany's Greens split by nuclear closure pact
fields.trailText: Germany's Green party was divided yesterday about its most substantial political achievement since joining Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's coalition government two years ago.
fields.body:
Germany's Green party was divided yesterday about its most substantial political achievement since joining Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's coalition government two years ago.

Their party's joint leader, Antje Radcke, disowned an agreement between the government and the electricity industry for the gradual closure of Germany's nuclear power stations, criticising the delay.

But, by a large majority, Green party MPs welcomed the deal, which was concluded in the early hours of yesterday. The split among Mr Schröder's junior coalition partners could create serious problems for his government. The Greens will hold a party conference at the end of next week and Ms Radcke said she would be recommending that they withdraw support for the closure plan.

Under the terms of the deal, Germany's 19 nuclear reactors will be granted an average life of 32 years. Since the newest of them went on stream in 1989, the deal implies closure of the final reactor by 2021.

However, the agreement would allow the utilities to switch output entitlement from older, less-efficient plants to newer, more-efficient ones, thus delaying the nuclear business's demise. In the meantime, the electricity firms will be under an obligation not to build any new reactors and the reprocessing of nuclear fuel will come to an end by the middle of 2005.

Jürgen Trittin, the Green party environment minister who helped broker the deal, said it was a more radical break than that being put into effect in Sweden, the only other country to opt for a nuclear shutdown. "[In Sweden] it is spread over 40 years of plant-operating life and will require compensation. But we are doing this over 32 years without paying any compensation," he said.

Mr Trittin added that, depending on how the utilities choose to phase out their reactors, the first could be shut in 2002. That is when the next general election is due and an imminent, or recent, shutdown could provide the Greens with a big boost. None of this impressed Ms Radcke, however.

"It's not acceptable," she said. "It looks to me like the Greens have put themselves on to a long-term peace footing with nuclear power."

What she and other party radicals fear is that the timetable will enable the "right" to get back into power and reverse the shutdown. She was joined in her criticism of the deal by Greenpeace and Germany's Environment and Nature Protection Federation.

Christian Democrats say privately that they would be able to reverse the pact if they win the next election, but that a u-turn would become progressively more difficult thereafter.

Mr Trittin's environment ministry officials concurred. A spokesman said the deal "sends out a signal which will radically alter vital decisions on training and all manner of business considerations in the long term. Even if subsequent governments try to reverse it, there will be no one still able to reverse it with them."

Shares in the leading German utilities nevertheless rose yesterday as investors priced in the greater certainty the deal affords.

Ms Radcke's colleague at the top of the party structure, Gunda Röstel said she favoured the compromise, and several other leading Greens also voiced their support. But the danger for the "Red-Green" alliance is that the radical view still holds great sway among the rank and file party members whose weight can be brought to bear at next week's conference. Earlier this year, Green party activists used a similar conference to torpedo proposals for internal reform, of which the leadership was passionately in favour.

Germany relies on atomic energy for more than 30% of its electricity. Its nuclear industry is the fourth largest in the world. The proposed shutdown would remove 6% of global atomic generating capacity.

webTitle: £1m cost of policing fox hunting fuels row over ban

fields.headline: £1m cost of policing fox hunting fuels row over ban
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: The cost of policing fox hunting in England is already an estimated £1m a year - with just three of the home counties having to spend more than £377,000, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The cost of policing fox hunting in England is already an estimated £1m a year - with just three of the home counties having to spend more than £377,000, it was revealed yesterday.

Figures supplied by police authorities to the Liberal Democrats on the cost of hunt policing are certain to fuel the row over a future ban. On Monday the Conservative frontbench spokesman, David Lidington, announced the Tories intended to make the cost of policing a plank in their opposition to a ban, pointing out that enforcing it would hit the constabulary in "hard- pressed rural areas".

The most detailed analysis, according to figures released to Norman Baker, Liberal Democrat MP for Lewes, comes from the Sussex police authority. It reveals it had to set up Operation Rook to deal with hunting and has spent £135,828 this year. Altogether, 115 hunts are policed every year and on average 77 officers are engaged in policing them every week. Most of the officers have to be moved from other duties protecting the public. The authority also puts on an "awareness day" for hunt organisers at its police headquarters before the season begins.

Kent police force estimates it spends £125,000 a year sending officers to check 212 hunts and hunt balls and investigate complaints and offences connected with local hunts.

Essex estimates its cost at £117,625, with £110,427 spent on paying officers to police hunts. Other figures released include £55,000 spent by Northamptonshire police, although it put the blame for the bill entirely on protesters trying to disrupt hunting.

Other police authorities quoted lower sums. Dorset said it cost £22,822, Humberside £16,000 and Staffordshire £15,000. Some police authorities quoted sums as low as £2,126 for Bedfordshire and £200 for Derbyshire. But most authorities did not include the full cost of police salaries or office backup.

The total figure obtained by the Liberal Democrats was £542,854 - but this is a huge underestimate, because several of the authorities which have a large number of hunts did not reply. These included Devon and Cornwall, which have hunts on Exmoor, Dartmoor and Bodmin Moor; Wiltshire, which includes the Beaufort Hunt at Badminton - a favourite venue for Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles and an expensive event to police. Other counties who did not reply include Gloucestershire, Cumbria, Thames Valley and Hertfordshire.

A number of police authorities also do not keep separate records. Cambridgeshire, Suffolk, Warwickshire and Leicestershire are among these.

A small number of authorities also did not have a policy to police hunts. These included Lancashire, Lincolnshire and Norfolk. Two authorities, West Mercia and Cleveland, said they already had no hunting in their areas.

Mr Baker said yesterday: "This research clearly backs up the need for action to ban hunting. It suggests that if a ban had been introduced police authorities would be able to save money. Police numbers are stretched enough as it is, without the unwelcome diversion of policing hunts."

The opposite view is argued by the Countryside Alliance, the pro-blood sport body. In its evidence to the Burns inquiry its representatives argued that police resources were already heavily overstretched and officers would not have time to enforce a ban, which would be given a low priority.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Adidas ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Adidas ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
A battered truck weaves its way along the streets and canals of Amsterdam early in the morning. It's being driven by Juventus stars Zinedine Zidane and Alessandro Del Piero, and in the back we have our very own David Beckham (before the head-shave) inflating a pile of footballs. The truck stops and all the balls are released out onto the streets. Unaware they're being filmed, everyone's soon having a sneaky kick, from commuters to little old ladies and babies, as well as the stars themselves. "Adidas. Forever sport" reads the endline.

The jargon:
The brief to ad agency Leagas Delaney was to "give soccer back to the people in the street, the real fans". The commercial plays on the universal truth that no one can walk past a ball without kicking it (or indeed nicking it, as the ad reveals). It's set in Amsterdam because Amsterdam is one of the cities hosting Euro 2000.

Personality:
You are anyone of any age, male or female, who loves soccer, whether it's watching it or playing it. The spot is running globally, in Asia, America and Europe, so you could also be living almost anywhere in the world.

Financial status:
Adidas products are premium-priced, but not as expensive as other leading brands. They have a boot for every price range, so kids can buy a pair for £25, while you can pay as much as £120 for a pair of Predators, as worn by the lovely Mr Beckham himself.

Telling lifestyle detail:
You're into music, fashion and pop culture generally. Like Beckham and Alessandro (who's the David Beckham of Italy, basically, and advertises everything from Adidas to sunglasses), you fancy yourself as a bit of a trend-setter.

Other relevant data:
The ad was shot using over 2,500 footballs. Cameramen hid in trees and wheelie bins, and masqueraded as workmen up cranes pretending to fix lamp-posts so as to get the "candid camera" effect. The spot was directed by soccer-mad Peter Cattaneo, director of The Full Monty.

It's set in Amsterdam because Amsterdam is one of the cities hosting Euro 2000. Personality: You are anyone of any age, male or female, who loves soccer, whether it's watching it or playing it. The spot is running globally, in Asia, America and Europe, so you could also be living almost anywhere in the world. Financial status: Adidas products are premium-priced, but not as expensive as other leading brands. They have a boot for every price range, so kids can buy a pair for £25, while you can pay as much as £120 for a pair of Predators, as worn by the lovely Mr Beckham himself. Telling lifestyle detail: You're into music, fashion and pop culture generally. Like Beckham and Alessandro (who's the David Beckham of Italy, basically, and advertises everything from Adidas to sunglasses), you fancy yourself as a bit of a trend-setter. Other relevant data: The ad was shot using over 2,500 footballs. Cameramen hid in trees and wheelie bins, and masqueraded as workmen up cranes pretending to fix lamp-posts so as to get the "candid camera" effect. The spot was directed by soccer-mad Peter Cattaneo, director of The Full Monty.

fields.headline: Favourite daughter
fields.standfirst: McCready And Daughter |  Chambers | Mysteries Of Lost Empires
fields.trailText: McCready And Daughter | Chambers | Mysteries Of Lost Empires
fields.body:
Soap princesses come with a rich dowry of ratings. They may bring a million viewers to the marriage, which makes them very desirable for a while.

Last night, Patsy Palmer, better known as Bianca from EastEnders, made her dramatic debut in a one-off drama, McCready And Daughter. Sarah Lancashire - Raquel in Coronation Street and now an established actress - was in a new situation comedy, Chambers.

McCready And Daughter (BBC 1) suffered a potentially devastating loss when Tony Doyle, who was to play McCready, died. In the event, it is difficult to imagine a better McCready than Lorcan Cranitch, who took over

McCready is a private detective - what else? - and his daughter is a handful, of course. Thereafter it takes you by surprise. You do sit up when a story starts with a man arriving late at an open grave, shouting "Can you get him up again?"

The storyline is seductively curly. Was the dead man, Gerry Geraghty, murdered? Since you ask, no. It was Happy Jack, an ill-named wino, who died. Gerry, a broken bareknuckle fighter, seized the chance to disappear. "It could have been me. It should have been me. Sooner or later, it's going to be me. I just upped out of there and left him. Then I heard I was dead. So it was me after all." If you think that has a Welsh lilt, I'd say you were right. The script was by Robert Jones.

There are entertaining eccentrics ("Now, Jim, if it's about the exorcism...") and woeful locations, like the steel cockpit where bareknuckle fights were held, and the graveyard where every staggering stone seemed drunk.

Patsy Palmer is a personality. Bianca's peacock screech was the most mimicked noise on TV. Here she seemed like someone playing the comb in a classical orchestra, often inaudible and very limited. It was perverse casting. Even on the wilder shores of soaps, where long-lost children are often cast up, this girl could never be McCready's daughter. She cried very touchingly in one scene. Bianca always did desolate well. You want to wipe away her freckles and say she will learn a lot working with such a fine cast.

Chambers (BBC 1) is a very old-fashioned situation comedy by a barrister about barristers and, judging by the roaring audience, for barristers. It's Only Words was about a game bored counsel play, trying to sneak surreptitious phrases into their submission, usually in the form of a frightful pun. Always a good game, particularly when played by Muir and Norden in My Word! I submit in mitigation, my lord, that Chambers has John Bird, who is A Good Thing. And, er, that's it.

It is a mystery why the Romans were so fond of a communal tub. This peculiar practice only survives now among footballers. The curiously gripping series Mysteries Of Lost Empires (Channel 4) set about rebuilding a Roman bath with no clear idea how it was done. This led to heated academic arguments and strained international relations ("You are talking out of your hat!")

Professor Garrett Fagan was steeped in Roman ablutions. First you were oiled down by a slave. Then you had a bit of a wrestle with a friend. (I knew there was something funny about all this). Romans had no soap, so dirt was scraped off. Body hair was unfashionable, so it was tweezed out. According to Seneca the Younger, the howls were frightful. Except for the stoics, of course. It all took hours. God knows how they found time to divide Gaul into three parts.

The invaluable Fagan was sound on Roman evacuations too. Their open-plan toilets ("Would I have women beside me? I think the answer was yes") seated 25. They had no toilet paper, so used a sponge and stick; I'm not clear about the stick. Tunics and togas, he conceded, would form a convenient screen - "But that doesn't account for odours and noises". Perhaps, you think wildly, someone sang.

A magnificently whiskered British archaelogist cooked up pink Roman concrete (I had no idea the Romans invented concrete) and a Turkish engineer beavered away building a frigidarium, tepidarium and caldarium. Ah, that foxed you, didn't it? With a touch of silicon sealant and some advice from the village baker, it was ready, and the squabbling academics, modestly draped, had a communal bath. They all emerged much better friends. which may have been the point of the whole thing...

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Who's That Knocking At My Door? | Reservoir Dogs | Texas Chainsaw Massacre | A Very Private Affair
fields.body:
Who's That Knocking At My Door? (Martin Scorsese, 1968) 9pm, TCM

Scorsese hit the ground running with this black-and-white tyro effort, shot in and around his old neighbourhood, New York's Little Italy. Introducing Harvey Keitel, the film is packed full of freeze-frames, voiceovers, bickering hoods, rock'n'roll and Catholic iconography (and guilt).
Phelim O'Neill

Reservoir Dogs (Quentin Tarantino, 1992) 10pm, FilmFour

The heist botched, the gang assemble in a warehouse, a traitor among them. Macho rage bounces off the walls - Tim Roth lying in a slick of blood, Harvey Keitel (pictured) and Steve Buscemi at each other's throats, and Michael Madsen dancing a comic-Gothic torture scene to Stuck In The Middle With You. Tarantino's potent debut is a brilliantly stylish and witty thriller - characters called Mr Orange and Mr Pink, but in cool black suits, deconstructing a Madonna song before the hit. The complex flashback structure was apparently borrowed from Kubrick's The Killing.

Texas Chainsaw Massacre (Tobe Hooper, 1974) 12midnight, FilmFour

Hooper's intelligent, disturbing horror movie based on the gruesome exploits of Winsconsin serial killer Ed Gein. A bunch of teenagers travelling in the Texas wilderness are carved up, one at a time, by Gunnar Hansen's Leatherface, an inbred loony who wears a mask of human skin and wields a chainsaw. The film has a notorious reputation, but there's little graphic violence; shocks mostly stem from the power of suggestion.
Paul Howlett

A Very Private Affair (Louis Malle, 1961) 12.25am, TCM

Oh the irony. Brigitte Bardot plays a young movie actress who shoots to uncontrollable levels of stardom, then retreats from the public eye as much as she can. Fame also threatens her relationship with high-culture merchant Marcello Mastroianni. Their passion doesn't set the screen on fire, but it's a powerful combination of Euro-heavyweights.
Steve Rose

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Age Gap | The Cotton Club
fields.body:
In Age Gap (2.15pm, Radio 4) Peter Tinniswood portrays two characters who might have stepped straight out of a Lowry painting. At 26, Anita has been put into a rest-home because her husband can no longer care for her. She is, naturally, housed with the next youngest patient. But Winifred is 62 and inhabits an inchoately jumbled past. Somehow the two must find a way of jogging along together.

Owney Madden headed the New York Gopher Gang in 1923 and was doing rather well out of Prohibition. But he lacked a place for the boys to relax in after a hard day's bootlegging. The obvious answer was a new night spot in Harlem, which could also offer the city's rich white jazz fans somewhere safe to hear the increasingly popular black bands. And so began The Cotton Club (10.0pm, Radio 2). George Melly (pictured) launches a four-part history of one of America's most influential musical institutions.
