fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: I'm attracted to a married man and confused. Should I stay away?
fields.trailText: I'm attracted to a married man and confused. Should I stay away?
fields.body:
I met a wonderful man in a club a few months ago and we both felt instantly attracted. Eventually he asked me back to his place for a drink and I accepted. It was at this stage he told me he was married. I was shocked and am sure that if I had not been drinking I would have gone straight home. However, I went and we spent the rest of the night talking. I have bumped into him several times since and he has told me his wife is going to work in another city for a year, only returning once a month. I know he is still keen to pursue a relationship with me and I feel it is probably more than just a fling he is after. He says he has never done anything like this before. I believe him. I'm confused as my instinct tells me to stay away but my emotions seem to be getting the better of me. I would have said six months ago that I would never entertain the idea of a relationship with a married man. Now I'm not so sure.

Don't be drawn into it

Stay away at all costs. Believe me, you will be saving yourself misery, hurt and humiliation at a later stage.

Speaking as someone who had an affair with a married man and has now lost my home, my job and my own marriage, I feel the only good that can come out of my own wretchedness is the warning to other people: it's not worth it.

You say he's wonderful: what evidence do you have? He's already lying and is being disrespectful to his wife, as he will be to you.

Please don't fall for the "I'm so confused and attracted to you. I've never done anything like this before" line. I fell for that for eight years, believing him right up until his wife found out, and then had to endure the devastating realisation that, despite all his previous protestations to the contrary, I indeed was "just a fling" and, when the stakes were too high, was perfectly expendable.

No matter how "attracted" you are or "attractive" the relationship makes you feel, it is a fantasy for both of you and counts as nothing when compared to the legitimate, or public, life he has with his wife. Ask yourself what they do together on her birthday, how he spends Christmas, what his relationship with his in-laws is like, might they have children one day, and then ask yourself if he would give it all up for you, someone he just met in a club?

He might, as my ex-lover did, revel in the agony and excitement of it all, and go to huge lengths to maintain both public (respectable, ie wife) and private (not respectable, ie you) aspects of his life. Can you really live with that?

I lost everything because I couldn't take the mental strain of it all. My self-esteem is the hardest thing to rebuild.

Please don't let yourself be drawn into something against your better judgment, before what you think of as "emotion" clouds your judgment completely. I would give anything to have my old life back again.
SL
Oxford

All you will get is a fling

I noticed from your letter that although the man said he had never done this sort of thing before, he did not make any mention of leaving his wife.

Whenever your emotions are involved in any situation it is very difficult to be objective.

However, the chances are that he has done this sort of thing before (particularly if his wife leaves him to his own devices regularly because of her job). From past experience, it is more than likely that even though he has implied that he wants more than just a fling, that will be all that you get.

I also think that the way the relationship started, with you spending an evening with a man you would normally have walked away from had you not been drinking, speaks volumes.

My advice to you would be to get away from him as quickly as possible before you become too emotionally attached to him.

By doing this you will be saving yourself from months, perhaps years of heartache and soul-searching - not to mention the effect it may have on future relationships.
Nichola Vincendeau
West Sussex

It's likely to end in tears

Don't go there, girl! I met a married man in similar circumstances. Like you I had never considered an affair before and neither had he.

Despite initial misgivings, our relationship became a full-blown, passionate, love affair and was difficult to walk away from. This, despite endless rearranged plans, the scorn of friends and family, nights, weekends and holidays spent alone, and the not-insignificant guilt.

Four years on, his wife rang me after discovering the truth. She told me a few home truths about him (he had hit her in front of their daughter, he was duplicitous by nature, emotionally crippled and so on). She was a strong, articulate woman and I realised that if he could cheat on her, he would do the same to me. Two months after we had split up, he was having an affair with another woman.

There are many instances of affairs working, but far more end in tears and recrimination. They are like an addiction: bad for your self-esteem, confidence and independence. And, because you see the other person infrequently and in the best circumstances, they drag on for years.

Find someone who is entirely yours. It really is the only way to go.
Name and address supplied

Next week

My partner is an academic. He works very hard, often in excess of 60 hours a week. The nature of his work, where anything less is seen as a lack of commitment, has meant that career and work have over the years sometimes taken precedence over home and family. Recently the stress has taken its toll - he is often unwell and always tired. He finds little time to exercise and is significantly overweight. Our relationship, although amicable, features little companionship and very few shared interests as I have pursued my own interests and developed my own circle of friends. Our sex life is sparse. As our children grow up, I am growing increasingly uneasy about what the future holds. I fear being tied to nursing a chronically sick partner, as my mother was. A future with a soulmate, with shared interests to enjoy together, seems unattainable. We have over the years really grown up into two different people. Once the children are independent, should I consider setting up on my own and making a new life? I do not expect that my situation is unique. What choices did other readers make and where did they lead them?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Wednesday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. fields.headline: Going for a song
fields.standfirst: Napster - the gizmo that sniffs out free music files on the internet - is causing outright panic in the music industry. But does it really work?  Nicholas Barber  decided to find out what's actually out there
fields.trailText: Napster - the gizmo that sniffs out free music files on the internet - is causing outright panic in the music industry. But does it really work?  Nicholas Barber  decided to find out what's actually out there
fields.body:
One place above "sex" and four above "Pokemon", the term which is typed most often in internet searches is "MP3". It's also the term which most terrifies the record industry - one place above "cocaine shortage" and four above "totally original band". But for those of you who don't know your email from your elbow, an MP3 is a digital music file. That is, it's the format used to download a song from the internet to your computer.

Until recently, this was an an off-putting process, involving long, often fruitless trawls through dozens of websites. With the arrival of Napster, that's all changed. A revolutionary piece of "shareware" created by a teenage student in Boston, Napster allows subscribers to pool their MP3s, but it's best to see it as a well-catalogued and well-stocked music library. By taking the hassles out of MP3-chasing, Napster at last makes the format a viable alternative to the CD.

For a start, Napster is as easy to find as a high street record store (they're the big, glass-fronted buildings filled with Buffy The Vampire Slayer videos). Just type in www.napster.com or, if you own a Mac, www.macster.com, and in a matter of seconds you'll be at a neatly laid-out, friendly website. Ignore the odd outbreak of jargon - "We have been porting Macster to carbon, and have a screenshot available" - and click on encouraging pieces of highlighted text like "Getting Started" and "Download". Almost immediately, you'll be plugged into the Napster network, "the fastest and largest growing on-line community ever". You can also get a free MP3 player while you're at it. How long this takes depends on the time of day and the power of your computer, but I was ready to download MP3 files from Napster within half an hour of logging on.

From that point, getting hold of the music you're after is even more of a doddle. Type in the name of an artist and/or song, and a list of tracks to choose from will appear on your screen a minute later. Click on your preference and the downloading begins. Wait another 10 minutes and your favourite Westlife tune will be pouring from your computer's speakers. It's simple. No need to ferret around different websites. No need to pay. No wonder the record industry is nervous.

Law-abiding pop stars from Elton John to Eminem have been fuming about piracy, and Madonna is particularly miffed. It seems that Guy Ritchie's gal has found time in between film premieres to complete a new single, Music, but it's not due for release until the autumn. Two weeks ago someone leaked it to Napster. Madonna's manager has threatened legal action, so it would be wrong of me to encourage anyone to log on to Napster and type in the words "Madonna" and "Music".

There's plenty of other material up for grabs, anyway. Having acquired tracks by the Beatles and the Velvet Underground, I thought I should be more adventurous. The beauty of Napster is that every MP3 which its several million users might have decided to upload from their own collections is there for the taking. Type in Simpsons, South Park, Star Trek or Star Wars and you'll soon have a bumper stock of annoying soundbites for your anwerphone - the "Yoda drunk on set" MP3 being especially popular.

If you're curious to hear Radiohead covering Wonderwall or Travis covering Baby One More Time, they're right there in the index. You can find the Coronation Street theme and you can find a stack of Beethoven pieces, including Fur Elise (The Techno Remix). Mind you, my request for Noel Coward numbers was rewarded with little more than Monty Python's Penis Song (Not The Noel Coward One).

I can testify that, however many records you own, you'll soon be intoxicated by a feeling not dissimilar to the one you got when you first attended a party with a free bar. True, there is the small matter of breach of copyright, but let's be honest - when you were first told about the internet, isn't this exactly the sort of thing you imagined you'd be able to do? Thanks to Napster, as long as one person can get hold of a song, it can be heard almost immediately and almost gratis by anyone in the world with a computer and a modem. Even the brand new service extended by some record stores, whereby you can "burn" your own personal compilation CD, becomes redundant - because, well, who needs CDs anyway?

And in case you're wondering, the Madonna single is, true to recent form, a toe-tapping slice of robotic pop with risible lyrics. "Hey, Mr DJ, put a record on, I wanna dance with my baby", hoots Maddy, giving herself away as a child of the 20th century. Instead, she should have sung: "Hey, Mr DJ, click an MP3 file".

Just type in www.napster.com or, if you own a Mac, www.macster.com, and in a matter of seconds you'll be at a neatly laid-out, friendly website. fields.headline: Green bridge illuminates urban wasteland
fields.standfirst: Showpiece design - meant to 'advertise the natural world' - across five lanes of east London traffic suffers vandalism worth £8,000
fields.trailText: Showpiece design - meant to 'advertise the natural world' - across five lanes of east London traffic suffers vandalism worth £8,000
fields.body:
It looks like a green and yellow squashed caterpillar, it has 10 25ft birch trees growing out of its top, it straddles five of the busiest traffic lanes in east London and it does not wobble.

But the Mile End Road "green bridge" which will be officially opened tomorrow with a parade of cars, bicycles and pedestrians may be suffering a mild dose of the millennium curse which has afflicted the dome, the London Eye and the pedestrian bridge over the Thames. Despite 24-hour security, vandals have already damaged trees, lighting and fixtures on the visionary 25m (82ft) wide structure which spans the east London artery.

"It makes my blood boil. They did £8,000 of damage in one day, snapped trees, de stroyed the lights. It's mindless, an absolute pain," said one of the contractors putting the final touches to the first stage of the £24m project.

The Piers Gough-designed bridge, which also has grass, flowers, a cycle track and footpath running over it, is the centrepiece of a grand ecological project to revitalise 90 acres of rundown, underused parkland divided by railway lines and roads.

Several minor roads have been closed, the previously flat landscape made into parkland in the 1950s from land blitzed in the war, has been sculpted into hills and terraces, with lakes, play areas, art centres and an ecology park to follow. The whole park, which may cost up to £1m a year to run, will be subsidised by up to £400,000 a year in rents from shops underneath the bridge.

"The idea was to mend the park. The bridge creates the illusion that it is winning out over the road," said Gough. "It's not meant to look like an ordinary bridge with trees growing out of it, but to advertise the natural world."

The bridge, open unofficially for a few months, is proving popular with cyclists and pedestrians. "It's really lovely," said Kim Gipson, who lives nearby. "It lets the kids roam. The money is well spent, far better than spending it on more roads. Lots of people use it."

"I love it, said Chris Francois, an office worker. "It's a new landmark. The traffic round here is dreadful but you can be up here on the bridge and feel you're in another world. How on earth did they do it?"

Engineers, who have spent 18 months on the park and bridge, are confident that the trees, which will eventually be 60ft, will not damage the structure. Planted in 2m-deep pits, their roots are contained in large fibreglass plant pots, which drop into the structure of the bridge.

Rainwater runs off the bridge and down into tanks on either side. It is then pumped back on to it and recycled. This is necessary because the soil on the top of the bridge is generally drier.

But the bridge's beauty was lost on one group of teenagers there yesterday. "It's crap, a complete waste of money," said Abdul Hashim

"Get real, man. We've got nature for free _ Where are the swings and the food?" said Boga Miah. "I like the millennium dustbins, though," said his half brother, Michael.

Mile End Park website

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Llantarnam comprehensive school in Cwmbran, south Wales was celebrating last night after selling a painting, left hanging in its foyer since 1954, for an undisclosed amount between £170,000 and £200,000.
fields.body:
Picture a new classroom

Llantarnam comprehensive school in Cwmbran, south Wales was celebrating last night after selling a painting, left hanging in its foyer since 1954, for an undisclosed amount between £170,000 and £200,000.

The Daughters of Eve by Royal Academy member George Dunlop Leslie was bought by a private US collector. The painting - given to the school by its architect after underspending the building budget - will pay for a new classroom block.

Widdecombe pie penalty: £100

A woman who hurled a custard pie into the face of the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, at a book signing session in Oxford on April 27 was yesterday ordered to pay her £100 in compensation. Melanie Jarman, 28, of Oxford, pleaded guilty to an offence under the Public Order Act at Oxford magistrates' court and was conditionally discharged for 12 months. She said afterwards: "It was worth it."

Drug smuggler jailed

Mohammad Abubakr, a Dutch national who tried to smuggle more than 1kg of cocaine, worth nearly £150,000, in latex packages in his intestines was jailed for nine years at Warwick crown court yesterday.

Abubakr, 39, was stopped by customs officials at Birmingham airport after arriving from his home city of Amsterdam last month. He admitted drug smuggling.

Constable skies fetch £531,000

Five cloud studies drawn on scraps of paper by John Constable, which later languished in a desk drawer for more than 150 years, fetched £531,000 at Sotheby's yesterday.

The artist gave them to his first biographer, the artist Charles Robert Leslie, who tucked them into his drawer.
Simon de Burton

Twins' 100th birthday

Britain's oldest twins, Alice and Nellie Clarke, of Eccles, Greater Manchester, celebrated their 100th birthday yesterday.

fields.headline: True stories
fields.standfirst: Forget the city girl oeuvre - if you want to write a successful novel, set it around a historical event.  Ros Coward  on why books are looking back
fields.trailText: Forget the city girl oeuvre - if you want to write a successful novel, set it around a historical event. Ros Coward on why books are looking back
fields.body:
An aspiring novelist searching for success could do worse than look through the history books. A surefire format would be to identify a peripheral figure - a wife, servant or daughter - whose story would coincide with a significant historical moment.

Bridget Jones is proving a hard format to reproduce, but history is a bottomless pit and the public appetite endless. In 2000, surprisingly, it's historical narrative we crave. This will win the prizes, have the longer shelflife and, importantly, make better films.

Most publishers reject the idea of this historical outpouring as a distinctive genre. Captain Corelli's Mandolin belongs to the love and war saga category, along with Sebastian Faulk's Birdsong and Charles Frazier's Cold Mountain. Giles Milton's account of the spice wars, Nathaniel's Nutmeg, is quirky social history, like Longitude. Mr Darwin's Shooter is historical fiction while Sarah Smith's The Vanished Child is detective fiction.

But is there really much difference between these genres?

There's more than a touch of zeitgeist in the sheer number of novelists using historical writing as a form of fiction. There's also something distinctive about how they are doing it. Whereas in earlier historical fiction, contemporary characters were projected onto a historical background, the current writers are all interested in documentary history itself.

Professor Peter Brooker, of University College, Northampton, says: "Fiction is blended with, or based on, authentic historical documentation. These are more, or other, than fiction. Examples would be Jay Parini's novel of Walter Benjamin's last days, Benjamin's Crossing; or Angela's Ashes which, although autobiographical, reads as a novel; or Dava Sobel's latest, Galileo's Daughter, which is again traditionally researched but told as a novel."

This "hybridisation" explains why, although ostensibly different, the social history of the tulip or the biography of the pound doesn't feel that different from contemporary historical fiction. It explains the phenomenon of Stalingrad, a military history, selling an astonishing 500,000 copies.

Is such looking backwards merely escapism or nostalgia? Certainly, many of these books focus on the individuals, scientific discoveries or objects which have brought our modern world into being: Galileo's astronomy, the discovery of longitude, the birth of natural history.

There is also a longing for a world without scientific or geographical knowledge, where travel was an act of courage; there is a sub-theme of epic sea voyages and wilderness novels including the real-life tales upon which Herman Melville based Moby-Dick. But these are no "heroic" accounts. So much of it is narrated from the margins, by women, by black people, by servants, by itinerant travellers. This summer, the Women's Press will bring out Ahab's Wife, the fictionalised account of the wife Captain Ahab invokes in moments of terror before the great white whale.

Fascination with history might look like turning back to the certainties of the past but it's the opposite. "This trend," says Brooker, "is consistent with postmodernist theory in academia. Indeed, it's an example of how those academic preoccupations get taken up in popular forms. This is taking up something in the margins and, to put it crudely, using it to decentre known history, exposing known history as narrative."

This is not new. Jean Rhys's Wide Sargasso Sea rewrote Jane Eyre from the point of view of the mad woman in the attic, a narrative ahead of its time for exposing the sexual and colonial assumption hidden by the mainstream literary canon.

Professor Peter Widdowson, of Cheltenham and Gloucester College, calls this "re-visionary writing", like JM Coetzee's Foe imagining a woman whom Defoe wrote out of the story of Robinson Crusoe. Or Jane Smiley's A Thousand Acres rewriting King Lear from the daughter's point of view. "The post-colonial writer is writing back to the canonical text which has itself sustained colonialism," says Widdowson.

This explains why so much contemporary fiction is interested in history. Typically, Graham Swift's Waterland and Peter Ackroyd's Hawksmoor are as interested in how you know things as what you know, concluding that history is only ever contesting stories.

In An Instance of the Fingerpost, Iain Pears not only rewrites the official history of the English civil war from the bottom up but also makes contesting versions of truth the centre of his narrative.

This is more than intellectual games. The irony of this post- modernism is that it has given us a fascination with the pre-modern. Perhaps we are lapping up what we can read about significant moments in the construction of modernity because we sense we are in the middle of another shift in what we know and think. This explains why we need to know how our beliefs came about, and how much has been excluded or forgotten in what we know.

The writers seem to agree that this trend is a reflection on the present.

Jane Rogers, author of two successful historical novels, Mr Wroe's Virgins and Promised Lands, says: "Setting something in the past makes it easier to engage with present-day ideas about which people have all sorts of preconceptions. In Mr Wroe's Virgins, I wanted to explore the notion of a woman who instinctively wanted independence, who instinctively knew she was equal to men and wanted to pursue her own path. If you put that in the present, people have all sorts of prejudices about feminism and so on. Setting it in the past, you cut away the clutter."

This construction of history as narrative is undoubtedly exciting. It has brought other histories in from the margins. It has created a new hybrid writing which combines historical record with autobiog-raphy, fiction and memoirs.

Breaking down the old generic boundaries like this means we now have social history that is much more pleasurable and fiction that is much more knowledgeable. But there is a possible downside.

Brooker asks: "Is there a danger that all distinctions between forms, orders of truth and types of evidence, and between the past and present, could be lost? If history is only 'texts' or stories, could we be entering a free-for-all in an eternal present in which plagiarism counts for nothing?"

More worrying is the possibility that historical relativism could also be taken as "anything goes", which would be a problem if authors were casual with the truth.

This concern has surfaced in the controversies about the accuracy of Captain Corelli's Mandolin and Hollywood's rewriting of history by ascribing the capture of the German enigma code machine to the Americans.

But Rogers thinks a flood of inadequately researched and bogus histories is improbable. "Most writers are just as interested in getting their facts right as a historian. They both want to say something that's truthful."

It is, after all, a good sign that Louis de Bernières is willing to alter Captain Corelli's Mandolin to fit the facts.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15
fields.body:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15

Churchill Arms,
119 Kensington Church Street, London W8. Tel: 020-7792 1246

Why is it that pubs have taken to Thai grub in such a major way? The Churchill is one of the better experiences in London, boozer in front, restaurant complete with rain forest décor at back. No common or garden fish tank bubbling quietly away in the corner here. Quick, slick service from usually friendly waitresses, frequently of South African origin. Decent, standard Thai dishes; variations on the stir fry/green curry/chilli fresh salads, plus rice or noodles. Nothing too fiddly, fancy or expensive - £8 a head for food average. Proximity to pub gives it a kind of buzz. But popular in its own right, so book.

Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Sausage & Mash Cafe ,
268 Portobello Road, London W10. Tel: 020-8968 8898

All the world loves a sausage. The S&M does them in style - comfort food for the day before, the morning after, and right now this minute. There's a gallery of about eight broad-shouldered bangers including a decent veggie option, plus six kinds of mash and five gravies. Presentation is a high art form - dishes (troughs) arrive with everything together - a mountain of creamy, monster mash with sausages jammed in at angles and gravy everywhere. It is a bit of a canteen - benches, smoke and noise. Not a trace of subtlety or sophistication. Great for groups or losing yourself in a crowd. Wine if you want/need it.

On the menu: hoisin

I know what that is. It's the sweet brown goo you spread on the pancakes with Peking duck.

True. But what's it made of?
It's yet another of the 1001 byproducts of the soya bean.

Where would we be without it?
Indeed. The original can be traced back to the Qi Min Yao Shu, written in the 6th century. Things haven't changed much. Begin the sauce by salting, fermenting and grinding soya beans.

Then?
Add sesame oil, garlic, five-spice powder and a hint of chilli. And sugar.

Sugar? Is that just for depraved western tastes?
Heavens, no. The Chinese love sweetness as much as we do .

What's five-spice powder?
Ask me next week.

Food on the net

www.fortnumandmason.com

Summer's here, and thoughts turn to picnics. If it's a feast on the riverbank rather than a sandwich on the park bench that you have in mind, then you're going to need to do some planning - a hamper and foods from the 300-year-old store should do the trick.

Pros: A site that takes service seriously - you're guided throughout by a "shopping assistant", which constantly displays your choices. Gift lists can be tailored to choose goodies for loved ones.
Cons: It might be secure, but there's no way of knowing here. Delivery information is sketchy.
Delivery: Within three or four days, quicker if you order fresh foods.
Charges: £5 per delivery.

Cheat's kitchen

Lemon and parsnip soup

6 onions
2 parsnips

Tel: 020-7792 1246 Why is it that pubs have taken to Thai grub in such a major way? The Churchill is one of the better experiences in London, boozer in front, restaurant complete with rain forest décor at back. No common or garden fish tank bubbling quietly away in the corner here. Quick, slick service from usually friendly waitresses, frequently of South African origin. Decent, standard Thai dishes; variations on the stir fry/green curry/chilli fresh salads, plus rice or noodles. Nothing too fiddly, fancy or expensive - £8 a head for food average. Proximity to pub gives it a kind of buzz. But popular in its own right, so book. Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes Sausage & Mash Cafe , 268 Portobello Road, London W10. Tel: 020-8968 8898 All the world loves a sausage. The S&M does them in style - comfort food for the day before, the morning after, and right now this minute. There's a gallery of about eight broad-shouldered bangers including a decent veggie option, plus six kinds of mash and five gravies. Presentation is a high art form - dishes (troughs) arrive with everything together - a mountain of creamy, monster mash with sausages jammed in at angles and gravy everywhere. It is a bit of a canteen - benches, smoke and noise. Not a trace of subtlety or sophistication. Great for groups or losing yourself in a crowd. Wine if you want/need it. On the menu: hoisin I know what that is. It's the sweet brown goo you spread on the pancakes with Peking duck. True. But what's it made of? It's yet another of the 1001 byproducts of the soya bean. Where would we be without it? Indeed. The original can be traced back to the Qi Min Yao Shu, written in the 6th century. Things haven't changed much. Begin the sauce by salting, fermenting and grinding soya beans. Then? Add sesame oil, garlic, five-spice powder and a hint of chilli. And sugar. Sugar? Is that just for depraved western tastes? Heavens, no. The Chinese love sweetness as much as we do . What's five-spice powder? Ask me next week. Food on the net www.fortnumandmason.com Summer's here, and thoughts turn to picnics. webTitle: Straw defends attempt to seize journalists' notes

fields.headline: Straw defends attempt to seize journalists' notes
fields.standfirst:
Freedom of information: special report
Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, has defended police attempts to force the Guardian and Observer newspapers to hand over any emails or notes they may have relating to the former MI5 officer, David Shayler.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, has defended police attempts to force the Guardian and Observer newspapers to hand over any emails or notes they may have relating to the former MI5 officer, David Shayler.

He also says the courts must balance journalistic freedom with other interests recognised by the European human rights convention. However, he makes no mention of the special importance attached to freedom of expression in the data protection and human rights acts.

It is unusual for a home secretary to comment on a case while it is before the courts. Mr Straw has done so in a letter to Richard Burden, Labour MP for Birmingham Northfield, who raised the case in response to concern expressed by a constituent, a member of the National Union of Journalists.

Mr Burden drew the home secretary's attention to a Commons motion signed by over 40 MPs of all parties expressing concern at "the assault on independent journalism represented by the attempt to intimidate the Guardian, the Observer, and the reporter Martin Bright, by obtaining orders under the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 to force them to surrender information relating to contacts with David Shayler, which was either in the public domain or has been supplied to ministers by Mr Shayler himself".

The two newspapers have been given leave by the high court to challenge an order by an Old Bailey judge forcing them to hand over any emails or notes they may have relating to Mr Shayler.

Mr Straw says in his letter that he cannot comment on particulars surrounding the case. However, he goes on to describe powers under the Police and Criminal Evidence Act which enable the courts to issue production orders.

"Failure to comply with a production order will leave it open for the judge to punish the person concerned for contempt," adds Mr Straw.

He refers to article 10 of the European convention covering freedom of expression but stresses that this principle can be subject to restrictions "necessary in a democratic society".

Concern that these restrictions could be interpreted too broadly by English judges led the government to agree to amendments in the Human Rights Act - which comes into force on October 2 - and the new Data Protection Act.

The first states that courts "must have particular regard to the importance of the convention right to freedom of expression" as well as to "journalistic material". The second refers to "the special importance of the public interest in freedom of expression".

The Commons motion calls on ministers to "restrain proceedings against journalists and ensure that the orders against the Guardian, the Observer and Mr Bright are withdrawn and that no charges are laid against them ... under the official secrets act."

Signatories to the motion, drafted by the Labour MP Austin Mitchell, include the Tory MP Nicholas Winterton, the Liberal Democrat MPs Malcolm Bruce and Mike Hancock, the Plaid Cymru leader Dafydd Wigley, and the Labour chairman of the Commons public administration committee, Tony Wright.

The motion also refers to Julie Ann Davies, a student at Kingston university, west London, arrested under the secrets act and now on police bail. All these actions, it says, were taken to "suppress legitimate inquiries in the public interest".

The Guardian and Observer argue that the police have no need to see any material the newspapers may have, not least because Mr Shayler has himself repeatedly and openly admitted disclosing information about the activities of MI5 and MI6.

fields.headline: No: 1657
fields.standfirst: Iceland
fields.trailText: Iceland
fields.body:
Age:
The modern republic is 56 but the country's parliament is the oldest in the world, dating from 930.

How lame. I think you know I meant the chain of frozen food stores:
Oh. It started life as a roadside strawberry stall run by two trainee Woolworth's managers in 1970.

Goodness, and to think nowadays it's a 700-store giant dedicated to delivering the cheapest frozen burgers on the planet:
Actually, you're rather out of date.

What, you mean they've diversified into frozen chicken tikka meals?
Actually they've just announced plans to become Britain's greenest supermarket by buying up 40% of the world's organic vegetables.

Goodness, that's a bit of a departure from frozen battery chickens isn't it?
Where have you been for the past few years? Iceland was the first retailer to ban GM products from its shelves, the first to banish artificial additives from its own brand products and the first to sell eggs without artificial colouring. Then there's the company's Greenpeace-supporting chairman, Malcolm Walker, who grows his own organic vegetables and...

OK, I think I get the message - not so much Iceland as Greenland.
I think you'll find that one has already occurred to the headline writers.

Just one question: doesn't freezing zap all the goodness in those lovely organic vegetables?
Not according to Mr Walker who likes to say: "Freezing is God's own way of preserving food."

Shame he can't extend his reformist zeal to that dreadful fluorescent orange colour scheme.
Beauty is in the eye of the beholder.

Not to be confused with:
Bjork; Selfridge's food hall; the republic founded in 1944 with the world's oldest parliament.

Do say:
"Isn't freezing God's way of preserving food?"

Don't say:
"Can I write a cheque for 67 pence, please?"

fields.headline: Mr Hague's also-rans
fields.standfirst:
His team is seriously short on talent

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: His team is seriously short on talent
fields.body:
In a characteristic series of playground exchanges in the Commons on Wednesday William Hague twitted Tony Blair with the leaked account of his failings as charted by Philip Gould's focus groups: pandering, lacking conviction, unable to hold a position, and so on. But Mr Blair had the focus group findings with him, and unleashed on the Tory leader the unflattering things which they said about him: boring, false, pathetic drip, nonentity, no substance, no personality, complete waste of time ... The last entry read: "very unimpressive team, particularly William Hague".

That catalogue is unjust to the Conservative leader and suggests that the public at large have yet to take much account of his rising political reputation. These things take time to filter through. But the adjectives mustered by Labour's focus groups were not out of place. Every one can be fairly applied to some or most of Mr Hague's frontbench team, and some deserve quite a lot of them. The cerebral David Willetts has done well with his social security brief, sometimes trespassing to good effect on colleagues' territory. Michael Portillo has mostly been deathly quiet, perhaps because he feared to overshadow his leader, perhaps because he has little to say. Francis Maude, who lost the shadow chancellorship for his lack of impact, has hardly caught the imagination now he is shadowing Robin Cook. Down the line, things are even worse. Who remembers anything said by Theresa May in that key electoral slot, education? Liam Fox (health) is better, but hardly outstanding. Has the old Asda boss Archie Norman done anything to suggest we should trust the environment to him? And how on earth has Andrew Mackay hung on so long to the Northern Ireland portfolio? As the gap betwen the parties narrows, voters will start to consider the likely shape of a Conservative government. When they do, the Tory recovery may - and certainly should - begin to abate.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Court clears Rwandan bishop
fields.body:
Court clears Rwandan bishop

A Rwandan court yesterday acquitted a Roman Catholic bishop of genocide charges, ruling that he played no part in the slaughter of hundreds of thousands of ethnic Tutsis.

Bishop Augustin Misago had been accused of helping to plan the genocide in 1994, but had consistently maintained his innocence and had won the support of the Pope and senior Vatican officials.

"All accusations against Misago have been dropped. Misago is free. Misago has won the trial," said Jariel Sekarusu, president of the criminal court in the capital, Kigali.
Reuters, Kigali

Two Serbs killed by landmine

Two Kosovan Serbs were killed and a third was injured yesterday when their van hit a landmine in an incident that international officials called an act of ethnic violence.

The victims were driving a red van towards the railway tracks in the village of Lepine, south-west of the provincial capital Pristina, when it ran over the mine.
Reuters, Lepine

Film star snubs Algerian leader

The French film star, Isabelle Adjani, has boycotted a state dinner honouring the Algerian president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, saying she refused to become an accomplice to continuing human rights abuses in Algeria.

"There's still no justice worthy of that name in Algeria and 10,000 people are still missing," Adjani, whose father was Algerian, was quoted as saying in the daily Libération.
AP, Paris

Bardot guilty of inciting hatred

A French court convicted the French actress and animal activist Brigitte Bardot yesterday of inciting "discrimination, hatred or racial violence" for criticising a Muslim festival in which sheep are slaughtered.

Bardot also was fined 20,000 francs (£1,950) for a passage in her book published in 1999 in which she criticised the Muslim practice of killing sheep to mark the end of the holy month of Ramadan, and in which she lamented the invasion of her "homeland" by "foreigners, especially Muslims".
AP, Paris

US man freed from toilet

A man was rescued by police near Philadelphia after he became stuck up to his hips in a portable toilet while trying to retrieve his keys.
AP, Pennsylvania

webTitle: Families make much of the gene business

fields.headline: Families make much of the gene business
fields.standfirst: News Analysis As C&A turns its back on Britain, the foibles of hereditary entrepreneurs come under scrutiny
fields.trailText: News Analysis As C&A turns its back on Britain, the foibles of hereditary entrepreneurs come under scrutiny
fields.body:
In the age of faceless multinational corporations, family businesses remain hugely important. In the US 40% of gross domestic product is generated by family businesses, which employ 60% of the workforce. In Britain such operations account for three-quarters of the GDP and 50% of employment.

Some of these family firms are ancient indeed. The Beretta family has been making guns for 450 years, while in Japan the Hoshi hotel company claims to date from the year 718 and to be in the hands of the 46th generation of the founding family. Most, however, collapse or are sold during the first generation and only one in ten makes it beyond the third generation.

Family values were often cited as the success of the C&A chain. Until four years ago there were no non-family members on the board of the chain which runs 577 stores in 12 European countries.

The company was set up in Holland by the Brenninkmeijer brothers, Clemens and August, in 1841 and its philosophy has been to let family values dictate business behaviour. And the values of the brothers were famously strict. They were from a staunchly Roman Catholic family and were notoriously tough on their own children.

Employees, if they kept "their nose clean" as a company spokesman once put it, could expect a job for life. Secrecy and loyalty were prized - as a elder Brenninkmeyer family member once put it: "Openness is a sign of weakness."

In a new book, author Carol Kennedy explores the family frictions and "the genetic lottery" of the retail dynasties.

Her frequent references to highly specialised genes makes them sound like what stars are to an astrologer. "The family itself," she says, "is wired into our survival genes," but in some families "the talent gene simply runs out."

Though John Lewis came to London from Somerset "the Welsh genes remained strong". While the Cadbury family "all seemed to be genetically blessed with a powerful social conscience and a gift for management", with the Sainsburys "provisioning was in their genes".

Thus with the Cadburys it's a chocolate story, from Aztec times to Dairy Milk.

How the chocolate got into the Quaker genes is not explained, but as it was with Fry and Rowntree, so it was with Cadbury. What first distinguishes the Cadbury saga is Bournville, the model factory and housing estate which the family firm built from the 1870s onwards.

With its gardens and orchards, playing fields and open-air swimming pool, education and healthcare, it set standards unmatched elsewhere in the industrial world. If this was paternalism it was of a kind that gives fathers a good name.

Edward Cadbury was very keen that his employees should belong to trade unions. He was against the honours system, rejected a peerage several times, as well as a privy counsellorship, and even an honorary doctorate. He was against the Boer war and in favour of Irish home rule.

His outspoken political views and large sums of cash enabled Lloyd George to manipulate him into newspaper ownership. Older readers might very well have been News Chronicle readers. The way in which Laurence Cadbury closed the pa per down in 1960 is still widely resented.

The Cadburys bred like rabbits and by the generation after Laurence there were hundreds of them. Instead of producing more genes this seems to have diluted them -Kennedy does not tell us. A recent television programme was more inclined to point the finger at the management consultant McKinseys.

Whoever was to blame, the merger with Schweppes evidently proved not to have been an entirely good idea.

Meanwhile the latest Sainsburys were also busily losing the plot. In 1982 they were Britain's biggest grocery retailers. When David Sainsbury became chairman the market value of the firm was £10bn; when he resigned two years ago it was worth only just over half that. His resignation sent shares up 22.5p - a blow to his self-respect that must have been softened by the fact that this added £50m to his personal wealth.

Of all the high street names tackled, the tale of the John Lewis Partnership stands out. The founder - who gave the shop his name - opened the first store in Oxford Street, London, in 1864. Mr Lewis was known as a litigious autocrat who ran the business single-handed till 1906 when he took his son Spedan into partnership.

When Spedan Lewis reached the age of 21 he had a look at the accounts. He saw that between them he, his father and his brother were taking from the firm as much as the entire staff, most of whom earned three shillings a week.

As soon as he was able he developed his ideas of industrial democracy, which meant that the partners (as staff were called) not only shared profits but also actual ownership - which came to include numerous other department stores as well as Waitrose.

His family progeny was tiny by the standards of the fecund Cadburys and Sainsburys but his legacy may be more durable.

fields.headline: Match of the day
fields.standfirst:
Money talked. ITV got to the altar

The future of the BBC: special report

Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: That Match of the Day as we have known and loved it all these years now seems doomed is not quite the end of the world for football fans - though it must seem that way to the BBC. Audiences at home will still get their televised premier league football, though not always in the form they prefer, while subscribers to Sky may have to pay more for it. The way that the system works made this outcome inescapable.
fields.body:
That Match of the Day as we have known and loved it all these years now seems doomed is not quite the end of the world for football fans - though it must seem that way to the BBC. Audiences at home will still get their televised premier league football, though not always in the form they prefer, while subscribers to Sky may have to pay more for it. The way that the system works made this outcome inescapable. The allocation of broadcasting rights was decided by auction, subject to basic quality standards - echoing the famously fallible system introduced by Margaret Thatcher which gave us our present brilliant array of terrestrial TV stations. Those who bid most in each case were the winners. The BBC reasonably thought that it should not commit more than £40m of licence fee payers' money. It probably bid a small fortune (the figure has not been disclosed) to land the FA Cup. But its pitch for the premier league left it a fatal £21m short of ITV's offer. And that was all that mattered: viewer loyalties, the BBC's record in televised football, Hansen and Lineker: the system ensured that such assets counted for nothing.

Who benefits? The clubs in the premier league, but the big ones especially. Which means to some extent the chairmen and shareholders, but above all the players. Even bigger stars will be signed around the world and even more staggering sums paid to them. The reputed top whack of £52,000 a week could look mean in a season or two. The gap between the rich and glamorous elite and the rest will widen still further, whatever comes out of negotiations for Nationwide games. Just 5% of the Premier loot will go to the game at the grassroots: better than nothing, but still hopelessly stingy if you think of a game where the young and eager and talented progress up the ladder to greater things. But the present grab-it-all system makes little allowance for that. Importing stars is easier, more certain to swell the crowds.

The process is classic short-termism. The only test for the allocation is how much it enriches those who control it. And anyway, as the game becomes more and more a part of big business, today's structure will crumble. The biggest clubs will want to play on the bigger, even more lucrative stage that is Europe, not at Charlton or Ipswich. We are already a very long way from Stanley Matthews; but the tyrannous reign of money suggests that we ain't seen nothing yet.

fields.headline: Abortion ship to defy protests
fields.standfirst: 5,000 operations a year planned around world
fields.trailText: The world's first floating abortion clinic has yet to set sail but it is already making waves. The brainchild of a Dutch doctor, Rebecca Gomperts, the ship will travel around the globe performing abortions off the coast of countries where the practice is outlawed.
fields.body:
The world's first floating abortion clinic has yet to set sail but it is already making waves. The brainchild of a Dutch doctor, Rebecca Gomperts, the ship will travel around the globe performing abortions off the coast of countries where the practice is outlawed.

The idea has not gone down well in Malta - one of the countries likely to receive a visit. The Maltese authorities earlier this week described the concept as "horrendous", while the island's Roman Catholic bishops have accused Dr Gomperts of seeking to carry out "heinous murders".

But Dr Gomperts, who spoke to the Guardian yesterday from her home in Amsterdam, was undaunted. "No major changes have ever taken place without a risk," she said. "Women should be empowered. We're talking about a human right here - the right to plan your offspring when and where you want.

"At the moment women are dying for nothing."

The idea for a "seagoing women's health clinic" came to Dr Gomperts when she was working as a doctor on the Rainbow Warrior, the Greenpeace boat sunk by the French secret service during an anti-nuclear protest in 1985.

The floating clinic, to be called the Sea Change, will target countries where abortion is illegal - all of South America, most of Africa, a large number of Asian countries and Poland, Malta and Ireland. Her organisation, the Women on Waves Foundation, has planned the initiative with military precision and seems to have considered every last detail.

The only obstacle now is money - £100,000 still needs to be collected to lease a ship to get started. The Sea Change will not be huge - 50 metres long - but it will be well equipped and very much like the hospital ships used during the second world war.

The "treatment room" will be housed in a shipping container which can be hoisted on and off shore and has already been designed. The vessel will drop its anchor 12 miles off the coast and will therefore, Dr Gomperts argued, be in international waters and subject to Dutch law.

Women will be ferried aboard in small boats in the morning and the clinic will include 10 beds and a waiting room. At other times of the day it will dispense contraception, advice and counselling.

Its crew, which is likely to include two doctors and a nurse, will be on hand to train local midwives in safe abortion techniques and open days will be held for local politicians and activists.

It is estimated that the ship will be able to perform 5,000 abortions a year and, since two thirds of the world's population live within 100 miles of a major port, its reach will be wide. Treatment will be free but women who are felt to be able to afford it will be asked to make a donation.

Aware that the ship is likely to be an easy target for anti-abortion campaigners, Dr Gomperts is adamant that security will be tight.

"In response to the potential for violent acts, we realise that we will have to be very vigilant and have therefore included security as a significant item in the ship's budget. This will include video and webcam surveillance systems, round the clock manned security watches on board and further measures which we cannot reveal."

The ship is unlikely to be sunk, she adds, and "the risk of harming women by attacking the ship would create very bad publicity for anti-choice terrorists".

The ship will stay in one place for up to six months and will arrive unannounced so as not to give anti-abortion activists a chance to organise themselves. Dr Gomperts vowed that it will sail the world until abortion is legalised everywhere.

"The Sea Change will continue to sail as long as there is a medical and political need or demand for it which means as long as there are still countries where women have no reproductive rights."

She points to the fact that around 100,000 women die as a result of botched backstreet abortions every year.

Women on Waves ultimately wants to buy and equip a ship but in the meantime a two-month pilot project is likely to get under way this year.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
So farewell Alastair Campbell ... sort of. As Alastair begins his stately withdrawal from the limelight (in preparation for becoming editor of the Mirror full-time after the next election, compared with the part-time work he now puts in through his sock puppet, Piers Morgan), we salute the man who enlivened the English language with words like "garbagic", and who humiliated political journalists on a daily basis for the past three years. Even on Wednesday, when Alastair announced he was taking a step back, the civil service notes of the lobby briefing show he'd lost none of his vim: "Asked where he had been over the last couple of days, the prime minister's official spokesman (PMOS) said he had been going about his business. Invited to elaborate, the PMOS said there was nothing to tell." Vintage stuff. " Pressed as to what he had been doing, the PMOS said it was a matter for him, the prime minister and the government for whom he worked. He didn't work for the press." Ah, the surly aggressiveness, the non-answer reply ... we'll all miss him.

Stepping into Alastair's shoes is his civil service deputy, Godric Smith. Yesterday we appealed for information about Godders, and got nothing in reply. Absolutely nothing. Apart from his reading classics at Worcester College, Oxford, and that he fervently supports Cambridge United, and is married, with two children, and lives in north London. We did discover Godric once worked as a press officer for Sane, the mental health charity - which could be handy if Mr Tony has one of his hissy fits, and starts swearing and kicking tables, as he did when he saw the Sun had stitched him up over his "handwritten" letter.

Speaking of Mr Tony, his recent declaration that he hated wearing a suit set off all sorts of talk about the casual look at work. Witness this memo sent to Deutsche Bank staff in London: "In line with policies prevailing in other locations, Global Markets staff will have the option to choose between wearing 'Formal Business' attire or 'Casual Business' (note, this is to be understood as an upgrade from 'Smart Casual') attire throughout the entire week between the dates of May 22 and September 1, 2000. This can only be adopted if the current standards for Fridays are improved within the guidelines above." Is that clear? Hmmm?

The Daily Mail continues its weird obsession with the Guardian (if it was a person, the Mail would probably be arrested for stalking). Leo McKinstry used a full-page rant yesterday to complain that "officialdom is extending its tentacles right across our society. There is no more graphic indicator of this trend than the public-appointments section of the liberal Guardian newspaper" - that's the Society section - "a staggering 110 pages of public-sector adverts". Except it's not of course, as a big chunk of the ads are for charities and trade unions, and even (this week) for an economist by the British Dental Association. "It is no coincidence that since the modern social-services industry was established in 1971, we have seen a huge rise in family collapse, child abuse, drug taking and juvenile delinquency," frothed Leo. That's another entry for our "non sequitur of the year" award.

Entries are rolling in for the Diary's Merge Matics competition, where you, the reader, are invited to combine two well-known works into one, and write an accompanying blurb. The result should be along the lines of ... The Remains of the Day of the Jackal (where a formal English butler puts his loyalty to his employer above all else, until he is persuaded to join a plot to assassinate Charles de Gaulle), or 2001: A Space Iliad (the Hal 9000 computer wages an insane 10-year war against the Greeks after falling victim to the Y2k bug). Entries to the Diary at the usual address, for the usual glittering array of prizes.

webTitle: Cash help to set up as childminder

fields.headline: Cash help to set up as childminder
fields.trailText: Childminders will get start-up grants of up to £600 under a government scheme announced yesterday to tackle a shortage of preschool places for the under-fours. Margaret Hodge, education and employment minister, said the grants would help childminders to equip their homes with stair gates, fireguards, insurance, toys and other capital items.
fields.body:
Childminders will get start-up grants of up to £600 under a government scheme announced yesterday to tackle a shortage of preschool places for the under-fours. Margaret Hodge, education and employment minister, said the grants would help childminders to equip their homes with stair gates, fireguards, insurance, toys and other capital items.

The grants, from £50 to £600, will come from an extra £4.5m for the early years programme. Ms Hodge said they should help up to 13,000 childminders in the next financial year.

"Childminders are key to the success of the national childcare strategy. For many parents it is what they prefer - having their child cared for in someone's home, often with their brothers and sisters and close to their own home."

webTitle: Heroin addicts' killer bug identified as untreatable

fields.headline: Heroin addicts' killer bug identified as untreatable
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Health officials yesterday confirmed they had isolated the bacterium they believe to be responsible for the deaths of 35 heroin addicts across Britain and Ireland - but cannot treat the virulent toxin it produces.
fields.body:
Health officials yesterday confirmed they had isolated the bacterium they believe to be responsible for the deaths of 35 heroin addicts across Britain and Ireland - but cannot treat the virulent toxin it produces.

After exhaustive worldwide research, scientists are now certain the clostridium bacteria is responsible for the death of 17 heroin addicts in Glasgow. They have also linked it to the deaths of the other addicts, but must await lab results for confirmation.

The bacterium is well known to scientists, but it generally affects animals rather than humans. Large scale human infection has not been recorded since outbreaks in the trenches of the first world war.

Officials first became aware of the illness in May when drug addicts began appearing at Glasgow hospitals with abscesses up to 12 inches in diameter. Many died within hours.

Investigators believe soil infected with the bug must have found its way into the heroin when it was being prepared for sale.

fields.headline: Rejected wife left 20 suicide notes
fields.trailText: The estranged wife of a millionaire who left her for his office tea lady drowned in the family swimming pool, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The estranged wife of a millionaire who left her for his office tea lady drowned in the family swimming pool, an inquest heard yesterday.

Paulene Elsbury, 62, who was abandoned for a woman 20 years younger by her husband David, was found dead at her luxury home.

A half empty bottle of champagne, a bottle of brandy and a glass were found at the poolside on what was to be her last night before moving out of the £1.2m riverside house in Whitchurch, Oxford coroner's court heard.

Mrs Elsbury's sister, Diane Hatcher, told the inquest that leaving the Oxfordshire house she had shared with her husband, then the chief executive of electronics giant Racal, was the final straw.

Mrs Elsbury was found by her sister and brother-in-law, Geoffrey, last September.

Mrs Hatcher, 55, had looked after her sister, who suffered from Parkinson's disease, since her marriage break-up.

She told the court Mrs Elsbury had made a suicide attempt when her husband left her in January 1998, for Rosalinde Tiller, but was found in time by the gardener.

The Hatchers found Mrs Elsbury in the shallow end of the pool with two packets of sleeping pills on the poolside. They also found more than 20 suicide notes and a request for her favourite hymns at her funeral and her will.

The coroner, Nicholas Gardiner, recorded an open verdict because he could not rule out that she might have stumbled into the pool when she was tipsy.

fields.headline: Euro fight hots up
fields.trailText: The treasurer of the pro-euro lobby Britain in Europe, Lord Sharman, asks why I "persist in claiming that [BiE] are funded by the European Commission" (Letters, June 15). The reason is that an official document from Britain in Europe states that "the European Movement [who are currently co-tenants with BiE] will be at the heart of the campaign's political, managerial and tactical leadership. European Movement staff will execute a very large number of the key campaign functions and its resources will be crucial to the ultimate success of the campaign."
fields.body:
The treasurer of the pro-euro lobby Britain in Europe, Lord Sharman, asks why I "persist in claiming that [BiE] are funded by the European Commission" (Letters, June 15). The reason is that an official document from Britain in Europe states that "the European Movement [who are currently co-tenants with BiE] will be at the heart of the campaign's political, managerial and tactical leadership. European Movement staff will execute a very large number of the key campaign functions and its resources will be crucial to the ultimate success of the campaign."

Further, it states that one of the European Movement's "key campaign functions" is "raising funds from the European Commission for public information campaigns etc" and says that such campaigns "should be [BiE] branded". So that the public is under no illusion that the pro-euro lobby is funded by the European Commission, we have published the relevant document on our website at www.businessforsterling.com.

Lord Sharman's description of Business for Sterling as "anti-European" is entirely typical of the kind of puerile tactics that the pro-euro lobby, in its desperation, has resorted to.
Dominic Cummings
Business for Sterling

webTitle: Solomon Islands police fail to regain guns

fields.headline: Solomon Islands police fail to regain guns
fields.standfirst: Solomon Islands: special report
fields.trailText: Rebels holding Honiara, the capital of the Solomon Islands, said yesterday that they would let police return to their jobs, one day after they forced the country's leader to resign.
fields.body:
Rebels holding Honiara, the capital of the Solomon Islands, said yesterday that they would let police return to their jobs, one day after they forced the country's leader to resign.

But the gesture of compromise seemed empty because they did not say they would allow the police to rearm. The rebels looted guns and vehicles from police headquarters last week when they detained the prime minister, Bartholomew Ulufa'alu, at gunpoint.

Last night, police said they still did not have their weapons and could not patrol effectively without them. As a result, it appeared that the well-armed militants themselves would continue to be the real enforcers of security.

The rebels said in a statement that they would work with the police "to ensure that there is a smooth transition to normal policing in Honiara". They also said that police vehicles would be returned and a rebel-imposed curfew would remain "until police regain adequate logistical capacity".

The document was signed by the rebel leader, Andrew Nori, and the deputy commissioner of police, Wilfred Akao, who joined the rebels' drive to oust Mr Ulufa'alu.

Tensions have been high on the main island of Guadalcanal for nearly two years as islanders feud over land rights. Indigenous residents have been using force and intimidation to expel thousands of migrants from the neighbouring island of Malaita.

Angry they have not been compensated for lost land and homes, Malaitans raided an armoury and took over the capital last week, demanding a change in government. Many of the indigenous residents retreated to the countryside, where they own most of the land. An unwritten ceasefire expires next week.

On Wednesday, the prime minister resigned and announced that a committee made up of government and opposition leaders would try to arrange peace talks. Mr Ulufa'alu said he hoped a deal could be reached within two weeks, allowing parliament to elect a new leader.

webTitle: I try to stop prisoners killing themselves

fields.headline: I try to stop prisoners killing themselves
fields.trailText: Clare Dyer reports a suggestion from Sir David Ramsbotham that ministers and myself are "dragging our feet" on suicide prevention and failing on the implementation of our drugs policy (Jails inspector backs US policy to halt suicides, June 14). Nothing could be further from the truth.
fields.body:
Clare Dyer reports a suggestion from Sir David Ramsbotham that ministers and myself are "dragging our feet" on suicide prevention and failing on the implementation of our drugs policy (Jails inspector backs US policy to halt suicides, June 14). Nothing could be further from the truth.

In the last 12 months we have: put in place in every prison a system and specialist staff to identify and support prisoners with drug misuse problems; increased the number of intensive drug treatment programmes from 18 to 45; increased the number of specialist drug dogs from 34 to 121; implemented a policy to ban visitors caught smuggling drugs; ensured that CCTV is available in 118 prisons; established formal contracts with external drugs agencies so that their staff may work in prisons; and introduced a national policy and contract for voluntary drug testing.

It is quite wrong to suggest that we gauge the success of our drug policy by testing only for cannabis abuse. Between 5 and 10% of the prison population are randomly tested, every month, for a range of illegal substances, including heroin, and the usage of heroin has fallen significantly.

I am as keen as Sir David to ensure that we reduce the numbers of suicides in our prisons. His thematic report last year gave us much to consider, including the New York Rikers Island suicide prevention programme which has, apparently, impressive results. We've considered that programme carefully. Neither I nor ministers gave an undertaking that we would conduct a full-scale pilot of the Rikers Island programme. That would have been both impractical and inappropriate. What we have done is start a pilot scheme based on the New York model where prisoners are paid in the role of prisoner observation aides.

We have a new staff training programme and strengthened our partnership with the Samaritans. We are testing ways of identifying prisoners at risk on reception and have improved the resources devoted to suicide prevention. We have stopped using unfurnished cells to prevent self harm. Finally, the new joint partnership with the NHS will also see improvements in mental health care. Reducing the number of suicides is my number one concern.
Martin Narey
Director general, HM Prison Service

fields.headline: Dodgy genes
fields.trailText: Conrad Lichtenstein (Letters June 12) has refused to visit our website  for its abundant references to scientific papers on the well-known invasiveness and instability of GM constructs in genetic engineering and insisted instead that I should supply them here.
fields.body:
Conrad Lichtenstein (Letters June 12) has refused to visit our website (www.i-sis.org) for its abundant references to scientific papers on the well-known invasiveness and instability of GM constructs in genetic engineering and insisted instead that I should supply them here.

Is he aware that the best-kept secret of the GM industry is that there is no documentation for the long term stability of GM constructs in terms of both structure and location in the plant genome for any GM line commercially released or undergoing field trial?

On grounds of safety and efficacy, such evidence should have been provided before approval for release was granted.
Dr Mae-Wan Ho

fields.headline: Fawlty perceptions
fields.trailText: So German TV is to buy the rights for Fawlty Towers (Germans about to hear a mention of the war, June 15) and the original series has already been screened. But how many German TV programmes have made it into our living rooms?
fields.body:
So German TV is to buy the rights for Fawlty Towers (Germans about to hear a mention of the war, June 15) and the original series has already been screened. But how many German TV programmes have made it into our living rooms? Many German TV police and paramedic programs are on par with The Bill or Casualty, but these never get a showing. If we were to have wider access to such programs it might go some way to dispelling the appalling stereotyped "Ach so" image which is almost taken for granted in this country and was so neatly exposed by Basil.
Chris Nowakowski
Surbiton, Surrey
chrisnowakowski@ hotmail.com

 Is there any significance in tomorrow's match against Germany kicking off at 1945?
Gary Pettecrew
Stockport
gpettecrew@freeuk.com

 Good to read that the England fans stayed relaxed and peaceful by smoking dope (Report, June 13). Was the England team on the same stuff?
Bernard Jarvis
Nottingham

 Please allow me to correct the inaccurate statements about the status of Blackheath High School in the 1950s when I was a pupil there (The Editor, June 9). It is true that the school is now completely private. This was not the case 45 years ago. The Girls' Day School Trust (of which Blackheath High was one of the earliest schools) confirms my statement that Blackheath High was a direct grant grammar school until 1976.
Baroness Jay
Oxford

fields.headline: Book watch
fields.trailText: We do like to blame TV for every social problem (How the British lag behind in reading, but lead the world in watching TV, June 15) - but the facts don't stack up.
fields.body:
We do like to blame TV for every social problem (How the British lag behind in reading, but lead the world in watching TV, June 15) - but the facts don't stack up. Four out of the top five countries for book reading were also in the top five for watching TV, while four of the seven worst countries for reading books watched the least TV. This would imply that we should be encouraging TV viewing, not fighting it. Maybe we just watch more TV because we have better programmes.
Robert Blood
Bridport, Dorset

 The caption to your picture of a fat kid stuffing his face in front of the telly is misleading. Surely he is American - he's eating from bags of "potato chips" rather than "crisps". Plus, of course, no British kid would wear denim shorts which had been hemmed. And I bet they've got an elasticated waist, too.
Chris Widgery
London

 The young couch potato might have looked more authentic if it weren't for the extensive collection of the literary magazine Granta on the bookcase beside him.
Rob Spence
St Annes on Sea, Lancs
spencro@edgehill.ac.uk

fields.headline: New goals for the BBC
fields.trailText: Des Lynam may be "personally delighted" (Angry BBC priced out of market, June 15) by ITV getting Premiership highlights, but those who love football should be disappointed and alarmed.
fields.body:
Des Lynam may be "personally delighted" (Angry BBC priced out of market, June 15) by ITV getting Premiership highlights, but those who love football should be disappointed and alarmed.

The BBC is streets ahead of ITV in its football coverage and preferred by the majority of fans. The head-to-head coming up during Euro 2000 will undoubtedly confirm viewers' preference, absence of the apostate Lynam notwithstanding. Even he looks out of his depth trying to cope with ITV's tacky sets and tabloid punditry, anxiously trying to squeeze in a few moments of chat before breaking off for interminable adverts.

Proven track record and unrivalled quality counted for nothing in the crude, loadsamoney auction. Most of this surfeit will end up in players' pockets, paid for by the ever suffering fan. Sooner or later this bubble is going to burst.
Brian Wilson
Manchester

 So, "the BBC's reputation has suffered another devastating blow when it lost the rights to screen Premiership football highlights". On the contrary, its reputation has been enhanced by its unwillingness to spend an excessive amount of licence fee income on this inflated auction.
KJ Rhodes
London

 As one who switches off or over whenever football appears on TV, I congratulate Mr Dyke on the success of his cunning plan to "lose" rights to the Premiership matches. I wait in anticipation for the new drama productions he has been nurturing for us, bringing opportunities for all those aspiring authors, actors and production staff, and the promise of awards for the true creativity the BBC is capable of showcasing.
Victoria Smillie
Norwich

 Great news. Perhaps now they can use some of this unexpected £40m on radio - maybe even get the moribund digital network nationwide.
Danny O'Hare
Brighton D.OHare@bton.ac.uk

 The worst thing is that millions of us will now have to suffer precious programme content shattered by adverts. Sport is just part of a growing casualty list.

We've heard Greg Dyke is toying with the idea of putting ads on BBC1. Why doesn't someone tell him the majority of punters are probably willing to pay £25 a year extra to keep ads away from our favourite content. £5 each from MOTD viewers alone would easily have saved it. (We've all found extra cash to surf the net).

Mr Dyke should show his TV genius by making the BBC market its unique selling point of keeping ads off our screens for a small premium (relative to other channels). Commercial stations would need millions to imitate such a core brand value "guarded" by the BBC, and, amazingly, still recognised globally (Chris Smith, please take note).
John Lilley
London bedslug@hotmail.com

 My couch kids will spend the same amount of time watching football but more time exposed to adverts for junk food and expensive designer sportswear. They may well become more flabby but they sure will look cool.
Ross Roberts
London

 No Match of the Day on BBC TV? There really is a God.
Tim Symonds
London
TSymonds@email.msn.com

webTitle: 18th century painting of wall inspires poet laureate's tribute

fields.headline: 18th century painting of wall inspires poet laureate's tribute
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Andrew Motion's latest poem is the only written piece in the National Gallery's latest exhibition, Encounters: New Art from Old.
fields.body:
You can still see crumbly walls like this all over the Mediterranean, old enough to contain Roman bricks, but still stubbornly lived in by humans.

At first glimpse, "it's a line of washing hanging from a rather manky building", the poet laureate Andrew Motion said yesterday.

Yet this wall, in Naples, has just inspired its second British work of art in 200 years. The first, a tiny canvas by the 18th century painter Thomas Jones, is worth hundreds of thousands of pounds and hangs in the National Gallery, London.

The new work is by Motion as part of the gallery's ambitious Encounters: New Art from Old exhibition which runs until September 17. His poem, the only writing in the exhibition, stands beside new works by artists including Eric Auerbach, David Hockney and Lucian Freud created in response to the traditional gallery collection.

Thomas Jones, a Welsh clergyman turned artist, painted A Wall in Naples in 1782. While his contemporaries were busy with classical landscapes or grandiose religious themes, he chose an ultra-plain subject with clear, intensely coloured geometric shapes at the top of his oil-painted paper on canvas.

The canvas shows rotting brickwork, holes left by scaffolding in an attempt to patch it with mortar and a stain made by a water overflow. Even the wood of the door and balcony is decaying.

It was the shapes, as well as the plainness, that drew Motion's eye. "It's extremely beautiful and looks so modern," he said. "He has just looked out of his studio and painted the ordinary human life opposite."

In tribute to Jones, the poem imagines a writer who cannot keep his mind on a more abstract subject and decides to anchor himself in what he sees.

The hunger in the last line is "for ordinary life", Motion said. The marks of this life are those left by the builders of the wall, those who lived in it and put out the washing and by Jones's painting.

The auction room value of the oil, which measures only 16cm by 11cm (6in by 4in), increased a thousand-fold between 1975 and 1979, according to an art market journal.

The National Gallery bought it in 1995. Its report on the purchase said Jones's "startlingly direct" approach had created new possibilities for landscape painting which were only properly followed up a century later.

Yesterday the gallery refused to disclose how much it had paid for the work.

A Wall in Naples

I have forgotten whatever it was

I wanted to say. Also the way I wanted

to say it. Form and music.

Perhaps it had something to do with - no,

that's not it. More likely, I should just

look at whatever there is

and fix myself to the earth. This wall,

I mean, which faces me over the street.

Smooth as a shaven chin

but pocked with the holes that the scaffolders left

and flicked with an overflow-flag. Which still

leaves pigeon-shit, rain-streaks, washing -

or maybe the whole thing's really a board

where tiny singing meteors strike.

How can we tell what is true? I rest my case.

I rest my case and I cannot imagine a hunger

greater than this. For marks.

For messages sent by hand. For signs of life.

Andrew Motion

webTitle: Student fell to death after drinks

fields.headline: Student fell to death after drinks
fields.trailText: An Oxford University student fell 200ft to his death from a crane after a night out drinking, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
An Oxford University student fell 200ft to his death from a crane after a night out drinking, an inquest heard yesterday.

Kai Dawson, 21, a metallurgy and materials science student in his final year, died on February 12 after scaling the crane in east Oxford.

Anthony Partridge, landlord of a pub opposite the crane, told Oxford coroner's court that he had alerted police late at night after seeing a man perched on the boom "bolt upright, his arms outstretched, like DiCaprio, Winslet sort of thing" [a reference to a scene in the film Titanic].

Dawson, from Freshford, Bath, had been celebrating a birthday. Following his death, his mother said he had been a keen rock climber who loved a challenge.

No one saw him fall but his body was discovered the following day in a garden.

He had an alcohol blood reading of 160mg per 100ml, double the drink-drive limit, and police said he may have fallen as the crane swung with the wind.

Verdict: accidental death.

Press Association
