webTitle: Korean rail links to reopen after 50 years

fields.headline: Korean rail links to reopen after 50 years
fields.standfirst:
The North's derelict economy brought it to the historic summit, but the South looks forward to mass family visits in August

Korea: special report
fields.trailText: The two Koreas' spectacular summit ended yesterday with more triumphant flag waving north and south - and the start of some hard thinking about how to sustain the new optimism.
fields.body:
The two Koreas' spectacular summit ended yesterday with more triumphant flag waving north and south - and the start of some hard thinking about how to sustain the new optimism.

The president of South Korea, Kim Dae-jung, proclaimed "a new day for Korea" after arriving home in Seoul but warned that it will take "time and patience to get results".

"We have to combine our burning love as compatriots with being practical and taking the easy steps first," he said.

An eye-catching plan to reopen rail links across the demilitarised zone may be one of the earliest steps. But more sensitive issues - ranging from reuniting families divided by the Korean war of 1950-53 to worries about the North's nuclear and missile plans - need to be addressed soon.

Kim Dae-jung was seen off at Pyongyang airport by the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, with as much public warmth as he was greeted on Tuesday. The route was again lined with several hundred thousand well-marshalled citizens brandishing paper flowers. The two leaders embraced at the foot of the steps to the plane, and Kim Jong-il waited to wave goodbye as it took off.

There were more spontaneous scenes in Seoul where Kim Dae-jung was greeted by thousands of cheering citizens waving flags and calling out congratulations. He left his car to shake their hands in the city centre and was greeted by a the release of thousands of balloons.

Elsewhere, the joint declaration he signed in Pyongyang was already being closely scrutinised for evidence that it will produce enough results to sustain public support.

More news emerged yesterday about North Korea's economic plight, which appears to have been a powerful motive behind Kim Jong-il's overtures to the South. North Korea's trade deficit was reported by the Japanese research organisation Jetro to have doubled in 1999. The sharp decline was said to be mainly due to foreign economic sanctions which Pyongyang is desperate to see lifted.

The South intends to speed up economic investment in the North. High on the list is an ambitious plan to rebuild the cross-border railways that have been silent for more than 50 years. Their reinstatement would link South Korea to China, Russia, and on to Europe.

One line will cross the border, the 38th parallel, at Munsan, near the joint-security area of Panmunjom. Another railway will link up with the eastern line to Vladivostok and the trans-Siberian railway.

The US is now expected to ease sanctions before the end of next week. The president of the American Chamber of Commerce in South Korea said that foreign companies were now "optimistic about investment in North Korea in the long term".

While the North looks forward to much-needed economic aid, public opinion in the South indicates a desire for rapid progress on the problem of divided families. Several million South Koreans have lost touch with their northern relatives since the Korean war. The two sides have agreed in the joint declaration to an exchange of visits by separated families on August 15, the anniversary of the 1945 liberation from Japan.

"Will this be just a token event, or the beginning of a real process of exchanges," asks a veteran South Korean journalist. "This is top of the list for the South."

Kim Dae-jung's officials said yesterday that Kim Jong-il has agreed to allow "investigations into whether family members in the North are still alive, and the freedom to travel and meet relatives". If this is true, North Korean society will be opening far more than many observers would have believed possible.

The first dissenting voice emerged yesterday when South Korea's opposition Grand National party (GNP) argued in a statement that Kim Dae-jung should have sought the return of South Korean prisoners of war and others who have been "abducted" by the North.

The GNP also complained that the joint declaration had not mentioned the issue of North Korea's missiles and its alleged nuclear weapons programme.

Kim Dae-jung addressed this sensitive issue on his return yesterday. "We did talk about nuclear weapons and missiles," he said. "It was a very fruitful discussion and I saw a great hope." The US and Japan - who wanted him to raise the issue with Kim Jong-il - will be anxious for further details.

However, even cynical South Koreans - and they are still few in number - concede that Kim Jong-il has impressed them favourably. "You can call it his coming-out party," said one of them. "He is completely confident and in control."

But the personal commitment of the two leaders is both a strength and a weakness. "It depends so much on these two men," said a European diplomat yesterday. "They both have to deliver."

South Korean officials insist that there is "firm agreement on the prevention of war and establishment of peace on the Korean peninsula" between the leaders. But no one expects the two sides' massive military forces to be reduced in size until the distant future - if at all.

Kim Dae-jung's officials said yesterday that Kim Jong-il has agreed to allow "investigations into whether family members in the North are still alive, and the freedom to travel and meet relatives". If this is true, North Korean society will be opening far more than many observers would have believed possible. The first dissenting voice emerged yesterday when South Korea's opposition Grand National party (GNP) argued in a statement that Kim Dae-jung should have sought the return of South Korean prisoners of war and others who have been "abducted" by the North. The GNP also complained that the joint declaration had not mentioned the issue of North Korea's missiles and its alleged nuclear weapons programme. Kim Dae-jung addressed this sensitive issue on his return yesterday. "We did talk about nuclear weapons and missiles," he said. "It was a very fruitful discussion and I saw a great hope." The US and Japan - who wanted him to raise the issue with Kim Jong-il - will be anxious for further details. However, even cynical South Koreans - and they are still few in number - concede that Kim Jong-il has impressed them favourably. "You can call it his coming-out party," said one of them. "He is completely confident and in control." But the personal commitment of the two leaders is both a strength and a weakness. "It depends so much on these two men," said a European diplomat yesterday. "They both have to deliver." South Korean officials insist that there is "firm agreement on the prevention of war and establishment of peace on the Korean peninsula" between the leaders. But no one expects the two sides' massive military forces to be reduced in size until the distant future - if at all.

fields.headline: 14 Britons in world richest list
fields.trailText: Fourteen British billionaires are in this year's list of the world's richest people, according to new figures published on Monday.
fields.body:
Fourteen British billionaires are in this year's list of the world's richest people, according to new figures published on Monday.

The Billionaires 2000 list in Forbes Global magazine contains more than 450 individuals and families whose estimated fortunes add up to nearly $2 trillion (£1.3 trillion).

Topping the list of British billionaires with $5.5bn (£3.7bn) is the Duke of Westminster, followed by supermarket heir David Sainsbury with $4.1bn and Virgin chief Sir Richard Branson with $3.3bn. Microsoft's Bill Gates, whose fortune was estimated at $100bn last year, still tops the list with $60bn.

Out of the UK's billionaires, only the Duke of Westminster and family make it into the list's top 100, at number 58.

Press Association

fields.headline: Pie in the sky
fields.standfirst: Among other defects, NMD will not work
fields.trailText: The disclosure that the Pentagon has been busily rigging the tests of America's prototype missile interceptors to demonstrate that they work, when in truth they do not, is the latest, persuasive reason why Washington's destabilising and ill-considered plans for a national missile defence system should be scrapped.
fields.body:
The disclosure that the Pentagon has been busily rigging the tests of America's prototype missile interceptors to demonstrate that they work, when in truth they do not, is the latest, persuasive reason why Washington's destabilising and ill-considered plans for a national missile defence system should be scrapped. According to Theodore Postol, a respected MIT arms expert, and Nira Schwartz, a former defence industry engineer turned whistleblower, the anti-missile missiles have a fatal flaw. They cannot discriminate between enemy warheads and the decoys which routinely accompany and protect them after launch.

A Pentagon planning chart obtained by Dr Postol showed the problem clearly: the interceptors' sensors, designed to pinpoint heat emissions from an incoming rocket in deep space, "see" only a large number of twinkles, one of which is the missile. In the first two tests, the decoys twinkled too much, causing the anti-missile to miss. The Pentagon's top boffins scratched their heads: how to overcome the "twinkle factor"? Simple. In a third test, the chart showed, decoys that twinkled as little as possible were substituted for their over-shiny brethren. Pointy and cone-like decoys emitting infra-red signals were found to be too twinkly by half. Stripey, spherical objects proved particularly effective in sending anti-missiles barking up the wrong galaxy. So they were discarded, too.

Banned also were "rigid decoys" on the odd grounds that they looked too much like the real thing. And to minimise further the chances of America's great new Star Wars shield being dished basically by a bunch of balloons, the overall number of decoys was reduced. In a report for the White House, Dr Postol said that all the NMD tests "have been carefully orchestrated to avoid encountering the discrimination problems". By such nefarious means, the Pentagon intended to declare after future tests that NMD was ready for deployment. But now its shabby game has been rumbled.

Beyond this Strangelove world there are other reasons for opposing NMD, apart from the fact it does not work. It potentially upsets the nuclear balance and breaches the cornerstone 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty. It may well provoke another arms race as countries like China seek ways to circumvent it. There are alternative ways, like diplomacy and international treaties, of dealing with the "rogue states" that the US says it needs protection against. There is also the Russian idea of a joint "booster-phase" defence involving the US and Europe. NMD is an issue dividing the Nato alliance; and it is wastefully expensive - $60bn for its first stage alone.

Even before deployment, NMD is already having a negative impact on US-Russian strategic arms reduction talks. As the president of the Centre for Defence Information, Bruce G Blair, pointed out this week, the US has actually enlarged to 3,000 its nuclear targets list since the 1993 Start II treaty was signed. These targets include Russian and Chinese "leadership sites". The US, Mr Blair said, also continues to maintain about 2,200 nuclear warheads on permanent, two-minute "hair-trigger" alert, thus enormously increasing the chances of an accidental launch. This is in any case irresponsibly dangerous, old thinking by Washington. Yet hopes of eliminating more of these warheads is undermined by NMD. Russia actually wants to drop the ceiling to 1,500 apiece as a next step, but will not do so if threatened by new space weapons. For all these reasons, NMD must be stopped while it is still just a twinkle in the generals' eyes.

fields.headline: Attilio Bertolucci
fields.standfirst:
Renowned Italian poet who tempered the musicality of his language with a reality drawn from humble places and human feelings

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The death of the Italian poet, Attilio Bertolucci, at the age of 88, marks the end of a poetic generation that consciously turned away from the symbolist search for some kind of absolute poem towards a re-routing of poetry in the phenomenal world and the world of place.
fields.body:
The death of the Italian poet, Attilio Bertolucci, at the age of 88, marks the end of a poetic generation that consciously turned away from the symbolist search for some kind of absolute poem towards a re-routing of poetry in the phenomenal world and the world of place.

In opposition to Italy's once most famous modernist poet, Gabriele D'Annunzio, Bertolucci's poetry qualifies the musicality of Italian with a wit and concreteness that brings words back to ground level and to daily human feeling. His sense of the sacred derives from places that are often quite humble, and which are not merely visited but lived in. Perhaps no other 20th-century poet has written so well, and so extensively, on his own family life.

Bertolucci was born near San Lazzaro di Parma. "I am," he has said, "the son of an agrarian middle-class family," his father coming from impoverished stock in the mountains, his mother from the rich middle-class of the valley of the lower Po. Parma itself offered a rooted continuity for his early years and, even after marriage, he continued to live in the parental house with his wife, Ninetta Giovanardi, and their first-born son, Bernardo, who began as a poet but was to become a film director under the tutelage of Pier Paulo Pasolini.

Bertolucci enrolled as a law student for a number of years, though without attending classes or taking any exams, then transferred to the study of art history, under Roberto Longhi at the University of Bologna. This subject he was to go on to teach at the Maria Luigia boarding school in Parma.

Parma also saw his debut as book reviewer, and theatre and film critic for La Gazzetta. Here, in the 1930s, he absorbed his anti-fascism from other Parmensi intellectuals. As foreign editor for the poetry publisher, Guanda, he was responsible for the La Fenice series, which introduced a wide range of overseas modern poetry to Italy.

As a poet, Bertolucci was an early beginner, his first book, Serio (Sirius), appearing in 1929, when he was 18. One poem here, Vento (Wind), was written three years earlier. After describing the aggression of the wind, the poem ends: ". . . weary, it falls asleep and a stupor/ Takes all things, as after making love." His older friends asked him what he, a 15-year-old could know about l'amore. "I could only blush in answer," he told me.

In 1934, a second volume, Fuochi In Novembre (Fires In November), attracted the attention of Eugenio Montale, always a perceptive reviewer, which helped to extend Bertolucci's reputation.

A long gap followed - there are several of these in the poet's career - and not until 1951 did Lettera Da Casa (Letter From Home) appear. This was a traumatic year for Bertolucci. He moved from the family house to Rome on the insistence of his father, who felt he had "a calling" there and gave Attilio and Ninetta the apartment in which they were to pass the rest of their life.

In Rome, along with another spell of teaching, Bertolucci worked for the publisher Garzanti, for the third programme of Italian radio and for the daily La Repubblica. He was also involved in various cultural projects for television. There was, by now, a second son, Giuseppe, also destined to become a film director and, if not as famous as his brother, an artist with a discriminating circle of admirers. After two other volumes - La Capanna Indiana (The Indian Wigwam, 1951) and In Un Tempo Incerto (In An Uncertain Time, 1955) - there appeared Viaggio d'Inverno (Winter Journey) in 1971.

This was Bertolucci's most stylistically adventurous book to date, its nervously roving syntax setting out for unpredictable destinations, enacting perhaps something of the nervous tensions that were involved in the deracination from Parma and the transfer to the capital.

The word ansia (anxiety) echoes time and again throughout the poems. "How anxiety is born," runs the title of one section of a later book. The word was anxiety, not depression, Bertolucci insisted.

When this condition became acute, he sought psychiatric aid. When it was alleviated, his psychiatrist refused payment, saying that the poet had cured himself by his own will to recover. That this ansia - for the feared loss of human certainties - should produce poems of such darting energy and loving attachment to the immediate world, is one of their creative fascinations.

Bertolucci's character stemmed from an intriguing mixture of timidity and boldness. Something of a malade imaginaire, he feared draughts more than the very real danger of being taken before the German authorities in 1944. When his house at Casarola was robbed, he responded with, "It could have been worse. Imagine if one had contracted pleurisy."

His friend, another great Italian poet, Vittorio Sereni, called him "a divine egoist", but the self-absorption was easily breached by his generosity to younger poets and by the sheer absorption in the flow of life which fills his poems.

Much of Bertolucci's subject matter - his family and his own childhood - remains constant. But now, in Viaggio d'Inverno, there is an amplitude behind the fears, and also the joys, of daily life nourished from deep within, and a force that is unwilling to brook stanzaic gaps, dispensing with punctuation and flowing forward like some sinuous river as it breaks out of the quatrains to make one final or provisional statement, as in I Papaveri (Poppies):

Half-way through my life, I'd seen

grown sons go off into their own

world, lost to sight beyond the cage in flights

which the swallows weave across the spent

glare of a stormy evening

and as is natural, my sorrow subsided

in the light of the house re-kindled

for another meal in an atmosphere freshened now

by a scattering of hailstones in the distance.

One sees from the form of a poem like I Papaveri why Bertolucci relished the advice Jean Renoir gave to his son Bernardo: "Remember always to leave the camera running, because things may enter it that you would never have imagined."

From the 1960s, Bertolucci tended to alternate between places of residence - the apartment in Rome during winter, an ancestral 17th-century house in the Apennine village of Casarola for spring and summer, and a pied-à-terre for autumn by the sea, in the Ligurian village of Tellaro. Tellaro is near to Lerici, where he was to become president of the committee for the Lerici prize and the biennial literary conference there. In 1991, he was made an honorary citizen of the town. The growing number of literary prizes attested the extent of his recognition throughout Italy.

It was at Tellaro that Bertolucci wrote large portions of his most ambitious work so far, a novel in verse, La Camera Da Letto (The Bedroom), published in 1984 and 1988, in which his parents' generation, his childhood (returned to after reading and translating Wordsworth), and his love for Ninetta are all celebrated. This exploration of a personal world reached out to a far wider audience than he had known previously, and the book became a great literary success - "an unpleasant word," Bertolucci was quick to add.

The appearance in 1994 of Imitazioni (Imitations), a book of verse translations, is a measure of Bertolucci's love of English literature: Milton, Wordsworth, Landor, Thomas Hardy and Edward Thomas are all here, beside a handful of Americans, including Ezra Pound, TS Eliot and Marianne Moore. Bertolucci accounted Proust "the most important writer of the 20th century". One might almost feel that Hardy and Proust are present in equal quantities in his often retrospective poems à la recherche du temps perdu, and there are moments when Edward Thomas seems close at hand.

These are, of course, intensely Italian poems, but Italian that has felt these other currents of language and sensibility. A life of translating both prose - Katherine Mansfield, DH Lawrence and Ernest Hemingway - and verse has shown Italian new possibilities in Bertolucci's work. "Translation," he said in All'improviso Ricordando (Unexpectedly Remembering, 1997) "is always an admirable exercise, which poets must do in the same spirit as painters, at times, copy their great predecessors."

The 1990s saw two other volumes of verse. The first of these, Verso Le Sorgenti Del Cinghio (Towards The Sources Of The Cinghio, 1993), consists in part of "lost" poems, refound in an old shoe box when Bertolucci was looking for materials to help Paolo Lagazzi, the most perceptive of Bertolucci scholars, in his researches.

In 1971, with the publication of Viaggio d'Inverno, Bertolucci thought himself at the end of his phase of lyrical poetry, as he turned more and more to the completion of the novel in verse. But Verso Le Sorgenti bears witness to the way in which a poet's conscious sense of where he is at can be confuted by the arrival of messages from unlooked-for sources, as the title of the book suggests. Four years later, La Lucertola Di Casarola (The Lizard Of Casarola, 1997) shows Bertolucci's lyric vein far from exhausted, and brings to light yet more mislaid or set-aside poems.

The rich fecundity of Bertolucci's work - both before and after the verse novel - provides an exceptional chapter in the history of 20th-century Italian poetry.

He is survived by Ninetta and their two film-director sons.

Attilio Bertolucci, poet, born November 18, 1911; died June 14 2000

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Raymond Gandy writes: In the summer of 1949, I was a national serviceman at 16 maintenance unit, RAF Stafford. The captain of our cricket team asked me to watch his fast bowler, and I saw, for the first time, the performance of Brian Statham (Obituary, June 12). The great potential was obvious.
fields.body:
Raymond Gandy writes: In the summer of 1949, I was a national serviceman at 16 maintenance unit, RAF Stafford. The captain of our cricket team asked me to watch his fast bowler, and I saw, for the first time, the performance of Brian Statham (Obituary, June 12). The great potential was obvious.

If the present England players studied Statham, they might start to eradicate the high-fives antics, infantile histrionics, outbursts of triumphalism - by fast bowlers, in particular - and the downright intimidation of umpires, all of which mar this beautiful game, which Brian Statham graced with such skill and quiet dignity. His gentle integrity and unique bowling action will remain in my memory for ever.

Frank Whitehead writes: David Foot's obituary of Brian Statham referred to his being known as "George". We Lancastrians like to believe that since the automatic pilot engaged to deliver aircraft and aircrew home from missions abroad was known as "George", this was applied to Statham's unerring accuracy. After all, he served in the RAF.

The vigilance needed to defend their stumps against him encouraged many batsmen to take chances against the bowler at the other end and provided wickets, which were acquired by, for instance, his England partner, as Freddie Trueman has acknowledged.

Lord Baker of Dorking writes: I worked twice with Jonathan Solomon (Obituary, June 13). The first time was in 1972, when he had the unenviable task of trying to fashion the prices and income legislation. His grin, and his chuckle, always indicated that he was sceptical about its effect, and he proved to be right.

Then, for three years, we worked together on the privatisation of Cable & Wireless and British Telecom. That whole exercise needed a civil servant like Jonathan, who was prepared to think the unthinkable and cope with all the sinuous twists and turns of the first major privatisation of the Thatcher government.

Unlike most civil servants, Jonathan could think laterally - and that was one of the most engaging things about him. When everything seemed impossible, he would come up with an ingenious and creative idea of doing things in a different way, but still achieving one's objective.

Jonathan was a delight to work with, for he always had some wonderful new scheme of mergers, takeovers, and alliances. Eric Sharpe was very perceptive in recruiting him to the board of Cable & Wire less, for Jonathan had the freest, widest-ranging mind of any director of that company, then and since.

Lady Susana Walton writes: Most of our 10 years of holding a summer course on Ischia, The Actor In Opera, have had the advantage of the presence of Johanna Peters (Obituary, June 7) - first as a guest, and later as a coach, teaching our young singers, unstintingly putting her invaluable expertise to good use. She communicated her artistic skill with tender sympathy, and over-sensitive musicians had their ruffled feathers smoothed by her unerring humour, wisdom and intelligence.

fields.headline: General Sir James Glover
fields.standfirst: Soldier whose assessment of the IRA changed the course of war and peace in Ireland
fields.trailText: General Sir James Glover, who has died aged 71, was one of a rare breed who, after a highly successful military career, moved effortlessly to an equally successful career on retirement. He was a natural soldier, with the army in his blood.
fields.body:
General Sir James Glover, who has died aged 71, was one of a rare breed who, after a highly successful military career, moved effortlessly to an equally successful career on retirement. He was a natural soldier, with the army in his blood. Mens sana in corpore sano could have been written to describe his ethos.

His ordered mind was represented in remarkably neat and regular handwriting. That was the outward and visible sign of a clear-sighted and intensely capable man, who was known for never doing things by halves - as in his typically clear assessment of the IRA when he was the senior army officer involved with intelligence work in Northern Ireland.

James, or "Jimmy" as he was universally known, was born in India, where his father, who also became a general, was serving with the Indian army. After Wellington College and the Royal Military College at Sandhurst, he was commissioned, in 1949, into the Royal Artillery, with which he served until 1956. He then transferred to the Rifle Brigade, then on operations in Malaya. On return to England, he attended the staff college, to which he had obtained a competitive entry, in 1959, from where he was appointed brigade major of 48 Gurkha Infantry Brigade in Hong Kong.

In 1963, Glover returned to his battalion, then in Cyprus, and, in 1967, after attending the Joint Services Staff College, went back as a member of the directing staff, being promoted lieutenant-colonel at the youngest age possible. In 1970, he was given command of his battalion, now 3rd battalion, the Royal Green Jackets, commanding it on operations in Northern Ireland and with the United Nations peace-keeping force in Cyprus. He also organised a memorable parade to mark the temporary reduction of the battalion to a company, about which Sir Arthur Bryant wrote most movingly on the demise of his favourite regiment, the Rifle Brigade.

From then on, Northern Ireland dominated Glover's career, certainly in the minds of the public who take an interest in the province. After promotion to colonel, and a first tour in the Ministry of Defence - in charge of the branch responsible for all operational deployments - and attendance at the Royal College of Defence Studies, he became Brigadier-General Staff (Intelligence), or BGS (Int), the senior army officer involved with intelligence work in Northern Ireland.

This was followed by promotion, firstly to major-general, as commander, Land Forces, Northern Ireland, and then to lieutenant-general, as deputy chief of the Defence Staff (Intelligence), the senior military intelligence post, which he held during the Falklands war.

But it was for a leaked document, entitled Future Terrorist Trends, written while he was still BGS (Int), that Jimmy became a well-known figure. In it, he pointed out that the IRA had taken a calculated decision to regroup from their earlier position of weakness. It now had a new and effective cellular structure, and was equipped with all the sinews of war - men, money and weapons - and must be taken seriously. This typically accurate assessment, however unpalatable to those who did not want to accept it, enabled the army to respond appropriately.

Ten years later, Glover gave an equally forthright interview on the BBC's Panorama programme, in which he pointed out that the Provisional IRA could never be defeated militarily, being dedicated to what it called the long war, and that Gerry Adams was a man "with whom we can do business".

Glover's only other military appointments were both connected with Northern Ireland. As vice-chief of the General Staff, with membership of the army board, from 1983-84, he was the immediate day-to-day link with the commander-in-chief, and, in his final appointment, with the rank of general, as commander-in-chief, United Kingdom Land Forces, he was responsible for the dispatch of troops to the province.

It was from this appointment that Jimmy went to great lengths to develop the army's links with the community. This included a number of briefings for senior people, including businessmen, from which he received an immediate invitation to join the board of British Petroleum on retirement.

He was also asked to chair the company responsible for building and operating the new Royal Armouries in Leeds, and, in 1997, became chairman of Merlin Communications International, the company formed from the privatised international transmission arm of the BBC. His retirement was thus as active as his military service.

Glover was awarded the MBE in 1964, the KCB in 1981, and appointed a deputy lieutenant of Hampshire in 1997. But he will, above all, be remembered as a cheerful companion, and a generous and welcoming host, with his wife Janet, whom he married in 1958. She survives him, with their two children, Carolyn and Jonathan, and five grandchildren.

In his younger days, Jimmy Glover was an accomplished middle-distance runner, whose classical style suggested a natural athlete. To the end, he looked lean, alert and fit, his daily routine invariably including a long walk at a brisk pace. It was typical of him that he should have spent much of his last day gardening and walking at his home.

General Sir James 'Jimmy' Malcolm Glover, soldier, born March 25 1929; died June 4 2000

fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: Ratcatcher | Dogma | Mystery Men
fields.trailText: Ratcatcher | Dogma | Mystery Men
fields.body:
Ratcatcher
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert 15
****

Use, and mainly misuse, of lottery money by our film industry has been a national disaster highlighted here and elsewhere. It's worth pointing out too that once in a while, some of the dosh goes where it should - to assist a young, talented film-maker to make a memorable movie, like Ratcatcher. The title come from a grim time in Glasgow's 70s history, when a binmen's strike made rats and head lice all too common. If that makes the film sound like a grim struggle with deprivation, it rises above that, due to director Lynne Ramsay's light touch.

Ratcatcher is broadly in the Leigh/Loach social realist tradition, but there's a lyrical quality that is very much her own. While the city is filmed with filters draining it of colour, 12-year-old central character William Eadie also finds his way to the country, which looks idyllic by contrast. At the end of a bus route a new house is nearing completion - which may possibly rehouse William's family. It backs on to a cornfield, and I haven't seen a cornfield filmed with this much beauty since Days of Heaven.

This is typical of the way Ramsay, a 29-year-old National Film and TV School graduate, combines gritty realism with surprising lyricism in an unpretentious way - like William's friend giving his pet white mouse a ride into a bright blue sky on a red balloon, a journey that can only mean death for the mouse. There's tragedy and courage among the adults too - William's father gets beaten up on the way home from receiving an award for bravery. The plot often leaves you slightly uncertain (some of it may be in William's mind) but the multi-award winning Ratcatcher deserves to be seen by far more than its modest cinema attendance.

Dogma
Rental
FilmFour Cert 15
**

Ironically, Kevin Smith's religious satire ends up rather preachy as well as being very talky and complicated. Writer-director Smith seems to have bitten off more than he can chew with this story of two fallen angels (Matt Damon and Ben Affleck) on a journey to New Jersey to enter a gateway back to Heaven. If they make it, the world will apparently come to an end because God will be proven fallible.

Ranged against them is a baffled Linda Fiorentino, selected by white-faced tequila-drinking seraph Alan Rickman (Truly, Madly dead again) to prevent this happening with the assistance of Chris Rock, "the 13th apostle" and of course Jay and Silent Bob, without whom no Smith film is complete.

Their presence had me longing for the simplicities of Smith's Clerks. At least Dogma is not a disaster on a scale of his Mallrats, but this kind of set-up was done so much better by Pete and Dud in Bedazzled. I think that's because they were aiming to be funny while Smith seems to have a serious purpose here, but apart from being pro-religion and anti-church, I'm not sure what it is. He juxtaposes some suprisingly earnest religious discussion and oodles of plot up against his traditional scatalogical obsessions and a running diatribe against John Hughes movies. His best joke is selecting Alanis Morissette as God. Isn't that ironic?

Mystery Men
Rental
Universal Cert PG
**

There's lots of talent in this cast - William H Macy, Janeane Garofalo, Geoffrey Rush, Tom Waits, Paul "Pee-Wee" Reubens and Lena Olin to name but a few. But beware. Eddie Izzard, whose instinct for duff films is as unerring as his ability to make us laugh without a script, plays the leader of the Disco Boys.

The mystery here is how so much talent got involved in this lame little comedy. Mystery Men is about a collection of superhero wannabes who don't have any superpowers but have to prove themselves by rescuing Captain Amazing from ace villain Casanova Frankenstein. It sounds like the plot for a three-minute Whose Line Is It Anyway sketch, especially when Invisible Boy (only invisible when no one's looking) appears. Based on a Dark Horse comic, this turns out to be a bit of a dead donkey.

fields.headline: There's something about Betty
fields.standfirst: Former Hill Street Blues star Betty Thomas is now a versatile director. She talks to Danny Leigh about her films - from subversive sitcom The Brady Bunch Movie to a new feelgood comedy about rehab, 28 Days
fields.trailText: Former Hill Street Blues star Betty Thomas is now a versatile director. She talks to Danny Leigh about her films - from subversive sitcom The Brady Bunch Movie to a new feelgood comedy about rehab, 28 Days
fields.body:
Betty Thomas, all 6ft 1in of her, slips off her shoes, raises her big, bare feet on to the chair opposite, and ponders her latest film, a confused rehab comedy called 28 Days. "Here's the thing," she says. "When I looked at the script for this movie, all I could think - I mean all I could think - was: why? Why the hell are they sending this to me?"

Her expression hovers between bemusement and irritation. "I mean... why?"

It wouldn't be the first time. For Thomas, sow's ears have become a speciality: taking the very worst of bad ideas and fashioning, if not silk purses, then perfectly serviceable, frequently inspired, mainstream comedies.

A big-screen version of long-cancelled family sitcom The Brady Bunch? Give it to Thomas and six months later she delivers a dry, gently subversive rag on all things apple pie. A biopic of shock jock Howard Stern? She turns round Private Parts, a quick-witted portrait of a surprisingly human subject. A remake - now we're getting ridiculous - of Dr Dolittle, dreamed up as an Eddie Murphy star vehicle? No problem. Eddie talks to the animals; we chuckle indulgently. The woman is less film-maker than lifeguard.

"You know what?" she exclaims. "A lot of people say: give me the greatest script in the world. And I don't know that I want that. I want a script where it's difficult to understand why it's funny, or moving, or why a person would want to spend millions of dollars making it. Because I like the idea that a script is just a blueprint, to blow open and explore."

She leans back, annoyance fading. Because the other thing you notice about Betty Thomas, apart from her big, bare feet, is her preternatural calm. "Here's the thing," she says, or "You know what?", anticipating every criticism you could throw her way. She knows that a movie like 28 Days, full of platitudes and Sandra Bullock, was never going to be a journalists' favourite. And here's the thing: she doesn't care. It's in her look of amused resignation when I ask if she's happy with it.

"You know what? I'm never happy with my films. I mean, it's a flawed film. I try to make my films flawed. Who wants to make the perfect film? All you'll do is piss off the gods."

Maybe the Zen-mistress shtick comes down to her scenic route into this most highwire of businesses, with its pit stops at improv comedy and low-key TV stardom. No baby director she, pestering relatives with a Super-8. Born into Eisenhower-era suburban Ohio, she instead found herself coming into adulthood just as the Age of Aquarius kicked in, and heading for that most modish of career choices: life as (in her words) a "freaky art student".

"Purely for a lark, I auditioned for the drama department. I mean, at the same time I was making this stupid little 8mm film, and that's what I thought was really me. But stuff happened, and somehow I became an actor."

She says stuff. She means a postgrad job as a waitress at Second City, the Chicago comedy club that helped launch John Belushi and was then playing host to John Candy and Bill Murray. Given the anything-goes tenor of both time and place, her moment in the spotlight wasn't long coming. And, when the troupe later dispersed to either Saturday Night Live or well-earned obscurity, there was an audition for small-screen svengali Stephen Bochco, busy developing an ensemble cop show titled Hill Street Blues. Which meant that, between 1980 and 1987, Betty Thomas was better known as Lucy Bates, the precinct's stern but kindly sergeant.

"So, largely by accident, I learned to act. Doing it every day for seven years, on a show which incidentally had better scripts than most movies I see."

Next, having badgered Bochco into letting her behind the camera, came an apprenticeship in directing for TV, including several episodes of the seminally dirty-minded Dream On. "And eventually," she recalls, "I do a couple of independent movies of the kind which never even get released, far less seen. But it gets to a point where someone says, 'Look, we want to a do a movie of The Brady Bunch. And we don't have any money. And you're kind of funny.' And then you have a career."

A career defined by her way with lost causes but not, it seems, by sex. A woman, working right in the belly of the studio system, traditionally the gender-relations equivalent of your average cave. So, what happened to Boy's Own Hollywood? Was it all just a myth?

"Well," she smiles, "if it's a myth, then why aren't more women directing? There must be something going on. What, I don't know. But then I was an actor" - she smirks through the word - "a popular, respected actor. Same with Penny Marshall. And that world is easier for us to get into, because we're already one of the boys. Here's the thing. Guys at the studio sit there and someone says, 'Here's this girl, why don't you give her $50m?' And it's like, woah. You know, scary. And I think that's down to guys naturally wanting to hire guys. I mean, many times I would have preferred to work with women. But this movie's the first time I've been able to do that."

Which brings us right back where we came in. 28 Days. It's a sticky moment. I didn't like 28 Days, and nor did many other people during its run in the US. The consensus appears to be that, even for someone with such faultless instincts as Thomas, this one got away from her: a comic drama in which the comedy's not dramatic, and the drama isn't funny.

"Sure," she breezes, "I can see that. I mean, when I first read the script, it was a very straightforward film about rehab. A melodrama, in fact, with a few snappy lines. Not my kind of movie at all. And if the script I had been working on had been anywhere near fruition, I would never have done it. But I had to admit I connected with it. I still can't put my finger on why..."

She trails off. Part of the problem, I say, waiting for the glare which never comes, is that 28 Days makes rehab look, essentially, like fun.

"Well, it can be. And I say that because I went there and I saw moments where it is fun. And real black comedy, where the horror is what's funny, I don't know if I could do that. I will say this - if it had been my script, it would have started out as a comedy. That's my one regret. But, hey, maybe I'm the one who messed it up."

Only she didn't. Where the film really comes apart is whenever star of the show Bullock is called upon to display any symptoms of substance abuse beyond shaky hands. Predictably, rumours abound concerning director and actress.

"What, that we're having an affair?"

Anything but. In fact, according to the more excitable entertainment press, the entire shoot was subject to a acrimonious power struggle. There was, so the story goes, Betty's way - and Sandra's way.

"You know what? Sandra Bullock is so much my friend. But here's the thing. All that started because of one interview I did, where the guy says: so, how was it working with Sandy? And I'm bored, and I say: how was it? Horrible. She's a demanding a little bitch. And then I burst out laughing and say: well, I'm tired of telling everyone what a fucking nice person she is. And, of course, they cut that out."

Her next project is called Zembic, and it's the real-life story of a guy who took up a $100,000 bet to have silicone breast implants fitted. Say what you like about Betty Thomas: she sure can pick 'em.

 28 Days is released today.

A big-screen version of long-cancelled family sitcom The Brady Bunch? Give it to Thomas and six months later she delivers a dry, gently subversive rag on all things apple pie. A biopic of shock jock Howard Stern? She turns round Private Parts, a quick-witted portrait of a surprisingly human subject. A remake - now we're getting ridiculous - of Dr Dolittle, dreamed up as an Eddie Murphy star vehicle? No problem. Eddie talks to the animals; we chuckle indulgently. The woman is less film-maker than lifeguard. "You know what?" she exclaims. "A lot of people say: give me the greatest script in the world. And I don't know that I want that. I want a script where it's difficult to understand why it's funny, or moving, or why a person would want to spend millions of dollars making it. Because I like the idea that a script is just a blueprint, to blow open and explore." She leans back, annoyance fading. Because the other thing you notice about Betty Thomas, apart from her big, bare feet, is her preternatural calm. "Here's the thing," she says, or "You know what?", anticipating every criticism you could throw her way. She knows that a movie like 28 Days, full of platitudes and Sandra Bullock, was never going to be a journalists' favourite. And here's the thing: she doesn't care. It's in her look of amused resignation when I ask if she's happy with it. "You know what? I'm never happy with my films. I mean, it's a flawed film. I try to make my films flawed. Who wants to make the perfect film? All you'll do is piss off the gods." Maybe the Zen-mistress shtick comes down to her scenic route into this most highwire of businesses, with its pit stops at improv comedy and low-key TV stardom. No baby director she, pestering relatives with a Super-8. Born into Eisenhower-era suburban Ohio, she instead found herself coming into adulthood just as the Age of Aquarius kicked in, and heading for that most modish of career choices: life as (in her words) a "freaky art student". "Purely for a lark, I auditioned for the drama department. I mean, at the same time I was making this stupid little 8mm film, and that's what I thought was really me. But stuff happened, and somehow I became an actor." She says stuff. She means a postgrad job as a waitress at Second City, the Chicago comedy club that helped launch John Belushi and was then playing host to John Candy and Bill Murray. Given the anything-goes tenor of both time and place, her moment in the spotlight wasn't long coming. And, when the troupe later dispersed to either Saturday Night Live or well-earned obscurity, there was an audition for small-screen svengali Stephen Bochco, busy developing an ensemble cop show titled Hill Street Blues. Which meant that, between 1980 and 1987, Betty Thomas was better known as Lucy Bates, the precinct's stern but kindly sergeant. "So, largely by accident, I learned to act. A career defined by her way with lost causes but not, it seems, by sex. A woman, working right in the belly of the studio system, traditionally the gender-relations equivalent of your average cave. So, what happened to Boy's Own Hollywood? Was it all just a myth? "Well," she smiles, "if it's a myth, then why aren't more women directing? There must be something going on. What, I don't know. Here's the thing. Guys at the studio sit there and someone says, 'Here's this girl, why don't you give her $50m?' And it's like, woah. You know, scary. Which brings us right back where we came in. 28 Days. It's a sticky moment. I didn't like 28 Days, and nor did many other people during its run in the US. fields.headline: Life after Gong Li
fields.standfirst: Chinese director Zhang Yimou tells Howard Feinstein how he lost his muse and a found a new path
fields.trailText: Chinese director Zhang Yimou tells Howard Feinstein how he lost his muse and a found a new path
fields.body:
'I gained a new freedom," says 49-year-old film-maker Zhang Yimou. He speaks softly, but with a deep voice. He is referring to the termination of his professional and personal relationship with Gong Li, China's best-known actress, with whom he collaborated in his first six films - from the 1988 Red Sorghum through to 1995's Shanghai Triad. During the production of the latter, Gong Li reportedly terminated the relationship, and, within one year, married a wealthy Singaporean businessman. Film-maker and performer have not collaborated since.

"Gong Li and I were together for eight years," he says. "Right after our very first film she became a movie star. We became a star combination. I was always thinking about the actress. Whenever I had an idea, I would wonder, 'Can she do it? Would it be good for her? Would we fight?' Working with her implied a certain shape of the film.

"Almost all of her parts were larger-than-life women, symbols living under the oppression of feudalism and patriarchy," he continues. "They were characters close to life, but not close to everyday people. The one closest to real life is her title role in The Story of Qiu Jiu [1992], which, I think, is her best performance. After Gong Li, I wanted to do something different. Sometimes you miss what you have not been eating. I decided to make films about little people: ordinary, common people."

Hence his decision to test new waters in the urban comedy Keep Cool (made 1996, but never released in the UK) and the rural drama Not One Less, which opens here next Friday, after taking the Golden Lion for best film at last year's Venice film festival. Money, or more precisely lack of it, is the prism through which he examines the lives of the "little people".

Keep Cool, which he shot with a maniacal handheld camera, and Not One Less can be seen as experiments for Zhang. After losing Gong Li, he began to search for new cinematic possibilities. He had also begun to tire of his recurring problems with the Chinese government over historical and political references in his films. (The authorities have always held against him the fact that his late father had studied at a pre-communist military academy, and that his father's brother was a general who fought against the communists and fled to Taiwan.)

His more recent subjects - money, its lack, its devastating effect on society - are humanistic, less political than in the earlier work. Keep Cool, for example, features underworld figures and a bookworm who pines for a woman interested only in a wealthy man. Wang Wei, who produced both Keep Cool and Shanghai Triad, adds: "Yimou wants to show that, with everybody in China making money, relationships between people are changing."

Zhang goes further in Not One Less. He takes on the enormous problem of under-financed education, especially in the desperately poor villages that do not possess the resources to adequately maintain and supply their tumble-down schools. Many of the young students drop out in order to work at the family home or in a nearby city, often on their own.

"Chinese people are not concerned with their kids not getting an education, because they are too busy pursuing material goods," says Zhang. "At the end of the film, during the final credits, the kids each write one word after another on the blackboard. It calls attention to the beauty of learning when we were kids. It also calls attention to the fact that we pay little attention to culture."

In Not One Less, Zhang cast all non-professionals to play out this drama in the village of Shuiquan, a three-and-a-half hour drive north of Beijing in the impoverished province of Hebei. The kids portray characters much like themselves, and even use their own names. His team looked at thousands of youngsters before casting Wei Minzhi as the underqualified, 13-year-old substitute teacher, and Zhang Huike as her most troublesome, and most endearing, student. Zhang felt that a near-documentary style, occasionally utilising hidden cameras, would best serve his subject, much as it had done in The Story of Qiu Jiu seven years earlier.

In Qiu Jiu, the title character - Gong Li - is a peasant who demands an apology from the village mayor for injuring her husband "where it counts", as she puts it. Obstinate as a mule, Qiu Jiu refuses to take no for an answer, even venturing to the city, where she becomes lost among the masses, to lodge a complaint with functionaries at the Public Security Bureau.

The stubbornness of Wei Minzhi, who can barely read and write herself, outweighs even Qiu Jiu's. Her main concern is to keep the class intact, for she has been assured a bonus upon the regular teacher's return only if there is "not one less" pupil in the class than when he departed. After Zhang Huike's invalid mother sends him to the city of Jiangjiakou to help pay off the family's debts, Wei Minzhi refuses to mind her flock and heads instead to town to find the boy.

She hunts for him blindly, while he begs in the streets. Teacher and student eventually meet up through a deus ex machina in the form of an afternoon TV programme that mildly exploits their separation, even collecting on-air contributions to improve the village school and Zhang Huike's family situation.

This relatively "happy" ending has brewed controversy, both within and outside of China. "You always have to take censors into account in China," explains Zhang. "I wouldn't have been able to make a story in which the child wasn't found."

"The Chinese critics wrote that the film was a shehui gongyepian , a public service announcement, propaganda like those big ads that tell you how to behave in the street," says Marco Muller, director of the Locarno film festival and a long-time champion of Chinese cinema. Another Chinese film scholar, Alberto Barbera, director of the Venice film festival, offers a more generous appraisal. "The end of the film can be seen as a surrender to the purposes of propaganda, but what comes before it is a strong denunciation of a regime that is unable to assure proper education for country children and better life conditions in the remote peasant villages."

Liu Lening, another Chinese film scholar who teaches linguistics at Columbia University and is a close friend of Zhang's, defends the film's ending. "It's not a propaganda movie at all," he says. "Yimou is genuinely concerned with children's education in rural areas. Both of us were born in a big city, Xian, but we were both sent to the countryside during the Cultural Revolution to do hard labour. He knows country life pretty well."

Liu does agree that the film could not have been made with worse things happening to the boy in the city. "Censorship is certainly a factor," he says.

Zhang admits that Not One Less has been heavily influenced by the work of Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, whose pared-down rural films about children he admires. (As a secondary benefit, these children's films have enabled Kiarostami to generally bypass a censorship machine tougher than China's.) "Kiarostami's films are very elementary. Simplicity is extremely difficult to achieve, especially when society today has become more complex. I've tried to follow a Chinese proverb: go back to simplicity."

Is this imitation or reinvention? "Yimou has produced Kiarostami-Lite that can work on the international market," charges Muller. "He will slowly transform the auteur films of people like Kiarostami into obsolete art."

Perhaps. "Yimou has always been pretty savvy about the need to market a film," says Barbara Robinson, the Hong Kong-based managing director of Columbia Pictures Film Production Asia, which bought the rights to sell Not One Less and The Road Home in foreign markets. "For him, it's always more than, 'This is my art, love it or loathe it.' "

Gong Li agrees. "The most important and passionate thing in his life is his work. But I don't think Zhang Yimou's films are just artistic," she says. "For him, the market is also an important element - as you can see in both Not One Less and The Road Home. These films have a certain commercial intention to them."

Zhang, who says he has no plans to shoot outside of China, has become increasingly astute about the finances of production and distribution. He has to. Some of his fellow Fifth Generation filmmakers (fellow 1982 graduates of the Beijing film academy after its reopening), like Tian Zhuangzhuang, director of The Horse Thief and The Blue Kite, have stopped making films, oblivious to new possibilities of financing. And Zhang sees himself as something of an anthropologist.

"There are so many Hollywood films around that you have to do what you can to be able to preserve Chinese culture and experience on film," he says. He shot Shanghai Triad with French money. He is currently negotiating with an American producer to provide dollars for a future project to be shot in China. And, depending on whom you talk to, American money played a big part in getting both Not One Less and The Road Home, each shot for a meagre $1m, off the ground - even though a company called Beijing New Picture Distribution Company takes credit for financing the films completely with money from private Chinese investors.

Following the experiments of Keep Cool and Not One Less, Zhang completed The Road Home, a romantic, lyrical, and much more conventional film which won the Silver Bear at this year's Berlin film festival. It features an attractive, 20-year-old actress named Zhang Ziyi, who plays a beautiful, illiterate village girl enamoured of the new village schoolteacher. Zhang's camera frequently - very frequently - lingers on her, often in slow motion. Like Red Sorghum, his first collaboration with Gong Li, The Road Home tells a passionate tale of courtship.

"It's possible that Ziyi can become another Gong Li," says Zhang, carefully avoiding any mention of their personal relationship. "I selected both of them in their second year at the Beijing Drama Academy. It's like a repeat 10 years later. When I started working with Gong Li, she was 22. When I started with Ziyi, she was not yet 19. I am the one who discovered her and groomed her." He says he plans to work with her again, but makes it clear that she can be no more than a part-time muse. Once bitten, twice shy. He laughs. "I don't think I can repeat what I did with Gong Li."

 Not One Less is released next Friday.

fields.headline: Lock up your motors
fields.trailText: Lock up your motors
fields.body:
Almost every night on local television in Los Angeles there is a cut to the "breaking news" of a car chase. Sometimes it is a biker weaving his way between oncoming traffic, or a pedal-to-the-metal desperado totalling his Pontiac and hotfooting it across the freeway. A couple of times recently it has ended fatally: one trapped driver killed himself, another was shot by police.

So at least the producers of Gone in 60 Seconds, the tale of a hard-driving car thief, knew that there was a ready market for the car chases on offer with this week's hot new vehicle.

Nicolas Cage, who plays the car thief coming out of retirement to give the police helicopters a run for their money, has been on local television programmes himself here over the last week, reassuring interviewers that the film in no way endorses such hot-rod speeding down flood channels, nor any 160mph attempts to give the police the slip. Of course it doesn't.

Based on the 1974 cult classic of the same name, 60 Seconds boasts an exotic soundtrack, a cast that also includes Angelina Jolie, Christopher Eccleston (as a villain, of course), Delroy Lindo and Robert Duvall, and a director, Dominic Sena, with a background in music videos.

But what the film's high-profile opening almost conceals is the fact that two out of this week's seven new releases are documentaries; not compilations of great escapes on the LA freeways, but serious and highly regarded explorations of parts of America not too regularly covered in film fiction. The releases coincide with what seems to be a modest boom in documentaries aimed at the big rather than the small screen.

In August, the Democratic Party holds its convention in LA, which, with a minimum of 30,000 demonstrators expected, should provide some entertaining footage. The event brings to mind that remarkable film Medium Cool, made in 1969 by Haskell Wexler, which used the bloody and violent 1968 Democrats' convention in Chicago as its backdrop.

Wexler, now 74, has just made a fascinating documentary for cinema release on what could be called a variation of the theme of Gone in 60 Seconds. Now based in Santa Barbara, Wexler had already won an Academy Award for his cinematography on Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? when he embarked on Medium Cool, an inspirational work for many young film-makers at the time.

He has managed to combine his cinematographic work (In the Heat of the Night, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, Bound for Glory, Colors, The Babe) with the making of documentaries on subjects close to his heart.

His latest, which has just been shown here in the Magic Johnson cinema, is called The Bus Riders Union and is about the campaign in LA to get the city to provide a halfway decent public transport system for the countless workers - mainly Latino and black - unable to afford a car.

The union, on the face of it an unlikely subject for a 90-minute documentary, is one of the few genuinely multiracial organisations around and has used a combination of recruiting on overcrowded buses, civil-rights legislation and civil disobedience to force the city to buy and staff more buses.

Hexler made the film - which could be subtitled Waiting for At Least 60 Minutes - with money from Liberty Hill, a charitable trust, and has turned out an entertaining, often funny and optimistic film which clearly benefits from being seen on a big screen and should be snapped up by someone in Britain.

The Hughes brothers, twins Allen and Albert, who have been making their own films since their mother gave them a video camera at the age of 12, are responsible for American Pimp, which is also released this week. The brothers had a spectacular hit with their 1993 film, Menace II Society, which looked at urban life in Watts, and another with Dead Presidents in 1995.

This feature-length documentary uses interviews with 39 pimps to tell its tale. Like 60 Seconds, Pimps has had mixed reviews, with some reviewers critical of its style and content. Erin Aubry in LA Weekly accused the brothers of "playing into the worst of public stereotypes, namely that all black men are hustlers".

Also opening in cinemas this week is Chris Roe's film, Pop & Me, which is a documentary on a different theme of masculinity. It is about a father and son, aged 56 and 30, who travel the world interviewing other fathers and sons, among them Julian Lennon, whose father was a musician from Liverpool. This has mainly received kindly reviews, although its release to coincide with Father's Day could make a cynic choke on his popcorn.

Another documentary which has also had a recent felicitous cinema release is American Babylon, a portrait of an Atlantic City vice detective, Jeff Fauntleroy (don't be misled by the name). Robert Stone's film tells the tale of this 38-year-old black officer, who believes that God has led him to the job of dealing with the underside of this divided gambling city. This too has been widely praised.

"The general impression is that documentaries are didactic, boring, unsurprising," wrote San Francisco Chronicle columnist Jon Carroll earlier this year. "Documentaries are good for you; they're the chemotherapy of films. "But of course they're not... Documentaries being made today are far more sophisticated, amusing, touching, surprising and ambiguous than 99.6% of the (how shall we say?) fictional films produced in Hollywood."

Carroll cites many recent successes, not least of course the wonderful When We Were Kings, as he calls for one cinema in each of the big multiplexes to consider devoting itself to feature-length documentaries. Slim chance, one feels, but worth the try. Carroll also points out that most people have never heard of the documentaries nominated for Academy Awards and often they barely receive a screening.

One recent exception has been Wim Wenders's Buena Vista Social Club, which reminded audiences last year that a documentary film could also be a commercial success, if not quite on the same level as a film starring Cage and Jolie and featuring a car that can outdistance a helicopter.

So at least the producers of Gone in 60 Seconds, the tale of a hard-driving car thief, knew that there was a ready market for the car chases on offer with this week's hot new vehicle. Nicolas Cage, who plays the car thief coming out of retirement to give the police helicopters a run for their money, has been on local television programmes himself here over the last week, reassuring interviewers that the film in no way endorses such hot-rod speeding down flood channels, nor any 160mph attempts to give the police the slip. Of course it doesn't. Based on the 1974 cult classic of the same name, 60 Seconds boasts an exotic soundtrack, a cast that also includes Angelina Jolie, Christopher Eccleston (as a villain, of course), Delroy Lindo and Robert Duvall, and a director, Dominic Sena, with a background in music videos. But what the film's high-profile opening almost conceals is the fact that two out of this week's seven new releases are documentaries; not compilations of great escapes on the LA freeways, but serious and highly regarded explorations of parts of America not too regularly covered in film fiction. The releases coincide with what seems to be a modest boom in documentaries aimed at the big rather than the small screen. In August, the Democratic Party holds its convention in LA, which, with a minimum of 30,000 demonstrators expected, should provide some entertaining footage. The event brings to mind that remarkable film Medium Cool, made in 1969 by Haskell Wexler, which used the bloody and violent 1968 Democrats' convention in Chicago as its backdrop. Wexler, now 74, has just made a fascinating documentary for cinema release on what could be called a variation of the theme of Gone in 60 Seconds. Now based in Santa Barbara, Wexler had already won an Academy Award for his cinematography on Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? when he embarked on Medium Cool, an inspirational work for many young film-makers at the time. He has managed to combine his cinematographic work (In the Heat of the Night, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, Bound for Glory, Colors, The Babe) with the making of documentaries on subjects close to his heart. His latest, which has just been shown here in the Magic Johnson cinema, is called The Bus Riders Union and is about the campaign in LA to get the city to provide a halfway decent public transport system for the countless workers - mainly Latino and black - unable to afford a car. The union, on the face of it an unlikely subject for a 90-minute documentary, is one of the few genuinely multiracial organisations around and has used a combination of recruiting on overcrowded buses, civil-rights legislation and civil disobedience to force the city to buy and staff more buses. Hexler made the film - which could be subtitled Waiting for At Least 60 Minutes - with money from Liberty Hill, a charitable trust, and has turned out an entertaining, often funny and optimistic film which clearly benefits from being seen on a big screen and should be snapped up by someone in Britain. The Hughes brothers, twins Allen and Albert, who have been making their own films since their mother gave them a video camera at the age of 12, are responsible for American Pimp, which is also released this week. The brothers had a spectacular hit with their 1993 film, Menace II Society, which looked at urban life in Watts, and another with Dead Presidents in 1995. This feature-length documentary uses interviews with 39 pimps to tell its tale. Like 60 Seconds, Pimps has had mixed reviews, with some reviewers critical of its style and content. Erin Aubry in LA Weekly accused the brothers of "playing into the worst of public stereotypes, namely that all black men are hustlers". Also opening in cinemas this week is Chris Roe's film, Pop & Me, which is a documentary on a different theme of masculinity. It is about a father and son, aged 56 and 30, who travel the world interviewing other fathers and sons, among them Julian Lennon, whose father was a musician from Liverpool. This has mainly received kindly reviews, although its release to coincide with Father's Day could make a cynic choke on his popcorn. Another documentary which has also had a recent felicitous cinema release is American Babylon, a portrait of an Atlantic City vice detective, Jeff Fauntleroy (don't be misled by the name). Robert Stone's film tells the tale of this 38-year-old black officer, who believes that God has led him to the job of dealing with the underside of this divided gambling city. This too has been widely praised. "The general impression is that documentaries are didactic, boring, unsurprising," wrote San Francisco Chronicle columnist Jon Carroll earlier this year. "Documentaries are good for you; they're the chemotherapy of films. "But of course they're not... Documentaries being made today are far more sophisticated, amusing, touching, surprising and ambiguous than 99.6% of the (how shall we say?) fictional films produced in Hollywood." Carroll cites many recent successes, not least of course the wonderful When We Were Kings, as he calls for one cinema in each of the big multiplexes to consider devoting itself to feature-length documentaries. Slim chance, one feels, but worth the try. Carroll also points out that most people have never heard of the documentaries nominated for Academy Awards and often they barely receive a screening. One recent exception has been Wim Wenders's Buena Vista Social Club, which reminded audiences last year that a documentary film could also be a commercial success, if not quite on the same level as a film starring Cage and Jolie and featuring a car that can outdistance a helicopter.

fields.headline: Lights, camera... new director
fields.standfirst: As MGM shot its sci-fi thriller Supernova, everything that could go wrong did
fields.trailText: As MGM shot its sci-fi thriller Supernova, everything that could go wrong did
fields.body:
"It just started off troubled and stayed that way," is how William Malone recalls Supernova, the $60m sci-fi thriller from MGM that opens in the UK today. With five screenwriters (three credited, including Malone himself) and five directors (none credited), numerous potential lawsuits and a production history more mysterious and intriguing than anything in the film, Supernova may represent the most troubled project in recent history.

The film's credited director is Thomas Lee, a name coined as the 21st-century equivalent of the imaginary Alan Smithee. The credit really belongs to Walter Hill, co-producer of the first three Alien films, and director of 48 Hours and Last Man Standing. But Hill jumped ship after rows with studio bosses last summer, and after two more directors (including Francis Ford Coppola) came aboard, it was decided to give it to the non-existent Lee. This is his first film - but it will almost certainly not be his last.

Despite Malone's claim that Supernova "started off troubled", its conception was far less painful than its birth. In 1990, the film - then called Dead Star - was pitched to studios as a modestly-budgeted futuristic rescue movie from the team behind Malone's 1985 film Titan Find (US title: Creature). "I had this idea to take the movie Dead Calm and make it a science fiction picture," Malone explains. The original script was about a space expedition "that discovers artefacts from an alien civilisation, and is going to bring them back when a whole bunch of things happen. One of the things they pick up is a portal to death, which is a place you can actually go to, and out of that comes the devil."

Malone and Ash R Shah, the producer of Sudden Death, asked Alien conceptual artist HR Giger to produce a series of pre-production sketches to encourage financing for a film that was then budgeted to cost between $5m and $6m. As Giger notes, Malone "had written the story himself, a sort of Hellraiser in space... He had already done some designs for it but he left the actual Prince of Darkness of the Cosmos to me."

Malone says that Giger "came up with some brilliant sketches. I spent 10 days working with him in Switzerland." Giger was paid 10,000 Swiss francs for his concepts and heard nothing more until 1995, when the sketches turned up in a promotional booklet for the film. It was now called Supernova and, according to Giger, suggested "a much simplified version of the script that had attracted me to the project"

Nevertheless, says Malone, "there was a lot of heat about the script, but nobody would step up to the plate and make it. After that, I lost track of it, until I heard that MGM had bought it. They brought in a lot of other writers to work on the picture." Those were credited co-screenwriters David Campbell Wilson (Tomorrow Never Dies) and Daniel Chuba, and uncredited contributors Cathy Rabin and Thomas Wheeler. "Then it sort of mutated into something else. What it is now, I don't have a clue."

Indeed, by 1997, when pre-production was announced, Supernova had mutated into the story of a deep space medical ship, the Nova, which answers a distress signal from a comet-mining operation in a distant galaxy. Using its unique two-dimensional drive to fold space, the ship appears on the other side of the universe, where the crew finds the hulk of an ageing cargo vessel, about to be sucked into a black hole formed by the collapse of a star. The sole survivor of the sinking ship, Anton Mason, comes aboard the Nova with a terrifying story about what transpired on the vessel.

Since then, the story has seen as many changes as the name on the director's chair. Australian director Geoffrey Wright, who launched Russell Crowe's career in Romper Stomper, was fired by MGM over a script dispute. Jack Sholder (The Hidden) was next up, until the studio, encouraged by Stargate star James Spader, who was cast in the lead role, passed in favour of Walter Hill.

With only weeks to go until a threatened strike by the Screen Actors Guild, which would shut down production, Hill began tinkering with the script, apparently trying to distance it from his own earlier production, Alien. Production finally commenced in April 1998, with Angela Bassett (What's Love Got to Do With It), Robert Forster (Jackie Brown) and Robin Tunney (End of Days) joining Spader, and The Fifth Element's visual effects supervisor Mark Stetson overseeing special effects at Digital Domain.

MGM, however, continued to balk at the number of effects shots Hill requested, and cut out fully half of them. Out went a complex sequence in which Spader performs a nail-biting zero-gravity rescue inside a giant bubble of water. Out too, went a sophisticated, remotely-operated medical robot in favour of a shuffling humanoid android described by one critic as "a cross between Kryten in Red Dwarf and Woody Allen in Sleeper."

Finally, out went Walter Hill, who quit shortly after principal photography was completed. David Campbell Wilson later commented: "Walter's vision for the film was different from the studio's. It's a shame that couldn't be resolved during production."

A disastrous test screening followed Hill's departure. MGM called Sholder back to re-edit Hill's footage, tested the film again, and then met Hill to discuss his proposal for $5m worth of re-shoots. Unwilling to throw good money after bad, the studio refused, and Hill walked out again.

One by one, potential release dates disappeared into a black hole, until MGM board member Francis Ford Coppola intervened, effecting a $1m re-edit. "I hope that my experience in the film industry has helped improve the picture and rectified some of the problems that losing a director caused," he said in a statement. In the event, Coppola's cut did not test any better than Sholder's; neither did it secure the hoped-for PG-13 rating, and the film was re-cut yet again.

Finally, with no pre-release screenings and little publicity (even the press materials feature only two direct quotations, both from chief science consultant Dr Jacklyn R Green), Supernova was released in the US on January 17, almost two years later than planned.

Opening with a dismal $6.7m, the film went on to gross just $14m - barely a quarter of its cost. The critics were similarly unimpressed, with one describing it as "a frustrating jumble of logic leaps, impenetrable technobabble, rote action, and not one distinctive F/X piece."

This latter remark was particularly surprising, given that journalists at a Digital Domain press junket in February 1999 were shown almost 40 minutes of what one viewer describes as "absolutely cutting edge, moving-camera effects shots".

With the credited director as imaginary as the premise of the film, and Walter Hill's silence guaranteed as part of his severance deal with MGM, the full story behind Supernova is unlikely to emerge any time soon. But with the film now opening in the UK, British audiences will at last be able to make up their own minds whether or not it was worth the trouble.

 Supernova is released today.
