fields.headline: Nothing but the truth
fields.standfirst: It's a golden age for documentaries - and for fiction that looks like fact. Jacques Peretti thinks he knows why
fields.trailText: It's a golden age for documentaries - and for fiction that looks like fact. Jacques Peretti thinks he knows why
fields.body:
In Beyond the Mat, Barry W Blaustein's extraordinary documentary about American wrestling (and hence America), there is one abiding image. Not blood fountaining on to canvas, nor fat white-trash men throwing beer cans at a wrestler lying face down in leather trunks, but a businessman called Vince McMahon in a revolving chair.

McMahon is owner of the World Wrestling Federation. At the beginning of the film, he's seen making billion-dollar deals and sipping mineral water. By the end, he has become a wrestler: one of the weirdest, and yet most inevitable, of transformations one is likely to see on a movie screen. Stranger than fiction.

McMahon's desire to put himself centre-stage is an attractive image for Blaustein, not least because it tells an in-joke. McMahon is an unwitting parody of the documentary film-maker as genial participant in his own work: he plays the boring business game, doing suity deals, and really all he wants to do is rip his shirt off and clown about in front of 20m people.

McMahon's bizarre, laughable, yet completely sincere career change is a lesson for the modern documentary film-maker, an indication of how far such directors have had to travel from their politically committed antecedents.

Blaustein fits the profile of the archetypal contemporary documentary-maker - to perfection. A balding fortysomething white man, wrestling - if you will - with an obsession. His film, like all documentaries of this kind, begins with a shot of a balding, fortysomething guy (guess who?) watching TV clips (the obsession, dramatised in its simplest form). A voice-over begins. "Since I was a child, I've been fascinated by wrestling/serial killers/budgerigars. I needed to get to the heart of my obsession, nail it once and for all."

Cue two hours of bald, fortysomething guy driving in hire-car, interviewing various white-trash lunatics, reaching moment of profound pathos, possibly intercut with poignant shots of own family, coming to suitably flippant but deep conclusion about obsession. Blaustein concludes that wrestlers are "just the same as us. Except they're totally different."

Don't get me wrong. I loved the film - in spite of, not because of, the convention it follows. It's simply that the style has become overused, like Nick Broomfield's furry boom microphone and billowing shirt.

The bald-guy-obsession convention is the one minor cloud occluding a golden era of documentary film-making: Beyond the Mat, Hoop Dreams, When We Were Kings and, just out, Wisconsin Death Trip. These are documentaries that have all surmounted the insurmountable and got a theatrical release.

Why is there such an appetite for documentaries on the big screen (beyond the obvious reason that these are very, very good)? It's not as though very, very good docs weren't made in the past. From the late 50s, an underground stream of passionate and polemical films flowed unhindered through select cinemas and film festivals of the world. Politically committed reportage, chronicling war and death and misery, directed by some of the world's greatest directors: Alain Resnais's Night and Fog (a meditation on Auschwitz); Barbara Kopple's Harlan County USA (an examination of a miners' strike in 1976); Peter Davis's anti-Vietnam classic Hearts and Minds; and so on, as far as one cares look.

Ironically, many viscera-jogging documentaries from the 60s and 70s now look like ground-breaking feature films. Oleg Astaulav's incredible film Reporting From North Vietnam, for example, was all but remade by Oliver Stone in his post-Nam epic, Heaven and Earth. Here were documentaries shorn of stylistic cool. None involved a central hero. They were downbeat, minimal, sometimes too painfully honest to watch - Reporting From North Vietnam unblinkingly shows a mother in a single four-minute shot, the reality slowly dawning on her that her children have been killed in an Agent Orange attack. It's unbearable and would have driven a generation to torch the US embassy, had they seen it.

Many of today's theatrically released documentaries hold on to pieces of the genre's uncompromising art, but are more concerned with borrowing sexy techniques from today's feature films and pop promos. These films are not part of a revolution - they're entertainment.

One Day in September, a study of the 1972 Munich Olympic massacre, currently on limited theatrical release, is really a glorified pop promo: rock'n'roll death with Israelis in trendy tracksuits getting blown up to the Rolling Stones.

Music-driven archive is a hugely popular genre. TV finds endless ways of repackaging grainy newsy nostalgia via endless mutations of the Rock'n'Roll Years format. One Day in September is the upmarket equivalent, telling an extraordinary story, but marring it with a sub-Scorsese soundtrack. Just as Blaustein's Beyond the Mat takes a flippant subject (wrestling) and draws out profound truths about the American class system, One Day in September does the opposite. It offers up a pivotal historical moment for re-evaluation (Munich, 1972) and turns it into a rock video.

The crossover between docs and features is as ubiquitous and messy as ever. When Gillo Pontecorvo made the ground-breaking Battle of Algiers in the mid-60s, a painstaking dramatic reconstruction of guerilla activities staged to look like raw war footage, many critics would not believe that it wasn't real.

The debate surrounding faction was as intense then as it is today. Nowadays, however, Hollywood has its own past to faithfully recreate, never mind history. Ridley Scott's Gladiator slugs it out between faithfully recreating Ancient Rome and the Technicolor 60s (with the latter winning out).

Today, a local multiplex could happily play the pseudo-documentary, no-fun thrills of a Dogme 95 release next to When We Were Kings, Leon Gast's lush cinematic odyssey about Muhammad Ali, which just happens to be a documentary. The inversion of genres means one looks like old-fashioned Hollywood entertainment, while the other looks like camcorder hell. Both are as real and meaningful as you wish them to be.

In spite of the increasingly messy spillage between verité and fiction, social realism and rock promo, the fact remains that we need a clear voice to intepret our times. A need for political documentary film-making remains as pressing today as when B52s were flattening Vietnam.

The present has become a foreign country, which many film-makers believe can only be approached tangentially, by reinterpreting the past. Never before has the past looked so alluring. The present is a horrible place: Gillette fighter planes shaving your face; U-boats morph-exploding under water; the on-line frazzle of communication for communication's sake. Never before has our landscape looked so uninteresting, so Trocadero Centre.

In this garish, structureless whirl, today's documentaries are a place to stand still. The attraction of a film like James Marsh's Wisconsin Death Trip is the way it looks as if it has been dug from the ground, its total disjunction from the present. Hence its ability to tell us about the present. Gazing on still images of 19th-century homesteaders is like staring at a fresco, as close as any of us will get to sitting quietly in a cold church in our hot foreign country of the present.

The story of how Wisconsin Death Trip came to be made further promotes the idea of the project as a forgotten artefact: as an Etruscan fragment, salvaged from obscurity. Director James Marsh came across the book of the title in a secondhand bookshop in New York. As he turned its dusty pages, cameras began to roll. Marsh's story sounds like the beginning of a Hollywood movie in itself (not dissimilar to the Exorcist). The past, though comforting and capable of elucidating the present, can also be a frightening place. The very act of disinterring the book from its grave brings forth demons.

Wisconsin Death Trip came out the same week as U-571, an effects-laden movie ostensibly telling the story of the breaking of the Enigma code. Here is a fantastically good subject for a documentary (so good, in fact, that Channel 4 has already made it). As Barry W Blaustein might say, they're exactly the same, except they're completely different.

Since Werner Herzog gave up making movies and concentrated on documentaries, he's made some of the best films of his life. I have a fantasy of the world's great directors following Herzog's example. It would make for an intriguing cinema experience, but I'm not sure many would realise they weren't making a movie.

 Beyond the Mat is released on June 30.

Today, a local multiplex could happily play the pseudo-documentary, no-fun thrills of a Dogme 95 release next to When We Were Kings, Leon Gast's lush cinematic odyssey about Muhammad Ali, which just happens to be a documentary. The inversion of genres means one looks like old-fashioned Hollywood entertainment, while the other looks like camcorder hell. Both are as real and meaningful as you wish them to be. In spite of the increasingly messy spillage between verité and fiction, social realism and rock promo, the fact remains that we need a clear voice to intepret our times. A need for political documentary film-making remains as pressing today as when B52s were flattening Vietnam. The present has become a foreign country, which many film-makers believe can only be approached tangentially, by reinterpreting the past. Never before has the past looked so alluring. The present is a horrible place: Gillette fighter planes shaving your face; U-boats morph-exploding under water; the on-line frazzle of communication for communication's sake. Never before has our landscape looked so uninteresting, so Trocadero Centre. In this garish, structureless whirl, today's documentaries are a place to stand still. The attraction of a film like James Marsh's Wisconsin Death Trip is the way it looks as if it has been dug from the ground, its total disjunction from the present. Hence its ability to tell us about the present. Gazing on still images of 19th-century homesteaders is like staring at a fresco, as close as any of us will get to sitting quietly in a cold church in our hot foreign country of the present. The story of how Wisconsin Death Trip came to be made further promotes the idea of the project as a forgotten artefact: as an Etruscan fragment, salvaged from obscurity. Director James Marsh came across the book of the title in a secondhand bookshop in New York. As he turned its dusty pages, cameras began to roll. Marsh's story sounds like the beginning of a Hollywood movie in itself (not dissimilar to the Exorcist). The past, though comforting and capable of elucidating the present, can also be a frightening place. The very act of disinterring the book from its grave brings forth demons. Wisconsin Death Trip came out the same week as U-571, an effects-laden movie ostensibly telling the story of the breaking of the Enigma code. Here is a fantastically good subject for a documentary (so good, in fact, that Channel 4 has already made it). As Barry W Blaustein might say, they're exactly the same, except they're completely different. Since Werner Herzog gave up making movies and concentrated on documentaries, he's made some of the best films of his life. I have a fantasy of the world's great directors following Herzog's example. It would make for an intriguing cinema experience, but I'm not sure many would realise they weren't making a movie.  Beyond the Mat is released on June 30.

webTitle: A legend still in the making

fields.headline: A legend still in the making
fields.standfirst: Peter O'Toole is hoping The Final Curtain will cement his reputation. Brian Pendreigh visits him on set
fields.trailText: Peter O'Toole is hoping The Final Curtain will cement his reputation. Brian Pendreigh visits him on set
fields.body:
In a 17th floor penthouse overlooking Trafalgar Square, Big Ben and the Thames, JJ Curtis, doyen of television celebrities, is in a good mood. He is holding a tabloid newspaper naming his main rival in a porn scandal and he has been having his portrait painted for posterity, wearing a cravat and a red, velvet dressing gown that sweeps the floor.

He greets his appointed biographer with old world charm, but his mood changes with the news that the writer wants to resign. The words "Beg pardon?" shoot from his lips with the velocity of a pair of bullets. "No, no, no," he says, regaining his composure. "That would be so ungrateful." Behind the gentle demeanour is an inherent menace.

Peter O'Toole's face fills the frame of the director's monitor and the familiar blue eyes seem as cold and unwelcoming as Christmas at a Siberian nudist camp. As he films a scene in his new movie The Final Curtain, he sculpts each word with the care of an artist. And yet he claims, that as he has grown older, acting has become increasingly difficult. "When you're young you just go boom," he says. "It seems to get more difficult the more one knows about it."

O'Toole has sometimes steered a narrow course between genius and ham, and the indifference of many of his recent films suggests he has not always made the right choice in terms of performance, or projects. The Final Curtain unites the veteran star of Lawrence of Arabia with the writer of Shallow Grave and Trainspotting in a vicious satire on modern television and modern television audiences. O'Toole describes it as "the most original script I've come across for many years". It is also the first feature for which writer John Hodge has broken away from the triumvirate he formed with producer Andrew Macdonald and director Danny Boyle and it is being billed as O'Toole's first leading role for over a decade.

O'Toole sits facing the door, his Gitane held in vintage cigarette-holder, like a character from a Coward play, except he has dispensed with dressing gown and cravat. He is a commanding figure, even in his vest, with his slacks unfastened to reveal white Y-fronts, in a seeming parody of the fashion for exposing the tops of designer underpants. He commands his little court, enjoying the sunshine and warmth that dances through the open door, while tourists wander down Waterloo Place towards St James's Park oblivious to the proximity of legend.

"This is your first lead role for 10-15 years," I begin. "Not true," he says majestically. "I don't know where you got your information from." Well, there is the film company press release, which describes The Final Curtain as his "first major feature film leading role" since 1982's My Favourite Year - the film that made it seven Oscar nominations for O'Toole without a win, a record he shares with Richard Burton. "I saw that too," he chirps, his tone noticeably lightening.

And then there is the fact that half the stuff he did in the 90s is entirely forgettable. O'Toole's recent oeuvre includes Fairytale: A True Story, in which he played the supporting role of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle; the Emperor of Lilliput in the expensive TV adaptation of Gulliver's Travels; and last year's Old Vic revival of Jeffrey Bernard is Unwell, in which he could finally put his decades of wild living and heavy drinking to creative use.

But there were also films like Rebecca's Daughters (in which he played a drunken 19th-century lord who dresses in women's clothes to infiltrate a transvestite road-toll protest group), Molokai: The Story of Father Damien and Dean Koontz's Phantoms. "Doesn't really matter," he says, sounding a little like Eeyore. "Maybe those weren't released."

He does not dwell on films once completed and apparently did not see Lawrence of Arabia until years after its release. Despite the accumulation of Oscar nominations, his best-known role remains that first starring role as TE Lawrence. There is a sense of unfulfilled potential. At 67, he is the same age as Michael Caine and slightly younger than Sean Connery, though he seems older. The blond hair is now silver and the thin features are gaunt, almost skeletal, as if a familiar face has been aged by computer technology.

O'Toole has had to wait a long time for a film role that could do for him what The Untouchables did for Connery, what Hannah and Her Sisters did for Caine and what Jeffrey Bernard did for O'Toole's own fortunes on stage. He had all but given up hope. "I'm afraid the scripts have become very poor," he says languidly. "We're going through a very poor passage right now." Does this malaise affect the whole of the British film industry, despite the boom in production? "Is there a British film industry?" he asks, with what seems like a genuine sense of surprise. "The British film industry." He ponders the notion, chews on the words. "Sounds like a very good idea."

"In times it's been economically sensible for films to be made here," he says, "but there's never been an industry as such." He believes the quality of scripts is poor in both Hollywood and Britain, making him all the more enthusiastic when he received the latest offering from Hodge, the quiet-spoken Scot who trained as a doctor before writing Shallow Grave on scraps of paper between seeing patients.

The Final Curtain's central character is JJ Curtis, a TV superstar, a national institution, and host of a traditional family game show. (Cinephiles might spot the apparent allusion to an earlier media superstar: JJ Hunsecker was the name of Burt Lancaster's showbiz columnist in Sweet Smell of Success). Curtis's preeminence is challenged by Dave Turner (Aidan Gillen), who hosts a show in which contestants sit in an electric chair. Meanwhile, JJ's doctor tells him he is dying. With his world collapsing, JJ recruits an intellectual, Jonathan Stitch (Adrian Lester), to write his life story, but Stitch does not like what he discovers about the self-styled "genial Uncle JJ, the housewife's choice" and wants out.

"We needed someone who was instantly recognisable," says producer Chris Young. They considered Michael Caine, but the feeling was that Caine was just too much Caine - whereas O'Toole was familiar, but without the same degree of personal baggage. "He starts killing people, but we need to like him too. We need to be unable to resist his charm, and Peter has that extraordinary combination of danger and charm."

O'Toole read the script and immediately re-read it three times to check his initial enthusiasm was justified. He was attracted by its combination of drama and black comedy. Though O'Toole had not seen Shallow Grave he had been impressed by Hodge's discipline in adapting Irvine Welsh's novel Trainspotting, an achievement that won Hodge an Oscar nomination.

Hodge is working with a new team, both fellow Scots. Chris Young is the Skye-based producer of Gregory's Two Girls and 1989's Venus Peter, the portrait of a boy growing up in a Scottish fishing village in the 50s. Pat Harkins is a first-time feature director. He made The Last Ten Minutes (a short which Hodge wrote and which was shown with Shallow Grave) and he worked for years as a props man, serving in that capacity on both Shallow Grave and Venus Peter. But his first taste of film-making was as one of the schoolboys in the original Gregory's Girl, selling food at break in the toilet.

Scottish film is a small world. Hodge's regular producer Andrew Macdonald was a runner on Venus Peter; a decade later he is joint head of DNA Films, the lottery-funded "mini-studio" that is backing The Final Curtain.

O'Toole denies he has modelled his character on any individual game-show host, though he finds the phenomenon compelling. "I found myself in a car the other day and the taxi driver had the radio on and I was half-minded to ask him to switch it off. And then I thought 'Hang on, I know the answer to that question.' " He is particularly fascinated by Japanese shows. "They'll do anything just to be on television for a minute. They'll be humiliated."

Young suggests the film comes at a time in O'Toole's life when he can readily connect with JJ. He previously played a power-crazed film director in The Stunt Man and a drunken has-been actor in My Favourite Year. "In the film you are playing a showbiz legend, albeit in a different branch of showbiz, a TV celebrity," I suggest, "but were there aspects of your character that you could empathise with... as one of Britain's leading screen actors over the last four decades?"

"In a word," replies O'Toole, "no."

After a pause, he decides a few more words might be useful. "He describes himself at one point as being from the trashier end of popular culture. No. An actor's job is to have a disinterested sympathy for any character he plays."

It is in the nature of film production, that having shot a scene in the morning in which Adrian Lester's character attempts to resign, the actors should return to the penthouse after lunch to shoot the scene in which Stitch accepts the job in the first place.

JJ babbles away about his health, while Stitch lays down his terms for the job. Rehearsing the lines, the actors find it difficult to keep straight faces as the two conversations pursue their own courses, till Stitch refers to the story of JJ's life.

"The story of my life? Why, that is a brilliant idea, Mr Stitch."

Harkins, a short, shaven-headed figure in jeans and faded grey T-shirt, prowls the set, turning his head at odd angles, as his stars deliver the lines. Like the officer promoted from the ranks, Harkins is on familiar ground, though he was not even born when O'Toole rode across the desert to his first Oscar nomination. He shows no signs of being overawed by the great man, asking him to turn towards Lester only at the words "story of your life", explaining that they are the first he has heard.

O'Toole cannot remember when last he saw a script this good. My Favourite Year was good, but not this good, he says. Now it is a case of translating the quality of writing to film. There has been many a slip between page and screen in the past. O'Toole does not watch the rushes. "But I'm hearing nice things," he says. And might it be eighth time lucky? "You never know," says O'Toole. He positively sings those words. And there is a twinkle in those famous blue eyes.

webTitle: Miami relatives to fight to bitter end over Elian

fields.headline: Miami relatives to fight to bitter end over Elian
fields.standfirst: The Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez's Miami relatives have signalled that they intend to use all their options in the legal battle over the boy, raising the prospect that it could still be many months before Juan Miguel Gonzalez can take his son home to Cuba.
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez's Miami relatives have signalled that they intend to use all their options in the legal battle over the boy, raising the prospect that it could still be many months before Juan Miguel Gonzalez can take his son home to Cuba.

Lawyers for the Miami relatives yesterday formally asked the full 11th US circuit appeal court to reverse its decision that Elian, aged six, is too young to bring an asylum claim in his own right. If that ruling is upheld, Mr Gonzalez will in effect be given the right to take Elian back to Cuba.

Two weeks ago, a three-judge panel of the 12-member appeal court ruled that the US immigration and naturalisation service had the right to deny the boy the asylum hearing requested by relatives. The relatives were given until yesterday to appeal.

By filing the request for the case to be heard by the full panel, the relatives' lawyers implicitly rejected the plea by Mr Gonzalez that they should drop their legal moves, as well as giving up the opportunity to lodge an immediate appeal to the supreme court.

The supreme court option still remains open if the appeal court decides to give the case a full hearing. As a result, and with court business at all levels of the US judicial system about to slow down for the summer, there is a real prospect that several months will pass before Elian will be allowed to leave the US, even if he and his father continue to win their case.

"Based on direction of other courts in this country, we think there's a very compelling case for the entire 11th circuit to reconsider its past views," said the Miami relatives' lawyer, Kendall Coffey, as he filed the appeal.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez and his lawyers have until Tuesday next week to respond to the Miami relatives' move. The court will then decide whether to allow the full hearing and will issue a ruling on whether the injunction against Elian leaving the United States should be extended.

Elian was rescued from the sea off Florida last November after his mother and 10 other Cubans drowned when their boat sank in an attempt to reach the US.

He was looked after by his great-uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, and other exile relatives in Miami until he was seized by federal agents in a dawn raid on April 22 and returned to the custody of his father. He is currently living with his father and other relatives in Washington.

fields.headline: The best mechanic scene
fields.standfirst: Gangster no 1
fields.trailText: Gangster no 1
fields.body:
London. 1968. Underworld boss Freddie Mays (David Thewlis) and associates Gangster (Paul Bettany), Roland and Mad John approach a mechanic working beneath a taxi. Without warning they pull him from under the vehicle.

"Hold him", instructs Freddie.

"What's the problem?" yells the mechanic.

"You are. Still, nothing I can't fix with a few tools, eh?"

Gangster hands him a sledgehammer.

"Oh come on, don't do anything stupid Freddie..."

"What, like waste my time talking to an arsehole like you? Remember the last time we went through all this, eh? That put a smile on your face."

Cut to the mechanic; he has a scar running from ear to ear. Meanwhile, Gangster and Freddie stroll around the cab. Almost casually, Freddie smashes the windscreen.

"Come on, Freddie! It's not even my taxi!"

Freddie and Gangster meticulously shatter every window.

"Not my fucking taxi, you bastards..."

Freddie wipes his hands on a chamois.

"I've got the name of a bloke that'll take a look at that for you. Now let's see that money. By tomorrow."

Freddie walks away. The mechanic gets to his feet and runs after him, wielding a chisel. Ever-alert, Gangster and company grab him, pushing him back beneath the cab.

"Now," Gangster declares, "let's get this back on the road."

They kick away the jack. Over the mechanic's screams, Gangster smirks:

"Stay lucky."

Freddie ponders the scene.

"Very nice. Creative. I like that."

See also: The Unbelievable Truth, Something Wild, Trees Lounge

Don't see also: Phenomenon

Pointless trivia: Paul Bettany has the lead role in the imminent movie adaptation of Martin Amis's Dead Babies.

webTitle: The Biographer's Tale by AS Byatt

fields.headline: The Biographer's Tale by AS Byatt
fields.standfirst: (Chatto, £15.99) condensed in the style of the original by John Crace
fields.trailText: "I'm so tired of postmodern litewawy theowy," I declaimed effetely. "I need facts, things, quiddity."
fields.body:
"I'm so tired of postmodern litewawy theowy," I declaimed effetely. "I need facts, things, quiddity."

"I do know what you mean, Phineas," replied Ormerod Goode, my tutor. "Why don't you try reading Scholes Destry-Scholes' three-volume biography of Elmer Bole."

fields.headline: The wrong medicine
fields.standfirst: A concordat with the private sector isn't the answer, nor is scapegoating doctors
fields.trailText: Do ministers regard private medicine as friend or foe? It has never declared whether private practice is a leech on its back, a partner of sorts or a competitor. The concordat with the private sector will muddy the waters yet further, says Polly Toynbee.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn announces grandly that there is to be a new "concordat" drawn up with the private health sector. What is a "concordat"? The dictionary calls it a treaty, implying it's between enemies. But what remains entirely unclear is whether the government regards private medicine as friend or foe. Ever since Bevan fudged it back in 1948, the NHS has writhed in uncomfortable cohabitation. It has never declared whether private practice is a leech on its back, a partner of sorts or a competitor. This concordat - prematurely announced since nothing is agreed - will define it no better than heretofore. In fact it will muddy the waters yet further.

What will it say? It will lay down national principles for local agreements, including possibly national tariffs on cost per operation. It will see that health authorities get value for money, highest quality of care and "no detriment to the NHS". Clear as mud. Currently the NHS buys a little, but only very little private treatment for its patients - some 30,000 operations last year. (The NHS did 6.5m.) The supposed purpose of the concordat is to increase the number of NHS patients treated in private hospitals in a blitz on waiting lists, especially in winter months when surgery lists get backed up by flu victims filling surgical beds. It makes sense, they say. So long as the above conditions are all adhered to, waiting lists will be cut, some patients will have a nice time in posh clinics, everyone's happy.

But the relationship between the private and the public sector can never be that clearcut as long as most private doctors are also NHS consultants. The balance between the amount of work they do in one or other sector can shift according to perverse incentive. It is the third condition on the concordat that will defy definition - "no detriment to the NHS". It's been proven time and again that surgeons with long waiting lists already do the most private practice. If there is suddenly more work available in the local private hospital there's a risk some doctors will reduce their NHS contracts and scuttle down the road to treat the very same people for twice the fee.

What might happen if the NHS draws closer to the private sector? Imagine a health authority strikes a good deal with a local private clinic to do 100 hips a year. It goes well. It becomes 200 hips. Insidiously over the years more and more doctors and nurses do more and more sessions in the private hospital and the work in the local NHS hospital dries up. Suddenly the private hospital is the only local hip provider and they can more or less name their price. It becomes like the European system where most state-paid work is provided by the private sector - and unit prices are hugely higher. That is why it matters - not for NHS trade union or ideological reasons but because one of the great (and unsung) successes of the NHS is that it has kept control of costs. It may be cash-starved but it spends its money far better than other western countries because it controls it all. If too much work moves permanently into the private sector, the NHS risks losing financial control of the system.

The extent to which the "concordat" remains a peculiar and ill-defined beast lies here. The Independent Health Association - with whom the treaty is being negotiated - said yesterday, "Yes! We want to move over to the European model. That's where we are going. Ask people in Germany or France and they are very happy to be treated in private hospitals. The government needs to mobilise our provision."

But does the government really want to incur European costs? Is the European model what the government has in mind? "Of course not!" say government sources. "It may be what the private sector wants, but that's not what we are going to agree." (So much for a concordat.) It won't happen, they say, because the "value for money" caveat means NHS hospitals can only buy private treatment at the same price as it would cost in the NHS . On average, private operations cost twice as much. So far the private sector has offered a few loss-leader deals, using up spare capacity for a few operations at more or less cost. But they couldn't run a significant business that way, paying doctors twice as much, yet charging the NHS the same. Private medicine is tiny - 10,000 beds compared with the NHS's 200,000. This is piffling, marginal, insignificant.

So why the big announcement and the big word "concordat"? Tell it not in Gath, it's a bit of a political game, they whisper. Shoot the Tory fox. Call their bluff. Remember how last winter the Tories said there'd be no crisis if we used the private sector? This shows we're not ideological, we'll work with anyone to cut waiting lists if they offer the same NHS price. Let the private sector and their Tory advocates put up, or shut up. Add in this: when we cut NHS waiting time to virtually nothing, once the national plan delivers a bright, modern service, no one will use the private sector. It'll be dead in the water - bar a few visiting Arabs.

However, Labour may never reach that nirvana unless they build a wall between the private and the state sector, instead of forging concordats. The best way would be to buy out the consultants, pay them more - most deserve it - and make them choose between NHS and private work.

Tony Blair plainly regards this concordat as an ideological talisman. He wants both sectors in his big tent. But it isn't that simple and it's not an old Labour class envy thing. Unless he grasps the way private practice fuels the length of NHS waiting lists, he will never reach his no-waiting goal. He should consider the many other ways private medicine coils itself around the NHS. In Surrey, some 30% of hips and even 20% of coronary bypass operations are performed privately. And yet Surrey NHS gets the same per capita government money as poor areas. Shouldn't it be factored into NHS funding? Due to private practice, the population in Hampstead is greatly more likely to be hospitalised than the far sicker population in Tower Hamlets. (Though Hampstead may be suffering hundreds of needless operations - another perverse incentive in private medicine). What does the concordat have to say about these things?

The political question is this: was it worth upsetting and angering vast numbers of NHS staff with this concordat? Was it worth angering Labour's heartlands with such talk - just to prove yet again that the Tory policy is rubbish? Come the election, voters are unlikely to credit cheap Tory jibes about waiting lists. Voters can see how 20 years of critical underfunding have left the NHS limping. Everywhere you look it's all held together with sticking plaster by underpaid people.

The great fear now is that all this hype about the national plan will raise expectations which cannot be quickly met. The NHS is not going to be modern in a hurry. A reminder of reality: yesterday I was stopped in a Lambeth street by an old lady who asked what day it was. No, she wasn't in the least confused, she just couldn't see. She'd been waiting for a cataract operation for a year. One day in a clinic, NHS or private would give her back her life.

webTitle: Keegan to stick with old system

fields.headline: Keegan to stick with old system
fields.standfirst:
Keown and Wise likely to be the only changes for showdown with Germany, David Lacey reports

Jim White on a fun-filled first week

Deadpan Shearer plays a straight bat
fields.trailText: Keown and Wise are likely to be the only changes for the showdown with Germany. David Lacey reports
fields.body:
First the good news. Alan Shearer believes that England will beat Germany in Charleroi tomorrow and go on to qualify for the quarter-finals of the European Championship.

Now the bad. Even if England do reach the knockout stage they will have to win Group A to avoid the probability of meeting Italy, the likely winners of Group B, for a place in the semi-finals.

Dino Zoff's present team may not be in the class of, say, Enzo Bearzot's successful sides, but to judge from the way they defeated Belgium 2-0 in Brussels on Wednesday night Italy are to Kevin Keegan's England as Tosca is to Fings Ain't What They Used To Be.

After two victories in Euro 2000 Italy are entitled to ponder their likely quarter-final opponents, a luxury England can hardly afford having lost 3-2 to Portugal in Eindhoven on Monday. The ramifications of that defeat, suffered after England had raced into a 2-0 lead, rumble on and are bound to gather momentum should a German victory bring an abrupt end to Keegan's interest in the tournament.

Not surprisingly, then, the atmosphere around Balmoral is becoming a little tense, with England's coach trying hard yesterday not to appear as jumpy as a grouse on August 12. With the newspaper reporters he was amiable enough, but a question from a television interviewer over a quote about Lothar Matthäus attributed to Les Reed, one of his coaches, drew a more emotional reaction.

Later Keegan explained that his assistants were there to be questioned, not interrogated. Only he himself could expect the Spanish Inquisition but as Monty Python hilariously made clear: "Nobody expects the Spanish Inquisition."

Keegan quite clearly is approaching the Germany match with three wheels on his wagon, but he still keeps rollin' along. Unless he is a supreme bluffer lost to the world of poker, it would appear that the England coach is set on persisting with a formation similar to that which flourished then folded against the Portuguese.

All sorts of alterations to the shape and make-up of tomorrow's side are being suggested but it will be no surprise should Keegan simply make those changes forced upon him by the injuries to Tony Adams and Steve McManaman. This would mean Martin Keown coming into the back four and Dennis Wise playing on the left side of midfield.

Until Keegan reveals his hand, however, the sky is the limit on hypothesis. One popular theory is that Paul Scholes could replicate the support that Alan Shearer received from Teddy Sheringham in Euro 96, playing off the England captain with Michael Owen left out and Steven Gerrard providing younger legs alongside Paul Ince in central midfield.

If no Gerrard, then why not move Wise into the middle and bring in Nick Barmby on the left? After all, Keegan has said Barmby could give his team something that it had been lacking, so why not pick him?

Then there is Emile Heskey, Shearer's preferred partner because this Liverpool striker has the pace and power to worry opposing centre-backs as well as an ability to go wide on the right, stretch defences and provide useful service for the man in the middle.

It is a fair point but one which, at this level, has been undermined by Heskey's failure so far to suggest that he could trap a bag of Blue Circle. It will all come down to Keegan weighing up Owen's apparent inability to hold the ball up for Shearer against the youngster's pace, which might make Matthäus feel even older than his 40 years.

Compared with Portugal, Germany will pose less subtle but more athletic problems for England. They have lost the talismanic Oliver Bierhoff to a calf strain but Carsten Jancker is not just about height and heading ability and, with Ulf Kirsten, will pose considerable problems to David Seaman and his centre-backs.

Keegan is well aware of the dangers. "Bierhoff is a proven player at international level," he said yesterday, "but Jancker is big, strong and fast and we know what he is capable of."

In addition, remembering the way Luis Figo was allowed a free run through the middle to score Portugal's first goal, England must be consistently aware of the threat posed by Mehmet Scholl, who drifts into spaces behind the front pair.

"He is clever with the ball and he's a team player," said Keegan. "It doesn't bother him whether or not he scores and in that sense he's a bit like David Beckham.

"Against Romania he turned the game in five seconds. One moment a move on the right was going nowhere and in the next he had scored a fantastic goal. You have to watch a player like Scholl for 90 minutes."

Otherwise with Keegan it is still general optimism with a reluctance to be pinned down on specifics. The Germany game, he started to say, had been blown up out of all proportion. But out of proportion to what? A final in 1966 and semi-finals in 1990 and 1996? England will be playing for their lives tomorrow just as much as they were at Wembley (twice) or in Turin. The moment has come a little earlier, that is all.

Keegan was asked what he would do if England again found themselves with a two-goal lead. "Please God I'll have the problem," he replied feelingly. "But if this happens we'll have to defend better as a team than we did against Portugal."

The England coach quoted the rousing 4-1 victory over Holland in Euro 96, under Terry Venables, as the summit to which his team needed to aspire. "So far we've not got to that level but we're still capable of doing it," he insisted.

"At the moment people keep questioning the things we are doing wrong and they have every right to do that. Until we start winning games against really good sides, and I believe Germany are a good side, the jury are going to be out."

The only problem with making the performance against Holland in 1996 your acme of excellence is that opponents of any standard are unlikely to defend as badly as the Dutch did that night. The manner in which England lost their lead on Monday was more reminiscent of the way a similar advantage was frittered away by Graham Taylor's team in a World Cup qualifier against Holland at Wembley in 1993.

 Pierluigi Collina will referee England's match with Germany tomorrow. The controversial Italian will be remembered for sending off Paul Ince at the start of England's Euro 2000 qualifying campaign against Sweden in Stockholm.

fields.headline: Lawyers give missiles a defence
fields.trailText: Lawyers at the Pentagon and the state department have told President Clinton that the United States can begin to build its controversial national missile defence system without violating the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty with Russia which had previously been understood to outlaw work on such systems.
fields.body:
Lawyers at the Pentagon and the state department have told President Clinton that the United States can begin to build its controversial national missile defence system without violating the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty with Russia which had previously been understood to outlaw work on such systems.

This legal interpretation is certain to be rejected by Russia, which believes that even the most minimal preparatory work on a permanent system would breach the treaty. But the lawyers' view might give Mr Clinton some domestic political "wiggle room" on the issue in an election year.

By beginning work on the system in the belief that he was not breaching the treaty, Mr Clinton might calculate that he could satisfy US hawks while assuring international critics that Washington was faithful to its treaty pledges.

The US is currently researching and developing the proposed missile system, activities that are permitted under the ABM treaty.

Mr Clinton is due to decide in the autumn whether to install and deploy the system, after another Pacific Ocean test of its ability to intercept and destroy hostile missiles. The test is due in July.

The US admits that deployment would be contrary to the treaty. Washington is trying, so far unsuccessfully, to persuade Moscow to allow a treaty amendment so that the US can go ahead.

But according to Pentagon and state department lawyers, the treaty does not preclude work to clear and prepare sites in Alaska and the Aleutian Islands on which the interceptor missiles and their ground-based radar tracking systems would be installed.

While Washington tries to square the treaty with its plans, a leading critic of US nuclear weapons policy accused the Pentagon this week of being actively committed to attacking a much bigger list of targets around the world in the event of nuclear war than has previously been made public.

Bruce Blair, a former launch officer for the Minuteman missile, claimed in the New York Times (reproduced in part on this page, left) that US war planning is based on the continuing assumption that at least 2,500 warheads must be ready to fire at targets in Russia and China, Iran, Iraq and North Korea.

Maintaining such levels on would make the US unable to cut warheads to below the 2,000 ceiling envisaged in the stalled Start III strategic arms limitation talks with Russia.

The administration's apparent commitment to national missile defence is causing an increasingly deep divide not only with Russia but with western Europe.

But in the administration it is justified on the grounds that Vice-President Al Gore - the Democrats' expected presidential candidate in this year's election - cannot afford to look soft on an issue which Republicans think is an election winner for George W Bush.

Paradoxically, the renewed signs that Mr Clinton is looking for ways of taking the first steps on constructing the missile defence system come at the very time North Korea - whose missile programme provides the ostensible threat cited to justify the new system - has held unprecedented public talks about reconciliation with its South Korean neighbour.
